column10: stoked for 2

I'm honestly disappointed in myself for NOT playing this game sooner. A 2016 masterpiece of an RPG with great progressive leveling, amazing boss fights, and an engaging story line. Glad I played it before DD2 arrives.
DDDA walked so Elden Ring could run.
This game is a masterwork all the way through, you can't go wrong.

I bought this game on sale for less than $5 and it's probably the best value I've ever received out of a game. The things you can do build/combat-wise make the game fun. The story and quests aren't really that great, so if that's what you want don't buy the game. If you want to cast spells that produce a screen wiping tornado, or shoot a magick bow with magick arrows, or spin through the air with daggers slashing your enemies a bunch of times, or pummeling enemies with a giant hammer - this is the game for you. The super bad-ass skills in this game make it great and fun to play through. 8/10

In a way this game reminds me of a mix of Monster Hunter and Elden Ring. That said: Gameplay is the main factor here.
I wanted to give it a try ever since I saw the trailer for Dragons Dogma 2.
It definitely has some very unique mechanics and it was way ahead of its time - (for some games nowadays, it still is)

It isn't too long either, so if you want to check out the original before heading into the second game. Go ahead!
It took me 55h on hard mode with 139 deaths :cqlol:
Hard mode on your first playthrough is not impossible, but.. oh boy!
Great action RPG, everyone should check it out and give it a shot.

Incredible game and story . 
Waiting for DD2 now

Having tried getting into this game multiple times, I've come to conclude that this game is far too janky to recommend - with its many questionable design decisions, and poorly optimized controls for the PC. 

[h1]Controls[/h1]
The game controls terribly: having to hold multiple buttons for (6 different) special attacks is clunky as hell, a remnant from it's origins as a console game with their controllers - hard to believe that this is the same developers that eventually made MHW's combat controls. 

Targetting ranged attacks feel clunky as hell, with the aimlock being finicky in deciding what your camera's pointing at.


[h1]Game design[/h1]
Having  played a warrior in the prologue, and felt underwhelmed with the anemic combat consisting of randomly swinging your sword at the enemy, I made the mistake of trying the mage, which is even more boring, consisting of keeping your distance from enemies and waiting for bars to fill up. You can't respec your character class until you reach some city ahead in game, which means that I was stuck with the class I chosen for the early game.

Being able to choose 3 skills for your primary and secondary weapons each is interesting in theory, but the game doesn't implement it well in game - from overwhelming you in the prologue when you're figuring out controls and whatnot... boring you in the actual start when you have very limited skills... and then when you learn skills you need to travel to one specific npc, and spend limited discipline points to obtain a skill based on text description alone, because being able to test out skills or have a video of that skill before purchasing them is too much to ask.

Climbing onto monsters isn't well developed, which isn't surprising  when it's never good in any Monster Hunter games either.

The party/pawn system isn't particularly great, to have a full party you need to adopt other players pawns, which may be unoptimized in skills and equipments, or just underleveled because they stagnate in levels (so you have to hassle with removing them [I initially thought I have to clear out their inventories first...] and recruiting new ones) - or you have access to a pawn with lvl ∞, trivializing the  game entirely.

The inventory is a hassle at best, with individual members having an individual inventory rather than simplifying it into a unified one,  especially considering that it is a single player game and there's no reason to have multiple inventories.

Crafting seems to be tacked on and unintuitive as hell, having to find specific items you want to craft requiring you to navigate through the hellscape that is the inventory screen and browse through multiple indistinct plants or rocks. Also the game doesn't tell you that items degrade over time, and you need to put them into inn storages - to which, why doesn't the game just do that automatically?

Quests seems pretty janky, at some point the game tells me that there's a quest NPC at the starting village pier - and no one is there; the game wants me to talk to Heraldo, who isn't marked on the map or in his shop; the game wants me to the witchwood, which the map markers & companion voiceover seems to indicate to be somewhere outside your starting village, when it is beyond the encampment.

Exploration is likely to give you motion sickness, the game's world is filled with pointless dead-ends to explore and doesn't seem to be designed with gameplay in mind. The character's ability to jump is so bad that it's more likely to kill them by fall damage (proc-ing a reset from last save) rather than getting across small gaps.

Dragons dogma has really good gameplay overall, i played as Magick Archer and it was fun to play. 
So, the combat, classes, pawns, are very cool game mechanics and fighting monsters with your team where everyone has a specific role to fulfill were things that i loved very much.
Climbing monsters is cool too, finding the weak spot, this is something that i would like Elden Ring for example to have.
The world is well built, if we compare to Elden Ring, i think Dragons Dogma still has to improve some aspects of his world. 
The characters overall didn't stick to me that much.
The final battle, i was expecting too much and it was.......mid. i think towards the end, the game started to rush, it feels incomplete for me.
I liked the story, but the ending idk, didn't liked it very much. 
But good game overall, recomend.
It's a masterwork you can't go wrong

This review will contain spoilers for the main story but nothing regarding endgame.

Dragon's Dogma is a flawed masterpiece, a game that was stuck in development hell and quite infamously had 60% of it's content cut, despite all this Dragon's Dogma still holds up as a fantastic game with some of the best combat in an action-rpg.

Dragons dogma is one of those games that has an intriguing sense of mystery, especially when you consider what was planned for this game. I find myself thinking of shadow of the colossus when I play this not only because we have a fairly small word with not much going on but looking at all the plans this game had and what could have been. I'm grateful that capcom have given this franchise a second chance as the game has so much potential. 

Before we get into why this game is such a cult classic we need to address some of the weaker aspects of this game, again this is mostly as a result of the game being cut down but it doesn't stop the final product from feeling imperfect in some aspects. 

My least favourite part of the whole game is 90% of the plot, it starts with a basic fantasy troupe, you have to fight a dragon that's attacked your city. The game has some really interesting ideas especially right at the end of the game but the vast majority of it is spent running pointless fetch quests which are literally given to you to waste your time, seriously. The Duke doesn't want to fight the dragon and whilst the reasons behind this are actually really interesting it doesn't stop basically all of the main story just being terrible. 

There is also some really underbaked ideas which I won't go into here but feel they need to be listed - 

the openworld is very small and isn't that interesting to explore as all enemy spawns are static, they do change at certain points in the story but that's about it and locations are reused often (and some are just not used at all.) 

Romance, BG3 this isn't. 9/10 players first playthrough will end up with you and some old, bald guy getting it on and you'll have no idea why.

Vocations (think classes.) whilst an incredible addition to the game and one of it's selling points, they are massively unbalanced. Thank god the warrior class is getting fixed in DD2.

However, if you look past all that then what you'll find is a deeply rewarding game with some of the finest action combat in an rpg, the vocation system has such flexibility and diversity that it makes it so incredibly exciting to experiment.

Monster design takes inspiration from all over the place from simple goblins to cyclops to chimeras, you can climb on creatures shadow of the colossus style and stab them in weak spots, seriously amazing stuff. 

Endgame is when this game really shines, it's hard to talk about this without spoiling the best part of the game but it gets deep and rewarding and almost enters the diablo genre without being too much like nioh 2. Also the DLC is fantastic for keeping up replayability with much more gear to grind and fantastic bosses to fight. 

No fast travel in the conventional sense, you put down your own waypoints which are consumable and use consumable items to initiate the fast travel, starfield this ain't, if you haven't planned your routes you will be walking a lot and it's glorious. 

The pawn system is a fantastic idea that bucks the traditional jrpg troupe of a party, whilst the lore surrounding them is odd at best the execution is phenomenal, having your own custom chracters running about whilst also recruiting other players pawns online is so cool.

All in all I really love this game, it's flawed and unfinished but the ideas at play are very unique even if they are borrowed from other games of the same genre. Playing this game evokes the same feelings I had when I played morrowind, shadow of the colossus, dark souls 2 and the endgame nioh 2. This game reminds of all these games whilst still being fresh and unique. 

This game is normally less than £5 and is at the very least a curious experiment from a Japanese developer tackling a western rpg, sure it is ripe with blemishes but if you can move past that you will find a deeply flawed gem that deserves more exposure. 

I really hope we go to the moon in DD2.

Dragon's Dogma?  Dragon's Dogma you say?  What is it, what exactly is the big deal with this unfinished, amalgamation of cancelled Capcom elements that at the very least is- actually fun?  I wish I could tell you.  I've never beaten the main story.  Not once.  Oh sure, I've beaten the big bad dragon in the most scripted and boring boss fight compared to all of the other boss fights in the game (namely all of the other Dragon fights), but have I ever "beaten" Dragon's Dogma?  Nope.  Sorry, can't vouch for that myself.  Its honestly because.. not unlike Diablo II from 20 years ago, pretty much the same crap with swapped enemy color pallets after that third act.  

You see, what Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen does to pad out the original story line is by literally filling the world with a dark green smoky sky box, making some of the enemies tougher, placing a new infinite dungeon in the game, and then allowing you to fight GOD after you're done with your adventures on earth.  Is it effective as a narrative driven single-player (mostly) Action RPG?  No.  No I don't think it is.  Dragon's Dogma has no story, no meaningful characters, no NPC's of any value and is an extremely hollow experience from the first hour on.  That isn't to say its terrible by any means, its just not the focus of the game.  Its more about the actual fights, vocations, party forming with "pawns" (struggling to watch them accomplish anything on their own) and essentially just farming for items or experience.  That's literally it.  Sure the spells look cool, and the Assassin vocation is great fun, but that's pretty much it.

People love to make Dragon's Dogma look like the coolest thing ever with various clips of people one hit K.O.'ing Gryphons, destroying dragons, or casting giant spells on Bitterblack Isle boss fights, but in all actuality- they are super high level characters obliterating stuff because that's what the "experience" becomes no matter what.  Dragon's Dogma is extraordinarily broken and can be cheesed immensely with all sorts of LAME exploits as well as items.  You can literally get end-game equipment in Bitterblack isle right at the beginning of the FREAKING GAME.  Its that ridiculous.  With enough patience and health items you can tear right through the expansion content- grabbing extremely good items if you're fast enough.  

Personally, that is hilarious to me, given how much freedom that people "believe" that the game was somehow designed to allow (and totally not just a failure of a rushed project that was obviously cut-down by Capcom last minute) is comical to me.  Heck, its part of the reason I have as many hours as I do.  Its a very fun game to run around in and break stuff, or find interesting items or challenge yourself early on with certain fights, or find exploits, or level up with a different vocation.. its a lot of customization and freedom that many Action RPG's don't actually have (though they like to pretend they do).

The actual map isn't very big.  Gransys feels more like the first "Dark Souls" in a lot of respects because you'll constantly find loads of shortcuts here or there to reduce travel time.  OF COURSE the most influential item added to the PC port is that eternal ferrystone, which when combined with the portcrystals allows you to basically travel everywhere (that matters) in an instant, and thank god for that or else mid-game would be unbelievably dull.  I still wish it just allowed quick traveling anyway, since this gameplay "feature" allows you instantly complete escort quests anyway.

So lets talk about those escort quests.  You can tell a lot from the state of the final product with how many of those actually work and behave.  They are basically endlessly recycled, which is fine, but not interesting when they're instantly completed by warping there.  However, there are a few "story" related escorts that literally SUCK and waste your time for a paltry reward.  Why?  I have no clue as to why these are even in the game, its totally pointless.  A lot of quests are utterly vacuous and some are just go to point A on map and kill Monster "Z" for reward.  Its really unfortunate that this was the system leftover and was CLEARLY cut-down or altered from its original concept.

The other problem I honestly think will turn off a lot of people is just the actual plot, cutscenes, terrible spoken dialogue that often doesn't even make sense within the context of what is happening, or the atrocious attempts at drama throughout.  Sure, there are some special NPC's that have a little bit more of an interaction or maybe some extra quest lines, but a lot of them also have like ONE or two and then vanish completely forever.  Its very odd.  You actually save the *beep boop generic love interest* at some point in the early-game and then she just disappears essentially unless she is your beloved, which means she'll maybe show back up again.  The entire "beloved" system is also hilarious, allowing some pretty gross NPC's to be present when you face off the big bad dragon.


All in all, it was a fun and entertaining combat system that always kept me coming back.  To this day I think it has one of the better Action RPG combat systems around, its a shame the rest of the title was clearly under-cooked.

AMAZING GAME!!! The map is sufficiently big, with lots to do. You will never get bored as you travel on foot, theres plenty of monsters, thieves, sorcerers, mystical boss monsters, etc. Fun thing is you may accidentally encounter bosses before you are even supposed to making for a fun experience where you must watch over your back. The main story is good not great, but at least its unique from most games. There is plenty of armour, swords, magic staffs, bows, magic bows, magic swords, helms, rings, etc. 

The combat is a lot of fun. You get to climb monsters and attack their weak spots, every monster is weak to a certain element so you have to plan your journey well, and you have aide from pawns. The movements, the skills, and magic for the vocations of warrior, mystic knight, and strider look so amazing.

ITS WORTH IT!!!!

TTDR: Highly recommend. One of my favorite games I've play. I played on Xbox a few years back, so probably at least double the hours when considering what I've got to say. If you want a "quick" game to play through, I'd say give it a shot! However, if you are looking for new to you RPG, maybe wait until Dragons Dogma 2 releases and start there. Game here is a little old, but I'd still call it gold.

   You get to craft two characters, your player character and your main pawn (more on that later). Character creation actually makes some differences. Like gender causes certain encounters to go certain ways. You have base stats determined by height, weight and length of extremities. That's more of something to keep in mind when you're trying to optimize stuff perfectly, but you really don't have to worry with it. It's totally reasonable just make your people look nice to look at (or as goofy as you can get) as you will be see them in 3rd person for the whole game. Personally, I still get a good laugh seeing Terry Crew run around and smack stuff around as my main pawn. 
   Its got a good feel to all the vocations (classes). You wanna be big 2 hander gal/guy? Go Warrior. Maybe do some powerful spell casting? Go Sorcerer! Maybe you wanna cast spells, but be a little dexterous with a a few movement options (gotta use the daggers to roll and double jump mind you) try out the Magick Archer! These are just 3 of the 9 vocations you get access to. You get a lot of options for you and your pawn in combat and it's one of my more enjoyed experiences in combat. It's not souls combat, but its still very fun and I would call it engaging. Not only can you just smack around your enemies, but you can grapple little ones and climb large foes!
   While it is a single player experience, something pretty neat is that you can hire other players pawns into your party to a grand total of 4 members including yourself. However, if your friends own the game, no matter the level difference, you can summon them into your party for free. So, if you too want Terry to run around with you, add me when you play the game and get him!
   Game has some good replay-ability to it and has near seamless transition into your next run besides the fact of being popped back out to the main menu after completion of the final quest. Story is easy to follow and is pretty short, but there a lot to the game that you miss out on if you just B line through it. Some decisions give access to other quests while shutting you out from others. There is a lot you can miss out on for not exploring and decisions you make, so that second or nth run isn't too far fetched.
   With all this said, its from a few years back. Graphics are gonna be better with the newer release, Dragons Dogma 2, in March. From what I understand about it, DD2 is going to be basically DD:DA but the way they intended it to be. More vocations, more questing to be done, more graphical quality. Over all, more game. At the price point of about 30$ compared to the 70$ DD2 going to be for probably a while though, it might be a good idea to pick it up and just try it out to see if you interested in dropping that full 70$.

   If you read this far, get it. You're clearly interested since you just sat through all my ramblings. Play this until DD2 releases and goes on sale at some point wouldn't be a bad idea. Waiting for DD2 is also probably a good idea if you don't wanna throw all your money to Steam or whatever key broker you go through. Thank you for taking your time to read all I had to say and have a good one.

'Ello, 'ello. Dragon's Dogma is a great game, but before you play, some things to have in mind:
Goblins ill like fire.
Wolves hunt in packs.
Even in numbers, a weakling is a weakling still.
A bridge makes a good landmark.
Be careful not to get soaked to the bone.
When the road splits, be doubly sure of which will see you to your destination.
and finally...
It's a masterwork, you can't go wrong!

A really interesting game! The combat is really nice in this game, it felt unique and great in most classes. I liked how you could change classes whenever you wanted. The pawn system was soooo good, the beginning was a great way to show how they worked and it felt so satisfactory to have useful pawns instead of glitchy, useless companions like other games. The pawn system would also allow others to use your pawn so it made me focus on getting good gear for her and to dedicate time to make sure they were fit for others.

The story is actually not a highlight for me, I wasn't a huge fan of it. I loved the ending but throughout the entire game, most quests were forgettable and some were glossed over with no effect to the game.  I also accidentally locked myself out of other quests since I would progress or not find areas with quests until later. The characters within the game were good, a few really shined though. [spoiler] I wish that the game would have explained the "Beloved" thing more, I gave Julien so many gifts but because I did the quest with the queen, I was locked with her which was not what I wanted. [/spoiler]

This game felt like Dark souls vibe meets monster hunter so if that appeals to you, I recommend this game. It is a bit of a grind but the combat system is worth it. Plus the new game plus is really interesting and the DLC was great!

"Czy Dragon's Dogma, w obliczu nadchodzącego sequela, dalej jest grywalną grą?"
Tak, ale tylko jak bardzo lubisz action RPGi. Jest w tej grze tak dużo dziwactw i tak dużo durnych mechanizmów*, że naprawdę trzeba mocno przymykać oko. Ja przebrnąłem przez tę grę, 2 razy przeszedłem post-game, 2 razy przeszedłem DLC (50h podstawki + 50h wszystkich rzeczy po grze), ale wybaczyłem tej grze te wszystkie bzdury tylko dlatego, że ta gra ma 12 lat i dlatego, że zamierzam grać w DD2 i DD1 było przystawką. 

*1. Bossowie/mini-bossowie z miliardem hp, będący gąbkami na DMG (prisoner gorecyclops, daimon2), niektórych bosów przez godzinę tłuczesz po kostkach (nie przesadzam, naprawdę godzinę), bossowie są według mnie źle skonstruowani, każdy z nich powinien być ciekawszy, mieć ciekawszy moveset i mniej hp. Nie mówię, że każda gra ma być Dark Soulsem, ale uważam, że bossowie będący ZEROWYM wyzwaniem i jedynym wyzwaniem przy nich jest czas potrzebny na ubicie - to (WEDŁUG MNIE) zła konstrukcja i niestety wiem, że to będzie znowu w DD2, bo oni uważają. że to jest spoko, a nie jest.
2. Do gry wgrałem z 10 modów, żeby poprawić przeróżne bardzo podstawowe pierdoły (żeby nie oślepiały czary, żeby armor/ubranie miało rozróżnienie w ekwipunku, żeby niektóre czary były trochę bardziej przydatne itd.) - oczywiście można grać w vanillę. ale nie polecam tego, szkoda się męczyć z niektórymi rzeczami. Czy to, że zdecydowałem się wgrać mody to na pewno minus dla tej gry? Tak, bo mieli bardzo dużo czasu (dodatek do gry, 12 lat?) żęby poprawić te pierdoły, a tego nie zrobili.
3. System pawnów (wpierających NPCów AI) - no zabijcie mnie, ale nie cierpię tego, wiem, że jest to podstawa tej gry i jest znak rozpoznawczy, ale nie cierpię tego i w DD2 będę grał solo. Wiem, że gra będzie 4 razy trudniejsza, ale chcę spróbować. Pawny w DD1 były głupie, ginęły w durny sposób, nie chciały używać dawanych im przedmiotów, dawały minimalny dmg - zero przydatności.
4. Questy i części gry, które można zepsuć przez naturalną progresję gry. Staram sięgrać w gry na ślepo a nie z wiki na kolanach, więc takie rzeczy mnie wkur*iają i jak ominiesz jakiegoś questa (który ma follow up i później daje niesamowicie ważny przedmiot) i czytasz później na reddicie, że "w NG+ to zrobisz" to szlag człowieka trafia. 
5. System save'ów, czyli najgłupszy system save'ów jaki widziałem kiedykolwiek w grach, naprawdę. W grze jest autosave i 1 slot save'a, więc zero marginesu na błąd, a jak wczytujesz grę, bo coś zepsułeś (sytuacja z mojej gry, jestem na bazarze i misskliknąłem - zamiast zamknąć dialog walnąłem sklepikarza, więc podbiegł do mnie strażnik i wsadził mnie do więzienia, wczytałem grę i miałem checkpointa jakieś pół godziny wcześniej) to cofa cię do ostatniego checkpointa, a nie do ostatniego save'a, więc tracisz X gry. No naprawdę, czegoś durniejszego w życiu nie widziałem. Wgrałem moda, żeby to naprawić, mod i tak nie naprawia tego w 100%, a daje tylko możliwość quicksave'a, dalej trzeba uważać z loadami.

This game did not age well, you cannot get proper 3440 support and even when I did get it to go that way it cuts off much of the screen. I know it is harsh to grade a game not recommended because it is older and not supporting modern features but I do not want someone else to buy it and have the same frustrations.

I honestly don't remember a time where a game I actively disliked so much addicted me as much as this one. I couldn't stop playing it despite having so many issues with it. It is a game that is a jack of all trades, and master of none.

Dragon's Dogma's gameplay isn't good. Climbing on enemies and targeting weak points is a novel concept, but in practice it becomes taxing when you've done the same methods time after time. Playing a Fighter or Warrior in this game is just utter garbage because there's no dodge roll for those Vocations, and there's no lock-on either. Without a disengage ability for those Vocations, the player has to just turn and run to disengage, and without a lock-on using a Shield is utterly janky. 

Dragon's Dogma has a story that is dull and uninteresting, unfortunately. I think many of the quests are fun gameplay-wise, but they're not written well. It just feels like I'm doing things to do them. The Duke's actions in particular are nonsensical, and other questlines feel unfinished, such as Alienore's, which punishes the player for something and doesn't have any repercussions afterwards, with nobody mentioning it.

The Pawn system is the game's iconic mechanic, and it's awesome on paper, creating a custom companion. However, beyond your custom Pawn, the other two Pawns you recruit don't upgrade in level and can't be equipped with better gear. So you end up having to constantly cycle out your other two Pawns with Pawns you find wandering around, because those Pawns capped out in level.

Dragon's Dogma just frustrates me because it has so much potential but the design decisions and flaws really hold it back from true greatness. It's why I'm optimistic for the sequel though.

Score: 78

This is a game with a lot of depth to it. Its biggest draw is its combat system which blends the dynamic combo potential of Devil May Cry, the weight and variability of FromSoft titles and party management similar to Dragon Age (though you won't get to know your traveling companions as intimately as there). 

There are 9 vocations/classes to choose from and for the most part they play quite differently although there is some overlap between classes which share some weapon types, but most skills are vocation specific rather than weapon specific anyway. They are divided into 3 basic archetypes and colors, red being straightforward tanky melee fighters who can restrain most stunned foes so that their allies can whale on them, yellow being highly mobile units using daggers and a bow variation and able to roll and double jump at no stamina cost (although both abilities must first be learned), and blue being magick classes which tend to be able to rack up monstrous damage easier than the others but have more trouble fighting off enemies alone since their basic attacks are mostly weak and many spells take a little while to cast during which period the caster must stay still or can move only very slowly. Beyond the basic vocations are the advanced and hybrid ones, the former sacrificing some aspect of the base class in exchange for being able to do something else better, while hybrids combine two colors for a mixed playstyle which makes them all incredibly versatile. The vocations and skills for them can be learned/changed at inns and the entrance of the difficult Bitterblack Isle area which was formerly DLC content and is unaffected by main story progress allowing it to be accessed or ignored at any time, essentially being a separate storyline. One cannot use equipment meant for other vocations (e.g. a mage cannot wear plate armor) and hybrid vocations are unavailable to pawns, limiting them to the basic and advanced ones. The one learnable upgrade all vocations can share are augments, essentially perk points up to 6 of which can be equipped, their usefulness varies but there are many more handy ones than useless ones, though some are so useful that it makes little sense for a particular vocation not to use them (e.g. the Warrior's Clout augment for any melee class which simply gives a huge 20% boost to one's physical strength). Stat growth depends on one's vocation on level up and the max level is 200, stats unfortunately cannot be respecced but beyond wanting one's main pawn to be appealing for others, ultimately one can easily play a mage after exclusively leveling up as a melee vocation as damage depends much more on equipment than a character's stats. 

All vocations are capable of grabbing and throwing (but not grappling) small enough foes and climbing large ones, though climbing isn't equally useful for every playstyle. Unequipping primary weapons lets you fight with your fists, and there's a certain ring that can boost the damage of unarmed attacks which can be useful for staff wielders fighting magickally-resistant foes, but aside from that it's ineffective. Yellow vocations can still roll and double jump while unarmed. There are also one-use items such as throwable knives, bombs and magick tomes which can be used by any class (except special arrows which are limited to non-magickal bow users), but frankly for the most part they're more of a novelty than a valuable tool, mostly because they can't be hotkeyed and weigh/cost a lot in large amounts. There is a way to get strong fast by buying copious amounts of throwblasts due to them being stronger than your regular attacks would be at the beginning but that strategy is not recommended for new players. 

The enemy types are diverse and fight in different ways so different enemy types never feel alike unlike, for example, the flying bosses in Witcher 3. The music in this game is notable in that outside battle tracks it tends to play at the moment one enters a new area or during/after a cutscene, after which it doesn't change or loop but fades into silence, but the ambient sounds of any area keep the silence from becoming an uncomfortable one. Any visual aspect of the Arisen and their main pawn can be completely changed by buying a certain endgame item, before then the changes are more limited as one can modify their haircut, makeup, voice and hair, eye and skin color at a barber in the capital or buy a one-use item from the same merchant who sells permanent access to the editor which lets one make a total makeover but disappears and won't be restocked afterwards. The height of a character affects things such as the size of their hitbox and melee reach while their weight affects stamina regeneration and carrying capacity (something which cannot change otherwise outside of a specific augment and certain Bitterblack equipment). Additionally, the torso type of a character is the only thing that affects their sprinting speed, though while this is a useful tidbit to know, in-game it doesn't make that much of a difference that one should sacrifice the way they would like their character to look for it. There are certain tiers of encumbrance and the higher ones are undesirable because they increasingly reduce all movement speed and increase stamina consumption. The personality and to a certain degree the fighting priorities of one's main pawn can also be changed by sitting down on a chair at an inn. There's a minor romance system but it's infamously hard to predict and can sometimes result in comical pairings due to the strange way the game determines one's beloved, that being the person with the highest affinity towards the player they talked to last before completing a certain main quest. All but a handful of NPCs can be your beloved (in short, other Arisens and most pawns). This is unavoidable but has no bearing on the gameplay and is much more of an afterthought than an important mechanic.

Just finished the main game. The story is comedic with characters not behaving they should. By the time the credits rolled I realized I enjoyed the game, not because of the story or the characters, which doesn't make sense in any world, but I did enjoy the gameplay aspects of it. I played as a Warrior vocation and found the combat satisfying and fun, you can feel he weight of the heavy warhammer as you swing around you, toppling foes. 

The game is not intuitive at all as it doesn't explain a lot of systems. I loved the simulated aspects of the game with many npcs having their own schedules as they move around the map. However, it also created some frustrations like not being able to find an npc for the quest at hand because they moved elsewhere at the time at day. 

The game also does a terrible job by not telling you the recommend level for quests. I tried to play safe and even then I came across random enemies on the road which one shot me and took so many hits. Fortunately it was only a problem early in the game, but led to a lot of frustrations.

Finally, the game's fast traveling system is intriguing. You cannot simply fast travel wherever you like in the game unless you out down some beacons, which you have in limited quantity. The problem is a lot of times you are asked to return back to an area you already completed, so if you don't have a beacon anywhere near the area, expect a very long hike with enemies respawning along the path. My advice is to spread out the beacons to cover as much of the map as possible.

The game gave me a lot of Elder Scrolls Oblivion vibes with intriguing world with jankness to the systems. I appreciate it for what it is. Just don't do go into this game thinking you will be deeply invested in the story or the characters, oooof....

Gameplay is really great! The bread and butter of DD:DA is you can mount large monsters and deal damage especially weak spots. But what makes the game unique is its Pawn System. Pawns can learn from you and they can also be used to aid other players.

This game is also not a requirement if you plan to play it's upcoming sequel. Have Fun!

[h1]Disclaimer[/h1]
I finished the game once in normal mode mostly as a melee character with some magic.
Edit: post 100% completion summary in the comment section.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
Though this game has massive flaws it also shines with pure brilliance at times. The biggest issue is that it starts very badly and boringly and it's easy to miss important quests that won't be available later on.

I recommend only if you can accept having to play through first 5-10h of slog to get to the mid and lategame where this game really opens up and begins to be very fun.

Grab it on a discount.

[h1]Description[/h1]
If I were to compare this game to another, I would choose Gothic. Dragon's Dogma in many ways is a reverse-Gothic action-RPG experience. Both games share the idea that you can go anywhere from the start. Wanna fight a cyclops on lvl1? Go for it, see how long you last. Wanna try your shot with a dragon in first 5h of the game when even a group of mangy wolves pose a threat? Go ahead, just keep a save handy to reload to once you get 1 shot-killed.

However, while Gothic had primitive, clunky combat and focused rather on creating a compelling, natural world filled with dangers and secrets as well as great quest design with fantastic character interactions...
... Dragon's Dogma takes the opposite route and focuses on a fun action combat and character progression, while leaving questing, story and world design as a secondary concern. Many quests are boring fetch or escort quests, most sidequests are legit MMO-style 'kill 50 skeletons'.

So, about that character progression... you can initially pick 1 of 3 classes - a mage, a scout or a fighter. You will then have ability to progress to 6 different advanced classes which either refine certain playstyle of the base classes like a 2h-weapon user Warrior class, or mix classes together like a sword-spell class Mage Knight.

Each class has access to it's own sets of weapons but also many passive and active skills or spells. Seriously, even melee classes have a bunch of attacks and special features. Combat itself is action-based with direct control over your character. You can even jump and climb big monsters, which can be useful to target their weakpoints.

You also have a companion, which you can customize just like your main character and you also hire 2 more companions through game's Pawn system, which lets you rent your companion and hire that of other player's.

The story starts with your fishing village getting attacked by an ancient dragon. You show bravery and fight the creature with nothing but a rusted sword and it apparently impresses the wyrm enough to form some kind of forced pact with you. Dragon steals your heart, turning you into an Arisen - a being capable of commanding Pawns as their personal entourage. The only way to regain your humanity is to find the Dragon and reclaim the heart it stole from you.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[b]+ Combat[/b]
Most classes save for a 2h Warrior has a large assortment of skills to use and they are almost always fun to experiment with. Different enemies will be weak to different damage types and react to what you are doing. You can, for example, climb onto a chimera's back to have easy access to it's goat-head, but it will try to bite you with it's snake-tail or shake you off.

[b]+ Big monsters[/b]
Speaking of chimera - it's one of my favorite monsters in this game. It has 3 heads - front of a lion, middle with a goat head sticking off the top of it's body and a tail with a snake head at the end. Each of these heads will attack independently - lion will pounce, bite and claw at you, goat will cast spells and snake will bite and spit poison. Each head is also weak to some damage - snake can be cut off, goat can be killed with physical attacks quick and lion is weak to magic. All of this creates a strong dynamic in a battle. Some classes rely on specific damage types, so you will have to work with your Pawns to succeed.

There are many other big monster types, but most of them are reserved for the DLC (included in PC release).

[b]+ Main story (later on)[/b]
It takes time to get going, but once it does - the story is far deeper than you may initially expect. I especially loved every time the Dragon showed up. His dialogue is unnerving and he is clearly toying with you. He steals the show when it comes to voice acting in the english version too.

Unfortunately you can't switch voices to Japanese without a mod.

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[b]- Running simulator[/b]
The world is big and filled with pretty narrow paths that take a ton of time to travel through to get to each of the points of interest. You will get ability to teleport to the main city for free, but it's not like it's close to everywhere from that place...

Combined with very low weight limit that also makes you slower the closer you get to max AND limited stamina for running - you will fking cry every time you realize you need to spend 20 minutes of walking through monster infested forests to get to a point where you need to talk to someone.

You will gain crystals you can plant into the ground which will create a teleport point. These can be obtained usually at the end of story-important dungeons. Using them requires special stones that are 2k Gold each and limited (although usually they restock in shops every few days or so). In the endgame you will have the money to get as many as you want, but early on? Prepare to run run run everywhere.

This is one of the main reasons people never finish this game - it takes so long to get to the good part AND it requires you to waste time on manual travel.

[b]- Board quests[/b]
All MMO-style quests. Fortunately not needed to finish the game.

[b]- Points of no return[/b]
Some of them are important as they will impact what side NPCs survive and potentially becomes your waifu. There are often difficult to find and will get unavailable if you miss them before progressing through main story.

I recommend using a quest progression guide.

[b]- Waifu[/b]
The game itself chooses an NPC you like the most based on arbitrary stuff. Doing quests for them, giving them gifts and giving them a special-someone ring all contribute to their affinity, but it's quite easy to max out affinity for multiple characters by only doing their quests. If multiple characters are maxed - the game decides who to make into your waifu. WARNING, your waifu may not be female. Yup. Progressive!

I gave ring to my ideal waifu magical girl and still the game matched me with a princess I saved from a tower. BTW it was weird when during the saving animation they threw themselves onto a bed together and the screen faded to black for a moment. Surely there was no time for a hanky-panky when I was supposed to grab her and lead her out of a prison with tons of guards running around, right? Maybe they did a quickie or something. Now that I think about it - that's the only character that sexes you during their quest, no wonder the game was adamant on making her into my wife. Conservative!

[h1]Lowdown[/h1]
I am replaying it in Japanese, maxing out different classes and going through DLC.

I'd give Dragon's Dogma a
[h1]7/10[/h1]
I need to be clear once more - you need to survive first part of the game. And I mean it - survive through it as this game will kill you, make you lose progress (if you forget to save) and make you make your huge hikes again and again.

Once you start being able to survive most wildlife and start building your characters and the story pick up - you will start enjoying it.

this is an absolute gem in the world of RPGs.

This has been one of the most fun and incredibly cool action RPGs I've ever played. TLDR; If you're at all into fantasy and RPGs I think this is one of the best. Sometimes the narrative is a little disjointed feeling though.

Every class I've played as feels incredibly unique and interesting, and their play styles are incredibly different.

DO KNOW that because their play styles are so incredibly extreme some classes might just not feel fun for some people. I usually LOVE playing mages but they really felt painful to use at first playing this game and sometimes you don't get to feel like a part of the action.

I've never played a game where being a mage felt so much like _being a mage_. Spells are impactful and take a ton of commitment, you can literally play a support character for the rest of your NPC party if you want. The upgraded mage class has incredibly powerful spells that take 10-20 seconds to cast and feel like you're actually warping reality: summoning meteor showers, giant spires of ice, etc.

And on the flip side the other classes feel just as unique and incredible, the fighter is pretty quick and agile, with gameplay that emphasizes both his sword and shield, the Mystic Knight is also super unique, able to use both magic and melee together to create this really unique preparation-focused playstyle combined with powerful counterattacks. I haven't even tried the archery-based classes yet and I hear they're incredible.

MY criticism is mostly around things that have been added to make the game easier at the start, Capcom added powerful armor and items sitting in your "bank" at the start of the game and in my opinion they just make the beginning less interesting and I chose not to use them for the most part. 

But depending on how you like to play games these boosts could feel like a great addition. Travel can take a _long_ time and fast travel is fairly restricted, but the world is densely populated with enemies, ambushes, bosses, secret areas, shortcuts, and collectables... 

Fast travel is tied to an infinite-use item that you'll be given near the beginning of the game, but in older versions required a consumable (which I personally actually preferred and used through my main playthrough). Even with infinite uses, there are very few permanent fast travel spots and instead you'll have to explore and find these stones you can place in the world to create points for yourself which is a fun bit of meta-strategy.

At core an interesting game, but in many points defined by the narrow boundaries of the old console generation, not the least the muddy graphics (of the beautiful game world). The port to PC made the interface which was already bad in the beginning to the main monster to fight. Actually this gives the game an old-school touch, because obviously there are no interface standards on the pc a porter should adhere to yet in the year 1990 - oh, no, 2016! 
This is a pity, because there are some interesting ideas here, the pawn system, the grapple stuff  (don't try this on your pc, btw) etc. But this doesn't play like a game which is 4 years old, but more like 15 years. Back then it was ok to have empty cities, repetive npcs, a bland story and an idiosyncratic interface as if they are the first to have the idea of an inventory. 
The fighting system is good, but not good enough to make you forget all of the other points. This game is definitely not 81  / 100 but more like 70. 

[Replaying this now, 2024, in expectation of the DD2 I think I didn't do justice to the innovative ideas in DD1. And in the years since 2016 I played so many ports or games which have been designed with consoles in mind first, that I am more used to bad UIs and controls. But it is still a strange mix of good and ugly. And the bugs (after all these years) and the quality of the port makes me sceptical about the PC version of DD2. ]

✇ Recommendation for playing in 2024 ✇

1. Download "Wabbajack" for mod installation.
2. Install Dragon's Dogma and launch once, then launch Wabbajack.
3. Browse modlists, filter by Dragons Dogma, choose Everfall.
4. Start installation and review the website it launches for instructions.
5. Turn off HDR if you have an Ultrawide monitor to fix bloom issues.

--------------------------------------------------------------

Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen stands as a towering colossus in the realm of role-playing games, weaving a mesmerizing tapestry of adventure, exploration, and combat. The world of Dragon's Dogma is a living, breathing entity, teeming with secrets to uncover and challenges to conquer. From the sprawling plains of Gransys to the foreboding depths of the Bitterblack Isle, every corner of the game world is crafted with meticulous detail, immersing players in a rich tapestry of lore and legend. The atmospheric day-night cycle and dynamic weather systems further enhance the sense of immersion, as players traverse rugged landscapes shrouded in mist or bask in the warm glow of a setting sun. The world feels alive, responding to the player's actions and decisions in ways that feel both organic and meaningful.

At the heart of Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen lies its revolutionary combat system, which seamlessly blends the depth of traditional RPG mechanics with the visceral action of a hack-and-slash masterpiece. Players are empowered to create their own unique play style through the game's robust class system, allowing for a staggering variety of character builds and strategies. Whether unleashing devastating spells as a Sorcerer, raining arrows from afar as a Ranger, or cleaving through enemies with brute force as a Warrior, every class feels distinct and satisfying to master.

The real brilliance of Dragon's Dogma's combat, however, lies in its innovative Pawn system. Players are accompanied by a customizable AI companion known as a Pawn, whose abilities and behaviors can be tailored to complement the player's own strengths and weaknesses. This adds a layer of strategy and depth to combat encounters, as players must coordinate with their Pawns to overcome formidable foes and exploit enemy weaknesses.

For negatives, I have to mention the map is bugged on Ultrawide monitors and to my knowledge still not fixed. There used to be a mod for it but it was abandoned a while ago. Bitterblack Isle is the only DLC which adds a huge challenge to the game but it's enjoyable if you're prepared. It was still somewhat lazy because it uses the guise of a "maze" design which just repeats the same areas as you go deeper which is only confusing and an obvious limitation of console technology for game file asset management. You can tell the DLC was made for seasoned players which may be a turn off for casual players which don't want to change their loadout and pawns for a single fight.

I really... REALLY... tried hard to fall in love with the game. And to some extend I succeeded. However, my playing sessions still felt a little forced after about 20 hours of gameplay. I wanted to go back to continue, but every time I felt a bit of doubt. 

I know many people love this game and call it one of the best action-RPGs out there. And in some things it does excel and is lovable. But as a sum of parts. I guess. it's just not for me. I am a long-time RPG fan, especially 3d person. 

But good combat doesn't fix the generic story and long tedious running around the map for me. 

I gave up.

Very often, a game has a few hours to grab your attention, to show you that it's going to be worth your time.
Dragon's Dogma fails on that end pretty hard.

I hear all the screams of JRPG fans, where tons of pointless NPCs make for better towns, large towns make for better realism, tiny stat upgrades make for rewarding experiences and quests that are far above your power-level lets you know the world is tough and you need to get stronger.
All of these things make for a drag of a start.
From the tutorial of fighting a cool creature, and then the sort-of rush to get to another cool creature... The in between sucks. It's incredibly frustrating to try and explore, only for the game to tell you, "You can't be here yet. Or you can run if you want."
Look up "Lost and Found Dragon's Dogma", and there's immediately discourse on the missions. If you can't deal with something like that, the game ends here for you. Hope you had a fun read of this review.

For every idiot like me who read that, and wants to keep pushing... I can tell this one is a rough diamond. The cities are rough to deal with, the escort quests are boring, the travel from place to place means you are walking if you don't make use of the honestly unexplained ferrystone/portstone stuff.
BUT
This game hides the fact that it's great. I remember my joy in Shadow of the Colossus when I climbed a monster for the first time. I remember my in XCOM when I needed to run from endless waves of enemies, and the slow but steady progression of similar RPGs.
I'm planning to pour many more hours into this, but with the release of DD2, I hope to see a better start to the game for newcomers to the series.

Pros:

- Good Pawn mechanic
Cons:
- Quests are boring and have lots of running

The beginning of the game was pleasant and promising up until the moment when you have already run through the world map once. After that the quests just forced you to run around the map several times between 2 spots. The main plot tries to be epic, but it consistently fails. The world by itself is huge but just filled with packs of mobs and you have no other option but to fight them, as you lack stamina to run through all those empty spaces. 
Moreover, grind is a must have, as the final quest is around 20 times more difficult than any other quest or opponent that you have encountered before. And bosses are just sponges for damage. 
Pawns are designed to help player, but not interfere. Maybe, for some playstyles they would suffice, but not for all of them.
So, the first around 20-30% are fascinating. Then it gradually becomes worse.

I was originally planning on modding Skyrim into a modern action RPG, but then I found this and other than the graphics, it checked all the boxes for what I wanted to mod into Skyrim. So I uninstalled Skyrim and have been playing this instead.

This game took me by surprise, I've heard that it was good, but I didn't know it would be this good. Got this because the initial trailers for dd2 looked cool, so I got this on sale. And **** did it make me a hardcore fan of the series. The exploration is decently large in this game, and the music is pretty good (bring back the old menu music though). But what really got me hooked is how surprisingly deep the pawn system goes, and the brilliant combat/vocation system. The attacks and spells in this game actually feel like they have some real strength to them, you just don't know how satisfying it is to dual summon meteors with your pawn on some unsuspecting enemies until you get to do it. And the magick archer in this game is perfection. You get some of the mid tier spells from sorcerer, with the added fun of a rogue class! The only weak point in this game is the story somewhat, because if you aren't paying attention to the story and miss one thing, then the whole thing just seems slow and lackluster. Would I recommend this at 30$? Probably not honestly due to the age and the fact the next one is right around the corner. But if it were on sale, I absolutely recommend this (granted, this game may not be for everyone, but it's definitely worth trying out!)

A true RPG in the traditional sense of the word. They don't make games like this anymore, is what I would say before playing this; guess I was wrong. The spirit of Dark Souls with the intricacies, depth and richness of an old school RPG in the same vein of 'Baldur's Gate' or 'Ever Quest'.

If you are a true RPG fan, if you like the Dungeons and Dragons universe, if you like fun, complex and nuanced combat, do yourself a favor and buy this.

EDIT: Sadly, the depth and intricacies of certain elements come at the expense of other systems, which have strikingly simplistic mechanics. So much so that it tarnishes an otherwise superb game. The story as well, didn't live up to expectations by the end.

If developers can maintain the same quality of already good systems and improve on the weaker aspects, the sequel may turn out to be among the best games of recent years.

I can't believe I never left a review of this game. I feel like I must have but I guess I didn't. With the oncoming announcement and release of Dragon's Dogma II I went back to replay this game and I have to leave a review.

Dragon's Dogma is one of my favorite games ever. It is in incredible game that should have been way more popular than it was but for some reason it was a cult classic. Those who know know, you know.

The combat is spectacular, imagine fighting really strong enemies, with a party, being able to climb on the enemies and do even more damage. You can be really any kind of character you want, a dual blader theif kind of person or a warrior, cleric, mage, and then once you level up you can pull in aspects of whatever other classes you like.

The story is interesting although a little slow-paced in the start, but its built that way so you interact with the world and level up before continuing. The game is punishing to those who fail to prepare. You should sleep in an inn or campfire before heading out on a journey. And you should have a party with you and not go alone. 

The world-building is incredible and you easily feel immersed in this unique and gritty fantasy world. There is a sense of progression with all the moves as you level them up and get stronger, enhance your weapons and armors etc.

I can't gush enough over this game. You do not need to play this one to play Dragon's Dogma II when it comes out. It has been confirmed by the developers. Dragon's Dogma II will probably be the better game, due to upgraded graphics and better fluid controls but this game is definitely worth a play if you love good games and action RPGs.

This "not recommended" is primarily for Capcom, and only to a lesser extent for the game. Let's see:

- I already owned it on GOG, but the game lacked important patches and online features, and I had to buy it again on Steam.
- Broken ultrawide support. I think it was originally letterboxed, then Capcom dropped the ball with the current implementation. Mods don't work either. I ended up creating a custom resolution in the driver to get a 16:9 letterboxed image at max resolution.
- Although Capcom can't (or rather won't) deal with these problems, they are always happy to introduce new DRM.

As for the game, I don't think I can recommend it to new players, especially right before Dragon's Dogma 2. Obviously, if your childhood was all about Dragon's Dogma, this might be the greatest game you've ever played, but right now it feels very dated and has quite a few questionable design decisions, some of which are so lame they've practically become memes. Of course there are a lot of features that I really love, such as the pawn system and the unique fast travel, but I still think that time has not been kind to this one.

it's worth every penny!

A fantastic cocktail of fluid 3rd-person RPG combat providing more options than just "attack and dodge" and brilliant Monster Hunter/Shadow of the Colossus mechanics, allowing the player to physically scale the monsters they face.

The game is not without its flaws, no game is perfect. Vocations obviously aren't really balanced, and anyone who has played the game for themselves knows exactly what I'm talking about, but at least all the different classes are viable for gameplay. None of them are so bad that they're practically unplayable, there are just very clear and objective imbalances among the vocations. In addition, the start of the game can feel like a trudge and with the cart-escort quest required to progress past the tutorial stage, it can put a lot of players off from becoming invested. 

However, once you get past the first half-hour of the game and get to the capital city, Dragon's Dogma becomes a masterwork of a video game title. Incredibly voice acting, solid progression systems compounded with great RPG mechanics, unique and dynamic monster encounters and quests, and the innovative combat make this game one of my favorites, even after a decade has passed since its release.

Absolutely incredible, way ahead of it's time (2012), and with Dragon's Dogma 2 right around the corner, there's nothing wrong with playing the first game and experiencing the cult classic for yourself. I might only have 37 hours (as of writing this review) on PC, but this game easily provided hundreds of hours when I originally bought it on the Xbox 360 and the PS4.

10/10, a must-have for any RPG fan.

I genuinely think this game is a classic. It took me three attempts and about 10 hours to get what it was putting down and meet it on its own terms, but once I did I found the flow of fun fairly easy. 

It does beg for a few QoL issues that would make it excel, little things like divesting your pawns of all of their picked-up items and placing them in storage with a menu option at an inn, or perhaps more clearly signalling that a quest is time or event specific. Still, a little bit of reading online has cleared up all of the issues I've had with progression and really opened my eyes to the full picture. 

This is a game that wants you to play it a few times consecutively, building up difficulty and rewards as you do NG+ and the DLC. Don't sleep on what it is requesting you do to adjust your approach and I think you'll have a good time. ARPGs like this are rare so I'm thankful to have it.

This was a fun game!
The progression really felt good, not so fast and not too slow. But people might want to understand and be patient because the traversal in here were slow (especially in early part of the game), we will walk a lot in here but sprinting outside safe zone will consume stamina, not only that the world may seems empty at some part, it might be tiring for some people but for me its not really a problem.
Whats good about Dragon's Dogma is the combat system and pawn system. The combat feels really satisfying, many vocation (class) to choose from and some of them are mixed class. Sorcerer in this game have an amazing skill, not a simple elemental shooting but you can summon a meteor rain and tornado at high skill that has a cool effect! You're rarely got the chance to do this in other RPG game.

There are many quality of life improvements missing, such as different save files, auto save, fast travel to an area already discovered, warnings to not advance in the plot missions or you will lose others, marking missions that have not yet been discovered on the map, etc, all this already common at the time, is a game design decision, but a wrong one, many people drop the game at the beginning because of this.

Even though I enjoy exploring the map, sometimes it gets tiring, especially if you end up dying and having to go back to the home screen to load the save, because retry is not always the last save. As the game only provides one save, you can lose hours of progress if you press retry in a hurry.

The game is poorly optimized for PC, which is normal coming from Capcom, to solve UI problems at high resolutions you will have to use mods and even with SSDs the loads are slow and having to go back to the home screen every time you see dying is a pain.

I don't usually rate games that I play, but I feel that it would be a disservice to this game, as I couldn't recommend it enough. I absolutely adore this game; it is incomparable to anything else I have played in my entire life. The game-play is absolutely *chef's kiss* even to this day, the character creation is astoundingly good for it's time, the graphics are actually still pretty good (though admittedly they could use a LITTLE tweak or two) the map is amazing, and the enemies are iconic in the genre. This game is completely timeless, and I wait in anticipation for the sequel.

It's a fun game with early open world RPG jank. Basically no QOL improvements - basically this isn't really a remaster. Having said that, it is fun. It plays similar to a Souls game combined with hack-and-slash games and Shadow of Colossus all tied together with a very intuitive party management system. I feel the devs wanted to do so much more (and probably will, in Dragon's Dogma 2!).

The gameplay is fun. This is some of the best combat I've felt in a game. That part doesn't feel dated, which is good. It could easily fit in with today's RPG's. Where it does fall off is the story. The story is so generic "old dragon came back to kill everyone". The parts where it is interesting (the whole Arisen aspect) they don't expand on it enough and you have to just accept that your character has this history with the people in the kingdom and villages you come across. Basically, you don't develop a relationship with characters. Sure, good RPG's don't need that (Elden Ring doesn't, for example)...but the game almost acts like it wants you to. Plus, the whole Pawn system with your party sets you up to develop relationships with the characters - but that never happens. This make role-playing fall off a bit. It takes about two hours to really get into the groove of the game and understand that quests are kind of supposed to come up randomly and you progress as you want in that regard...it's weird because with all the tutorial boxes the game gives you - the devs didn't weave it into a quest, really. You kind of are told to go talk to people. That could be a great idea if people didn't have one or two sentences to say (i.e., many NPC's feel like JRPG NPC's)

The other iffy aspect of the game is the traversal...though I won't come down on that too much because it is an early open world RPG...because of that it comes with some of that jank I mentioned: thing things like loading screens whenever you enter a village, questionable village placement, awkward paths, and an open world that isn't vast - just interconnect paths from village to village or forest or cave. 

So, why do I recommend this game? Well, I can't stop playing it. The combat is enjoyable as all hell and you come across it often. Particularly, boss fights are fantastic - you can damage every part of the large bosses and climb all over them. You can chop off the tail of an enemy or the head, or leg. The early jankiness is endearing in a way. The game is humble and doesn't take itself seriously when it comes to story - think Shenmue.

I'm enjoying myself - which is what I look for in a game. Plus, this game is almost always on sale for $5 so definitely give it a try.

Great game, biggest selling points for me:
- the combat (duh it's cap com)
-pawn system (once you understand it)
- very in depth game mechanics and unique mechanics like being able to grab smaller enemies and grapple larger ones
-story themes such as the cyclic nature of life

The early game is pretty rough though especially if you're like me and don't like playing with a walk through guide, highly recommend looking up a spoiler free one though honestly, they do a poor job of explaining some mechanic to the player and others are just obtuse and cause a lot of unnecessary frustration.

Biggest cons to me:
-The story plot wise feels very unfinished with lots of immersion breaking holes 
-Feels like your decisions have no consequences until 1 before post game and 1 after
-Lots of minor QOL changes that would make the game more enjoyable without killing what makes it unique (Vocation load out system, more intuitive quests such as the escort quests, etc.)

Despite it's many flaws I still consider this game a gem and the combat is honestly enough to keep me coming back. solid 8/10

Pros: Amazing combat, lots of build paths, semi (?) optimized, decent graphics

Cons: Repetitive combat, grinding is pointless, loot is horrible, empty world, 80% of quests are either fetch or escort, UI sucks, severely limited hotkeys, inventory management sucks, pawns are pain in the a$$.

In short, this game doesn't take 40 hours to finish. It only takes 10, the rest 30 is just you running all over the map. Lore is close to non-existent. I loved the first 2-3 hours but then the things i mentioned in cons ruined the game for me. 

Some funny things to mention: The BBI DLC becomes available right after prologue but the general consensus for required level to start is level 50. Guess what? you don't usually reach level 50 in the base game unless you get out of your comfort zone.

Overall, this game was promising. It could have been an AAA game easily. Dunno when it went wrong though.

Astounding game. 1/4 through Main Campaign review after waiting 10 years! Slightly modded to help with inventory and visuals. Vanilla Dark Arisen PC release stat wise.

It took me years to force myself to play this, and I've a few tips for people on the bench.
It takes a good 6 hours until the good stuff kicks in, but then you're already a powerhouse. Sell the DLC Monocle and you're off to a great start with enough cash to mess about and level up without fear of wastage. It helped me get over the games apparent quirks. It just plays like a console game, but I'm smashing my way through the menus now, so you'll swiftly pick it up on Keyboard & Mouse .

You will NOT have to run everywhere all the time. About 20-30 hrs into the game you'll get two items that together will allow you to Port around the map. Big locations have Portals you can unlock, and together with a PORTABLE RIFT CRYSTAL in your inventory, you can place it on the ground ANYWHERE and zip back to any uncovered location, such as a big city to stock up. So halfway up a mountain and you're getting hammered, you just run away, plop your crystal down and bob off to the city to tool up, improve gear and level up from the XP from the first third of the journey! When you're ready, portal back - the location you left the Rift Crystal will appear as an option, and now you're ready for the next 1/3rd of the mountain pass. Until you unlock this, it really is a Map unlocking cycle.

There are hundreds of guides, but every one ALSO says just play whatever and however and have fun. You'll complete it no matter. It was designed as a solo PS3 game, so just smash away and see what happens.
The animations are nuts. The pawns you hire are nuts. The game is a bit odd, but its good crazy oldschool odd, if you know what I mean. When what was achieved in this game from 2012 clicked with me, it made many other ARPG's feel like an excel spreadsheet. It's like going on holiday with all the weird kids from school, but you're all smashing the crap out of everything in a ballet of designed chaos of your making. It's simply great fun to mess with.
Questing is a bit crap and things can be failed, and the save system needs your attention asap so you can learn how to spam it, and yeah, maaaaybe look up a class guide, but it wont really matter as it wasn't designed to play with a walkthrough and perfect stats, it was designed to make PS3 players scream "WTF IS HAPPENING!??!" at the screen.

I have sixty hours in this game and still don't understand what in this game is appealing.

Starting with the good:
-This game has very nice combat, animations are fluid, characters are responsive and abilities feel worthwhile and useful.
-Pawns (your npc followers) can be incredibly helpful at tackling tasks your class isn't suited for and supporting you.
-Boss/mini-boss battles are very engaging, the music is engaging, they have interesting mechanics and they allow you to feel how much stronger you have grown since beginning of the game.

Now here is the bad:
-The quests in this game may be the worst of all and every other open world RPG I have played, somehow even worse than modern Assassin's Creed titles. 90% of the quests are fetch quests that want you to revisit places you have previously explored over and over again while providing no interesting story, for the most part, no actual rewards.

I struggle to see how any son of God can actually preserve through these unimaginative fetch quests plaguing the game, even in Skyrim which is also polluted by a lot of repetitive and un-intuitive quests, you at least face some form of attempt at character development, an ultimatum, a reward or some form of return for your investment of time even if its futile. This game? none of that; 
"Oh arisen, I dropped my letter, please find," 
"Oh arisen, my son died please find three resurrection stones," 
"Oh arisen sickness has struck, 5 herbs please," 
"Oh arisen, skeletons and stuff, explore catacombs for the 3rd time please."

In the rare event you actually have something impactful happen through a quest, you realize its plot value is equivalent to a south park episode, nothing actually happens, hell even the NPCs you kill in town come back a week later lmao.

-Second issue, the game has a small amount of enemies and not a lot of ways to kill them, the combat is really engaging and all but majority of the encounters are trivial if anything, you can just kill everyone and everything with the same combo, save for mini-bosses maybe, the most engaging class may be the archer variants because they actually need to you aim at stuff instead of mashing/holding the same button combo for 30 minutes to get through the same dungeon.

-Class balancing, warrior was my favorite class but its as shallow as a pool, the highest creativity you can display as a warrior is using combat cry to get flying mobs down or using the ladder/catapult sword to launch pawns onto large creatures, maybe distancing yourself from mobs to charge up your attack. Sorcerer is holding down 1 button to watch cool effects come out and kill shit, Mystic Knight consists of 1 cool gimmick and the regular Knight is just ability spam.

Despite the combat feeling very good you run out of room to grow as a player in almost no time, you will use the same combos but with different VFX and more damage from the start until the end of the game.

In conclusion, apart from the cultural value the game offers everything of the game maybe except the smoothness of the combat is incredibly outdated, many older RPG titles despite not delivering on combat as well as this game outdo it significantly in every other aspect, give this a try if you don't mind doing brainless fetch tasks for a few hours to crank up useless rewards or if you want to build yourself a foundation for DD2.

Having come back to Dragons Dogma: Dark Arisen in preparation for the March release of Dragon's Dogma 2, I found it interesting how this game held up.  

Bear in mind that this 2012 game (that this 2016 expansion re-releases) came out a year after Skyrim's 2011 release, five years before Breath of the Wild, and six years before Monster Hunter World.  So what we have in Dragon's Dogma is an early Capcom overture towards a full-sized open-world game.  It's only quasi-open world, mostly enclosed set pieces of larger-than-usual size.  Instead, they focus more on the action gameplay mechanics.  And, honestly, it's a pretty good trade. Even Elden Ring pales in comparison to some of the over-the-top graphical effects involved in the spectacular moves you'll be doing in Dragon's Dogma, albeit that game has a much finer balance and difficulty curve.

Technically, I've seen worse decade-old compatibility.  I'm noticing a top review right now warns of a new DRM, but I don't think they've even added it to Dragons Dogma yet.  My main problem was it couldn't handle my ultrawide monitor.  It was hard-locked in full-screen mode with most of it overflowing below the screen, so I could not see the controls.  However, once I  hooked up an XBox-compatible gamepad and guessed that [b]I needed to hit the gamepad start button to commit changes to the graphics configuration screen[/b], I was able to get it into to run in a 1080p window.  Then Dragons Dogma: Dark Arisen was fully playable at maximum graphical settings, rock solid and playing well.

After that, I had to get used to Dragon's Dogma again.  It turned out I couldn't start a new game from scratch without throwing away everything I accomplished in 2016.  You get 1 save slot, the freedom to change your character build whenever you like, and that's it.  Fortunately, not starting over turned out to be the right call.  True, the combat is fairly sophisticated, but the Xbox gamepad hasn't changed a whole lot over the past decade, and you can only push the envelope so far with a few buttons and timing.  I was able to re-acclimate fairly painlessly thanks in part to everything close to town being easy enough to steamroll with my preexisting level 40-ish character.

Once I got the proverbial dragon ball rolling, I was surprised at how much of a slow burn Dragons Dogma: Dark Arisen was.  Capcom makes you retread old ground often in this game, like a classic Monster Hunter game.  But there are baddies to fight and loot to find everywhere you go, so it's never boring.  I fell into this flow of constant console-style action RPG, and the time melted away.  There's something really easygoing about Dragon's Dogma.  From the slightly cheesy way everyone acts, the way the monsters are presented, and the over-the-top spells and skills, it's oddly pitch perfect for a dated console video game.  This is classic action RPG comfort food right down to its core.

Overall, I can recommend Dragon's Dogma, especially for that patient gamer price.  Just expect Dragons Dogma to eat a lot of time.  It's surprisingly good at it.

Despite several major issues, the game is really fun and had the potential to be so much more.

GOOD:
- Combat is fun. The skills and monster-climbing ability make it very engaging.
- Although you have to walk to unexplored areas, journeying to a new location usually felt like a rewarding adventure with unexpected things along the way (at least the first time)
- Fights against big monsters generally felt epic, with interesting approaches to fight them
- Utilizing a party of 4 and upgrading your character felt satisfying
- Nice theme and some OSTs

BAD:
The game sometimes tries to be an immersive experience but some things always make it silly and unrealistic
- Horrible character design. Most NPCs feel really bland and make you feel like you can't wait to leave town and go fight things rather than care about the characters
- Story is underwhelming. Many things go unexplained, which may be nice as you can take it for your interpretation, but it feels like the devs didn't invest into the story
- Dialogue is bad. In quest conversations, this relates to the boring story. Moreover, it's common for NPC dialogue, especially talking with your companions, to give you obvious hints about playing the game which went against immersion and could have been told in a more subtle way
- Too many inventory items with similar effects that just clutter your storage or bags
- Menu could be simplified, navigating it was quite tedious
- Stamina limitation, especially in open world when running outside of combat. The most valuable consumable to me was always a stamina regen

This is a decent game except for one glaring problem: the save system. It forces you to lose progress at times, and is extremely annoying. The combat system is fine, but the quests are also tedious and annoying. Therefore, I cannot recommend the game unless you are very bored and are tired of all the better adventure games out there.

Having played it some more hours, I can add some things: You absolutely must do some of the quests in the order that they intended, or you lose access to some key areas. In some cases, especially early in the game, there is no warning about this. The love plot is also clumsy and poorly implemented. That said, I do like the combat and there are some interesting parts in the game. Add to this the bugs that keep appearing and not getting fixed (such as: Inflection doing the opposite of what it says). It's just not anywhere near flawless, and the flaws that it has are exceedingly annoying and could always have been easily fixed during game design.

Only worth while if you like meticulous, often times tedious games with higher difficulty level. But  horrible save system / retry system that take chunks of progress away, cheap deaths, and sometimes clunky combat might infuriate some.
