The best game ever made.

Dragon's Dogma is one of the most fascinating and unique games I've ever played. After 8 years of owning Dark Arisen, and many times hitting walls and bouncing off certain aspects of the game, I just recently smashed through that wall and finished the game entirely (minus the expansion content, Bitterblack Isle). 

DDDA has one of the most intricate and interesting class systems - called Vocations - which gives you so much control over your playstyle in a way I find comparable only to Monster Hunter. Do you want to climb all over big monsters to hit weak spots? Strider. Do you want to be big smash man? Warrior. Do you want to conjure the most insane magical spells I've ever seen in a third-person action RPG? Sorcerer. And then my favorite: do you want to play as a hybrid Vocation where you essentially cast spells through your bow? Magick Archer. 

DDDA can be little jank at times, but the feeling you get defeating a big monster is unparalleled, and the structure of the game lending itself to trying out all the Vocations on one save file means there's a lot of replayability. In fact, the game and story are basically designed for it, with its cyclical nature meaning that you finish the game and start back at the beginning with all your gear and levels. 

Honestly so much more to say for Dragon's Dogma, but I'm so happy to finally be able to say I've finished it, and am probably going to be finishing it again at least 2 more times before Dragon's Dogma 2 releases in March. If you are a fan of in depth combat and progression, fighting big monsters, and more than a little bit of cheese, you will want to try this game. 

This game is a masterwork. Can't go wrong.

Dis is a very good game

some of the systems and mechanics are at times a bit rudimentary. the story is told in a somewhat nontraditional format and much of the "lore" of the world seems very vague or surface level. I saw someone equate this game to a classic 1980's high fantasy movie in terms of overall design, and I'd say that's pretty accurate.

That being said, Every Vocation feels unique, and each one---even the three beginning classes---are viable through the end of the game. Combat is absolutely the flagship selling point of this game. Since its initial release all the way back in 2012 or so, few games boast a Character Creation system as deep as Dragon's Dogma's, and the upcoming sequel promises to double down on that depth. 

The pawn system is an incredibly unique approach to party-based gameplay and can bring a ton of added benefit to a playthrough. I for one though, am a sucker for a story and world that i can really, truly sink my teeth into. At the time of penning this review, I am only a dozen hours or so deep into the game with little complete in the way of story. At the present time however, I feel that the pawns' place in the lore of Dragon's Dogma's universe feels a bit tacked on. We're given very shallow excuses within the story/lore for these ever-faithful husks that serve at our whim and charge unflinchingly into the most dangerous of battles. Personally, I'd have liked a selection of well-developed characters, or the ability to customize a full party of Pawns (not big on the anachronistic nature of that name) with some choice in terms of character background---much like the character creation system in Mount & Blade. 

Aside from some dated mechanics, odd story structure and the myriad little gaps in immersion with AI companions, the brutally satisfying combat and unique approach to open world action RPG gaming ensure that Dragon's Dogma remains a diamond in the rough over a decade beyond its release. For anyone itching to play the sequel in a little over a month, this first game will absolutely tide you over until March.

Dragon's Dogma Dark Arisen delivers a thrilling fantasy adventure with captivating gameplay and a rich, immersive world. The dynamic combat system and the Pawn system add depth, making each battle and decision impactful.

The open-world of Gransys is beautifully crafted, offering a fair illusion of living, breathing environment with a compelling day-night cycle and dynamic weather. However, the inventory system can be cumbersome, hindering the overall experience. Additionally, while the game's art direction is commendable, the graphics show signs of aging.

Despite these drawbacks, Dragon's Dogma Dark Arisen remains a must-play for action RPG enthusiasts. Its engaging gameplay and immersive world overshadow the minor inconveniences, ensuring a memorable and enjoyable gaming experience. Dive into Gransys and embark on an epic journey that will keep you hooked from start to finish.

Dragon's Dogma was never perfect or the greatest game ever made. As an Open-World game, it lacks some core aspects. Throughout my gameplay, I wished many features from other games were present in this game. But there are too many reasons to love this game.

When this game first came out, there were many comparisons made between Dragon's Dogma and The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim. Although Dragon's Dogma was not as highly rated and made a massive impact as Skyrim, it is also an excellent game in its original style.

The Pawn system introduced in this game was one of the most revolutionary systems I have experienced in any game I have played so far. You will create a companion called Pawn, who is always on your side throughout your journey. And you are not limited to having only one Pawn. The Pawn created by other players can join your adventure, as can your Pawn join the adventure of other players.

Dragon's Dogma also has one of the best Battle Systems of all time. There are nine Vocations that players can choose and switch around. Each vocation has a unique and exciting battle style that players can experience differently. Personally, The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim has always been my favorite game, but I always thought its action lacked some intensity. There is no doubt that Skyrim is a better game overall than Dragon's Dogma in many eyes, including mine. But as an Action game, Dragon's Dogma could be the best in the Open-World Fantasy genre.

One of my all-time favorites. I cannot wait for Dragon's Dogma 2 to come out.

Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen - A Timeless Adventure (5/5)

🌟 Graphics: Still Impressive - For an aged game, the visuals surprisingly hold up. The lighting is top-notch, and most textures, except for some world textures like mountain boundaries, remain appealing.

🎮 Gameplay: Rewarding and Impactful - Every fight feels significant, delivering a satisfying sense of accomplishment. The effort put into battles feels equally rewarded, enhancing the overall gaming experience.

🔍 Quests: Engaging and Worthwhile - The quests, especially board quests, offer great incentives and goals to pursue, adding depth to the gameplay.

🛠️ Vocations: Diverse and Unique - Having played five vocations, each feels distinctively special. The way attributes carry over to new vocations allows for creating tailored builds, adding a strategic layer to the gameplay.

👗 Gear: Stylish and Functional - The gear choices perfectly balance aesthetics and functionality, always aligning with my playstyle preferences.

👥 Pawn System: Innovative and Social - As a big fan of MMOs, the pawn system fills the gap of playing with friends. Creating a personal pawn and recruiting others (including those made by other players) is brilliant. Their AI is commendably smart, often feeling like real players, which greatly enhances the game's social aspect.

🐉 Monster Combat: Thrilling and Dynamic - The giant monster battles, akin to Monster Hunter, are exhilarating. The climbing mechanic adds an engaging twist to combat.

💬 Final Thoughts: A Favorite Classic - "Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen" ranks as one of my all-time favorite games. Playing it in 2024, it still offers a profound and memorable experience. With "Dragon's Dogma 2" on the horizon, my excitement is through the roof! Kudos to Capcom for this remarkable creation.

This is one of the greatest fantasy RPGs ever made. I've played it a lot more off steam so the hours here don't reflect the amount of time i've played it. This is Elden Ring meets monster hunter - enemies are huge, and you can scale them and climb them to strike at their weak points. 9 different vocations and classes. multiple weapons and armor. Multiple ways to play the game. Sure the plot is meh, and the end game comes too fast, but the real joy in this game is the after-game - the NG cycles and going down the DLC bitter black isle - one of the best designed dungeons that really test your skills. 

This game doesn't hold your hand after the first few levels. The enemies are tough, and if you're under levelled or not using the right tactics, you're going to have a hard time. If your party composition isn't good, you'll get wiped quick. At lower levels, you'll frequently run into enemies that are much stronger than you. But the good thing is, there are multiple ways to resolve things - mostly by running away, or running past, or going at a different time of the day. 

This game is for you if you like Dark Souls, Elden Ring, Skyrim, Baldurs Gate, Monster Hunter.

Have I seriously never written a review for this game?  Let's fix that.  Yes.  I recommend Dragon's Dogma.  For the sake of getting complaints out of the way early yes the game is a bit jank, a little obnoxious and at least slightly janky.  However, none of that really matters.  People remember Skyrim so fondly and I'm like, "Have you played Dragon's Dogma?"  That isn't fair, the two aren't really that much like one another.  But Dragon's Dogma is an action RPG with great character customization, awesome fights and interesting mechanics.  I liked it so much I beat the original and the Dark Arisen version on X360, then bought it on Steam to play again.  It's awesome.

I forgive anyone who doesn't realize this: the game isn't perfect and it fails to tell you a lot of things about it.  But the fact that you can make yourself a four foot tall child or a six foot tall fat person and have that actually reflect in how you perform in combat is amazing.  The goofiness of the pawn system and even their repetitive banter is kind of charming in how stupid it all is.  Plus, you get to grab onto the side of an ogre, climb up to his eye and stab him in the face or maybe coat him in oil and set him on fire.  The game has an excellent immersive and experimental quality to it that extends to the exploration and story.

My biggest complaint about the game is that the default arrows are really weak.  That might sound like a strange "top complaint" to have but in a game with so much variety an interactivity, they didn't trust the player to manage their arrows and have them just do regular damage.  Instead you get infinite regular arrows and they are weak.  The reason this stands out is you can GET special arrows so all the mechanics to "fix" this balance issue were there, it just is what it is.  I mostly add this complaint to show that yeah, when your worst complaint about the game is the arrows aren't as satisfying to use as they could be: you are onto something special.  This was a criminally overlooked game and while I don't know the sequel will do it justice, I would gladly recommend any fan of action RPGs to give this one a shot.

Precisou o segundo jogo ser anunciado pra eu tomar vergonha na cara e vir corrigir o erro. Mesmo adorando, eu fui muito injusto com esse jogo. Ok, ele tem problemas, mas que jogo não tem?

Vou tentar fazer uma lista de prós e contras pra organizar o que gosto e não gosto no jogo, e espero que todos os contras (ou pelo menos 100% deles - requer compreensão de ironia pra fazer sentido) sejam devidamente corrigidos na sequência. Ei, Capcom, dá tempo ainda! E vamos começar de trás pra frente!

Contras:

 - basicamente a história do jogo. Não que eu não goste dela, eu gosto - e bastante -, mas é extremamente claro que ela foi acelerada PRA CARAMBA. Tem muito potencial, muitos fios de trama que poderiam ser melhor explorados, mas tudo é bastante superficial. O final corrige um pouco disso, mas nem de longe faz justiça ao potencial bruto do plot.

 - mundo. Ok, é um mapa relativamente amplo... Mas apenas porque te força a explorar tudo a pé. Tem um sistema de fast travel, mas poxa... Apenas duas cidades? Umas dez dungeons? Sim, eu sei que o jogo é produto de sua época e provavelmente teve um orçamento e janela de desenvolvimento pequenos, mas...

 - inteligência artificial. Olha, às vezes é uma negação quando você precisa de um determinado tipo de suporte dos seus pawns (mais sobre o sistema abaixo) e eles simplesmente não fazem o que é necessário, como encantar sua arma com magia sagrada em meio a um combate contra mortos-vivos.

 - we are (NOT) the Dangan. Poxa, retiraram a música do menu original... Eu gostava tanto dela... =(

Se os contras não te afastaram dessa opinião, os prós provavelmente te farão amar a experiência desse jogo!

Prós:

 - mundo (sim). Ok, sei que achei que poderia ser maior e mais elaborado, mas o mundo é gostoso de explorar, especialmente com a dualidade do sistema de dia e noite. Tem uma quantidade relativamente interessante de segredos e locais que só aparecem se você realmente presta atenção onde está andando.

 - combate. Vamos combinar, o combate desse jogo é maravilhoso, seja você fã de espadas, arcos ou magias. As classes tem habilidades interessantes, poder se agarrar aos inimigos grandes e acertar partes específicas para causar dano localizado, arrancar partes de monstros, causar diferentes tipos de aflições... As batalhas contra dragões então? Acho que tirando Monster Hunter (ora, ora), nunca me diverti tanto enfretando inimigos gigantes em nenhum jogo.

 - quantidade de itens. Falo de tudo, de itens comuns dropados por monstros a equipamentos. Há um senso estético bacana nas composições de armaduras, sejam sets ou combinações que você pode fazer. Outro dia vi um cara com uma couraça no peito usando calça de lona e sapato de pano, pra vocês terem uma noção.

 - sistema "off'nline". O sistema de pawns do jogo é muito bom. Há um senso de camaradagem e cooperação em usar seu pawn principal e mandá-lo pra outras pessoas usarem, ele voltando então com mais experiência do mundo e podendo ajudá-lo de forma ainda mais efetiva.

 - senso geral de diversão. Se o jogo clicar pra você, você vai amar e vai gastar horas na campanha principal... E na sequência, já irá emplacar um New Game+, pois tem coisa legal que abre recomeçando o jogo. E eu nem citei a área da expansão, que comecei a explorar a pouco, mas tem super cara de ser uma mega dungeon de respeito.

Enfim, é um excelente jogo. Se a sequência for 1,5 vezes melhor, teremos a consolidação de uma franquia com potencial de rivalizar os gigantes do segmento. No fim do dia, é um jogo da Capcom, e o que sabemos sobre os jogos da Capcom?

Haven't seen an open world game with worse traversal in my entire life. Fast travel is absurdly limited (and you have little to no access to it in early game). You are forced to walk (not ride mounts, not glide, not even RUN due to stamina, just walk) between locations while constantly encountering trash mobs like goblins and bandits on the way. You'll spend most of the early game walking and fighting goblins/bandits while experiencing an extremely barebones story with no characters. 2 boss fights I've encountered (Hydra and Manticore) also felt terrible to fight compared to games like Monster Hunter (yes, even old as hell MH games have combat that destroys this game). I, for the life of me, can't see why people like this game and can't recommend this game to anyone who's not looking to waste time.

Es un gran juego. Sonidos envolventes y muy buena ambientación. Hay una gran variedad de armas, armadruas, e items.
Existe una buena variedad de habilidades y bastantes clases (como 10), y puedes usarlas a todas, pero no a la vez, sino que puedes ir cambiando a tu personaje de una clase a la otra, e ir mejorando esa clase con los puntos que ganas al subir de nivel.

La creación de tu personaje está bastante compleja, incluso puedes elegir su altura y su voz. No solo puedes crear a tu personaje, sino que tambien creas al compañero que vas a tener durante todo el juego, y luego puedes recrutar 2 compañeros más, los cuales (si los reclutas a travez de internet), serán esos "compañeros" que otros jugadores crearon para ellos mismos, pero que tu tambien puedes reclutarlos si quieres. (Me refiero a que tu te creas tu personaje y tu compañero, y luego por ejemplo, otro jugador puede reclutar a mi compañero para que tambien sea el suyo en su historia, pero eso no significa que yo no pueda usarlo más, obviamente).
Puedes cambiar tus otros 2 compañeros tantas veces como quieras llendo a las piedras de falla que te lo permiten.

Hay una buena variedad de enemigos, y los mapas son muy grandes, asi que te encontraras algunos que se repiten constantemente, pero otros que son "minibosses" que daran una pelea interesante, ya que puedes aprovechar sus puntos debiles (tipo puzzle) para sacarles ventaja e incluso para obtener drops extra de items especiales.

La verdad que es un excelente juego. Una de las cosas malas que he visto, es la IA. Cuando tienes la tarea de escoltar a alguien, (algun npc), si aparecen enemigos, este no dudará en mandarse entre todos los enemigos y dejarse dañar hasta morir, y asi hacerte fallar la mision. Por supuesto, tus compañeros tambien tienen algunos problemas de IA. Me he visto en el caso de yo estar bajando con cuidado por algun lugar, y que mis compañeros se caigan y se hagan mierda contra el suelo por no haber bajado bien. (Tambien me he visto en el caso positivo en el que cuando uno de mis compañeros cae, otro de mis compañeros lo alza en los brazos y me lo acerca para que lo pueda curar sin tener que acercarme a los enemigos. Esto en el caso de que el enemigo sea un BOSS, es sumamente util y la verdad es genial. Tambien me ha pasado de tener que hacer tareas de "llevar cosas de un lugar a otro", pero llevarlas en mis manos, no en el inventario. Y en estos casos mis compañeros agarran esas cosas y me ayudan a llevarlas... Tambien esta genial esto).

Tus compañeros pueden obtener informacion y conocimientos sobre mounstruos para poder aprovechar automaticamente sus puntos debiles, y poder utilizar habilidades que sean efectivas contra ellos. Esta experiencia la ganas haciendoles leer rollos que contengan informacion sobre dichos mounstruos, o luchando contra los mounstruos y probando distintas habildiades que demuestren ser efectivas, o inefectivas. Tu compañero mencionará algo como, "he aprendido una nueva forma de pelear contra los de su tipo", cuando aprenda algo nuevo sobre el enemigo.

Otra cosa que no me ha gustado, ha sido el hecho de que ciertas habilidades que solo puedes usar si tienes cierta clase, (como aseisino o strider por ejemplo), tambien estan limitadas por arma, y esto no tiene sentido. Me explico... Si tu te pones la clase asesino, y te equipas una espada, no puedes usar la habilidad de esta clase para rodar, ni para tenr un doble salto. Solo puedes hacerlo si te equipas con dagas, pero por que?... Sigues siendo la misma clase, por que se limita solo a dagas?, joder.

Otra cosa muy tediosa de la IA, es que hay muchos poderes enemigos que aplican estados irreversibles, (basicamente que oneshootean, osea, que matan de 1 solo golpe). Como pueden imaginarse cuando digo "problema de IA", me refiero a que tus compañeros literalmente (estoy muy seguro) apropósito se quedan quietos mientras el enemigo prepara la habilidad y se las mete de lleno una y otra y otra y otra y otra vez. He tenido que reiniciar la misma parte unas 50 veces porque los retrasados de mierda de mis compañeros se quedaban quietos dentro del area del poder mientras yo salia y al verlos decía, "salgan de ahi, salgan de ahi!", y utilizaba F2 que es el boton para decirles que vengan conmigo. Sin embargo ignoraban completamente lo que les decia, y morian constantemente una y otra vez. (Completamente tedioso y cansino).

Por último antes de resumir mi opinión, debo remarcar que la historia es muy muy mala. Practicamente no hay personajes importantes, y si los hay aparecen tan rapido como se van y no vuelven a aparecer nunca más. El malo incluido. Además, nunca tienes la oportunidad de vengarte de un npc al que estoy seguro de que muchos odiaron... Que te hace quedar como traidor ante toda una ciudad luego de haberlos salvados, y tras esto los vuelves a salvar y termina el juego sin que cambie nada. (Horrible historia, pésima).

En fin. Juego recomendado si ignoras todo lo referente a la historia y no buscas personajes importantes, falla muchisimo en la IA y se pone tremendamente tedioso cuando sucede, lo cual le quita mucha gracia y diversion al juego. Le daria una nota desaprobatoria si no fuera porque realmente el apartado rpg es muy disfrutable. 7/10

[h1] A well grounded classic game [/h1]

[h3] Summary [/h3]
An older game with some questionable UI and lack of keybindings for some things; however not a deal breaker for me. A well grounded story with side stories to go with it. The map is large and I even left quite a bit unexplored. The graphics, honestly, for me still stand out pretty well; has a charm to it, playing it nowadays. The voice acting from the dragon is amazing, side characters are sometimes comical. It's really hard not to enjoy this game. There's so much content to be explored even after you "finish" the game the first time. Has a lot of value and replay-ability. I especially like the fact you can change your vocations (mage, fighter etc) forever, whenever.

[h3] To note: [/h3]
I played this game on and off quite a few times. It was hard for me to get into it, but i really wanted to "finish" it before DD2. [u] So, I haven't done a different ending (if there is one(i'd assume there's "2" endings)), nor experienced BBI, nor new game+ [/u]. However, upon finishing the game, I believe I'll go back. There's more lore from side quests and from exploring the world in general; so I'd want to take my time. I will say, that as much as I rushed it, one fault of this game is; the level of enemies when you progress through the main story are, for lack of a better word, comically weak. Like, you've put their HP to 0 but they still have really important things to say before they die so they keep attacking until they've finished their monologue. Regardless, this game has a lot going for it, even as an older game. 

Something to be experienced if you're a fan of the RPG and open world genre.

Ah yes, Dragon Dogma or what I like to call it. Monster Hunter: RPG Edition. Makes sense, given this game was a precursor to what Monster Hunter World would become.  

Wanted to relive the good ol early ps3 days by 100% this rough jewel again but for Steam and by god is it as corny and cheesy as I remembered. Oh how I miss hearing Into Free ~Dangan~ theme during the start of the game, utter shame most missed out on hearing it in the Dark Arisen version.

At the time, this was a very ambitious game that experimented with a lot of new things that was never done in the industry before. Some would argue it was a mix bag though, between the story, conflicting plot points (shameless stolen plot points taken out of Berserk, I might add), wonky brain dead A.I and repetitive/boring fetch quests but the more you played it, the more you'll understand it all blends into a experience that most 3rd person action-dugeon crawling games could never give. There was a time when everyone unanimously hated the repetitive pawn dialogue but even looking back on that, it was truly a unique way of having the NPC interact/react to the environments around you and though those interaction gained knowledge that helped you learned the weaknesses of the enemy, even shortcuts when dealing with various quests. To this day, I still consider the dugeon crawling aspect of Dark Arisen to be the best out of any 3rd person action RPG I've ever played. Truly felt like it took a page out of DND but with a grimdark tone to the atmosphere. Literally the best part of the game that'll have you spend most of your playtime on. 

Sadly, due to the outright brutal nature of the DLC, it's highly recommend you attempt doing it till after you're well into the 2nd play-though and because of this, through the misconception of it being "artificially-difficult", most people never got the full experience of Dark Arisen. However, despite all of Dragon Dogma janky flaws, dragon dogma has earned its right to being a cult classic for standing out and doing something that was not only different but was actually fun experiencing to the end.

Remember. Let the wind push you free and always kick the Ox!

Dragons Dogma: Dark Arisen is, a fantasy role playing game, in which the player is encouraged to level up a character alongside their own (a Pawn), and build a combat team no bigger than four (the player, the players Pawn, and up to two other players Pawns), and then traverse the countryside slaying monsters of various sizes on a quest to slay a specific Dragon. The player has three classes available to them at the start, and a further six classes (three 'hybrid' classes and three 'advanced' classes) once sufficient gameplay progress is attained. The players pawn can be any of the starter or advanced classes as well, and building a synergistic party is an evolving challenge. Seeking to complete the campaign and all side quests should take no less than 80 hours for a first run, and that's assuming you don't get lost exploring the width and breadth of the land. Without saying too much, the end game leads to a New Game Plus system for as long as a player wants to pursue it, with the additional options to play in a Hard mode or a Speedrun mode.

If any of that sounds good at all, do yourself a favor and pick this game up. I'm probably going to keep playing this until the sequel comes out! :D

An intriguing ARPG widely regarded as one of the all-time greats, playing it 12 years after its initial release proves to be a bit challenging, as many aspects of the game haven't aged gracefully. At the forefront of Dragon's Dogma is the classic, muddy, saturated grey color palette synonymous with games from the early 2010s. The art style fails to alleviate the drab aesthetic, with everything and everyone (except for a few well-designed monsters) appearing awkward, as if stuck in an uncanny valley state—surprised-looking and robotic in their movements.

Nevertheless, the world and scenery are well-designed, despite being somewhat empty. The writing and dialogue present a mix of strangeness, oddity, and forgettable moments. Each scene feels as if directed by David Lynch (perhaps excusable given it's a Capcom game). The overarching story lacks cohesion, offering an unending list of barely connected tasks until, near the end, a plot is somewhat revealed and abruptly concluded.

The game is plagued by numerous odd design decisions related to inventory management, encumbrance affecting travel speed, extremely limited fast travel, and companion control, among other issues. Despite these drawbacks, a few unique and potentially genre-defining aspects, such as satisfying character development, engaging combat (featuring an interesting but occasionally janky monster climbing system), and the pawn system, redeem the overall experience.

Despite its many negatives, Dragon's Dogma exudes a certain charm—a mishmash of exceptional ideas that, with more development time, could have resulted in a timeless experience. In 2012, it was likely something very unique, but in 2024, I would recommend playing it only if you're interested in experiencing an awkward but charming piece of gaming history.

Despite being an older game that had a troubled development process resulting in a lot of cut/unfinished content, the core experience is still extremely engaging.

Combat is chunky and satisfying, and the gimmick of being able to grab, carry, and climb on monsters helps enforce the sense of freedom the developers want you to feel in their grounded, medieval sandbox world.

The Pawn system really did make me feel as though I was adventuring with a group.
Pawns have knowledge to share about quests, areas of the world, and how to fight specific monsters, and it's amazing seeing them use this knowledge in the middle of a fight.

If you want to play this game for 50+ hours you do need to invest in the New Game+ mode and the grindy post-game Everfall and Bitterblack Isle areas, but experimenting with the different vocations and playstyles can give you many hours of fun after the campaign.

Overall I highly recommend this game, the Pawn system provides something truly unique you can't find in other games, and I'm looking forward to the next iteration this year with Dragon's Dogma 2!

The most solid thing here is the game-play which is to this day is one of the best ARPG combat systems ever and few games have ever came close. The game itself is surprisingly deep in game mechanics, anyone who likes ARPGs should give it a try!

I played this game so you don't have to. 

Parts of the combat are fun, but it's pretty clunky and not very well balanced. My experience was that the game started at very hard, then went to really easy after getting the first round of good gear, to boring because eventually enemies had so much health. I ended up dropping it at the final boss because it has literally 10 health bars and limited damage opportunities, but also is pretty easy to dodge. It's a bad sign when I find myself going "I'm bored, can this be over now?" after about 30 minutes in the final climactic fight.

The story and characters are fairly bare bones. There were some good ideas in general with the lore and certain events, but it didn't come together for me. I guess I didn't finish it, but if a story hasn't hooked me in tens of hours, maybe there's just not much there.

Maybe this game will land better for you than it did for me. Unless you really think you'll like this type of game though, I recommend giving this one a pass.

Edit: So I beat the game. I gave in and decided to use the wiki and learned that the damage formula is apparently "damage - enemy defense" so if you do 210 damage to an enemy with 200 defense, the result will only be 10 hp removed. If you increase your damage by a trivial amount, it actually can multiply what you do the enemy. With upgrading my weapon to have about 4% more total power, and learning of a spell that knocks 1.5 bars off the boss HP, the final boss was trivial. Could I have figured this out with only in game knowledge? Probably not.

There's a kind of cool area that opens up at the end of the game, or more a kind of cool hub with a bunch of generic temple tunnels full of the same enemies you've been fighting the whole time (but with more defense, of course). I spent a bit more time exploring this, but my opinion on the game hasn't changed. I've played quite a few hours, but only a few had me going "this is awesome!" and the rest were just hoping that would happen again.

A fantastic game that still holds up in 2023/2024. 

The story is not much to go off of, but the game play is phenomenal. You get 3 vocations to pick from at the start with 9 in total, you can swap vocations once you get to the capital which is about 8 hours in casually and 2 if you rush. Character creator is what you would expect for a 2011 release title, but you can turn yourself into Leon from Resident Evil, which is pretty cool. I am not a big fan of the party system in this game, but it is not terrible. You create 1 party member (called Pawns) and the other 2 you need to constantly replace for some other random Pawns that you recruit. The random Pawns do not increase in level while they are in your party which is why you need to replace them. Though you can spend in-game currency to recruit pawns of a higher level. The skill and combat system is a ton of fun, I enjoyed playing a Mystic Warrior with the holy enhancement and Magic Cannon combo, where I converted my damage to holy and shot magic bolts from a magic source that is placed on the ground (floating at chest height) so myself or pawns can smack it to shoot bolts at an enemy for a ranged attack.

Really good game, highly recommend it.

dragon's dogma: dark arisen is an hack & slash action-rpg developed and published by capcom. it first released on xbox 360 and ps3 in may 2012, with the dark arisen expansion releasing the following year, about eleven months later in april 2013. we then got ports of the full definitive game released on pc in 2016, ps4/xbox one in 2017, and nintendo switch in 2019. it is set in an open-world environment played from a third person perspective. the visual spectacle is impressive, as the art design seamlessly blends medieval fantasy with dark undertones, creating a world that feels both enchanting and mysterious at the same time. the diverse landscapes, from lush forests to desolate dungeons, showcase the developers' attention to detail. while the graphics may not rival the latest AAA titles, the art style compensates, providing a timeless and visually engaging experience.

the narrative is a tale of epic proportions, rich in lore and intrigue. as a 100% completionist, i relished every little piece of lore scattered throughout the game that i could find. the main story, though occasionally predictable, unfolds with enough twists and turns to keep players invested. i enjoyed how the lore extends beyond the main plot as well, encouraging exploration and discovery of the setting's deep history and mythical creatures. the game also excels in character development offering a wide array of classes and skills. the vocation system allows for versatile builds catering to different play styles. the pawn system additionally adds depth to the entire experience as you can experiment with different combinations of classes and skills, which honestly becomes a highlight of each playthrough, also contributing to the gameplay's replay value. 

the combat system is honestly pretty intricate and rewards skill and strategy alike. the weight and impact of each attack/ability feels realistic, enhancing the immersion. big boss battles against colossal creatures, such as literal dragons, are a true test of one's combat prowess. the pawn AI, while occasionally imperfect, generally provides competent support throughout the entirety of a battle, especially when tailored to complement your character's abilities. 

the game is filled to the brim with quests, both major story quests and side quests/minor content, offering a plethora of content, but especially so for completionists like myself. from escort missions to monster hunting, each quest feels uniquely crafted while also being able to provide a variety of challenges. exploring every nook and cranny of world is not just rewarding like i mentioned earlier, but it is essential for those seeking 100% completion.

dragon's dogma: dark arisen is a testament to the brilliance of action RPGs. my journey through completion was a fulfilling odyssey filled with memorable encounters and awe-inspiring moments. the combination of deep lore, versatile character customization, and challenging quests ensures that every character/playthrough feels fresh and unique. while not without minor flaws, this is still considered by most to be a masterpiece in the genre, and a must-play for any RPG enthusiast. i find it a bit overrated but still think it's a solid seven or seven and a half out of ten.

Review Updated:

Warning: Capcom is adding unfamiliar DRM to their back catalogue of games. This corp has repeatedly shown their stance towards mods in their games as well and seem to be taking action. I would caution you against purchasing any capcom product that contains this DRM as it’s unfamiliar, and untrustworthy. For now, if you really want this game, or any capcom game, I would stress that you watch and observe to see what happens in the near-ish future. 

Please note that there is a lot of misinfo circulating about with regards to this situation. Please do your due diligence and research everything and even fact check myself before making a final judgement. I am doing the best I can to sift through the false info and properly inform myself and will update this review accordingly.

DRM is not always a bad thing, if used correctly, it protects initial sales. Then good publishers will remove it later on allowing for better experiences. I am upset when DRM harms performance, which it often does (like Jedi Survivor). I find that inexcusable, poor performance that screws over the paying customer should always be frowned upon. Recently, denuvo was removed from RE8, which is good. But, when it was first added the game suffered many problems which modders had to remedy until its removal. Enigma seems to be capcom’s replacement for denuvo.

Earlier this month, RE Rev was updated and performance was harmed. Shortly after, capcom reversed the update. This is concerning because REV was released almost 11 years ago and the game’s already been cracked (both the pc and 3ds version), as with most older games. This update to add DRM to an old game is incredibly fishy, especially with how it came with no announcement from the publishers themselves. Almost as if somebody was trying to hide it.
Denuvo a very good DRM, since there’s few who know how to crack it, even then it’s tough. Denuvo itself costs ~$5,000 per month for the license, ~$60,000 a year. A game’s sales can’t keep up with the fee forever, and the DRM has to be removed/replaced to salvage income. 

Enigma is $59,920 cheaper. It costs about $400 for initial purchase, and $80 annually for upkeep. Enigma was checked with a virus scanner, and got 34 positive flags, ~%50 of what Virus Total checks for. Scanners can have false positives. The REV .exe will show 1 positive flag (at least for me). This one is easily written off as a false positive. Generally low single digits are fine. When you are getting into double digits, there’s problem. The dev for Enigma has been purported to have a fake address in the US, and the domain name’s been alleged to be bought through a Moscow front (fact check me). This DRM is incredibly sneaky, and according to others, is capable of quietly worming its way through your PC. These factors, even if partially false, are concerning, keep this away from your pc.

On October 25 of 2023, there was a capcom R&D presentation.
“RE:2023 Anti-cheat and Anti-Piracy Measures in PC Games Recommendations for In-House Production”
14:00 – 16:00 ish. The pres states that all mods, unless officially supported, are no different than cheating. Yes, with regards to DRM, all foreign code is considered tampering. But, they go further, and say that mods tarnish the product’s (and corp’s) image as they may be mistaken for legitimate parts of said product. Earlier last July, a tournament competitor in a SF6 match forgot to disable his Chun-Li n*de mod. This is likely what capcom is referencing. But, they’ve taken things further.

Capcom is no newb to “nuking” youtube creators’ channels. They’ve removed content and channels for discussing info that the corp themselves leaked. Capcom has taken action against MH creators, most notably speedrunners. This was because their videos featured mods, some as harmless as to simply aid with running or slightly modify the experience (skins/costumes/fov). Capcom has tried to take down modders’ work as well. Yes, these modders were making n*de mods, but never the less they came after a modder, who’s to stop them from taking things further and coming for everyone else?

Considering the corp’s past and recent actions and statements, it’s safe to say that they are/will be coming after modders. People like to add that Enigma was added to RE5 last year and that no one has had any problems. Even so, ghost updates are sketchy, since there’s no point in copy protecting a long-cracked game. For now, I advise customers to watch, listen, and wait to see what the corp does. We can choose to make it apparent to them that mods are an inevitable factor of PC gaming. I know where my stance is, if I can’t use a pawn editor, then I’ll happily take my money elsewhere.

Thank you if you read this far, I’d be happy if you had any info (legit that is) or comments you’d like to share.

Warning: Pseudo-rant ahead
I have one more speculation (not an allegation or accusation, simply a theory coming straight outa my rear end). I think that modders are beginning to pose a business threat to companies like capcom. 

This corp is known to have a lot of stinker dlcs.
Example:
REV has dlc, 2 fun characters, and 4 more that suck. There’s 2 shoddy weapon reskins and 2 parts packs that boost damage. All of these things are already in the purchased game. This leads to my theory, capcom is scared of modders. We can simply repaint the base G18 and make it look like jessica’s, and have a better gun too. The same goes for parker’s gun dlc. Whip out CE and give yourself the gun parts. For one customer, the corp has lost out of possibly $4. Apply that to a large portion of the consumer base, even more money lost out.

Another, Street Fighter 6. Its dlc has one year character pass costs $30. You get 4 characters..and character colors. Not outfits, colors; and in game currency…which you can earn for free. The same goes for the $50 ultimate dlc, it just adds 2 backgrounds (stages) and some costume colors with a little extra in game currency. You can get so much more for this amount, just look at the steam reviews.

We also see modders making far better outfits for free. The recent Yor update was bad too, just a worthless reskin. So, modders will fix it and make it look better. Both of these scenarios DO harm the their image, it just shows that some dudes in blender can do so much better than a multi-billion dollar corp. 

Their claims about “public order”, I believe, are total bs. I believe this corp recognizes that it churns out dumpster fire (ignoring the rare cases like Separate Ways, which is only $10) and are too afraid to admit that they want money. At least EA is obvious abt it.

The same goes for so many other capcom dlcs.

I love these games, I am a big fan of RE, DD, MH and more. Yes, your writers often suck, but I still love the stories in these games. I love to play them, I have so many happy memories of these wonderful little gems from my childhood. I WANT to support the talented, skillful, and passionate people behind these pieces of digital-art. No not the suits, I mean the programmers, artists, musicians, voice actors, mocap dudes, sound guys etc. But, unfortunately, these people work for a corp who is rapidly growing greedier, and at a scary pace. Soon, they’ll be just another EA, a money vacuum that cares about microtransactions more than making a great experience that keeps people comin back to that game and for more in the future.

Whoever is currently in charge (in my opinion) is out of touch with what customers actually want and will support. I have blacklisted this corp from my steam page, and it will be sometime, if ever, I consider purchasing their products ever again given their recent statements, actions, practices, and routine behavior. 

End of Review.

Thoroughly impressive combat system with customization. Many ARPGs these days are "soulslikes," or barely teeter on the edge of being an RPG, dipping 1 foot into a more action adventure or hack and slash combat system; (Like with what final fantasy has become). Dragon's Dogma creates its own fresh system of combat and customization with impressive user experience to boot. 

My only cons are the early game which was a slow trek to get through, and the overall game is pretty short with a small open world. Eventually as the game picks up and you get familiarized with how build-making (Vocations) and combat works and how much customization you can truly have with your character and combat style, its pretty impressive and satisfying. Also I appreciate the focus on limb-destruction when it comes to boss fights. The goal of fights isn't to dodge and deal DPS or tank through attacks like we see in so many RPGs, but to destroy limbs and other aspects of the boss, proceed to stagger it, then DPS race. 

The Pawn system is incredible as well, a system that Square Enix has been trying to nail down with their AI-controlled party for a while, but just hasn't seemed to find their footing. Dragon's Dogma nailed it. I'm excited to see what Quality of Life improvements Dragon's Dogma 2 will have

The dialogue and story is interesting at times, but nothing revolutionary. I appreciate that Capcom went with a more mature tone. You can see how Capcom really focused more so on emulating western RPGs like Skyrim with the quest freedom and design direction, rather than a light-hearted JRPG direction.

Overall 7.5/10 for me

[h1] 100% Review [/h1]

Pretty epic action rpg, if you still like games from a decade ago this ones still good. 
Retroactively this should get game of the year 2012, now way TWD got it, absolutely robbed by a mobile game... 
This game is better than Skyrim for sure. 

[h2] Should you play it before Dragon's Dogma 2? [/h2]

The 100% is quite a grind, if you are interested in catching up for the new game I would certainly recommend doing an easy mode play-through. I ran my first save on normal for 20 levels before resetting to hard mode.
In doing so I experienced much hardship and CBT but still had fun. 
This is a game that likely will require you to do your own research to figure out. 
Some of the systems are confusing at first and a lot of the quests can be missed very easily if you don't have a guide to follow. 
If you go in with these expectations it should be fun. 

[h2] Open-World Aspects: [/h2]

The traversal can be a slow process, when you are low level you have very little stamina. But if you hang in there you get access to this cool custom fast travel points system in port-crystals. These can be placed almost anywhere in the world so you can quickly get back from anywhere in the map. As you slowly collect more and more of these your speed in completing quests increases. With some smart placements of your port-crystals you can later speed-run the game in the speed-run mode and its pretty cool to see the progress you made in action. 
The day and night cycle when you are travelling in the early game feels very quick, you can set off in the morning and still be battling through the night to get into some sections. Get used to using your lamp because the game is pretty dark, probably the lack of a moon. 

[h2] The Level System: [/h2]

They have a class system called Vocations, I ran the ranged class for the entirety of the game.
They have access to different item pools and skills, but interestingly you can equip some skills from other vocations when you unlock them. It is recommenced you level up as warrior for their skill of taking less physical damage, do this at the start of the game for a slightly easier time. 
I found this system to be very fun and engaging, swapping my vocation when I maxed it out until i settled on the ranger. 
Depending on what vocation you are when you level up your base stats will level accordingly, so maybe keep that in mind for what your end game build might be. 

[h2] The Bosses: [/h2]

This game has some very cool boss designs, namely the chimera and the Ur-Dragon. 
It also has a cool system where you can jump up and climb all over these massive boss monsters to deal damage in the way of a prison style shank. 
The camera can go a bit wild when you are climbing on monsters but it's still pretty fun. 
The golem and the metal wearing ogres can go on my shit list tho. 
Side note, never do I want to see a flying enemy ever again. Any devs listening, putting small flying type enemies that exist just to stay out of your cross-hairs and to knock you down mid attack is a sin and you will be going to hell for it. Quite frankly its too late to repent. 

[h2] Customisation: [/h2]

In this game when you are creating your character your physical attributes actually matter somewhat. 
The bigger and bulkier you are the more you can carry and the less able you are to be knocked over. So if you are more interested in having a fashionable experience, your carry weight will suffer for it. Which can be kind of annoying but its still cool. 
I found the customisation to be better than some games that came out in the last few years even. 
They have some cool weapons and outfits in the game and if you are stubborn enough everything is viable. 
I beat the game in hard-mode with hardly any useful gear on, only for it to then become dragon forged and still not that great. But hey, it works. 

[h2] Quality of Life: [/h2]

If you are playing this game for the first time on hard-mode then this game does not hold your hand and you will be relentlessly beat into the ground until you learn your lesson. Save early and save often. 
When I was first playing the game with the 2x xp bow (terrible damage btw) I thought the bosses had too much health (they do) and the only balance was to buy 50 throwblasts and use those instead (this is a semi viable way to complete the game) and I wasn't entirely wrong. 
When you first run into bosses they often have a ton of health and in the late game it really feels like the devs are trying my patience. To me there are only two ways you can fight a boss, you are either way under-leveled or way over-leveled. I never felt to be in the right zone for fighting the bosses, even when I was following a guide to do 100% of the main/side quests. But again, I was using one of the worst bows for damage and had not yet discovered the thrills of blast arrows. 
Of all the bosses, offline Ur-Dragon felt like a battle of epic proportion. Well for the first two run throughs then I was resigned to waging the endless war until I could finally get the achievement. (note I was only around level 100 for this and should really have waited to level max.) 

[h2] The Story: [/h2] 

I like the story, the intro cut-scene and playing through the tutorial is all good stuff. 
It has an overarching story that is similarly meta like Dark Souls but is different enough to feel unique. 
If you like cyclical stories about the struggles of mankind then this is one for you. 

[h2] The Endings: [/h2]

For starters this game is very kind in that they allow you to watch the dark endings without having the game complete and make you do it all again, they simply reset you to before the choice is made. 10/10 does not waste your time, the devs know what the gamers want when they did this one. Unlike some recent games that make you sit through the same long winded cut-scenes you just watched to arrive at a not entirely different result. Another cool thing is that because the story is cyclical, you can see other characters who are at different points in their own story having once been chosen like you were.

[h2] The Achievements: [/h2]

I managed to 100% the game in under 100 hours. 
Playing through on hard-mode to begin with was definitely the culprit of many added hours but I have no regrets. If you are looking to 100% this game I will tell you it is very achievable, follow a guide for quests, build a strong vocation.  Good luck have fun. 

[h2] DLC: [/h2]

With very few useful guides for the DLC existing online that I could find, it was troublesome to figure out on my own. Everything is super strong so you really need to be high-leveled in order to tackle it. I had no chance at beating the final boss until I switched to easy mode on my second playthrough and level maxed, even then I had to take in hundreds of blast arrows and strength buffs. So good luck I guess. 

[h2] Crashes and Bugs: [/h2]

I had 3 or so times where I alt-tabbed and came back to a black screen and the program not responding, causing me to restart the computer because even task manager didn't know what to do. I had maybe one hard crash but for the most part it was fine, no actual performance issues. 

[h2] Conclusion: [/h2]

If you are at all interested then it is definitely worth a play-through, I believe it still holds up and is a lot of fun. 
Thanks for reading!

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

This title came to me upon its release many years ago on console. It was, very different from what I've been used to and the lack of hand holding in understanding the world, lore and history, including some quests was at the time quite frustrating. However, I would pick it up again on PC years later for the memorable impression it left on me. Dragons Dogma is a title where the action of playing the game outweighs its story elements. Once I committed to beating the game, I found it to be somewhat simple and straightforward. Now in New Game+ and with the expansion under my belt I feel like I have a solid grasp on Dragons Dogma. 

The story is entertaining for me up until a particular point where it becomes very philosophical and begins tackling a lot in a short amount of time. Trying to understand most of the integral pillars of the story is only possible via reading and paying extra attention to details that do not posit themselves along the main path of the campaign. Admittedly, I took to the web after my initial completion of the game to try and understand what I just went through. After some reading, I understood the message even if it wasn't very moving or interesting, personally.  
Dragons Dogma has a number of interesting mechanics and some solid gameplay. That is what brought me back to want to play it unto completion. The story however, is quite complicated beyond the initial slay the dragon and save the world bit, which might appeal to some audiences but I found it to be jamming far too much into far too little of a space. 

I am excited for the second installment to see how they build upon the excellent combat and character handling details, especially the pawn system which is quite unique. If I had one tidbit that I wish they would have improved upon it would be the "romance" system. A nearly hidden mechanic that serves very little to no true purpose in the game aside from cutscene differences. Do away with it and the game does not change at all. I've enjoyed romance options in games since Harvest Moon on the PS1 and Dragons Dogma's idea for having significant others for you to interact with is, well, it's weird. Have them join you for quests at the very least.

I tell people this game is like a soft souls game mixed with Monster Hunter. You will enjoy the combat / magic system that is on offer here but as far as story and extra curricular activities go be prepared for mystery and a lot of grinding in order to access the games most difficult challenges.

I've played this game about two years ago, and all this time I've never seen a more unique and combat-packed RPG. The story holds a traditional, dragon-slaying medieval outlook mixed with magic and mixes it into something legendary. Sure, the storyline's short summary-wise, but with the amount of side-quests they added that can change it's outcome at every turn, it makes all the more enjoyable. The Dark Arisen expansion was a great touch and just made the game more interesting. Lock all of that with the new-game-plus and the online interactions, and you rarely get bored. I rate it a mind-blowing 11/10. Will never regret it taking up that one year of my life.
Edit: Capcom has been stealthy adding garbage DRM to new and old games that slows them and has kernel-level access. It is an incredibly scummy move and should not be tolerated as a community. Update:
I decided to revisit this game after seeing some YouTubers review it and hearing about a long-awaited sequel on the horizon.  After actually finishing the game this time, most of my original frustrations with it are still relevant.  I found the story became intriguing way too far into the game.  Overall I feel this game had a lot of neat ideas that were simply presented poorly or half-finished.  Here's hoping the sequel has better AI and storytelling.

Original Review:
This game emphasizes the importance of team building with AI characters but the system is terrible. They constantly get in the way and your only commands to give are "go" "help" and "come". They will run ahead of you and when in tight corridors or dungeons, having a full party of 4 makes navigation a nightmare. There are no options for things like follow distance, aggressiveness, or any tactics whatsoever. 

Another annoyance is how enemies will simply spawn out of nowhere. There are animations for enemies like zombies crawling out of the ground and portals appearing before the enemy does but I have watched too many wolves and goblins just appear instantaneously. Also the ability to climb on large monsters to target specific body parts is ruined by removing your camera control. You are giving control to the monster when you do this, and boy do they like flail about... I don't even bother with this mechanic unless absolutely nothing else works. 

The game does get a few things right though. The combat system and vocation system are very fun. You don't have to worry about being stuck to 1 class in this game. The game world is also enjoyable to explore and the limited fast travelling really makes going beyond city walls feel like a true adventure. 

At this point I am unsure whether or not I should stick with this game to finish the story. It is just too frustrating to deal with dumb AI teammates and enemies that spawn out of thin air. It is becoming less and less fun as I go on.

[h1][b]Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen[/b][/h1]

[b]Rating: 6/10 - Fine[/b]

This game is the skeleton of something [b]Great[/b] or maybe even [b]Amazing[/b]. Combat is fun and smooth. There are ton of skills and multiple interesting classes (vocations) to play as. I also really like the idea behind the pawn system although the ai felt a little janky at times. The story isn't really the best but I don't think it suffers from being a bad story, more from the fact that it's not told in the best way it could have possibly been told. My major problems with the game are how janky maneuvering through the menus can be and how dull some of the open world looks. Exploration is a huge part of the game but, in my opinion, it just wasn't that interesting to look at this world. There also should have been more dungeons in the game as they were some of the best parts of the entire game.

Overall this game could've been great and playing it made me really excited for the sequel.

End-game UPD.
So if you're like me, and you've never played this game and wanted to check it after the hype about the second game - don't bother. There is almost nothing good about it. It is more like tech-demo with a couple novel ideas, then an actual game.
Story is almost non-existent. Most of the quests are farm 30 something and escort missions. There are like 5 quests that developed a story, including the very first and the very last encounters with the dragon.
Everything is very repetative. It is like whole game is Elden Ring's copypaste dungeons and nothing more. They reused sevearal dungeon layouts again and again. Same with bosses - there are very few unique ones and you encounter different variations of them again and again.
Bosses aren't too interesting either, very easy patterns, no need to learn anything. They are mostly a stat-check. Espetially considering that you may insta heal from inventory, opening which pauses the game. But if you don't have good stats, you may waste like half an hour spoon killing one boss.
Pawn system is the unique feature of the game. At any point you can hire 3 npcs (pawns) to fiollow you. One you create yourself, and two others - are copies of the ones that other players created. They are nice dummies to distract enemies, but you can't really control them. Just three commands: go, come, help - whatever they mean. So during the easier stages they doesn't matter, it is easy anyway. And in the harder stages of the game they are kind of useless, because the only reliable thing they do is die.
Big spectacular spells is probably the other thing that enjoyers would praise about the game. But how do you cast one? Well, you press a button and wait while it channels. Sometimes for like 10 seconds. And if you get disrupted, ot you had to cancel it to move away from void-zone, well then nothing happens and you have to channel again. Isn't that fun? 

So don't believe enjoyer's propaganda, don't waste your time on this one, and be very cautious about the second game. Wait for reviews, watch gameplay videos. If it will be as clunky as this one then it will be just another boring open world grind fest.

[h1] Dragon's Dogma in 2024. Is it worth playing before the Sequel? [/h1]

Dragon's Dogma, a 2012 hack-and-slash title made by Capcom, definitely takes time to get used to. It tries to guide you with the missions, but the result of that is often mixed, especially if you don't listen to the quest givers properly.

You might need to give the game about 6-10 hours to sink in. Some people say that this game is a walking simulator, and I can agree with them. You are going to visit point A, go to point B and back to point A just to exchange a few dialogues; this happens often and feels like an inspiration taken from Bethesda titles like Skyrim. So expect a lot of sprinting! It can get annoying at times, especially at the beginning. But after a while, with fast travel, you'll be able to travel quickly.

The combat will feel clunky at the start; wait until you get vocations – they make the combat really fun, and the gameplay smooth. Recruiting Pawns with different classes, watching them fight beside you, has its own joy. For different sets of enemies, you'll have to recruit Pawns with different classes who can help you with a certain enemy type; this will be helpful if you want to choose Hard mode in the game. As a new player, you'll find the enemy types and boss designs to be really cool. You don't have to worry much about having a proper build for your pawns and yourself if you play the game on normal difficulty; you'll have lots of fun.

The story is pretty interesting. However, I think that it might not be for everyone; some bits and parts of the game will feel unnecessary, unworthy of your time, and boring. For me, it's been a fun experience; the story intrigued me especially the end of game. It's just the side quests that can be a pain. You might not be able to figure out and get stuck with them and end up looking for a solution on the internet, only to find out that it's glitched or that you missed a very minor detail. I suggest that you listen to the quest givers carefully as well as your Pawns as they try to guide you almost every single time. 

Apart from some of the mildly infuriating side quests, lots and lots of running; the game is solid, even for 2024. I strongly recommend that you use an ultimate sprinting mod, a mod named "Don't Blind Me," and a vanilla ENB preset, or any of the ENB presets that you can find on Nexus. With these small adjustments, you can have more fun playing this 2012 title over Starfield.

This game was my childhood. Obviously by now, the graphics don't hold a candle to more modern games, but it is more than made up for with the game's well-developed combat system. from monster and follower AI's to the myriad of physical and magic weapon skills one has at their disposal. It is truly an A-tier game, and I look forward to seeing how Dragons Dogma 2 compares after its release.

I don't even have a formal review, all I can say is "How have I never heard of this game before?".

You can literally climb onto giant monsters, slicing into their: eyes, face, arms, wings, legs or nether-region and sometimes doing this is the only way to get to a weakpoint.

You can also grab and carry, just about anything, which makes those goblins you just killed into deadly throwing weapons; or just carrry an explosive barrel everywhere and lob it at anything you want dead.

The AI companions are surprisingly useful, actually gathering and scavenging resources without command. I can't emphasise how many times I've needed a crafting material, only to realise that one of my companions scavenged it themselves.

The companions also come with really cool stats, that allow different ones to help with quests or guide you around unknown lands, hell they might even know the weakness to that troublesome boss you're stuck on. Since the hired companions don't level up alongside you, it means constantly re-evaluating your team is needed for success. (My only complaint is that they don't shut up, but tbh that's all video game companions)


The way you build characters is great. You have to change and master multiple classes to get your perfect build, using their augments (equip-able buffs) to make your character fit your playstyle. 

If you've never played this game before, give it a try; and hey if you like it you only have to wait a short time for the second game to come out which is a bonus.

This game is seriously fun. Keep in mind that this game was first released in the 2012. With the 'Remaster' (Dark Arisen) release in 2016.

I'll help temper your expectations when you read my review. Graphically, it will look similar to RPG games of the time. The game world will also feel the same of the RPG games of the time (Example: Skyrim).

What sets this game apart is the innovative combination of RPG elements and action combat elements. You could spend 12 hours as a swashbuckling tanker, then the next 12 you might feel like playing as a supreme mage raining fireballs. At first glance, players may not notice, but this game has part damage (if the intro battle didn't explain already).

As such, you could play as an archer and snipe cyclop's eye and tell your minions to beat TF out of it. Or you can be Guts from Berserk, sweep and slice enemies all around you. Heck, you could be a super nuisance mage with mainly using debuff spells. So many ways to fight and so many ways you can play with your Pawn.

For example, I was fighting a Griffin once and it was just flying around teasing us while we were helpless on the ground. I used my shield to signal my Strider pawn to get launched high up in the air and forced the griffin down with a Skull Splitter. Another battle with an Ogre, my pawn with a skull crusher 2 handed hammer broke it's legs. Allowing me to perfectly hit a fully charged overhead greatsword swing onto it's neck, killing it instantly from 40% health.

For the $30 Capcom for some reason thinks its worth, you could instead get MH World, which is essentially this game, but way better in every way, or you could  get Shadow of the Colossus on PS2, 3, or 4 which is also essentially this game, but way better.

-The game has a lot of neat ideas, but absolutely nothing feels flushed out.
-The world is huge, empty, and you backtrack way more than you explore new areas. 
-Basic mobs take forever to kill regardless of how powerful you are.
-Climbing is glitchy at best, borderline suicidal at worst, and generally offers no real benefit.
-NPC's are shallow husks that send you on a lot of escort quests, passive kill quests, and sometimes a story mission. 
-There is no sorting side quests and main quests. They're all in a single log in the order you obtained them.

All that said, *I'm* going to keep playing this game, but I don't actually suggest anyone play it.

It's really impressive what they accomplished in 2012. The game takes into account player agency in a way a lot of modern RPGs don't. It's also one of the few games that clearly took inspiration from Souls without just making a 1:1 copy. The online component is an unique take on players helping each other asynchronously, something we only saw again in 2020 with Death Stranding.

Gameplay is fun. A bit of a thoughtless hack'n slash where the gear matters more than skill. It starts off really hard and with the heavy "wait and punish" combat, but by the end it allows for some ridiculously overpowered skill combinations. I might be tempted to say that it "didn't aged well", but fuck it, I still enjoyed it far more than a lot of modern titles. It's fun, that's something Capcom always put in their list of priorities even in their bad games.

The attention to detail is quite impressive at times, like making heavier characters activate pressure plates faster and taller ones having more reach in melee weapons. The oil lamp goes out if you roll in the water. Metal conducts electricity so every armored enemy is a walking "please thunder magick me" sign. There's one quest that allows you to forge the delivery item and "complete" the quest twice by delivering it to both people who want it. It doesn't actually change events later, which is a shame, but these things make the game more memorable by itself.

Sadly, the story is a trainwreck. Starts off fine and honestly stays at mostly "OK fodder" throughout its play time, but the ending throws it all away. It's clearly not a narrative-focused game, yet the ending tries to pretend it is and... It doesn't pull off gracefully. At all. It's so messy that it makes me wonder if the second game will just quietly never acknowledge the events of the first game, or will "reboot" it entirely but this time trying to flesh it out.

Dragon's Dogma is a great game, but also visibly an incomplete one. It's a game where you can see the signs of "crap, we've blown the entire budget. Wrap it up and release it NOW", a sign that is depressively common in the gaming industry. It's still a good game on it's own right and worth playing it, but clearly doesn't reach its full potential.

This is very different to other RPGs. I don't generally enjoy them and all the inventory management but this really streamlines a lot of that using NPCs and also seems to have a focus on combat. Unlike elden ring where only equipped armor is count as your weight, here, every item counted and you have plenty of item to pick up. I wish they do a better job in Dragon Dogma 2 regarding the inventory.

This game has an unbelievable amount of content considering when it was made. Early in the game you may find yourself maxing skills and weapons and armor, while later you will experience heart-stopping, out of this world cutscenes, boss-fights, and choice based endings. With tons of optional boss-fights, quests, locations, new game + content, this game has hundreds of hours of fun, and will easily go down as one of my favorite, and most recommended games EVER.

I get pissed off at my handsome warrior companion, grab him and hold him up like he's my wife and then throw him off the nearest cliff straight to his death. The only thing I have a slight issue with is that the romantic interest of your character is determined by interaction and it is unavoidable since it is tied with the climatic final battle. <<<To show how epic this game can be, heres a tale from my time with it>>>


I was playing this and wandering a grassy plain when there was a loud skree from above. I turned the camera and saw it. There was huge griffin flying towards me! I dodge rolled out of the way as it swooped in and landed, shaking the ground and kicking up dust particle effects as my controller rumbled furiously.

 My party members began their attack first, hacking at its legs and knocking off a talon which prompted it to take off and flee in response. I acted quickly and grabbed onto its hind leg right as it took flight then began climbing up towards its head, As it ascended far beyond the point where i could survive fall damage, it frantically bagan spiraling and bucking mid air to try and throw me off. My stamina bar was draining fast but there was no going back. 

It was do or die epic gamer time so i persisted in climbing up its huge body until i reached its head. I then latched my legs around its neck and began stabbing it in the back of its skull with my flaming dual daggers, setting its feathers ablaze and sending it careening downwards. I rode its burning corpse down into the ground like a meteor and leapt off just before it came skidding through the dirt, reducing my fall damage just enough to narrowly avoid death. My character tumbled across the ground until she stopped and stood up. With just sliver of health left, my healer cast a healing spell as i walked over to relieve the still burning remains of its loot. 

None of this was in a cutscene. No quick time events or cinematics of any kind. Not even part of the story or a sidequest. 100% pure action packed gameplay against a monster that decided to show up randomly as i explored.



If this doesn't sound exciting or fun to you then idk what to say. Maybe try checkers?

The game is stable and it looks nice, its an amusing thing to go and wander through a big map and look at some nice views here and there, somtimes simple sometimes a little complex.

The combat is passable, it functions but it also doesn't feel like its own, it is like shadow of the colossus trying to be a final fantasy game in that you can cast a big spell and hurt a monster or you can climb the monster and hurt them that way, climbing isn't really all that good, just gets in the way and often times just isnt really necessary or called for.

Traveling also takes too long, you have a couple things you can do to make some of it quick but theres only a little bit of fast travel, ultimately you will be wandering valleys and country sides for most of your gameplay wondering to yourself why you would bother fighting enemies under various conditions or which quest actually progresses the story.

Speaking of story there isn't one, theres cutscenes but there isn't a story, thats vague but it is genuinely the situation, you start the game and get an introduction to a dragon and from there a loose concept of whoever kills said dragon is the head honcho, but from there people just sort of babble at you in really bad Shakespearean and the game just expects you to decipher everything from a quick conversation for really most quests.

Hey lets talk about progression, and the fact that once you have SOME of your armor you will likely hit a wall and be expected to advance the game, as well as start chasing upgrades before you have a set of gear you like using, or can meaningfully enchant anything to begin with, this is all coupled with what honestly just feels like a really really small and limited item table, i don't know how anyone plays "fashion" in this game when there aren't really that many "outfit" ideas to be had from whats available.

TLDR: This is a game for people who don't like games.

Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen is an incredible experience to have at least once in your life. It's a great game for those seeking a relatively short single-player RPG.

The game itself features an extensive map, making it easy to get sidetracked while on a mission. It's rich and fun to explore – I've often paused a mission to spend two hours exploring a random cave or venturing into areas my level couldn't quite handle yet. That's the real joy of the game.

The combat system is a delight in itself. From the very beginning, you realize how solid the mechanics are, allowing you to grab and climb on enemies, even if it's considered "old."

I have no comments on the soundtrack of this game; it's simply wonderful.

Character creation is very comprehensive; you can easily craft characters from other worlds within the Dragon's Dogma universe. There are even many tutorials on YouTube for creating specific characters in the DDDA world. You can even determine the personality of the main pawn according to your taste.

I've played almost 100 hours, and this was one of the games that kept me up at night, like caffeine trying to keep me awake 24/7, and I regret nothing about it.

Now, it'll be a few more hours until I get the platinum trophy. Here's a tip if you're interested in platinum: follow a tutorial because there are side missions that can be missed by changing chapters, and you can't go back to replay them. Or just play it your way and then play again because it's worth it, and the experience is raw and better, right?
