I never got a round to playing this when it came out and I wish I had, because it seems like it had some good ideas for the time.  But it's got way too much terrible design and has not aged well to try to play now.

Armor is a mess.  Rather than using a percentage system like nearly every other game in existence this uses a straight reduction.  So it's entirely possible to run into one random enemy in a bunch that you just can't hurt, even though you 2-3 shot all of his allies.

AI is garbage.  Yeah there are options for editing it but there's little explanation as to what any given value means, there's almost no manual control since the orders you can shout are largely ignored, and if we're going to have the option to truly edit the values then just let us set what we want and leave them.  Having to go back and keep tweaking things to keep the bots from doing something stupid gets old.  And that's only for the pawns, if you're on an escort quest and your ally decides to engage an enemy they can't hurt then congrats, you failed.  They actually found a way to make escort quests even worse.

The quest system is pretty junk.  I had several "kill x enemy" quests that as soon as I took them the creature type in question stopped spawning in the world.  One of which was extremely obvious since it was seabirds that were everywhere until that exact moment.  You'll lose access to quests ridiculously quick with no warning or reason.  An early quest lead me straight into a group with an invulnerable enemy so I assumed I just needed to circle back and handle it after getting some upgrades, but one mainline quest later and it was failed.  So much for that entire questline...

Overall it's not unplayable but I say give it a pass unless you're prepared to just weather the garbage.

I need you to picture this: A party of 4 adventurers is traveling through a plain that features expansive patches of greenery, scattered ruins all around, and a castle town visible in the distance. Suddenly, a griffin appears! It comes crashing down from the sky, with the sole purpose of making a meal out of the party, no doubt.

The sorcerer begins preparing a devastating fire spell, while the warrior charges forward with his massive sword to meet the beast. As the griffin sustains more and more damage, it takes off to the skies, trying to regain the advantage. The mage (not to be confused with the sorcerer) infuses the ranger's arrows with the element of fire, and they both manage to return the monster back to the ground.

*END OF THE STRUGGLE STARTS PLAYING*

The sorcerer's spell is ready! Multiple flaming meteors start raining down from the sky, heavily damaging the weakened griffin. Amidst the fiery chaos, the warrior manages to focus his strength in a singular earth-shattering strike that puts an end to the winged menace...

I don't care about this game's flaws; the rose-tinted glasses are NEVER coming off.

After 8 hours my sword still damages like a nail.
It's not level up when progression is negative.

I wanted to like this game, but it just did not click with me. 

The fighting mechanics such as climbing monsters to get to the weak spots and weak spots in general were great, and the class/skill mechanics were decent. 

It is just that I found the spawn mechanic boring. It is hardly a new thing in action RPGs, but making them boring emotionless puppets on purpose which you cannot even actively control beyond the most basics made it feel unnecessary and clunky. 

The narrative at points also lacked focus at some points, leaving me wondering around not sure what to do except grinding and blind exploration. Don't get me wrong, I love exploration, but I prefer to be able to progress the story once I am done with it. The lack of any fast travel mechanics (except returning home) did not help. At times I felt I was wondering around all over the map, constantly fighting/outrunning monsters that by that time were just boring speed bumps.

So, maybe it is a good game if you like the grind and don't mind blindly wandering around, but it is just not for me.

Everything about Dragons Dogma lives up to the hype surrounding it. I wouldn't call it a Soulslike, and I wouldn't quite call it an open world ARPG. It falls somewhere in between and really lets the player feel like an behemoth taking down literal gods. The main campaign is fairly easy, but the Bitter Black Isle added as part of the Dark Arisen DLC is really challenging and ups the sense tension at every turn. As said before in other reviews, this is one of the few games out there that gets spell casting right and the power fantasy this game induces is unparalleled by anything else in the genre. If you're interested in this game because of the sequel coming out soon, take the dive and give it a try. Easy 9.5/10

Lantern gets put out if you step in water, I have to go into my inventory, un-equip my lantern, exit my inventory menu, wait 3 seconds for my character to slowly un-equip my lantern, then go back into my inventory to re-equip my lantern. All this for it to get put out by water 20 seconds later.

Extremely railroaded story, I wanted to go back into the village to fight the dragon instead of fighting him on the beach and I hit an invisible wall and a cut-scene force started where I was teleported back on the beach getting hurt by the dragon.

Realising there was a maximum carry weight made me not want to pick up the random items I find which was most of the fun.
Graphics and lighting even when adjusted with mods look very lacking.
The starting village was bland, bleak, with no soul. I'm not taking pity on this world if it's not even beautiful enough to be worth protecting.

Barely any room for creativity in combat or story, I felt the game was telling me "you will enjoy this story because I told you so and there's nothing you can do about it" but I definitely didn't consent to this madness.

I have a strange relationship with this game.

On the one hand, there's a lot of not very good stuff in it: godawful english voice acting (Japanese one is waaay better), pretty confusing story, strict timetable that can lock you out of some quests just because you've STARTED some main quest, pawns AI can be annoyingly bad (like if you got captured and they don't do sht to free you, so you have to mash A/D), beloved system, save system.

But on the other hand, I love this game. Music is top notch (especially in the Bitterblack Isle and late game Everfall) , you can do surprisingly cute MC, there's huge amount of freedom. Combine equipment however you want - will still look good probably (unless it's silk tights); do any class with any skills at ANY point in the game - got bored playing as a all-powerful sorcerer? just switch to assassin that can solo ANYTHING; you can change your pawn at any pawn too, so they are better suited to your play style at the moment; you can explore almost all of the map after doing just a couple starting quests; you can combine almost every item to create another item; you can kill enemies by just grabbing them and tossing them of the cliff. Really, gameplay is where this game shines.

Story is pretty confusing, it's a bit disappointing that there's [spoiler]no good ending for the MC[/spoiler], it's really annoying how much of a bias there's for beloved characters. Like, it's so obvious that Alienor is meant to be canon beloved - it pisses me off. And also, all of the main girl beloved have epilogue dialogue, yet not a single male has one? The hell.
The big battle and the ending are pretty epic though.

Overall, it's one of the few games that I actually play not for the story, but for the gameplay. And for a 10 year old game, it holds up surprisingly well.

Haven't played it long, but just found out that you can only have one character at a time because of the way the save functionality was implemented.  If you create a new character, the save for your old character is deleted.  Also, if you have to reinstall for some reason, your save gets wiped.  How could they, in good conscience, do this to players... absolutely horrible.

I finally played the game this year (2023) so it had already been out for at least a decade. It holds up surprisingly well. The graphics are fit for purpose, some idle and walking animations are wonky, but the monsters move REALLY well! Dragon's Dogma 2 (which was announced around the time I wrote this) is going to look and feel gorgeous.

The character designer is really good - albeit with some wonkiness - and I've seen some amazing and hilarious ones online.

Combat is quite fun. Strongly recommend a controller rather than KB and mouse. 

I gravitated towards the magic classes and finished the game as a Sorcerer. As others have mentioned, I also feel it makes the normally "stand in the back and shoot things" nature of the magic classes more fun and "crunchy" to use. I never got bored of Maelstrom, the tornado spell. There are some enemies that are frustrating for a Sorcerer, but making sure you have a Strider and Fighter for companions helps a lot

If you are very particular about waifus (or husbandos), I strongly recommend reading the wiki and other discussions about the "Beloved" mechanics. The game WILL railroad you into 2 choices, and thankfully I was able to avoid that (but at the cost of skipping a mission and getting arrested 😆).

Only downside for me is in order to get the best and coolest gear and weapons, there is a lot of grinding involved with a "dungeon" called Bitterblack Isle. I don't have the patience and gacha / %age mechanics for finding gear just annoy me. But this might be a positive for those who enjoy perfecting their dungeon runs.   

The main story is actually really short. A lot of time as a n00b is spent exploring the world and finding out where things are, which adds time. Rolling into a New Game+ keeps all the map knowledge and gear you have collected, so each game is more streamlined. 

Anyway, it was a fun action kinda-sorta-RPG with an interesting story twist/concept.
One of my favorite games.

I AM THE DANGAN

Pros
1. The combat system. Climbing up monsters, epic sorcerer attacks and variety of skills for each class
2. The ability to change class mid-game gives you the option to try all special skills for each class without restrictions.



Cons
1. Story, presentation and lore. Bad dialogue and the story makes no sense at times and it gets way over its head in my opinion - trying to be philosophical and clever. Everybody talks like when Joey found the online thesaurus. Underwhelming and anticlimactic bosses, at least in the main story.  I won't be playing the expansion (Bitterblack isle)
2. Lack of commands makes the pawns a bit harder to use - they tend to be  stupid.
3. The silent protagonist acts more like a pawn than the pawns. He/she stares at the void with a stupid look on his face in every cutscene.   
4. Too many items that are way too similar make the looting tedious and the whole exploring thing feels kind of, empty to me. 99% of items you find, you don't really need them, as they are not better than the equipment you already have 
5. Although the skills have variety and are very good overall, some are implemented in a way I did not like and the classes have too many restrictions. For example, the roll should be a core skill - not a dagger skill - if I know the skill to roll, why can I roll with the dagger, but can't I do it with a sword? And if  I know how to roll as an assassin, what's stopping me to roll when I become a sorceress? Also, no crouching or any form of stealth - assassin class excluded. 
6. The whole interface of the inventory and player profile/status seems unpolished to me. Tedious crafting system with little explanation, tedious comparing of items and class skills. No skill-stats to compare which skill is stronger etc.
7. Mediocre music

Summary
1. I have played almost 50 hours and it's all because of the combat system. It's a fun game to play. I did the main quest and stopped there, because I've tasted the gameplay - which was the reason I played this game - and now I'm full. I don't want to play the expansion. Everything other than the combat system was unpolished and/or mediocre at best. 

I recommend this game for it's combat, but personally I wouldn't do more than one playthrough.

The combat's a blast, no doubt about it. But let's call a spade a spade – the story is pure dogshit. I mean, how do you mess up a fantasy setup where your main premise is taking down a fucking dragon? It's like the ABCs of fantasy, and yet, they delivered it like a blindfolded kid swinging at a piñata. To break down the story first:

[b]1. Your Character:[/b]
So, you kick off as a humble fisherman, right? Your village gets trashed by the dragon, and you decide to step up. Cool. But here's the kicker – you work your way up, gear up, get stronger, and when it's showdown time with the dragon, you still look like a mumbling moron. Teeth out like some mutt trying to scare off a burglar. And here's the cherry on top – you don't talk. At all. This leads to some seriously awkward cutscenes. I get we're supposed to fill in the blanks, but when your character's interactions with the NPCs are so off (It gets especially awkward because they really tried to use words like "Aught" or try to talk like "I see it's best if we bla bla or summit like it" like it's supposed to be medieval talk, I guess? But it's delivered so awkwardly that it's simply too noticeable.), it's hard to step into their shoes. Speak up, dammit! And the lack of choices for your character? Come on! When the Duke accuses you of dragon conspiracy, defend yourself! Show him the dragon loot or something. Nope, you just run like you've got a traitor's stamp.
And the forced "beloved"? I never liked her, but apparently, I gotta save her to fight the dragon? Why? And why doesn't my character care about her initial betrayal? They just follow her orders like a lost puppy.

[b]2. The Main Story:[/b]
Dragons and fantasy – easy, right? Nope, they tried so hard to make it deep. After beating the dragon, it's supposed to be a victory lap, but nah, you get tossed out of the capital you saved, and no one vouches for you. Not the people you've helped, or the ones you've saved, nothing. And the story gets so confusing in the second half. Defeat the dragon, and instead of fireworks, you end up in some oblivion. Inconsistencies and loose ends with the side quests also pile up, and it's a hot doodoo.

[b]3. Relationships (Affinity) System:[/b]
Building relationships with NPCs by giving them gifts? Mentioned once or twice, but who's got the time to figure out what each NPC likes? And what's the deal with the importance of these relationships? Does it affect quests? Who knows? And the story's inconsistencies spill into relationships too. Duke's wife betrayed you, but when you face the Duke, it's business as usual. You helped the knight Ser Maximilius (?) with the Salvation cultists, after he personally asked you for that favor, he will say "I've known you were a villain from the start!" when the Duke said you coerced with the dragon. Did everyone get amnesia? Why bother raising affinity when they love you one day and hate you the next?

And then there are those moments where you think, "Can I do that?" but chicken out because you're scared the game will glitch. It's a mood killer. The quest system? Walking to quest marks 80% of the time, only to get sent back to the same spot after reporting? Lazy as hell. Give your pawns a bunch of port crystals, teleport everywhere, and save yourself from hearing them repeat the same yap over and over.

in conclusion:
- [b]Combat 8.8/10:[/b] It's a lot of fun, only minus is the fact that once you have progressed a lot in the "physical" or "magical" vocations, switching mid game would make your character really weak and half-assed as opposed to try and at least min max a little bit. The enemy types are varied enough even though it can be summarized into like 10 different enemy types.
- [b]Story 0/10:[/b] Absolute dogshit. Stick to the cliché story, and at least do that well. This narrative is a train wreck.

Just get the game if you want to get introduced to Dragon's Dogma, the JRPG equivalent of the Souls series, it's a blast, but prepare for the worst narrative of all time.

This game is really really really good.  I didn't like it at first - YEARS AGO - because I thought it was a poorly done Dragon's Age rip off with barely anything to do but now I realize it's not like that at all. It's not even a soulsborne-like RPG either. This game is it's own thing and once you get over the opening - which is a slog and I think a reason why a lot of people abandon this gem - the game picks up and is absolutely amazing.

There are some gripes that I have though - like the fast travel system and some UI and UX issues - but the fun to be had in this game far outweighs them.  I cannot wait for Dragon's Dogma 2 to come out.

If you're a fan of Elden Ring you need to play this game since it understood a lot about creating a living open world - without Ubisoft levels of random markers and shit to do - and it's cool to see that kind of design a decade or so before Elden Ring came out.  

It's just fun running around in this world and fighting things. Once you realize how the story is doled out (a few main mission 'objectives' at a time and a TON of 'goals' you can just ignore and let auto complete through osmosis then you can lock in on the story and the pacing picks right up.

Also, fighting giant monsters and climbing over them Shadow of the Colossus style never gets old and all the abilities are amazing; even if the weapon and armor variety leave a lot to be desired.

I also like  how the game simplified leveling up since it's a lot like Skyrim where you level up stats by playing the game and you invest into new abilities that you can swap out at any time but you need to go to a special NPC to do it.

Esse jogo é uma total perda de tempo, você fica o jogo inteiro pensando "acho que depois dessa quest o jogo fica bom". Spoiler: Não fica.

90% do tempo você fica andando, matando goblin, bandido ou harpia. RARAMENTE você vai encontrar inimigos maiores que são basicamente só esses: Quimera, Cockatrice, Grifo e o Mini Dragão, todos tem um padrão de ataque simples nada de demais, a mecanica de se pendurar no bixo perde a graça depois da terceira vez.

A história do jogo é péssima não tem pé nem cabeça, os npcs tem zero personalidade, o NPC com maior profundidade e carisma é literalmente o bobo da corte, Feste.

Tudo nesse jogo é um empecilho, quests, inventário, sistema de pawns (que por sinal não calam a boca nunca, é muito repetitivo).

No geral o jogo é muito tedioso e repetitivo, a luta do boss final não é nada de demais. Eu quero reembolso das minhas 15 horas.

Note:
As of writing this review I haven't done the post game quests (yet). It took me ~16 hours to beat main story on normal difficulty, I didn't really do any side quests and did use fast travel.

Dragon's Dogma is a game that surprised me in multiple ways. There are a couple gripes I have with the game, but nothing [i]game[/i] ruining, I will talk about those first.

The stamina system isn't the greatest; it works well in combat, but when you have to run (you will do a lot of running between locations) it is very annoying. Running between locations is actually quite fun even though it takes a while, the world is just good.

Pawns are one of the main mechanics of this game, definitely the one that sets it apart from other games the most. Overall they are good, but they can be very very stupid some times and were the only cause for frustration for me.

Another minor thing that I don't like is that there is no ultrawide support, the game is a bit older so it can be forgiving but still disappointing.


Those were about my only complaints, now the good parts.

I got this game because it is praised for its combat and god, it is just amazing. There is a lot of freedom in how you take on foes and it does not get boring at all. You can choose between 9 vocations and all of them are very different. I played as a warrior (big two handed sword/hammer) and it was really enjoyable except for flying fuckers. The difficulty was perfect, it never got too easy or too hard, normal is definitely the way to go for your first playthrough.

The pawn system is another thing that is praised by the fanbase and it was more fun than I expected. Opposed to other games, your pawns are actually usefull. They pick up things you do (looting and how you attack) and are very usefull in general. The game was designed with pawns in mind so playing without them would be a bad idea for your first playthrough.

This game also nails atmosphere, and world and enemy design. It has the perfect medieval fantasy feel to it and so do the enemies. Even though the map is quite small, it feels really big and grandiose due to the big structures and height differences. Quite a lot of enemies are based on Greek Mythology and every one of them is fun and cinematic to fight. Enemies have weak spots, are weak to certain elements and can be climbed on. The music also fits perfectly.

I also enjoyed the progression, you feel stronger every time you get a new piece of gear/skill. I never got OP, but still felt quite strong at the end of the game. Some enemies are really tough at the start and midway through the game you can dominate them.

The story and characters are ok, good enough to give purpose to whatever you are doing but nothing special.


If you want a medieval fantasy RPG with amazing gameplay and atmosphere, get this.

ETA:
I also did the post game content and that took me another 3-4 hours, quite a bit harder than the main game.Definitely do it though, there are new enemies and enemy combinations that make for interesting battles. I did skip out on the entire DLC, because that is apparently quite difficult and I would have to grind a lot to take that on [i]I think[/i]. So the main story + post main story with very little side quests and using fast travel took me ~20 hours.

A monster hunter type of game that was interesting in year 2012 --6/10

Weirdly enough, this game has some dark souls ideas like the interface, medieval scenery (Red dragons/bridges), one save slot, terrible menus, lots of item descriptions (Obviously it's not a souls like). 

For me, the game didn't age well. Walking/running in a "open world" relying on stamina and later on a move set (to save stamina, mind you) is tedious, later you can have a kind of fast travel that is awful, but better than nothing. Inventory management is also a tedious task, with so many items, no sort option and good luck finding out what overencumbered you. Also to solve some quests you need to look for a internet guide, because the game expects that you will eventually talk with the right NPC or stumble on the correct area... which is also tedious. The fights are most of the time good, but there are many enemies that felt like bullet sponge and will required a lot of time just repeating the same strategy until they are defeated. I started playing on Hard mode, but there are so many BS and waste of time that i gave up.

There are some good ideas here and there and I'm being a little harsh just because of the hype for the second installment.  Hopefully more quality of life will be there.

As a friend suggested, go easy on this classic and we will have some good times.

Yes, it's a 2016 game but in 2023 it still hits the right spots! 

Looking for customizing options to build your own look for your character? This got it. 
Looking for some brand new adventures, along with some pretty huge bosses? This got it. 
Looking for a new map to traverse and some wild dungeons to crawl? This got it. 
Looking for a group of ai companions to join you along the way? This got it. 
Looking for unbridled graphics+optimized fidelity? This has some of that, at 60fps. 
Looking for superior controls and zero ui jank? Well nah, but it's not horrible at all.

All in all $6 or so was a great price to start off a pretty generous experience in the land of action combat and role play exploration. I'm already interested in how the sequel will look and play yet I've barely scratched this game's surface.

Create a character, then a companion to fight alongside. Then, choose from the ranks of other player-created characters to add two more companions to your party. Take that party on a dark fantasy quest through craggy green hills and forests and mountain paths and dungeons, unlocking different classes and abilities and combining them in various ways to create builds you enjoy. Use those abilities to fight huge monsters and swarming mobs on your way through the story.

It's a weird, well-written, well-directed, hack and slash adventure with lots of good voice actors. It's $5 right now during the Winter Sale 2023 and that is an absolute steal given how much fun it is. It's worth playing through in preparation for the SEQUEL ARRIVING EARLY NEXT YEAR.

In the year when this game came out, I never bothered to buy it despite it received positive feedback overwhelmingly. I asked myself, was there a reason to convince me purchasing it? 

In one hand, I never heard of Capcom is good at making Western Fantasy RPGs, Capcom had like none at that time. In the other hand, there are games who had well known in this genre already, e.g Elder Scrolls, Dragon Age franchise. In short, best FRPGs based on western culture are made from western studios, they knew what they were doing, like pretty well, to my knowledge. Though I wasn’t particularly fond of this genre, why would I give this game a special pass? So I ignored it.

Now let’s fast forward time to this present day. Dragon’s Dogma 2 was announced and incoming within a few months. It has a far better presentation and advertisement, undoubtedly, it met my definition of what a modern game suppose to be, so it got my attention. Because it is a continuation of the 1st game, I brought it's ancestor, in hope through the journey of the first one, will eventually help me have a better understanding and experience in the 2nd entry of this franchise.

However I was wrong, I regretted the choice I’ve made.

After playing Dragon’s Dogma Dark Arisen for several hours, I went back to it's store page, to check whether my eyes had some problems or not. Because I can’t believe the game is from Capcom, a company who produced extremely high quality games like Resident Evil Remakes, Street Fighter franchise. I have double checked the time when this game was out, that’s right, the year of 2016. The very same year that Rise of the Tomb Raider landed us a mind blow experience in video games history. On the contrary, this game looks so ancient as if I dig it from somebody’s gravestone and started playing right away.

Here’s an image I shot. https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3121839878
Did you notice the strange look of this poor guy? He looked like a terrible dwarf with an unusual big head as if he had some kind of sickness. I guess this is what happens when you hid yourself in a well for too long.
The character model of this game is horrible, I can barely make myself a satisfied character in order to hop into this world. Not to mention, the environment overall looks rough too, specially for a player who has just finished Avatar: The Frontiers of Pandora. I had hard time to adjust myself to pick up this game right from the beginning. Alright, if comparing to a game of 2023 was not fair, I don’t think I need to link a video of mine from Rise of the Tomb Raider here to back up my argument, do I?

Capcom, if you want to make an open world RPG or other genres with a large world to explore, the world itself must look real, it is how this genre works, OK? It’s not an JRPG of anime style, graphics doesn’t really matter.

If graphics are horrifying wasn’t bad enough, does the gameplay any better, so I misjudged it somehow? Unfortunately, not really.

Despite I am not too far in the game while writing this review, the mechanics of the gameplay isn’t too awful, but nothing impressive either.
The game doesn’t teach me too much at this stage, but I would still prefer a place to review all tutorials I’ve learnt so far. Not trust my memories for everything, you’re not the only game I am playing at the same time after all, DDDR. And some design choices are questionable. E.g there aren’t any level recommendations for all kinds of quests, the enemies don’t have any level indicators on their head, which resulted me having no clue of what kind of danger I am running into. It’s a red flag for an open-world RPG to be honest. Because, sometimes enemies are very weak, sometimes, they’re too OP even though they don’t look like it. E.g sometimes, I received a quest like sleeping for a while then suddenly facing a hydra head on the next day which making me look like a fool in front of my display. I don’t feel shame of running away from powerful foes, but I do mind knowing what I am doing, not bumping into some kind of challenge without consideration. Half of the time, the game feels random and unpredictable, and illogic, sometimes too. This is one kind of question.

The system of the game is rather complex than I’d expect. However, some details need more extra care. Like, weapons and gears can be upgraded, so when you purchase a new one, the comparison should base on the base status of what you’re equipped and what you are going to buy, otherwise we will have no idea of which one is better to go. The materials you need for leveling up  gears should be highlighted somewhere in the menu, in case you coming across them while exploring the map but forgetting what they are called. Specially the game followed the Witcher’s tradition, the weight system. So you are unlikely going to pick up everything you found in the game. What are needed and what are not, should be clear. Again, the option of doing so is none.

Last, the game has only 1 save. To my experience, 1 save is a risking thing to begin with. Devs gotta be extremely confident of their games by doing so, which means there won’t be any ‘accident’ at any given stages of the game. Because if it were, we got problems. If a bug triggers in any part of the main quest line for example, 1 save could get me stuck. I have to beg the game is bug/issue free through the entirely long road ahead.

I don’t want my review being super long, so I am going to stop listing more flaws here. Generally speaking, DDDR fell into a mediocre RPG that I do not feel a strong desire to continue, despite I will still try. In other words, it’s too boring to play it for long judging by the content it represents.

In conclusion, I would recommend skipping this game, just wait up to jump into the 2nd game straight away. There’s no need for a backtracking this time.

Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen is a game that immerses you in exhilarating battles against massive foes, giving every encounter a sense of epic scale. However, the absence of multiplayer can make your journey feel solitary at times. Beyond the thrill of combat, the quest-related glitches such as objectives failing to trigger or complete, can significantly hinder progress. These issues disrupt the flow of the adventure, occasionally leaving you frustrated and unable to advance.

Moreover, the occasional performance hiccups, like frame rate drops, occasional freezes, or even crashes, can disrupt the otherwise immersive experience. While the combat mechanics remain a highlight, these technical shortcomings and quest related bugs detract from the overall enjoyment.

Yet, the announcement of Dragon's Dogma 2 brings hope for a more refined and engaging sequel, promising a potentially smoother and more immersive adventure for fans of the series.

This is a really underrated (TLDR you should get it) fantasy rpg where you play as one main character and you can have 3 mercenaries that travel with you called pawns, to make a party of 4. As need arises, you can change the jobs and equipment of the pawns and issue orders to them. You can also hire the pawns of other players to round out your party and they can hire yours. The pawns can carry messages and gifts to other players along with helping them in combat, which is a very original way of adding an online component to a single player rpg. If Dragon's Dogma had been more popular I could see a lot of games stealing this pawn system, and when Dragon's Dogma 2 comes out and inevitably competes with BG3 and the like, other developers may take notice. 

The story seems to be your standard "you are the chosen one" quest where you are trying to stop a world ending event from happening. I don't really care for a lot of video game stories, and this one feels pretty basic. The world is very nicely built though, full of lore, and unfolds and expands as you play in a satisfying way. There are some very 2012 bits of graphical, UI, and combat jank, and some of the monsters get a bit repetitive after you encounter them a few times. The graphics really aren't a problem, if you have played the original Dark Souls they are about on par with that. I believe Capcom used whatever engine they make Monster Hunter or Resident Evil to make this so despite it looking a little old it's perfectly fine with some blocky effects and low res textures here and there. The menu system is not great though, in fact it's right down there with Skyrim among the worst ones I have seen. You end up scrolling through huge lists of items and each of your four party members has their own inventory. It gets very tedious when you become overburdened and have to go back to the inn in town and do a bit of inventory management before you can do anything else. 

The combat is pretty great overall, but it does get repetitive sometimes, but the repetition is made up for by ambition. Along with the pawn system, the combat has a few really nice touches. There is a lot of different types of magic flying around and fast paced action. The classes all feel different to play, some more than others, but the three starting classes are your standard tank, melee dps, and ranged magic/healer. There are 9 total classes including 3 hybrid ones to branch out into. You can switch in and out of them any time and this is necessary in order to meet various threats and continue leveling up once you max out in your original class. It was really funny to switch from a mage to a rogue type about 20 hours in, because suddenly I didn't know how to do combat encounters all over again. The game feels pretty fresh like that as you change classes, but you can make up for inexperience by having solid pawns to round out your party while you learn a new thing.

My favorite part of the combat in Dragon's Dogma is the ability to climb up on large monsters and attack different parts of their body. Because it is played as a party of 4, you often get ambushed by a large gang of enemies and have to use all the strategies available to you such as crowd control, tanking, and healing. I think it also is worth highlighting that the combat is real time, unlike some of the more wellknown AAA games at the time. This is quite the achievement for a game from this period when all they had to do was copy Bioware. In combat the AI pawns are competent, and rarely felt like my npc party was lacking in ability but not overpowered either. Since you can swap classes and pawns in and out, you never feel like anything is a brick wall and this encourages players to try different things and innovate rather than cheesing encounters with OP strats. This balance of constant fair challenges and a good set of tools and systems for any occasion is very commendable on Capcom's part.

 I think the music and sound are probably the weakest part of this game, with an (imo) obnoxious main menu theme, generic fantasy music in game, and a lot of repetitive audio cues. Your npc party will constantly call out when they see a monster and what its weaknesses are, which is really irritating when you hear them screaming about goblins or wolves for the thousandth time. Other callouts are useful though such as advice about where to go next so it's a mixed bag. Overall it's a shame that this game didn't get the recognition it deserved at the time, but I recommend it as a really solid rpg if you like fantasy and a party based tactical experience. And it's usually really cheap so pick it up for $5 and have a good time before the sequel comes out.

What an incredibly brilliant game! Perhaps one of the most hidden gems in all of gaming. 

I want to ask, “why don’t more people know about this game?” 

And the answer is, I don’t know. In fact, I’ve only recently discovered it myself. And that discovery was purely by happenstance, reading an article on Gameranx called, "31 Best PC RPGs of All Time"

So I said to myself, what the hell – let’s give it a shot. And it turned out to be one of my favorite games of all time. 

It’s such an incredibly good game. And yet, so few people know about it. 

Now having played it for hundreds of hours, I have to 100% agree with Gameranx…. it's definitely one of the best RPGs of all time.

And for those of you on Linux, it runs beautifully on Linux Mint, Linux Mint Debian Edition and MX Linux… and very likely many other distributions. But those are the three I’m using.   

And to boot, I'm currently playing this on my oldest computer… K9A2 Platinum Motherboard…  AMD Phenom X4 970…  8GB DDR2…  and a GTX 750 Ti graphics card. 

So if it works for me on this old rig, it’ll certainly run like a charm for you. 

~/~

Update: For whatever reason this game no longer works on Linux Mint 21.2… so I’ve switched over to MX Linux 23.1 and it works like a charm. 

Maybe something is going on with Ubuntu upstream; I’m not certain. But I feel much better using a Debian Based distribution – and as it turns out, not only does it work flawlessly – but it’s much faster.

Hello, character creation connoisseur here. Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen is great. It actually feels like an adventure. There's slaying and quest boards and hiring, improving skills, etc. But I digress. Character creation. This game's character creation is sweet. I'll go ahead and praise it for you.

- Heterochromia (two different colored eyes): Most modern games with character creation have this feature, so I can say I was delightfully surprised to see the feature in this game, being 11 years old as of this review.
- Body Scaling: I believe this game went above and beyond for body scaling. Weight and height are factors that change statistics in-game, like weight capacity, stamina, and stamina regen. Also short characters can crawl through small spaces. Large characters (If I'm not mistaken) can pin down enemies of a certain size. Also gender matters. Some enemies target certain genders.
- Pawn creation: Not only can you change how you look, but you can also change how your pawn looks. YOUR pawn is basically your right hand man/woman etc.

I just reviewed Baldur's Gate three and I firmly believe this game is leagues better in character creation, and I'd wager gameplay too.

I tried. I really, REALLY tried to make it through this game, even just the central story quests, just so I could say I finished it and gave it a fair shot. But I can't. 

I've only played the Dark Arisen version of Dragon's Dogma, and apparently, the original version was even WORSE about limiting your fast travel abilities. Yet the expanded version of the game STILL feels like it is CONSTANTLY punishing you by making you revisit locations you've been to three to four times previously. Oh, you didn't leave a port crystal there? Too bad. Now you're making the same trek to the same, unchanging location YET AGAIN, and what do you get for your trouble? The same mobs, the same encounters, and maybe, if you're lucky, one or more of the same mini-bosses you've already seen half-a-dozen times already.

I'm sorry, but the fast travel system feels like a punishment in this game. It forces you to micromanage where you leave your travel points, of which you have very few versus the number of locales in the game's map, and if you happen to forget to leave one behind, or you happened to pick it up because you were JUST THERE and you assume there's NO POSSIBLE WAY you'll have to return to it two quests later, too bad. Run miles upon miles while watching your dumb ass character endlessly run out of breath if you dared to equip them with heavy armor. It's so much worse if you're the sort of player who wants to be prepared with items and curatives to make combat easier -- they just weight you down more, and while you can distribute them amongst your pawns, eventually the absurdity of having to manage your wares becomes so obnoxious and time-consuming that you'll probably say "fuck it" and just endure running out of breath every thirteen seconds.

The combat in the game is fun, but it, too, becomes repetitive after a while, and switching between vocations only diminishes this problem to a certain extent. The story is INCREDIBLY bland and generic fantasy, the characters are all but devoid of unique personalities, you're yet another silent protagonist so YOU have no personality outside of whatever stupid, pointless choices you make, and for the most part, unless you go out of the way to handicap yourself, you will invariably be forced to grind until the enemies become comically weak against you unless you avoid every single random encounter, of which there are so, so many. This shouldn't be a problem, but after a while, fighting a pack of wolves that can knock you over but can't really damage you gets SO FUCKING BORING that you'll find yourself sprinting past them, only to run out of stamina YET AGAIN so that they can knock you on your ass.

There is the seed of a fantastic experience buried in this game, but it's bogged down by so much fluff, so much padding and so much POINTLESS FUCKING LONG-DISTANCE WALKING that it becomes insignificant in the grand scheme of your experience. I'm still vaguely interested in the sequel, but only if they streamline travel somehow. Otherwise, I'm done with this series.

In another life DDDA would have its own sub-genre called Dogma-like with developers competing to perfect mechanics such as large scale monster combat, crafting, rich open world, the perfect pawn system. Fun action RPG with creative combat, satisfying abilities and good build customisation. Suffers from some clunky UI issues, a handful of missable/time-sensitive quests, some translation issues and mechanics that aren't intuitive. 

For example the unlockable augments you can use to create your build are often unclear or outright misleading in their descriptions, and learning how to best make use of your AI companion pawn requires an understanding of several mechanics that in-game sources don't properly provide. The actual value of augments that boost stats like stagger/knockdown or your own resistance to it are hard to parse given the large enemy variety. Thankfully the game is old enough that plenty of testing information can be found from other players on the wiki which goes a long way towards sorting the wheat from the chaff.

Overall its strengths outshine the weaknesses and it's still a worthwhile game today; picking up and throwing goblins off cliffs (or your useless AI companion) never really gets old.

The story is not something to brag about but it's good enough to keep the game going and entertain you a bit. If do the main story/quest-line only it would take about 7 hours or less. Overall, it's good story even if a bit simple, but simple and straightforward can be great at times. This may stem from me playing the game too much/too long and/or having played games with more depth in their story. However, I quite found the characters to be enjoyable.

The game truly shines when it comes to game-play and combat. It is what keeps me coming back to the game even months after. I really like how they implemented mechanics like stamina management, night cycles, enemy grappling, etc. More so love how the game doesn't wait for you and how you can miss out on quests after some time has passed, and how the enemies are at a static level so if you're at lvl 1 and enemy is lvl 10 mopping the floor with you, after you grind and level up to reach their level or beyond it becomes a "fair" fight as they don't level up alongside you. This provides a sense of improvement on your part, a sense of accomplishment. The enemy variety is great too, each with different strengths and weaknesses, more so in the DLC isle.


As a side rant, my gripe with the game boils down to two matters, though these are [b]HIGHLY personal preference and not subject to sway your interest in the game.[/b] Hopefully Mr Hideaki Itsuno addresses these in the sequel though, not likely but hopeful :D.

- First one is that despite the meh story there are some side quests that cause inconsistencies with the main story for me as someone who like's to be "immersed" in a game. Top of my head example being [spoiler]the side quest for the dukes wife. Imagine "shagging" the kings wife, get caught and she pins the blame on you and sent to jail, escape the jail cell, and come back tomorrow to chat with the king and continue like none of that ever happened. Worst of all is you'd be romancing some other character but mandem be getting into relations with a bunch others willy nilly like he has amnesia when meeting someone new lol.[/spoiler]
- Lastly, how the heck does immolation (setting oneself on fire) skill from the magic archer vocation not remove getting wet/drenched Mr Itsuno?!


P.S.: I'm aware this game was released way back and was ahead of its time at the time, and given what I've seen of the sequel getting released next year (2024), it has improved exponentially better, so this "review" or recommendation is just kinda pointless :D.

I can't believe I slept on this game for so long! With all the hype around the sequel, I finally decided to give the original a shot, and wow, did it just pull me in. Been rocking it on my Steam Deck about 90% of the time, and let me tell you, it's pure brilliance. Never thought playing a magic-focused character could be this damn enjoyable, especially with the sorceress.

The combat is like a sweet blend of action and targeting systems that just hit the spot. It's getting dangerously close to that 'perfect 3D Action RPG', and it's giving off some serious Monster Hunter RPG feels. The story? Solid and engaging, with this cool mix of western and eastern influences that I'm totally digging. And can we talk about the party system with those 'pawns'? It's such a unique way to assemble a crew with your buddies or random players that THEY created, tailoring it to fit your needs. Plus, there are perks for creating a pawn that catches the eye of other players – super slick implementation for sure.

Now, let's be real – the game's starting to show its age in some areas. The movement feels a bit clunky, the user interface could use a bit of a usability facelift, and the character models aren't exactly amazing (though the big bosses look downright stellar).

But hey, I'm officially lost in this world and super hyped for the sequel. Capcom's got me hooked on another one of their IPs, and I'm loving every minute of it!
straight up awful

Dragon's Dogma is an open world 3D action rpg.

con:
- Minimalistic story. It starts strong with the opening cutscene and prologue, but then there is nothing for 30 hours until you reach the final battle and post-game content. Npc sidequests are short too.
- Forced romance. The game will pick a love interest for your character from among the sidequest npcs and you can't say no to any of it, not even if you don't like the npc that the game selected for you.
- Worldbuilding. You hardly get to know anything about most characters or their culture. It lacks atmosphere and immersion. In some instances, the world just doesn't make sense, like how there is a fishing village when the ocean is canonically contaminated by "the Brine", or the respawning bandit ambush right outside the capital where soldiers patrol. Suicidal civilians traveling unarmed, constantly getting assaulted by wolves and whatnot.
- Missing quest markers. Some quests have them, many others don't, often those where you would have wanted them the most.
- It is a 2012 console game through and through. The default graphics looks dated. Has a high chance of freezing and crashing if you alt-tab out. No borderless window mode.
- The audio volume is all over the place.
- Too many tanky bosses. Most bosses & minibosses are easy, they just take ages to beat (on a first playthrough at normal difficulty).
- The game does a poor job at explaining things. There are many popup messages and such, but I still felt like I had to figure out most things by myself.
- Item weight. You can't carry much, even just being "Heavy" negatively affects your stamina regeneration.
- Minimalistic equipment progression, which gets in the way of customization. You rarely find equipment that's better than the stuff available in the shops. The free armor sets that you get early on are better than any of the other armor that you can get until the end of the game.
- There are lots of flying enemies and sometimes objects to shoot down or enemies on ledges that you can't reach, but not every class has a ranged attack.
- There is no aim-assist for the bow and no lock on, playing on a controller is a bit of a pain.

pro:
- The "pawns". I've never seen AI companioins done like this, it is very unique. You can have two, one of which is a customizable character, while the other is recruitable/dismissable and can be a copy of another player's pawn.
- Dynamic difficulty. There is a difficulty setting, but ignoring that, you can go from regular self-imposed-restrictions to letting the max-level pawn of a Steam friend solo half the game for you and when that gets boring, you can simply dismiss that pawn and try something else.
- You can climb monsters, break monster parts, etc. Combat is interactive, a little bit like in Monster Hunter.
- The fast travel system. The "Eternal Ferrystone" lets you teleport to any town [b]or[/b] directly to one of up to 10 "Portcrystals" that you can collect and place anywhere on the map and they won't disappear until you pick them back up, they even stay in place for NG+.
- Exploration is alright. Finding optional bosses and quest npcs in the wild is fun and the fast travel system makes it not a slog. Dungeons also rarely have pointless branches, its overall relatively time efficient. Almost all enemies respawn if you let several (ingame) days pass.
- There are 9 different classes ("Vocations") and you are encouraged to master multiple of them, since passive bonuses carry over between classes. It keeps the gameplay fresh, while simultaneously advancing your character build. Each class is unique, Capcop took the combat of several different games, tossed it into a blender and somehow ended up with something good.
- Has multiple endings, post-game content and a NG+ system that retains your progress.
- Has a dedicated speedrun mode.
- The day-night cycle. At night there are harder enemies and you can't see anything without a lantern, just like in caves. (One of the few things that the game does right in the atmosphere department.)
- Occasionally, it matters how you complete a quest. It doesn't come up often, but there are some quests where you get a different quest ending or reward based on a decision.
- The game is cheap, often on sale at -84% and the "Dark Arisen" DLC comes with the game for free. 

It's a great game, but has many flaws.
Worth it for the combat, AI pawns and exploration/sidequesting. Not worth it for the story or open world.

zI enjoyed my time with Dragon's Dogma, but I can't recommend it to others. It's a 2013 game that feels dated and a bit janky. I really enjoyed the combat despite the jank. I also liked the invocation system and the pawn system. The 5 out of 9 invocations (aka classes) were all enjoyable. I ended up going strider for the second half of the game and loved it. Exploring felt extremely fun and dangerous early on. 

The problem with the game is it was clearly rushed out. Areas are reused for main quests and there is no fast travel to those areas. So you walk the same path and fight the same enemies. It looks like half the map wasn't used when you look at the big map. The main quest line is rushed and hobbled together. You can tell some of these areas and systems just didn't have the time they needed during development. The main cinematics are decent but sparce. The main plot is simple but works well. Sadly it's all rushed and limited.

I can see why this game has a following but I don't think its something I recommend to most people. I will say that I am very psyched to check out Dragon's Dogma 2 now. If this game does peek your interest I would keep an eye on the sequel which looks like it could be more of a complete product.

[b]TL;DR: Hard Mode breaks the pacing due to double XP and extra gold, it starts off very frustrating due to 1-shot from enemies, but becomes extremely easy mid/late game.[/b]


Piece of advice, don't play on Hard Mode for your first run. Yeah you might be a Soulsborne veteran and all, but hear me out. There's no difference on enemy behavior or types encountered, the only change is that they do double damage (to you alone, your Pawns remain unchanged) and you use more stamina for all attacks/spells.

Most enemies at early levels will 1-shot you. You may say 'git gud' or 'skill issue', however it's not challenging hard, it's frustrating hard. There are no iframes to carry your ass on the early game, a bushwhacking wolf or a stray bandit arrow may kill you outright. Of course there are ways to deal with this, playing super safe, or with a shield, but my main gripe comes with the Gold and XP rewards. 

On Hard Mode you and your Pawns get double XP and any enemies may drop random bags of 10k gold (whereas normally you'd get few hundreds at most). Due to this, it's not long before you outpace the enemies and suddenly you are sitting on a pile of gold and overleveled. IMO this breaks the intended pacing of the game. 

Stick to Normal the first time around, there are difficulty spikes in new areas and you must adapt your game (attack damage type and strategy) to fight different types of enemies. Still, if you want an extra challenge, you may simple take less Pawns with you OR even not using mid-combat healing items.

Fantastic game.

Been playing a pirated copy of this game on and off for the past few years, and after finally beating it and seeing it was on sale, I decided to buy it to show my support.

This game deserves it. The combat system alone is worth the price of admission. The game feel of beating the shit out of goblins is spot on, and this game's legendary ability to let you climb on larger enemies to hit them in the face never gets old. All the different classes are at least viable, and messing around with them all meant I never ran out of toys to play with even after restarting the game half a dozen times. 

This games quests also deserve some recognition. Some of them are admitably not great (looking at you cow escort quest) and there are a fair share of generic "Slay X amount of monster" ones, but more often than not I was given a surprising amount of options for completing what initially seemed like basic tasks. My favorite example of this involves forging a spellbook that you're supposed to return. Doing so costs more than the quest reward gives you, makes a later boss fight harder, and only really serves to bully one specific NPC, but the game lets you do it and is all the richer for it.

This game has its rough edges and more than its fair share of jank, but it rarely gets frustrating. More often then not it just makes the game more charming. I don't know why everyone talks like they're at a Renaissance fair, or why the NPC companions decide to run headlong into enemy attacks at every opportunity, or why the romance system is so busted that it almost made the 'Masterworks All" guy my soulmate. I do know that I will remember all this weirdness for years to come, which is more than I can say for some more polished titles,

Also, the soundtrack is full of bangers. My personal favorite is the Cassardis theme, which I listen to when I want to feel sad on purpose.

I can't wait for the sequel, please don't disappoint me Itsuno.

There's not much to say here; if you like Action RPGs, this is a must-have for you!

The only thing this game has going for it is it's combat. If you are someone who has played many modern rpgs I don't recommend the game. Many aspects of the game are pretty outdated. Story is pretty mid it's wasn't engaging enough to keep me excited on what comes next. 

Gear drop is pretty bad. For the most part its what ever has the highest number you use. 99% of the gear you run into for the campaign has no interesting sub stats your pretty much looking at the main stat.

General UI and inventory management is terrible, too many clicks to do things. Minimap is to zoomed in causing you to have to open the map often which there is no dedicated button for, so you have to make 2 actions to view the map and like wise to see your current quest.

Side quest are pretty boring. Most of the quest are kill x, escort or deliver/find some item.

Actually character progression is very limited. Levelling up doesn't feel as rewarding. When you level up you get stats which the game doesn't tell how much unless you manually do the math and the type of stat you get are based on your current class. You cannot allocate any stats yourself making build variety very limiting and levelling doesn't feel rewarding.

Party system feels really restricted. You can have a party of 4 including your self. 1 party member you create and will level up with you. The other 2 members you have to use other people's party member and those 2 party members you borrow don't level up with you. This results in you having to keep getting new party members every few levels to keep up with you. You can see the stats of other peoples' characters but this results in you having to waste time to check each character to see if they are built right and have the right skill for your ideal party composition.

Overall I recommend the game if you want to experience a game that I would say is pretty innovated for its time. But if your going into this game expecting a masterpiece because everyone else says it is your going to be disappointed especially if your someone who has played a lot of modern games like Baldurs Gate 3, FInal fantasy or other highly acclaimed modern rpg.

You should definitely give this a go if you like intense fights and RPG elements. 
The leveling and classes system is unique and fun. Making your pawn exactly the way you want him/her to be, is also a huge task in this game. Perfection takes a long time as your pawns take a lot of time to learn all the enemy's behaviours. It's truly a gem and I'm looking forward to Dragon's Dogma 2.
Multiple runs are actually fun. In the beginning you feel really weak and if you play the way it's intended to, it takes a lot of time to actually get pretty strong. 

I gotta admit, the first time I started it up, I was pretty frustrated and quit it after like 10 minutes. Then I gave it a chance again a few weeks later and went through the first learning curve. Since then I love it.

Dragons Dogma is like when a really ugly person says they have a crush on you, at first you have zero interest. However, as you delve deeper, you discover that this unassuming exterior hides a ton of captivating qualities, like realising that the unattractive person's family is incredibly wealthy.

If you can make it past the outdated clunkiness, Dragons Dogma is an incredibly deep experience with a lot of replayability. Theres a ton of content you're unlikely to find without extensive research. This is one of those games you'll want the wiki open on a second monitor.

Graphics and Presentation:

 Not bad considering the original year of release, but not the best of that particular year either.  The cut-scenes are okay.

Sound:

The soundtrack is a symphony that complements the epic battles and moments of solitude alike. The ambient sounds of nature and the menacing roars of mythical creatures further enrich the gaming experience. While the voice acting is generally solid, there are instances of repetitive NPC dialogue that can be immersion-breaking.

Gameplay:

The combat system is where this title truly shines. The visceral, weighty feel of every swing and spell is unparalleled, providing a satisfying and challenging experience. The pawn system, allows recruiting companions and customize their behavior, adds depth to the gameplay. The variety of classes and the ability to climb massive foes add strategic layers to battles, making each encounter unique.  However their is a problem. The affinity system, which governs relationships with NPCs and pawns, often feels arbitrary and poorly explained. Building connections with characters can be confusing, and the consequences of certain actions aren't always clear. This lack of transparency in the affinity system diminishes the impact of choices on the game world.

Story:

Unfortunately, the narrative falls short due to persistent inconsistencies. NPCs that turn hostile one moment can later be found offering quests as if nothing happened. This breaks the immersion and makes it challenging to invest emotionally in the story.  Another gripe is one of the endings, where a pawn of the potentially opposite gender inherits the protagonist's body.

Open World:

While the vast open world initially impresses, it quickly reveals its shortcomings. The lack of meaningful activities and a sense of life in the world makes exploration feel somewhat hollow. A more dynamic and interactive open world could have added depth to the experience.

Conclusion:
Capcom excels with the combat and gameplay mechanics, offering a thrilling and engaging experience. However, the story's inconsistencies, awkward narrative moments, and lackluster affinity system detract from what could have been a truly epic adventure. The open world, while expansive, feels devoid of life and activities.

Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen. What is there to say that hasn't been said before?

I f*cking LOVE this game, every time I come back to it, I fall in love all over again. I love Dark Souls, DS1 is one of my favourite games of all time, but Dragon's Dogma, oh boy. While it's unfair to compare the two, since they're way different to eachother, I need to say I think DD is 10x better than the entire Soulsbourne series. Everything about DD just feels... right. The combat, the exploration, the pawns... It all feels so perfectly thought out. Regrettably, I never played it back when it came out, it was only in about 2018-19 that I first played it and gods, this game dominated my brain for so long it's not funny. The sadness I felt, despite being a newer fan, for a lack of even acknowledgement of the series from Capcom hurt me.

But that hurt? It's gone now, because DD2 is coming out in just over 3 months as I type this, and I'm ngl, I shed a tear back when it was announced. I had written off the idea of us getting a sequel, and seeing Dragon's Dogma 2 in my feed back when it was announced had me more hyped for it than anything ever.

I'll see all of you, my fellow Arisen, there when it finally releases.
Absolutely fantastic

There are a lot of very interesting choices in terms of game design here: the hitstops during combat animations, the way that magic works, the class structure, how your character's height and weight affect the way they move around the world, climbing on monsters, the story itself.

I really love this game, but there are also some problems: the emptiness of the world, the too punishing nature of Bitterblack Isle, the poor way that different story choices are communicated to the player, and the poor quality of the side quests all come to mind.

However, this is still a game that has a lot of original, creative choices that work, and that make for fun, interesting gameplay. Even in 2023, I'd recommend that fans of action RPGs give this a serious look.

Hyped for Dragon's Dogma 2.
Amazing epic awesome

Do you like being a hero in a weird love affair with a dragon? Do you like casting spells that make you feel like god? Do you like looking cool in ridiculous imitation medieval armor and swords? Do you think it would be rad to wield awesome looking staves, hammers, clubs, maces, bows, and daggers? Want to be a magic archer that fires mystical tracking bolts at enemies from a distance? What about a mystic knight that wields a machine gun orb and anti-intruder warning system? Think it would be cool to fire an arrow into the eye of a cyclops from 200 yards? Want to chop the snake tail off a chimera? Strike a griffon's wings with lightning and burn its body with meteor fire? Want to forge new weapons in the soul of a wyvern?

Dragon's Dogma will let you do this, but it will force you to play one of the poorest narratives and most frustrating quest systems I can think of as compensation. Seriously, there is a lot to love about this game, especially the combat and music, but it's been a long time since I've played something that felt so good and so awful at the same time. The world is big and empty, the quests have you retreading tons of familiar ground for no reason at all, and the story is so full of holes, you could fly a troll the size of the Chicxulub crater through it and still have room to spare. There's literally a monumental event that happens mid-game, which should change how the game is played and who you find yourself fighting for, but it literally ceases to matter the moment it's over... so it seems to exist merely to be shocking, or to hint at a direction the game might have gone had it received full development.

Short version? If you like killer combat, some tough bosses, and lots of cool weapons and magic, this game is a blast. If you care about story or narrative consistency, or if you hate repetitive quest structures and fetch BS so bad that the DLC gives you a way to partially skip it, then you might want to try the game out on sale, and just test the waters. I played the game for 40+ hours just because I liked fighting stuff and getting new equipment. But I can absolutely see why someone might quit sooner. There's a lot of jank in the way.

BIG DAMAGE WARRIOR!
BIG DAMAGE MAGE!
BIG DAMAGE STRIKER!!
A LOT OF DAMAGE WITH HELM/BRAIN/SKULL SPLITTER!!!

[b]TL; DR[/b] [i]Dragon’s Dogma[/i] is one of my favourite games of all times, I've bought, rebought, played, replayed It countless times since 2012, and I still never get bored with it.

[b]Note[/b] fanboy spotted, and unfortunately, I had to cut down the review after reaching the character limit.

[h1] Story [/h1]
The Arisen must face the Dragon, that is a truth of the world, it brings destruction both on its own and by the hordes of monsters that appear alongside it, as long as it remains the world is not safe. Ages ago, Savan fought against the Wyrm, a generation ago so did Edmund the Wyrmking, but it has returned, it laid waste to your home and when you tried to stand against it you were powerless. It took your heart, marking you, you recover from your injuries a heartless Arisen, destined to fight the Dragon or perish along the way.

I really like the stories in [i]Dragon’s Dogma[/i], however, a lot of the main quests boil down to preparing for and researching the Dragon. Overall, I think I would describe my impression of the main plot as a sort of corrupted folktale, you have all sorts of classical tropes, a ruler, a princess, a fool, a dragon, and a hero, but it is also somewhat subversive. Not to say that there are not a lot of issues, there is an especially jarring event where it is obvious that something [i]more[/i] would have followed but no you are actually that close to the end of the game.
The most frustrating thing is how little they integrate supplemental material in the game, for example there are digital comics that feature Savan these explains that pawns are influenced by the Arisen’s thoughts at that moment, in his case his pawn looks very much like his dead father. Another example is the rich backstories that were written for a number of characters, these can be found online preserved on the wiki. One of the most interesting characters that exemplifies my issues is Feste, a jester, he is a liar and a trickster, his backstory is very interesting, but this did not translate into the game perfectly. If you pay attention, hear his optional dialogue and see what he does in an empty throne room you would notice that there is more to him than your first impression, but a lot of people would never bother. It is a shame but ultimately this is a result of scaling down, cuts or troubled development and not the fault of the audience.

[h1] Presentation [/h1]
One of my favourite things about [i]Dragon’s Dogma[/i] is the sense of scale. You travel vast distances and you can look back and [i]see[/i] how far you have come, it gives a sweet feeling of accomplishment for something as mundane as traveling, it is one of my favourite games for feeling like I am on a journey.
This sense of scale also extends to other things , Gran Soren is a great city and it feels a lot bigger than it is, and the enemies! They are big and they feel big, climbing around on a cyclops to reach the eye is awesome, so is mounting a griffin clinging desperately as it tries to fly away or being flung left to right on a serpent. I genuinely love it.

Another highlight is the character creator it is quite robust and gives you a number of options to create nice looking characters or simply just decent ones (I am bad at character creation), there are images detailing how to recreate various people and characters such as Geralt and Ciri from the Witcher. As in most games the endgame is fashion and you do get a lot of cool looking equipment, and capes! Never forget the capes! There are also nice smaller details such as helmets being opened when you are in safe areas, characters' lantern affixing animation, or the several knights each with their own coat of arms.
What I especially like with the creator is the ability to change the height and weight of characters because that is so very rare, it also has some slight effect on gameplay which is cool but also annoying as you might expect.
Same could be said for the voice options, some of them are pretty good but you will hear them a lot since your pawn will give a lot of advice, so you should make sure not to select one that sounds obviously pitch shifted, but that is hard to do when all you can hear in the character creator is grunts.

The music is another great aspect of [i]Dragon’s Dogma[/i] and its expansion [i]Dark Arisen[/i]. I really like the recurring motif but also that each major enemy has their own theme, it sounds great and there is a lot of versatility to it, with drums, guitars, and various vocals. A fairly frequent track like [i]End of the Struggle[/i] never fails to send dopamine into my brain. Perhaps I would not this name if my favourite OST of all time, but it is certainly up there, especially the vocalised tracks like [i]Eternal Return[/i] or [i]Coils of Light[/i].

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
I believe it's fair to say that most people like [i]Dragon’s Dogma[/i] for the gameplay, I do love the combat, and frankly I find all vocations fun to play, but as I hope I've made clear I find other aspects enjoyable too.
Nevertheless, combat is most of what you will be doing when you are not exploring, and it is awesome. Enemies require and use different tactics making them all different experiences even when they have other similarities, and your pawns slowly accrue knowledge and become better at fighting them, sometimes, this is mostly voice lines, but mages in particular are often best at utilising elemental weaknesses. However, you will be using other players’ pawns or pre-made ones to fill out your party, and you should be switching them out frequently on low levels, which means their actual bestiary knowledge will vary.

Clearly, it is great to climb big monsters to go after their weak spots, or to get them to claw off their own armour but that is not where all the fun lies. Using ‘Arc of Deliverance’ as a Warrior is tons of fun with some slight planning you can get off massive hits, and one-shot most of the story bosses, but that is like the only fun skill they get lol. 
Magic is more fun since there is a lot of diverse spells, grabbing enemies is cool, lightning whip is cooler and so is GIANT ICE TENDRILS. 
My very first character was an assassin and, yes climbing, but archery is also great, especially with exploding arrows, and so is the kicking. But there is certainly a vocation for everyone so you should try them out and find what you like best, equipment will be most of your damage so try not to bother about stats if it is your first playthrough.

As for quests, they are often an excuse to do combat. Such as notice boards with bounties, these are completely optional but give some nice rewards, maybe you do want to hunt a Griffin anyways, so might as well get a guaranteed reward for it, or perhaps you are going north so why not bring the NPC where they want to go? Fear not though, NPCs respawn after a few days, but they remember what you did... For a while. You can also give them the petrified heart of your predecessors and they will probably recover from death. 
Unfortunately, the actual side quests are rarely much better than the bounties, there are a few that could be considered interesting but generally they are simple affairs, fetching items or committing treason, that sort of thing. The best ones are questline associated with specific characters but since certain quests fail when you progress through the main story it can be easy to miss stuff on your first playthrough, as I myself did.  
It is worth remembering that you should not fight a losing battle, which was emphasised more pre-[i]Dark Arisen[/i]. Now you can teleport back to Gran Soren whenever you want instead of needing to plan around your return voyage and only being able to teleport on rare occasions. This and most players instinct of fighting everything the first time they see it can cause problem especially early on as they head towards Witchwood, or they can do what I did and fight until they win. Either way works, if you are having fun.

Dragon's Dogma is a game that I enjoyed immensely, especially for its combat mechanics, vocations, story and how it still holds up to most games ever released since 2010. The game is an open-world action RPG that lets you create your own character and choose from nine different classes, each with their own skills and abilities. You can also recruit up to three companions, called pawns, who will assist you in your quests and battles.

The combat system is one of the best aspects of the game, as it is fast-paced, dynamic and satisfying. You can use various weapons, spells and items to fight against a variety of enemies, from goblins and bandits to giant monsters and dragons. You can also climb on larger foes and target their weak points, which adds a lot of strategy and excitement to the fights. The game also features a day and night cycle, which affects the difficulty and appearance of the enemies, as well as the availability of certain quests and events.

The vocations are another highlight of the game, as they allow you to customize your character and play style. You can choose from three basic vocations: Fighter, Strider and Mage, and later unlock six advanced vocations: Warrior, Ranger, Sorcerer, Mystic Knight, Assassin and Magick Archer. Each vocation has its own strengths and weaknesses, as well as unique skills and equipment. You can also switch vocations at any time, and level up each one separately, which gives you a lot of freedom and flexibility.

The story of the game is intriguing and engaging, as it revolves around the Arisen, a chosen one who has to face the Dragon, a mysterious and powerful creature that threatens the world. The game has a lot of lore and history, as well as interesting characters and factions, that make the world feel alive and immersive. The game also has multiple endings, depending on your choices and actions throughout the game, which adds a lot of replay value and consequences.

The game is also impressive for its graphics and sound, as it still looks and sounds great, even though it was released in 2012. The game has a realistic and detailed art style, with beautiful landscapes, environments and lighting effects. The game also has a superb soundtrack, composed by Tadayoshi Makino, Rei Kondoh and Inon Zur, that matches the mood and atmosphere of the game. The game also has a good voice acting, with a diverse cast of actors and accents, that adds a lot of personality and charm to the game.

Overall, Dragon's Dogma is a game that I highly recommend to anyone who loves action RPGs, as it offers a lot of fun, challenge and depth. The game has a lot of content and features, such as crafting, upgrading, exploring, questing and more, that will keep you entertained for hours. The game also has a loyal and active fan base, as well as a sequel and an anime adaptation, which shows how popular and beloved the game is. Dragon's Dogma is a game that deserves a lot of praise and recognition, as it is one of the best games of its genre and generation.

I went into this game fully blind and was presently surprised by this. I was assuming it was going be a janky mess akin to older Monster Hunter games but the game feels fantastic and its very clear that a lot of the improvements in game design Capcom made here went into Monster Hunter World.

The overall setting, story and gameplay is just fantastic as well its a very unique take on the fantasy genre while also wearing its influences with pride as well. My biggest issues with the game is I wanted more to explore but after about the 20th hour I've already explored the majority of the map. Overall a solid experience especially for the under 5 bucks I paid, easily a 9/10.
