Dragon's Dogma is a strange game full of jank and is missing a lot of QoL you would expect, but it's a game that grows on you because of the things it does differently. It's very much a Japanese take on a Western RPG mechanically. 

To get the bad out of the way, there is no lock on system, and if you aren't a Strider there is no rolling either. Fast traveling is fairly limited, even with this edition having an reusable fast travel item there are relatively few fast travel points... not that all of that is bad.

That is a great point to transition into what's unique here, you get to set some of your own fast travel points. Choose wisely. The pawn system is unique, you can summon other player's pawns to help you out and the players get rift crystals for you using them, win/win. It's a neat way to make the game feel like a cooperative experience, especially summoning friend's pawns. There is 0 cost for summoning a pawn of your level or lower, or your friend's pawn regardless of level which can lead to fun moments summoning in help much stronger than you, thanks college friends that apparently played Dragon's Dogma at one point. 

Overall it's an enjoyable game, not the best balanced (looking at you Magick Archer) but you probably won't hit major walls once you get rolling if you adapt to the enemies you are dealing with.. until Bitterblack Isle (content added in Dark Arisen as post-post game content).

Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen is probably one of the most gameful games ever gamed. Often [i]role-playing games[/i] let you express yourself through choices in the story that influence how your character is perceived in the game world through dialogue options or how you complete a quest; but I have never played another game that puts so much emphasis on the "action" aspect of an "action-rpg", where you can also express yourself through the combat, in a very awesome and flashy way of doing so. There are so many mechanics that allow this, from the way enemies behave to the way pawns also aid you through the journey.
Also, pawns! They're the best AI companion I've ever encountered in a game, you can customize them with looks, gear, actions and even their manner of interacting, being shy, agressive, confident, along with a few other options. They're far from perfect, though, as the developers intended them to resemble actual humans, and humans are dumb. As you progress through the story, they'll pick up on some of your habits and even mimic some of your actions, you can of course also set your main pawn with different inclinations that'll make them more active or more passive, depending on their vocation or role you want them to play in your party.
There aren't many vocations to chose from, but each feel very unique in their own way to play, even if they do share some commonalities among them. There isn't much balance to find here, as you will ultimately find, all vocations are, in fact, OP.
Want to i-frame your way through everything? Fighter is your vocation. Want to support your party with buffs and healing? Mage is your vocation. Want to quickly and swiftly dispose of enemies with style? Strider is your vocation. My personal favorite is Ranger, I'm always social distancing and dealing with trouble from afar, if anything ever touches me, I can just instant reset and walk it off. Never has any game with ranged combat felt so good. About the story? Well, it mainly bogs down to choice, it's your choice to become an Arisen, it's your choice what to do with that and if you'll take the responsabilty or just the power that it brings.
My personal favorite high fantasy game. Pawn dialogue can be a bit repetitive but that is the only flaw I personally find with this game.

And if your mage is completely fire magic based, there is no way to change spells since dragon is immune to fire. I tried my best but after several attempts the potions always run dry so you always have no more stamina and no more healing left.

And about crafting - every time you want to craft some healing or stamina potion you have to really remember which potions are for healing/stamina since game never tells you what effects of potions are being crafted. And you have to run over whole crafting materials inventory every single time for finding what you want to craft.

+Fun quests.
+Good enough story.
+BEST ADVANCED character customization one could ask for. (a perv like me might have wanted bigger tits for females :), maybe not you?)
+Fun combat with lots of skills and abilities.
+Vocations/classes to swap from freely. 
+Good boss fights that you can tackle hard or easy (with meta).
+Farming that is fun,
+Pawn system that is fun yet not. I still like it, yet today it's a fresh idea.
+Climbing system, climb on an enemy and go stabby.
+Pawns learning more and more, and by other pawns.
+Many different enemies.
+Portal crystals that you drop and can teleport where bloody ever you want, how hard can it be? Still amazing because so few games give you that freedom.
+There are chests just about everywhere that can be of use to you, exploration value = high
+quests and actions matters,some quests have to be done in order to get different items, and you can restart whole game to get the other items, how many times as you like
+hard mode = master mode
+character customization will become freely changeable after completion, you can change it how many times you want, for you and your main pawn.
+dlc offers a lot of content that can even prove a bit challenging at max level
+mods, I use a mod that helps me with a lot of things in a normal good way, no stamina drain while running, more inventory and no scar on body, popular mod, choose your version. 

-no real in built ultra widescreen support, I don't really cry that much about it, the blacks on the sides is something i get used to fast.
-chests have always same drops, some chests you have to loot forever and ever, I would have liked more tier chests more, or such. farming one chest over and over is a bit boring. Kingdoms of amalur did this good I think.
-I really loved the fashion in this game and it will never be enough, more fashion, even if it has a lot I want more!

This is my game of all times. Might be mad but even if this game has little to or next to nothing to do with might and magic 7 (not hereos), they are competing for the title. Somehow that old game just have a feeling no other game have.

Also another minus is: -add save slots so we don't have to create multiple fake steam accounts for reruns. THANKS!

A few tips btw:
Inclinations:
*Attack pawns you would generally want Scather and Utilarian or mitigator.
*Healer pawns you want medicator, if they are guardian medicator they will rarely do damage and just heal and support, which can be quite nice in beginning but medicator for healers! 
*You can buy these potions to change your pawns inclinations at the camp, where you first got your main pawn.
*No need to min max, especially not first playthrough, just enjoy, you can't fail! Still it's not advicable to level up as mage or magick archer at all.
Rusted weapons (the starter gear) can become GOD tier once upgraded because it they make/cause enemies to move and attack slower and few enemeis are resistant to it.
*Kill even low experience monster you see, lower experience monster gives more vocation experience. So you max out it faster etc. Once you got all vocations and augments you can skip them.
*The game is harder in beginning, so kill lots of stuff!
*Enemies have hitboxes, if you hit a dragon in the face he may drop a horn, if you hit its claw it may drop.. a claw.

More tips:
Fournival is the best romance options, if you play for practical causes, he is a bit of a pain to find post game so having him as your spouse will make him stay at your home and you can find him easily!
UR(offline) dragon sucks at lower levels. Just a large boss fight who takes up time and the one thing you may want is the weapons from it. So better kill it almost dead - leave area and make a checkpoint save by resting and then kill it over and over until you get your weapons.
UR(online) has some gear I wanted to try for fashion but there is no way in hell that I have the patience for that. I read if you deal too much damage it registers none and yada yada, and it just seems like a clusterfuck of an idea. Fire the guy who did that and make UR online to work as offline! Anyway no real reason to do that dragon either, it just has some cool fashion I think, kinda sucks though but I don't have patience for such crap.

Improvements I wish to see in DDA and Dragon's Dogma 2 are:
-Faster incantations for mage classes and-/or have a quick fighting side weapon as a wand or such to fight a little more quickly like a fighter. Running around focusing bolting gets a bit annoying. 
-A clock to tell time, map button, quick keys more consumables, up to 10? Make food heal over time as insta heal is "a bit" OP, or have a you're full meter, forcing people to play more safely and wise.
-To search for pawns after inclinations, have a set of types, not 3 types of inclination. Defensive healer, Offensive Healer. protective tank, offensive tank, bit worse but more aggressive and deals damage. Just an idea. When going for pawns it's inclinations and certain buffs/spells that can be desirable.
-Two-handed weapon attacks should be increased, maybe reduce the damage to balance it but not so rarely do enemies just easily run away from your swing as you're slow as hell. If one wanted the assassins skill gale harness anywhere it would be for the warrior class.
-I would have wanted to level as a mage healer for a while but the stats growth is so bad and I am a bit of a min/max player which makes it nearly impossible for me to do it. At higher levels I doubt that idea is even fun. I should probably try it anyway sometime.
-I want the duplicate system gone, as much as it pains me to say this, but I think it would be funnier to force us to go out farming than running back and forth in Gran Soren. I like the idea that we can duplicate certain quest items like the wyrm king's ring. If you want it, pay up!
-MOST OF ALL a transmog system and to remove helmet visually through it as well.

*Have fun and play with moderation - not that I do :)

It is a very well-made action RPG. The combat is amazing. Each combat skill has a purpose. Each enemy has unique combat mechanics and animations, that you can observe and learn to better defeat them. Even if it is an action game, it has a tactical layer to it, which I have not often seen in this genre. The closest comparison would probably be Elden Ring, also it takes some inspiration from games like Monster Hunter, and Shadow of The Colossus. When you mention this games when talking about Dragon's Dogma, you know you are in for a great experience.

Fantastic gameplay, fun vocations that dramatically change how you play the game based on what you pick, story needs a little work but the amount of fun you can have just running around killing different monsters is unmatched. Also the optional revealing armors is a plus for me.

FOR ANYONE HAVING TROUBLE WITH THE "FAILED TO CREATE SAVE" ERROR:

1) Uninstall Dragon's Dogma
2) Restart your PC
3) Use task manager to make sure steam is completely shut down
4) Launch steam as administrator
6) Reinstall Dragon's Dogma
7) Use task manager to make sure steam is completely shut down again
8) Launch steam as administrator again
9) Launch Dragon's Dogma
10) Cross your fingers and pray to whatever deity you so please
11) Attempt to create a new game

This is what worked for me and now I can actually play the game. I cannot guarantee this will work for everyone else. You might need to restart your pc again after reinstalling the game. From the 10 or so minutes I have played, it looks enjoyable.

Hope this helps!

[quote] Love RPG? [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/39973073/]Make sure to Follow my Curator Page[/url] for plenty more! [/quote]
Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen is a monumental triumph in the realm of fantasy RPGs. Its breathtaking world, teeming with mythical creatures and intricate lore, sets the stage for an unparalleled adventure. The innovative pawn system adds a layer of strategic brilliance to the intense combat, making each encounter a thrilling challenge. With its vast open world, mesmerizing visuals, and a storyline that leaves an indelible mark.

GOOD:
✔️Deep and Engaging Combat: The game features a complex and satisfying combat system, allowing for strategic encounters with a variety of mythical creatures.
✔️Pawn System: The innovative pawn system enhances gameplay, providing a unique twist to party dynamics and strategic decision-making.
✔️Expansive Open World: Dark Arisen offers a vast and beautifully crafted open world, encouraging exploration and discovery.
✔️Mythical Atmosphere: The game successfully creates a mythical and immersive atmosphere with its rich lore, fantastical creatures, and atmospheric design.
✔️Enduring Challenge: The difficulty and challenges in the game provide a rewarding experience for players who enjoy overcoming formidable foes.

BAD:
❌Outdated Graphics
❌Repeatable quests
❌Sparse Storytelling: While the game's lore is rich, the main storyline may feel sparse at times, leaving some players yearning for a more deeply woven narrative.

Oooooooohhh, this game is my baby.
I remember playing it ages ago on PS3 and immediately getting hooked (even more so than Skyrim). This game had features that no other game had ever implemented and TO THIS DAY, I have yet to find a game that even attempts (or at least is able to properly execute) some of the ingenuity this game applied so well (and this game is over a decade old)

So, of course, the opportunity to play it again on PC? SIGN ME UP. 

I’m gonna try and make this quick. Firstly, [b]the graphics[/b] look great, the game is gorgeous and definitely holds up to this day, and it runs like a dream on PC so no complaints there. Second, [b]the story[/b] was honestly never WOW but it's also not too bad, mostly interesting characters with a decent plot. But given most of the plot is given through in-game dialogue and since the animations for said dialogue honestly kinda sucks (almost getting oblivion vibes), it's kinda hard to get really invested. There are cut-scenes and they are awesome, but again, it was still a little hard to get really invested in the story. Don't get me wrong here though, this game's main villain (and subsequent villains) are amazing, you really do feel their impact and they were very well executed.

Buuut, story-shortcomings aside, the main star here is [b]The Gameplay[/b]
Spot on gameplay, super fun. You’ve got 9 classes (the game calls them “Vocations”), 3 basic ones you start with and 6 hybrids from the 3 basic ones. They all play incredibly different and are suuuper fun, give them all a try. And just a give a little sneak peak, you can go from epicly climbing massive beasts, striking weak points and severing limbs, to strategically taking them on from a distance with arrow-fire, to barrelling through with heavy weapons, to just absolutely OBLITERATING with insane spells (and I mean INSANE spells).

Wanna know what's great about progression in this game? [b]No skill trees, no tedious menus[/b]. The only thing you have to worry about Character-wise as you level up is what special ability or vocation you wanna try next. THAT'S IT. The game will adjust everything else for you based on how you play. Just play the game, the game will handle the rest. If you really wanted to though, you could totally nerd out on stats because certain armor pieces and weapons blend really well with certain vocations and abilities, but that's totally optional.

Guess what, the same applies for your companions (or "pawns" as the game calls them). You have one main pawn that always stays with you (which you get to fully customize along with yourself, and by the way, your size, height, and muscularity matters in this game) and then you can choose two other pawns that other people made. And guess what, you don't have to go through tedious options and menus to set your AI companion’s playstyle and skills because the way companions are handled in this game is genius. Other than choosing their vocation and special abilities, you don’t have to do anything, [b]they will learn everything they need to know by watching you fight.[/b] "Monkey see, monkey do" style babyyy.

I know, [b]genius[/b] and it baffles me that no other game (in my experience) has been able to pull off a better companion system and this game is [b]OVER A DECADE OLD[/b]

The very best action RPG from 10 years ago!  underapppreacited but this game is great and despite the age on it, its aged like a fine wine! This game is awesome super excited for the sequel! Highly suggest playing this one until that one comes out. 

The endgame content in this game is insane you've got tons and tons of content ! The main story is cool a bit of a grind at times. Honestly go buy this game its on sale right now! see for yourself! 

The class system is 3 different classes (warrior, mage, archer) but then you can also mix them. Want to be a warrior with a bow, a mage with a knife, an archer with a staff? sure! In total 9 classes. 

The customization is pretty straight forward and I was impressed with the amount of stuff you are going to have! Each armour set is beautiful and their is a fine line between looking cool and having good armour stats. Luckily, any innkeeper will let you deposit your extra goods with them so you can horde to your hearts content!

The 1 downside in this game which I hope is improved upon in the next game is the combination of items mechanic, its kind silly having to just try each combination of items without knowing if it will succeed like a tree branch with a oil flask to make a torch.  I would love to find recipes for crafting stuff out of random items instead, and you could even add in weapons or armour schematics that you can find and then craft from these random items and monster parts like a cyclops bone for a melee club.

A real gem of a game. Sort of a blend between Skyrim and Dark Souls. It's its own unique thing, and does not disappoint. Truly a feeling of a bygone era of video games when developers were testing new ideas.

This game definitely has a healthy amount of clunkiness and jank, but there's so much personality in the world and the combat is some of the most tactile and satisfying that I've ever played. Nothing quite compares to the fights against the cyclopes, griffons, and dragons in this game. It's part Shadow of the Colossus, part Dragon Age.
By the end of the game, you might find yourself weary of the same-y environments and cumbersome inventory management, but you'll have had a damn good time on your jounrey, and you'll have at least a half-dozen voice lines stuck in your head for the rest of eternity, Arisen.

This game is a must-play, you have to experience the pawns, combat, and its amazing classes. Cant wait for #2!

[b] Pros : [/b]
- The pawns were a cool idea with a deep AI system behind it. The fact the pawn's behaviors change based on your actions is cool enough!

- The combat & classes were some of the best I had ever seen in a game. Playing as a magic archer was a lot of fun and felt awesome. The combat is 10 out of 10. if you want a game where the combat feels and looks great this is the one. And you have so many classes to choose from, all with unique play styles that really keeps things fresh.

- Dragons! The main villain (who is a dragon) is so menacing.

[b] Cons:[/b]
- The story was trash. Didn't make sense half the time, or just wasn't explained well enough half the time. When I beat the game I didn't really care because I didn't care about the story. Thankfully the game play is good enough to make you want to keep playing.

- Too many pointless fetch quests. about mid-game, the story just falls off and get super weak and you're just running around doing a quest that feels like they have no connection to anything.

- No fast travel till later on and even then, its an item you have to buy. There are also no mounts. That got annoying fast especially when you were constantly trekking across wide open fields.

Dragon's Sugma

A game where the writers failed to address the questions that arise when a player decides to look past the shallow veneer of the game. The authorial opportunities that pawns present into the game are completely overlooked. They simply are. Not once can you discuss the world or ask what your pawn thinks about their self or the wide world. There are only canned lines to give them the semblance of personality.

The world has no eco-system, there was no time spent thinking about the world-building. It's entirely gameified for the player to constantly engage in repetitive combat. Goblins and wolves roam populated roads and represent an existential threat to civilization. Pawns roam the world like lost neglected robots. Other characters in the world are one-dimensional plot-devices for the player to go on quests with them so that you may have one whom you have helped the most and are utilized in the final quest as your 'beloved.'

The game is a master class in how to create a thoughtless story and plot. Its game-play was novel at release. The directors have no vision for creating a thought-provoking or profound story. They have no original world-building ideas to create a world that could exist, only one that exists to serve the player.

I've played 2000+ hours across XBOX 360 and PC. This is my favorite game of the seventh generation over the likes of Dark Souls, Skyrim and Mass Effect which is a close second. Is it perfect? No. There are a number of glaring flaws such as its obviously rushed and unfinished nature which permeates the world building and storytelling but despite this the gameplay shines through in a way that I have rarely seen. The Pawn system is the best AI companion system of any game ever made. This is one of the few games that actually makes you feel like part of a party that is equally capable to you. There are layers to the pawn system and those must be understood to get the most out of it but once you understand those nuances your pawns can be just as effective at handling threats as you can . The moment t moment gameplay is amazing and the large monster fights can only be compared to one of this game's spiritual predecessors, Monster Hunter. Without rambling too long I have nothing but endless praise for this game as it has a myriad ways of playing and even after seeing everything a dozen times it is still a blast to play. It definitely has the charm of older generations of games which while not 100 hour sprawling epics could still be played for hundreds and thousands of hours based on the enjoyment of the gameplay alone.
I've probably played through this game twice on console and once on PC. It's fantastic every time. Monster Hunter but made super fantasy.

During the attack, he spares the life of a local that was born on a certain day to uncertain parents but not before stealing his Thu'um. This local soon finds out that he is the last Dragonborn. Hands down one of the best games I've ever played. It's probably up there with Borderlands 2 and LittleBigPlanet. Yes, the graphics are starting to show the game's age, but all you really need to fix that is just some reshade/retexture mods and it'll look pretty close to what (at least I think) a PS5 remaster would look like for the game. Only problem is that some of the NPCs might look a little... weird in certain lighting. But besides that, the gameplay is extremely fun, especially since there is 9 different classes you can choose from, and all of them are fun in their own way. Example: Assasin gives you the highest physical attack per level, so if you want to destroy everything in your path, go with that. Or, if you wanna spice things up, you could be a Magick Archer and make all of your arrows lock onto your targets, set yourself on fire, etc. I know I've probably missed a ton of points as to how this is a great game, but this is all I can think of atm. 10/10.

Edit: DD2 just got announced, and I am so f*cking happy rn.

Edit #2: Currently going on a final achievement hunt to 100% this game as sort of a final sendoff before the sequel comes out.

This is an open world game that is quite a 'hell' to complete, for completionist.
Many quests have different outcome or just different interaction that may or may not affect the progression of the game.

"Progression", what I meant by that is how one would experience the game. For main story, it is not affected much. But for availability of certain quests (these become available if some particular previous quest is completed in certain way) and possibility to get certain item (that is "fixed" available during that time but unable to be get because quest is not done in certain way). It may not seems much but there are just so many diverging paths in this game. Need multiple playthrough to get all things covered.

There is also random drop in this game. Which is something I didnot know about until, like, 20 hours(?) in. It is no big deal. But the cooler equipments are behind this randomness.

I apologize for maybe confusing-short writing here. I just complete the game with lenghty gaming session each day, everyday, for under 4 weeks. I need some break.

Dragon's Dogma is, without a doubt, my favorite game ever. 

I've already completed it an handful of times in different platforms, achieved everything again here on Steam as well and it even got better thanks to the addiction of some game/class changing mods that showed me something new too. A lot of new mechanics introduced at its release date were already innovative and interesting: to think that they've passed the test of time, is truly remarkable to me.

So...with that said, I'll immediately start with the obvious downsides that plague the success of this game from the very start.

[h3] Fast Travel [/h3] aka [i]"start walking you fool"[/i]
I've never found it as a weakness, because I really love to explore around in every videogame, but, in the beginning, there was no way to teleport around at all, until you reached a certain point in the story; it was also very limited in numbers and was bounded to where you had placed the teleporting crystals. You had the power to place your own favorite place to teleport to, with every pros and cons that come with it, but later in it got, umh...eased with a bit more choices. It was frustrating at first, but I've found it as a good excuse to acknowledge more and more the landscapes and where enemies roamed around, learning their patterns and where to find the things I needed the fastest way. This was a big turning point for some people, that kept them away from DD.

[h3] Don't Blink [/h3]
Another odd thing is that it's really easy to miss, like...[b] SO MANY THINGS [/b] and side missions if you do not pay attention or you do not explore your surroundings in some specific frames of time; and there is no way to go back, or in some cases it's the opposite. Hope in heavens that your last checkpoint was a couple minutes from where you are now, because you're gonna reload a whole fuckin section that started 45 minutes before you decided to make a guess.

[h3] Dark Arisen [/h3]
Bitterblack Isle (the island where the DD expansion takes place at) is extremely unwelcoming, punishing and gloomy...almost depressing. Some encounters seem unjustifiably impossible even compared to the endgame challenges you get faced with in the base game at first glance (even at a second glance lol), but, if you're leveled up, you're geared for good and you know what you're doing (which is like, the hard part of the game duh), it doesn't feel impossible, just...very, VERY hard to accomplish!

Oh yes, you get to fight [b] SATAN [/b]...and SATAN II as well! Oh and you can also well, you know, [b] CASUALLY WALK INTO THE GRIM REAPER AND LITERALLY KILL DEATH [/b].

[h3] Old Gen, Dated Polygons [/h3]
As the title suggests, yeah...the graphics were another one of those set backs that probably didn't helped at all to lift up the already infamous reputation that the game had among most of the majority of players. Some mods can circle around these old.

Still related to something of an old gen limitation (or probably as an artistic decision, being related to the lore as it is) there is no kind of co-op possibility whatsover, other than the pawns mechanic, leaving people wondering why in such a co-op dictated combat system, a thing like this got overlooked in favor of something else. Performance issues where a lot more consistent back in 2010-2011, so, it was for the best experience I believe.

So:
[b] 1] [/b] No real freedom of fast travelling in a vast world filled with dangerous encounters.
[b] 2] [/b] Very missable side quests, which means less money, equipment and deadly weapons.
[b] 3] [/b] Easily one of the hardest (yet most satisfying) DLC/expansion ever released.
[b] 4] [/b] Graphically outdated even for its time.

With that aside...

Dragon's Dogma, for me, can easily boast [b] the best [/b] action-paced combat system ever created for a videogame, way too engaging to be skipped because of the aformentioned issues, and the main reason why you should also play it! The freedom, the possibilities and the verticality that you can create while fighting any kind of monster is unprecedented, even to this day. You really feel like an important piece of a medieval-fantasy party going for the most epic bounty quest ever when the soundtrack kicks in and you're grappled into a giant hawk flying you towards your impending doom, and it delivers every time something really big and dangerous approaches your path. It's surely pointed towards a much more mature audience than other games in the same genre, with its dark themes and story, its grim creatures and the feeling of being completely lost and having to go on foot for the next fifty minutes back to where you were supposed to be, BUT, it's a damn journey that you have to try and endure at, in order to truly appreciate what Dragon's Dogma has to offer.

You must buy it, like, now, [i] or else [/i]...
Good
I never thought I would live long enough to see a "Elden Ring Killer", but I was wrong, that game already existed long before its creation and it's Dragons Dogma.

Listen. I know it looks kind of like Dark Souls. It is not Dark Souls.
This plays like an action game with swords and sorcery and dragons.
Yeah. Dragons are definitely involved.

The key difference? Dark Souls wants to make you feel weak and miserable.
Dragon's Dogma wants you to feel like a badass. On that I can say it delivers.
It's over a decade old, so it's rough around the edges, for sure. But a fun ride till the end.
And if you're left wanting more? Check out the sequel coming out in 2024.

Dragon's Dogma shines with its action fighting mechanics, its innovative "pawn" ally system, and its story driven quests in a world that is fun to explore. There are a few setbacks of confusingly marked quests, age old full inventory problems of many rpgs, and constant retracing on foot, but it is incredibly worth sticking with this game to see where the Main quest leads.  The normal game is not difficult, but I was surprised how large the end game and the Bitterback DLC area extended beyond the main quest, and it re-calibrated my understanding that this game does have quests for Higher Leveling and Gear Enhancements, and more in depth Strategies.

GREAT ACTION
Dragon's Dogma has stellar, action fighting dynamics, where you hack, shoot, cast spells, and can even climb up large beasts like Spider Man to hit their weak spots. The creatures you encounter in the regular travels are well known mythical creatures, like goblins, harpies, wolves, while there are fantastic the large creatures that can be in the regular paths are amazing to see in this game such as griffins, cyclops, and dragons.  The battles with the large creatures are epic and chaotic, and can be fairly forgiving without very many deaths if you are decently leveled.  It relies on a fun team of three computer assisted "pawns" that aid your fight using their own AI battling.  You need to build an interchangeable team of various skills and spells to take on the adventures ahead.

PAWNS
Your team of Pawns is a very welcomed accompaniment on your journeys, since they are your Computer Assistants who help you fight, cast spells, and pick up items independently of you.  It can get a little chaotic to reign them in as they run off to a fight, or open lots of item containers like a kid opening presents, but they mostly work very well and feel like a great team.  
Pawns are a large focus of the game since to aid your main character, you always keep 1 pawn that you created, but the other 2 pawns you will constantly replace with stronger pawns as you level up because they will not level up.
The inventive feature of the Pawn system is that many pawns are copies of other another players' pawn and you borrow a copy of that pawn, and at the same time your 1 pawn that you created is also available for other players to use a copy. It is really a neat long distance connection to other players, and you can gift an item back to the pawn's owner when you release a copy of their pawn.

WORLD MOOD
The game has a charm and levity as your company of pawns speak all the time in encouraging and optimistic ways, but that levity is smashed by the darker world, such as the opening scene of the Dragon taking your heart, or the Duke's crazed mind and his messed up wife, or live sacrifices of the cult, Salvation. It is a strange dichotomy of tone, and seems like the game wants to show the contrast of a safe, friendly town, to a darker world outside.

BOGGED DOWN
Constantly during questing far away on foot, the game is bogged down by issues of full Inventory and you need to keep passing items among your party or dumping items, because you do not know which items to keep. The crafting system is disappointing because although it is well designed, I spent way too much time trying to experiment, and rarely are the economics worth combining ingredients when you can sell those same components to buy the potion that you are trying to create.  I enjoy crafting systems that better profit the player with Gold for taking the time to combine items.  For the early game, Gold is plentiful when you need a few thousand Gold, but items and enhancement upgrades nearer the end game skyrocket to half a million Gold or more, so I was pressing for methods to make Gold.
Exploring in this game did get tedious when you run into the same enemies and return to the same areas over again.  This "Dark Arisen" version of the game gives you an Infinite Warping stone, yet there are still too few warping points, and you will spend the majority of your game time retreading land on foot, and returning to inventory storage locations. You can explore much of the land early in the game, although you can find yourself wondering for hours stopped by mountains and closed obstacles without knowing what you need to progress.

CHALLENGE
Most of the game only lightly challenged my team and barely required the use of counter potions, which was fine because I felt dominant and kept the game fun.  But do not get too comfortable since at one point it surprised me when a dragon in the world cast the spell Possession on my pawn, set Fire to me, and instantly killed my remaining pawns. That was the first time I needed to plan counter potions to battle the ill effects of a beast.  The game is not hard if you level up and carry healing potions, but if you can push ahead there are bigger end-game challenges that need a strategy of potions and spells.


GREAT END - EPIC
I encourage you to push ahead the main Quest and to get to the Dragon who took your heart, since it is a stellar part of the story and I was completely blown away by how it all goes down. I set aside the game a few times because I took my time on the wandering quests, but I am so glad I pressed to the main story to the Dragon. I was level 55, brought a bunch of Spring healing potions, and had no idea what to expect of the fight or how strong I needed to be. It really is a masterful event that pushes beyond the vanilla rpg story of the rest of the game.  

ONWARD
Surprisingly I learned that there is more depth and replay to this game than meets the eye, and that depth welcomes dedicated players to study the game and further test their team. There are tons of weapons, and character builds, and tricks to get better gear.  I ventured a bit into the DLC Bitterback island expecting a small temple but to my surprise it seems to be a vast area, and challenging strategies need to be deployed. I noticed some players online even are past Level 150 while venturing in the area!  The NORMAL game to me started to stagnate by level 50, although my play continued to around level 90 as I started to have fun re-battling the big beasts, and then venturing further into Bitterback DLC. I was hoping for a definite end to beat the game, but you seem to have some flexibility if you want to do Bitterback DLC at any time Lvl 1 and/or even if you continue to NewGame+.  This was a great game and at times invigorating in the journey, if you can get past the searching and wandering, and find a way to complete the Normal game, it is an incredible journey.  Bitterback DLC looks like a great bonus to test more advanced players.

I am excited to eventually try Dragons Dogma 2 (maybe wait a year or so) and see if a new journey will provide renewed engagement in this flavor of an action RPG.

TBH, the main game to me is a mixed bag (6.5/10) because it has so much charm but you can't help feeling like it missed a few tricks in places. There's a lot more going on than it appears and little handholding. It does a good (but not perfect) job of making every class viable throughout the game, with assistance from NPC comrades (pawns) that you can USUALLY rely on.
The additional area to Gransys, Bitterblack Isle, is where the game really starts to get compelling (8.5/10) (and feels more like dark souls lol), I really enjoyed that. 

General Pros:
* The character customisation is great (9 available classes to mix and match with, including MAGE = average magic + healing and SORCERER = no healing + insanely OP elemental spells (had lots of fun with MAGIC ARCHER's ricochet shots too after my magic stat got high). This game has incredible magic attacks, but I do wish you could mix and match a bit more (I would sacrifice 1 or 2 (but not the best ones!) elemental attacks to keep healing ability!)
* The soundtrack is very memorable and the atmosphere with it = spot on to an open world, fantasy locale.
* It feels like armours (many are per similar class) have generally not that much stat difference between them (weapons absolutely do though), so you can do 'fashion souls' if you like and not be penalised too badly for it!
* Your steam friends' pawns can be max level (200) and cost 0 rift points to help you out, so if you're really stuck on a boss, you might have a lifeline in them!
* With little handholding, the map has a real feeling of being left to explore. Infact, it's not actually that big of a map (nothing like Elden ring for example) and dungeons/zones are often copy-pasted with only slight variations to be honest (it doesn't stand out too badly), but it does FEEL bigger than it is and the enemy varieties within them are always good.
* The over the top, massive boss battles are done so well in this game. Hydras, Griffins, Manticores, Beholders, Dragons and all their variations for DAYS.

Cons/thoughts:
* Your helper NPCs (pawns) are fun to listen to, but they're not always helpful in combat (even with pawn elixirs meant to outright set their 'mode' (scather/challenger/mitigator etc and nor even after training them with 'come' and 'go' commands all the live long day. Perhaps you can rely on them less as a strength build yourself, but as a spellcaster, ideally you want them to distract enemies so you can be the glass cannon, and sometimes they take your evasive/clever positioning as a cue to stare into space lol
Hopefully a sequel allows for more precise pawn commanding (like 'open that chest with a maneater in it for me, please' lol)

*The Main story quests (sidequests are a little more involved) repeatedly caught me off guard for how quick/easy they were. (More a bad thing than good). They're over SO quickly! Am I saying they're too easy? Not necessarily, some quests can be a good challenge on the journey and they do all mesh well with a narrative, but equally they seem very short. It's also very easy to miss main quests because you did another, and without any warning, making the 'Hero' achievement rarer, though you can finish them up in NG+.

*I also don't think we really spend anywhere near enough time on character development and even the Duke/members of court would have benefitted from more interaction/storytime, so characters can feel a bit hollow. Lots of facial expressions, little meaningful dialogue lol 
In dark souls fashion, since cutscenes are rare and characters quite 1 dimensional, I think the game could do with lore snippets here and there to fill it out at least (like item description stuff).

*The system of being able to pay a specific price to duplicate almost EVERY ITEM in the game (usually without any consequence lol) is strange but a def positive (encourages getting coin to keep doing it, to then upgrade weapons and armour fully etc).
Noteworthy, but the game can also get a bit grindy (for specific loot etc) in the same area which might put some people off. You also only find a few of the teleport crystals your first time around so you might have to teleport to main cities instead and do a bit of a trek. 

* I admit in the beginning, I found the mechanic of some items (food and some plants) perishing after not that long to be quite intimidating. (You have to buy and combine them with airtight flasks). Not very important mid to late game, but in the beginning when it's all you have or items need to stay fresh for a sidequest, and you do might need to keep an eye on this.

It also has a bizarre saving system of 'checkpoints' whenever you rest/sleep which is your ACTUAL checkpoint and any saves (or autosaves) can be loaded but equally you can undo everything you've done back to your last sleep e.g. if you bumped into an NPC and made them not like you lol (Yes, there's a questionable NPC-likeability mechanic and you can give people presents!).
It also doesn't say, but I think there's like a 7 day ingame timer where killed/angry NPCs and certain items/enemies will respawn as if nothing happened. Go figure!

* There are a few 'Metal Golems' in the game. They can be killed by hitting their medallions scattered around the level to whittle down its health. Absolutely no problem for a warrior/fighter who can reach them, or a bow user strider/archer who can shoot them and do physical damage...but mage? sorcerer? magic archer? it becomes a real slog trying to hit them and doing next to no damage with predominantly magic dmg attacks that only have minor physical dmg on top of them. "Throwable bombs" or "respec temporarily" here, it might have to be!

*Fall damage is a bit silly lol Levitating at the end of dropping from a not-that-high fall should prevent you falling flat on your face but it doesn't :(

===BBI===
Bitterblack Isle REALLY elevates the game beyond the falling and grinding in the Everfall.
Definitely a huge plus for fans of dark souls and it requires the same kind of persistence to get through.
You don't dare go there until you're either very sneaky or at least around lvl 60, and even then it will be a challenge (though you can go whenever you like!) where everything is lethal and trying to kill you - even death!
I know it's just essentially another dungeon-crawler separate to the main journey, but the oppressive and haunting atmospheres (sometimes to be greeted by hulking dark abominations spawning in at random) are just a joy to descend deeper into and the rewards (equipment etc) are many (some wpns can be worth millions to sell on if you're in need of cash.). Intensely engaging and rewards persistence.
Masterworks all you can't go wrong.

I'm not sure why I gave up on this game the first few times I tried to play through it (I actually refunded this twice in the past). Somehow, it felt "janky" or "too difficult" or "unrefined". But really, I just needed to put the game on easy, then switch it to normal, and then switch it to hard. Oh, and also, not start as a mage. At some point, everything seemed to click - the combat felt really quite fluid, I knew exactly how to get the best combination of Pawns depending on how I was playing, and I was absolutely smashing every enemy type I came across, even the dragons. 

Then, I found a pretty addictive game loop that I kept coming back to, and before I knew it, I was a good 80 hours in and level 70 - 80, at the endgame, but with still content to do.

At almost 5 bucks on sale, this game is an absolute no brainer; I can see why it did so well in the past when it came out, and I am absolutely looking forward to Dragon's Dogma 2 (hopefully they don't botch it up).

Of course, being an old game, it lacks a lot of quality of life features of modern games, has some poor dialog and narrative direction / storytelling, and really really could do with a horse or unlimited stamina outside combat (although, on this latter point, eventually the portcrystal systems make it such that you can have a teleport location at just about anywhere you choose - you just have to replay parts of the game enough times to amass a sizable number of portcrystals).

[h1]Score: Masterworks all, can't go wrong[/h1]

I've been singing the praises of this game for the longest pf time, and I dearly hope that it gets the sequel it deserves!

[h1]The Good[/h1]
+9 Vocations, each with six (Except warrior, but I'll talk about that later) assignable skills to your primary and secondary weapons. These skills vary from counter spells activated on block, explosive pocket sand, shield spring boards and a life stealing magic bolt called "great sacrifice". Not to mention you get to select from a huge list of augments, both shared and not, and mix and match them to your hearts content. 

+Combat is the bread and butter of this game! It's just fun! Once you reach bitterblack isle, you might find yourself spending time entering and leaving an arena room that respawns unique groups of enemies - I know I did.

+Evil eyes, hydras, cockatrices, wyverns, demons, living armour, death himself and more. This game has an absolutely massive boss variety, all with interesting enough challenges to keep you interested in battling it out. If only the same could be said for the small enemies, which are oft just recolours.
   
+Spells, my god, the spells. If you've ever wanted to send a cataclysmic meteor, or summon a tornado on unsuspecting foes, the magic in this game is for you. It's just beautiful.

[h1]The Variable[/h1]
+/- Massive item variety, almost too great. The game contains pages upon pages of healing items, crafting materials, special items and the like - and has an absolutely huge crafting list... Most of which I was unable to ever make because I hadn't managed to either find the item required, or the drop/find rate was so low, that you never had any in stock. It's variable, because you can literally ignore it. All periapt buffs, all special arrow types and any curatives that will serve can all be bought at some point in the game.

+/- Good items require a massive grind. I like a bit of grinding, and for the most part the game fed me good enough items as the game went along so I wasn't bothered by it, but the moment you're looking to find some special weapon or armour, be prepared for tens of runs giving you nothing but dupes in bitterblack.

+/- The pawns - I love them, but I also hate them, [b] goblins hate ice and fire both [/b]. Don't forget to sit your pawn down in a knowledge chair, ask them to pick up EVERYTHING and shut the hell up while they're at it.

+/- Enemy damage and armour scaling. The damage system works like this: 
Damage = [enemy armour] - [weapon damage + damage type stat]  where Damage<0 = 1
This means that the only thing that truly matters is your gear. Personally, I enjoy seeing my gear vastly improve my performance, but if you overstep your bounds, a boss that should take 5 minutes now can take upwards of 40. 

+/- Equipment load management - When you start the game, you get to choose your height and your weight. Don't be fooled though, your height affects your movement speed (walking, climbing, NOT sprinting) and your weight, which affects your equipment load and stamina regeneration rate. Before deciding these, you should look at the wiki to find what would work best for you. The problem comes from the amount of time you might have to spend in menu's, sending all your monster parts to your pawns after you become overencumbered. Oh, and remember, when depositing items into your item box, remember that you can press "Category" to deposit all of one category, it's really handy. 

+/- The story. Personally, I think the story is acceptable. Some of it makes sense, most of it doesn't. Most of the fun in the game does not come from the story, however.

[h1]The bad[/h1]
-There is a single obligatory escort mission where you have to slowly walk alongside a convoy ferrying a hydra's head. This takes literally 15 minutes. In order to avoid this problem, make sure to summon a healing pawn with anodyne, and [b] Kick. That. Ox[/b]. It makes it go faster, no it's still terrible.  

-The entire Warrior vocation. This vocation gets to use a big eff-off sword, with some really hard hitting attacks. You can charge up an Arc of Deliverance, which is a channel ability with absolutely humongous damage potential, and whose impact representation in-game is fantastic. Wait, right, this is a bad point. Warrior only gets to have three active skills, and most of the skills are borderline unusable against endgame enemies (they don't reach weak points). If warrior had gotten the last three skill slots that it should have, then it would have been fantastic, but as it stands, it cannot compare to any of the other classes. Which brings me to..

-This game felt like it was designed around co-op. You have abilities like springboard, or Ladder blade, whose purpose is to launch an ally onto an enemy for damage, the problem is that your allies can't ever make use of it. Many skills are made redundant because of this lack of foresight.

-Lack of balance in skill selection. Some skills are undeniably better than the rest, and to a ridiculous extent. Attacks like brain splitter, fracture dart, and when combined, instant reset become almost essential for late-game efficiency. The last boss of the game can be permanently stun-locked by just you, and one other pawn, spamming fracture dart. The problem therefore is that many skills that are fun, like foot binder, toss and trigger, dazzle blast, easy kill etc, are not really useful late game.

-Your stats levels are determined by which vocation you were using when you gained a level, this actively discourages you from mixing and matching str/mag vocations, since your endgame character will have a much harder time dealing damage in each of the damage types. 

-Communicating with the pawns - you have only three options, "go", "help" and "come". If only you could equip your melee pawn with springboard, and ask for it. It's ok, I guess...

[h1] Final Verdict [/h1]

This game is great, buy a copy and play it! You'll get, at the very least, a good 20-30 hours from the base game, and if you enjoy farming for better gear, upward 80-120 hours from the bitterblack endgame.
The combat is satisfying, the soundtrack is great, the story is there (???) and there's loads of fun weapon and armour combinations to fashion yourself out with. I highly recommend it. Now that Dragon's dogma 2 has been revealed, one can only hope they improve on the formula.

The combat system in this game is one of the best you could ever find, climbing/grabbing monsters, all vocations(classes) are unique & fun to play, and the day-night cycle is just perfect. Pawn(follower) AI is mind-blowing as they can literally learn from your habit, for example if you likes to loot things even when the fight is still going on then the pawn will later learn and do the same thing, to think this game released 10y ago is just insane. I read that this game is actually only 40% due to budget crisis in the middle of development, and I can really tell with how rushed it is on the later part of the story. And I'd say for an open world rpg this game map isn't really as huge as others, but the perfect day-night cycle implemented really well that it really encourages us to explore. The game has it flaws but the part that they finished are perfect. What I need to say is don't stick with the main quest, do your side quests, take your time with it, because the game feels really short if you stick to main quest too much. Also, LOVES the old English-British accent in this game! This is the best 7/10 game you'll ever find!

Edit: Hundreds of hours in to this game, and I gotta say that this game replayability is just insane. I rarely do NG+ in any games that I played, but I can't stop playing this!
this game came out around the same month as Skyrim, be that the reason it wasnt given it's own limelight. it is a rich and captivating game. can not wait or the 2nd one

If you enjoy Skyrim / Dark souls / elden ring and games alike.

You'll enjoy this!

Pawns are brilliant as you can specialise your character and your pawn and effectively 'hire' other players pawns to assist you with your quests (Can hire up to 2 more pawns to run alongside you and your pawn) 

The Pawn have their own skill set and will develop as the game continues. If you fight plenty of one enemy type your pawn will start to develop their fighting skills to take the enemy out quicker and deadlier.

Equipment is where you have to read what benefits you get out of each piece and that alone is common in many games which falls under the RPG aspect

Character level - You can change what class you want to be and can purchase / level up your move set which would vary between each class. obviously more you level up the more health and damage can be done.

Pawn - Now this aspect they are brilliant and they do aid you in a big way. Your main pawn you want to level up and equip as much as your main guy does due to other 'Arisen' players can hire your pawn (You still get to keep em with you) and every time you go to an inn the other players can send you gifts to you for hire and you would get a load of points to level your guy/pawn up so you can get better skills/move sets

Open world - It isn't as big as Dark souls / elden ring but big enough to have fun in and to explore!

The game has been made a long time ago now but the graphics are good and the gameplay is brilliant. 

I will admit some of the quests is a bit of a snore but some do keep you hooked! I have played solid 4 hours without realising and I've enjoyed it enough to leave a review.

Will update as I go along and if you see my Pawn Violet (Class Strider) do send me some goodies eh? ;)

Cheers for reading!

I felt as if the game was constantly wrestling with itself, trying to be a "move at your own pace" and "figure it out yourself" game, while also featuring points-of-no-return and enigmatic or just outright stupid quest design.

Some quests are great, giving you a rough direction and an estimate of what you need to do and then providing you with the tools to figure it out yourself - explore a dungeon and check out what's happening in there.
And other quests just say something like "Gather evidence (you have 4 days)" which means you either run around talking to random NPCs on the streets for an hour or two, most of which have nothing to say outside of general "What nice weather we have today", or pull up a walkthrough and follow it step by step.
And these are main quests. You can't just skip them because you don't care. 
And even if in theory you can fail them and move on, you will miss out on lore and cutscenes.

The devs knew this and tried to remedy it with the pawn learning system - in theory your companions learn how to complete quests when witnessing other players doing them and can later help you with the more enigmatic quests.
In practice, this mostly doesn't work and the quests that are braindead simple - go to this dungeon and kill this boss - are the only ones that my pawns "helped" with.

At the same time, you can't just say "I'll figure it out later." and do some different quests, beacuse many of them can be failed if they aren't done in time and others are automatically failed after some point-of-no-return.

This is my main problem with the game and the reason I can't bring myself to play it more.

Other than that, many of the systems featured here are great.
I love the vocation system - it allows you do drastically change your playstyle whenever you want and improves replayability.
The pawns are an interesting idea, although 90% of them are females with huge breasts, wearing only underwear.
And I like the overall theme and colourscheme, being more bland and "realistic" than most others in the genre.

But the quests are just too frustrating and boring.

When Dragon's Dogma 2 comes out, I'll probably try it out.
This game had a lot of potential, but just wasn't polished enough.

Overall, I like the idea.
The execution not so much.
if you want to climb a chimera, ogre, cyclops, griffin or dragon and slap it in the face. this is the game for you.

This could have been Capcom's Demon's Souls. There could have been a sub-genre of action adventure games called Dogmalikes. Alas, they've waited 12 years for a sequel.

There is an alternate universe where every developer is trying to recreate pawn mechanics of Dragons Dogma. Making boss fights where instead of hitting the giant enemy between their toes until it's health bar reaches zero, you climb on them, find their weak spots, try to stay on them while it tries to throw you off, chop off their limbs to weaken them. 

It's crazy none off these feels scripted in Dragons Dogma. The sandbox nature of combat flows so naturally that it makes you feel like you are watching a scene from a fantasy action movie but every moment is under your control. 

I was not expecting this game to be this good at all. It was such a delight. Very much recommended.

I wanted to try this game for a while, but having been underwhelmed by a few other open world RPGs and maybe a bit bored of the genre, I was reluctant to cough up the money. Was it really going to be anything special, anything I hadn't seen before? But I took a chance and picked it up recently in the post-Christmas sale. 

Good decision! 

This feels different from any other open world RPG I've played. It's a game that doesn't try to do everything well, but instead really delivers on two or three key elements. The story (so far) is nothing special, the characters are 2D, the script is mediocre, the voice acting is meh, the lip-sync is shoddy, the interface is annoying and the quests are pretty basic. But none of this matters too much, because (a) the world is great to explore and (b) the combat is so much fun.

Other reviewers have gone into the combat in depth. I'll just reiterate what they've said: it's the best I've come across in an open world RPG. And there's a lot of fighting in this game! Cutting down armed bandits, scorching lizard men to death, shooting down harpies, immobilizing giant cyclopes with lightning blasts... It's all good fun, with enough diversity in terms of play-styles and enemy types to keep me engaged.

The game's other great strength is the design of the world and how satisfying it is to explore. It looks great, it's neither too big nor too small, it feels dangerous to get lost in (especially when it gets dark). The game rewards you for exploration but punishes the overly-intrepid. It's a bit annoying that some quests have an intrinsic time limit, though, so exploring at your leisure comes at a cost. 

Recommended, especially if you can get it on sale.

While the game could use some QoL changes with UI, Traversal, Maps; Dragon's Dogma, for being a RPG released in 2012, has some of the best customization and combat in any RPG I've ever played. The game was very ahead of its time, with emphasis on exploration, risk vs. reward combat, pacing with leveling, a unique companion system with Pawns, and exploiting vulnerabilities on enemies big and small. The game both draws and serves inspirations from other titles, like enemy climbing/mantling from Shadow of the Colossus or studying enemies and environments from FromSoft Souls games. It's definitely a title worth picking up, and just in time before Dragon's Dogma 2 releases in 2024.

This game has so many good and fresh ideas. Both in gameplay and in quest design. It's just rough around the edges, probably due to low budget and time constraints. That's why I'm looking forward to the sequel. I just want to talk about 3 main points that the game got so well and it is what makes the game so fresh and original.

[b] Combat / Vocation system: [/b]

This game has many classes that you can play as. And they all change the combat dramatically. The combat is really good. It plays like a good action game.

What's great about it is that you can swap vocations with little cost. If you get bored with one, you can switch to another one. No need to commit to one build throughout the whole game. To be able to switch around builds and experiment is something I'd like in more RPG's.

The day-night cycle actually matters. Things change at night. The enemies change, and it's actually pitch dark. You feel it. It's awesome.

The meat of the combat is fighting many types of big creatures that you can climb on. It's a lot like Monster Hunter. You have to know about each monster's weaknesses to have an edge. You also have to cooperate with your pawns.

[b] Pawn system: [/b]

Pawns are your CPU-controlled party members. You have your main pawn that you build yourself, and 2 others. The other 2 are pawns from other players. You could say this is a [i]strand type[/i] mechanic. Through pawns, the game connects you to other real life players.

Pawns also learn different things as they experience the world; and they help you in many ways, even in quests by giving you quest information. Their knowledge isn't hard coded, though. If they know something, it's because they actually experienced it either in your world or in some other player's.

You could talk about this pawn system for hours so i'll stop here. But it's one of the coolest and most original game mechanics I've seen in an RPG.

[b] Quest design: [/b]

Choices you make actually matter, even in-between quests. NPC's remember what you do. You build a reputation with them throughout the game. All of this contributes to a feeling of immersion and real consequences.

[b] Downsides and final thoughts: [/b]

The game is rough around the edges and there is a lot of jank. The story isn't told very well and it feels rushed at many points. The world sometimes feels not enough populated and rich. Also, you'll be spending too much time running to get to point A to B, due to no mounts and a very limited fast-travel system.

This game just needed more budget and it'd be one of the greatest games ever made. Let's hope they perfect it in the sequel.

This game is a mixed bag. It's tough. It does something wrong for every right.

The good...

Combat is the game. It's a lot of fun. It's very 80's/90's arcade like. Climbing up big monsters is a lot of fun. There's a lot of classes with cool abilities to work between.

The pawn system is fun. You build the right party, and you'll have a lot fun. Customizing your main pawn is a cool addition. 

The class system is really cool with what you can mix from different classes.

Actions have consequences in this game. Doing the right or wrong thing can change the world in unintended ways. Things really matter, and that's rare these days.

This has probably the best day/night cycle in a game I've played since Castlevania 2. Night has different enemies. The lantern only lights up so much, and it can be hard to see enemies. Finding things in the dark can be challenging.

The soundtrack was really fitting.



The ok...

The pawns don't have much use. You can't command them to do what you want.

Excessive amount of pawns exclaiming loudly in slow motion can break up the flow of combat.

The map isn't too big, but you'll be backtracking a lot.

The story is ok. There's a good story there, just poorly told.

The inventory weight limit will have you spending a lot of time micro-managing storage between pawns.



The bad.

The game actually gives you a manual that explains some things. In today's day it's a miracle to even get anything. However, the game fails to explain almost anything outside of the basics to you. You can easily miss most of this game. This is sadly common with the low standards of today's gaming. I miss detailed manuals.

The game design can be poor. I see why so few people bought it, or played past a few hours (very low achievement rates.) The combat is strictly numbers, with no skill. This wouldn't be bad except that early on you may encounter random bandits that are impossible to kill. I imagine this frustrated a lot of players out of the game. The stamina system is terrible for exploring. You will always run out fast.

Overall, I recommend it on a good sale. I spent about $10-15 on it. Worth it.

Dragon's Dogma 2 when

Trying hard to like this game, for me its frustrating to play. Avoid this game if you're a min/maxer or a completionist, or just have OCD like I do. xD

There's an input delay when using controller on the Start screen that I've come loathe. My reason: this game has randomized loot tables. The same chest can give a useless item or highly valued items, depending on RNG. Even in the first village, Cassardis, there are spots to gain gold with possible loot at 100g, 1000g, 3500g, up to 10000g. 

It is absolutely in your favor to meta game by looking up loot tables and save scumming chests. There's even a late game meta known as "godsbaning", where you suicide to cut reload time. You're going to be seeing that start screen A LOT. This takes the joy out of finding a chest, knowing you might spend the next 30 mins reloading or leave with FOMO. Treasures respawn, but so do enemies. Your pawns can also open chests unprompted...

The pawn system is a great and novel, but deeply flawed. The AI is simply lacking. They'll fall off cliffs, throw bombs at you, smash barrels you need to climb up, your mages will cast spells standing out in the open, etc. They'll also learn and change disposition by player action, so every so often you'll need to literally sit them down and have a talk... over and over because Knowledge Chair convos are also randomized. Or if its really necessary, spend rift crystals which may mean spending several hours farming Bitterblack Isle.

Your only other means of controlling your pawns are commands: "Go!", "Help!" and "Come!" I would've liked a basic "Stay" for when I'm trying to stealth. But nope, they've already drawn aggro. This can also make it seem like the game is one long escort quest (which this game also has). It's little wonder many players prefer to play solo. (lol in Mystic Knight)

But you'll want to build your pawn for late game, and occasionally need to borrow pawns from other players. However many pawns out there are from players who played and quit, or players who didnt give thought to pawn build. Obvious joke pawns are also common. And there's no good way to search the pawn directory (and the official Capcom pawn exchange has gone down). So it can take hours to find the right pawn.

Oh, and all the loli and child pawns, although partly due to game design. There's a meta of carry weight vs stamina/mana regen based on the height and weight. Short/light pawns have low carry weight but high regen. You see a lot of mage pawns that are as short as possible, disturbing for obv reasons.

Oh, and as many have mentioned, a single save file! Honestly, I feel like it was done just for "replayability" which otherwise wouldn't be there. On PC its easy to work around by making copies of the save file, but the game's auto save can still make you have to backtrack or just wait for NewGame+. But NG+ would mean replaying through the story, which isn't really DD's strong point? xD

Combat is the reason I've tried to stick with this game. The grapple mechanic is great (except directional control when climbing a monster) - again good but flawed. The vocations are fleshed out have a certain play style but still intuitive enough to regularly swap out. Environments can also be used in combat, either strategically or to player's detriment.

Except for The Brine. The Brine is dumb. Its just a border around the playable area. Invisible walls would've been better. Oh wait, the game has those too. Seriously, you start in fishing village but they cant swim.

All in all, this game has a lot going for it. It's really a matter of how much of the flaws a player is willing to overlook. Dragon's Dogma 2 has been announced and hopefully with improved systems.

The pawn system, and how you can respec your character's vocation almost infinitely while experimenting with every skill and playstyle the game has to offer on a single playthrough is what keeps the gameplay refreshing and fun.

In a genre that often feels stale with the same overused systems, Dragon's Dogma tries something a bit different for a change, and it works quite well.

Combine that with the tight combat system and the very Monster Hunter-ish boss battles and you get a mix of solid features that make for a pretty good action RPG.

The open world, although at times feels a bit empty, is still interesting to explore a little bit.

So Dragon's Dogma, ill admit, when i first knew of this game i wasnt particularly interested in it, but it went on sale so i decided to buy it and give it a try, man, what ive been missing. 

It was better than i though, the world building is great, the fantasy elements are good, the OST is good, the combat system is enjoyable, granted, the game is kinda dated, which is largely noticeable on the Menu and Inventory management.

So lets get to specifics:

Gameplay: 
Overall, the gameplay is good, theres several classes to choose from, each with their own flair, which allow you to customize them with different skills to suit your needs, fighting enemies is enjoyable, since each enemy has its own weaknesses and strategies to deal with them, like climbing behind a Cyclops to make him remove his helmet trying to grab you, exposing his eye, travelling can be a bit tedious at the beginning since theres A LOT of walking, but has you progress through the game you can gain Warp Crystals that essentially serve has fast travels you can place pretty much anywhere. 

Pawn System:
Probably one of the best if not the best aspects of this game, you can create your own companion in the game, which is called Pawn, this is essentially a second character you can customize to your liking, and you can even hire up to 2 pawns created by other players to help you in your journey, making it a total party of 4, with you the Arisen, the Main (your) Pawn, and two extra Pawns, so you can create your adventure party, with each member filling a role, like a ranged dps, a support, a tank, etc.

This king of thing heavily reminded me of the likes of World of Warcraft, of making a party to tackle dungeons, bosses and such, which was pretty good. 

Performance: 
Didnt really ran into many issues, there were a few crashes here and there, but nothing else besides that. 

The HUD: 
Yeah here is where the game really shows its age (besides the graphics), the K&M keybinds for the menu are messy to say the least, and changing equipment feels clunky, and the game could REALLY have used a search bar, since you can acquire a large amount of items, so sometimes it can take a while to find whatever item youre looking for, but like i said, this largely a product of its time, which is likely fixed for the sequel.

The DLC:
Oh god the Bitterblack Isle... yeah i have to voice some issues with this area, its meant to be the endgame zone, so it is meant to be the hardest area in the game, but some of that difficulty just felt frustrating, to begin with if you dont deal enough dmg to bypass the REALLY high defenses of the enemies there, then you literally do no dmg, i learned the hard way, also several enemies can be outright obnoxious, one being the Living Armors which do considerable dmg and need both Physical and Magic dmg to kill, so depending on your class, youre gonna have to depend on the AI of the pawns to deal with the first or second form of these things (first is weak to physical while the second is to magick), its doable, but again, be prepared for it, or youre gonna hate it.

Writing:
I found the overall Lore to be good and interesting, but the plot itself felt weak and had pacing issues, and i felt several characters were underused, Selene being an example. 

Conclusion:
The game is good, its aged mostly well, if you want a good Fantasy game, this is it. 

Cant wait for the sequel which looks really good.

There are two kinds of people in the world: 
Those who love Dragon's Dogma and those who hate it...
There is no middle ground... It is one or another.

Highly Recommended for Action/RPG fans. 

Some game systems require further explanation (so don't be ashamed to look them up), and min-maxing isn't all that important. You can, however, absolutely break this game with certain builds if that is what you are looking for. Classes are varied, and enemy types require strategy depending on your loadout.

Graphics are great, with the sound design to match.
A lot of game systems that lend themselves well to role-playing gamers, but can be entirely avoided if you are just an action-game fan wanting to enjoy the combat mechanics (which are also great).

Story for a JRPG is good, but it is somewhat lacking to be something even lore gamers won't be compelled enough to look into, unfortunately.

A bit rough around the edges, in an otherwise masterpiece game

One of the indications of a good game for me is that I would feel sad and lonely after finishing the game.   
Friday, 3 a.m., I wander around in my room for 10 minutes feeling like I just lost a friend.  

Now, the review: 
- The game is far from perfect. It has a lot of "point of no return" moments due to the autosave and single savefile feature.   
- The difficulty is quite terrible. I know running is an option but the game is bad at teaching it.  
- I started playing this game after watching the combat (especially the mage playstyle) and the pawn system. After seeing how you can make another character as an NPC, I was like "say no more" and bought the game.
- The pawn system is very interesting. It has more depth than the main character itself. I will not be satisfied until I make a perfect pawn.  
- I also love the mage playstyle. It makes me feel like I am, well, a mage. However, I became an archer later because some enemies easily counter pure magic build. [i]Damn those golems and wolves[/i].
- The main disappointment in this game is that there is no way to continue your adventure after watching the credit scene without starting a New Game+ due to how the story goes.
I recommend.

ye

sure, its an older game graphics, less developed characterizations and plotting, but it does some things very well. I'm not that far in, and playing on hardmode, and am very satisfied on the difficulty/challenge. (hardmode is you take more dmg, that's it, but that isn't such an issue because the fighting mechanics lend itself to playing smart and striking hard, so hardmode makes all encounters more threatening, but beatable). 

I'm playing as Fighter, so it's possible the other classes will have a more difficult time, but as a fighter, you can block all strikes (so far), then dash in for high damage before relocating defensively for the next opponent while your team do their thing creating distractions and openings. 

The creatures all have unique weaknesses, figuring them out is fun, and impactful, you can climb onto monsters (that's new to me, even though i am aware other games since have this mechanic) and get to their weakpoints. You can knock opponents down and/or up, grab them as a shield, and other theatrical skill moves. Combat is fun and tactical (on hardmode)

the story-loop, is a bit flat and their reality feels crazy (i mean the pawns? really? wierdest lore ever). The quest delivery method feel a bit too much like mmorpg fetch questing (but it is a product of its time, 2012-2016), and it's not too bad, there are plenty worse in present day.

The main storyline missions are engaging enough, and the world/threats are satisfyingly dangerous (on hardmode) and uniquely challenging (ie. the unique monster weaknesses and attack patterns). Get it. It's fun if you are into some sword and board action and rpg mechanics.

edit: i got to say their loot design/progression is poor. my experience is hardmode so i can speak only from that perspective. your initial starting items are the strongest in the game. i'm at the midway point, and i've never really had to change my gear. Everything they present to you, in chests or shops is weaker. And money drops like crazy. 10k gold drops happen frequently. money is not a factor. anyway, the loot progression is a mess.  acquiring upgrade components off creatures is the only thing that is paced correctly.
