October fools.

This game did not age gracefully. 
- Game is clearly unfinished with content abruptly dropping off on the end.
- Gameplay is very rough and buggy despite being released multiple times.
- Absurd systems like having levels tied to the class your playing as you level up with no in-game explanation of how it works, and no way to respec if you mess up or how a random NPC can be made into a forced romance based on simply being the last person you talk to before doing the final mission (hint: all the main romances leave your world before this quest, so if you talk to ANY NPC afterwards, they can potentially replace them as your romance. EVEN if you give them the wedding ring accessory. :')
- Fixed how certain classes are straight up broken and can even one shot bosses while other classes are objectively nerfed by comparison / have less abilities / Abilities come with absurd penalties or costs in exchange for "equal" damage / significantly put you at a disadvantage when you to play them.

Things they should have fixed but didn't include:
- Fixed the atrocious save system which literally lost me 2 days worth of gameplay due to how checkpoints and autosave work.
- Added additional save slots instead of limiting you to 1 slot and forcing you to overwrite it if you want to try something new.
- Fixed the Pawn system to be more competent.
- Added actual coop instead of having you recruit online players character's to join you as offline summons, like "42069[redacted]GothBf" which totally kill your immersion and cannot be customised in a meaningful way.
- Fixed any of the thousands of bugs and glitches in the game.
- Fixed any of the absurd systems that don't make sense or don't work properly.
- Added explanations in the game for these absurd systems so you don't have to play with a wiki open.

Honestly just wait for / get the sequel and don't bother with this mess. It was a great idea, but it's unfinished and did not age well enough to be worth playing honestly.

I do reccomend it. Battles are really nice and most of the times responsive. Skills feel like they matter. Loot is good-ish, but so far, no diablo/destiny-like loot system where you switch weapons every boss, which I happen to think has some charm, but I'd like to change more. 
But a few things you ought to remember:
ALWAYS SAVE THE GAME (feels like I'm back in 2000's but yeah don't forget to save manually, or you'll lose hours of grind on a daily basis, if you suck at playing this like me)
There's a lot of walking in this game (couldn't they put some horses or anything geez)
This game is prone to bugs when you alt+tab, so remember again, to save before every time you go back to your desktop/internet browser where you are reading guides for quests/character builds.

It was a pure accident that i stumble across dragon's dogma 2 trailer and saw that the prequel was on sales and decided to give it a shot, oh boi was it one of the best decision made ever.

This game, despite the lacking in graphic department(given that it's a rather old game) hold up well in other department. Combat is unique with each class/vocation giving a fresh paint to the series as different classes have their own ways of dishing out damage. Kind of like using different weapon in monster hunter giving it a whole new type of play style.

The pawn system is way WAY ahead of it's time, a sort of AI companion that gain quest and enemy knowledge as they travel with you. An online system where other players can "rent" your pawn to go on their adventure and you can rent others too. Not only that when the pawn have finish their online adventure, any additional knowledge on quest/enemy info get added to your pawn. And if you rent a pawn that have already finish a quest that you are currently doing, talking to them might drop hints or they will guide you to the necessary npc to progress the quest.

Now for some cons. This game while not as hard as dark soul, is no walk in the park either, the open world can be quite unforgiving especially to those unprepared, it is especially dangerous to travel at night.

Quest are easily miss or can't progress after a certain story point and if you have no backup save you got to wait till the next run to do them so if you are looking to finish every quest it is better to refer to a guide.

The very first run of the game is a bit unforgiving as the whole map is open to explore which make escort quest annoying to finish but after you have places your port crystal (a sort of teleport land marker) new game+ will be a breeze.

So if you are into rpg and open world and see this game on sales its definitely worth giving it a shot.

This game is fantastic. The story is a bit of a mess, but ultimately the world and setting it presents, while a bit messy, is a pretty nice and interesting deal. The combat, and classes... It's fantastic. If I were asked what the best combat I've experienced in a game was, I'd point to this game. It's like a combination of Souls, and Monster Hunter... Even the magic in this game really feels great. Probably the coolest and most impactful magic I've seen in a game. Sorcerers can summon spells that just wreck everything, it really makes you feel like a crazy powerful mage... Downside is you have to sit there for like 30 seconds charging a spell, and if you get knocked around at all, it's obviously cancelled. 

The idea of "Pawns" is really neat. You can bring a NPC companion of a friend or a random person online with you to help out. It's not quite multiplayer, but it's nice. They're mostly kinda stupid, their AI isn't the best, but yeah lol, still a neat concept. Waifu trading.

The only complaints I'd have, is that when you play anything that requires you to climb the big monsters to get to their weak spots... basically any melee class, the camera isn't great. Climbing can be awkward, because the direction you climb isn't quite how you'd think it'd be, but you get use to it. Sometimes you're on the dude's chest, but somehow get clipped through his arm, and now you're on his arm. The way the leveling and stat distribution work is kinda awful too. If you want to min/max, you basically HAVE to play Assassin or Sorcerer until max level, because leveling in those classes gives the most strength/magic attributes, THEN you can play whatever you want. 

I've played the hell out of this game on PS3/PS4... And a bit on PC... It's definitely a fun game that I still come back to. Definitely worth it imo. And now we're geting Dogma 2? Daaaang.

Highly suggest checking out "Infinite Cringe" on youtube.

Fun rpg that gives hours of gaming worth.
Lots of different play styles to chose from and you're not bound to your first choice at the start of the game. 
Bored with being a mage? Switch to twohanded warrior when youre in the tavern.
Then there's the teamplay a la dungeons and dragons. You complete your team by chosing 3 more characters. They are called Pawns. One of them you will need to create yourself and the other two are characters made by other gamers. These can be anyone you like and if you're fed up with one you can switch them in for a different character. You want to be a party of 4 mages? Go ahead.

Downsides of this game? Lot's of backtracking so you'll be running your arse off.
Also the Pawns that complement your team are really annoying. It took me 15 minutes to get pissed off at them. They just never shut up and repeat the same lines over and over depending on where you are. Can't turn it off as an option (only the audio). Weird choice by the devs to implement this.

There isn't much that I can say that hasn't already been said, the game has flaws that really bring enjoyment down, like stamina in the open world makes it really annoying to explore and most of the quests are really boring or not interesting.

But despite that I still believe this is the best RPG I have played in my life, Elden Ring, Dark Souls 1-3, Monster Hunter World, Cyberpunk 2077, Baldurs Gate 3, all of these games are great and I loved playing them but they don't have this special gameplay that Dragons Dogma offers, the magic the combos, the ways some items work, the weaknesses of the enemies, a lot of  the combat mechanics in this game just work so beautifully.

My personal score for this game would be an easy 9/10 but as an objective score I'd have to give it a 7/10

This game had a ton of potential and many good ideas, but the execution is lacking in many departments.
First, the pawns.
Your party is made up of yourself and 3 AI controlled characters called "pawns".
The game prides itself on it's "pawn" system, where your AI companions assist you not only in combat but with quests and general tips for fighting different monsters.
Unfortunately, every single aspect of the pawn system leads to frustration.
You can only customize your main pawn, who levels up alongside you. The other 2 pawns have to be borrowed from other players. This means you have to dig through the countless pawns other people have made trying to find pawns that are set up the way you want them to be.  Then, when the pawns fall behind in level(which doesn't take long, levels come quick in this game), you have to go looking for new ones that match your criteria to replace them. This is tedious as hell and there's absolutely no reason not to allow the player to customize their own damn party members.
Then, despite all that effort, your pawns serve as lobotomized meat shields in combat that either spam their abilities or sprint to their deaths at random. 
This brings us to the combat.
The combat system gives you all kinds of interesting tools to deal with various enemies and situations, and the tools different classes have access to encourage a well-balanced party and creativity in combat.
But three of your characters are braindead and don't make proper use of those tools.
This spoils the otherwise interesting and complex combat and leaves your party feeling lopsided because only your characters capabilities are utilized effectively.
Not only that, but most enemies seem even more clueless than your pawns. They aren't much of a threat most of the time until you suddenly get two shot by an ogre who finally remembered he was supposed to be fighting you.
If any enemy does prove to be a challenge, you can always pause and use one of the million free instant healing items the game showers you with anyway.
The Quest system is also more broken and obtuse than any I have ever seen. You can miss quests easily, and some quests lock you out of others with no warning.
In order for this game to be enjoyable, the AI would have to be massively improved or co-op implemented.

I finally faced the dragon that stole my heart, and as I raise my shield and ready my sword for this final clash a girl I vaguely remember giving flowers to a dozen hours ago runs into the room, chased by a horde of goblins. Now I have to choose whether to exact my vengeance or save the damsel.

Dragon's Dogma felt slightly weird to me for most of its runtime. I'm no stranger to threadbare stories, having some experience with the Souls series, but I just always felt that I was missing something. Why do I care about getting my heart back? The dragon taking it turned me into a demi-god who could bring down monsters ten times my size. What's with the duke's second castle? Why can't I go in? I ran to the end of the world for nothing? And what happened to my childhood friend, she just disappeared from the village.

I thought Dark Souls 2 didn't care about its story, but Dragon's Dogma really doesn't. It fully expects you to complete [b][u] every [/u][/b] quest, just because you enjoy playing the game that much. Yes, and this includes that random fetch quest where you need to get flowers or deliver ten fish to someone.

And dammit, the game is that fun. I never cared that I had no idea what or why I was doing something. I just enjoyed the fact that I was riding atop a gryphon, stabbing it while my pawns where raining down arrows and spells.

So when faced with the choice of saving the damsel or fighting a honest to goodness dragon, I did what I'd been doing up until that point. I called for a buff from the party mage and then headed into the fray.
Yes. Just, Yes.

It took me 52 hours and a bottle of wine to finish the game.

-Graphics are past era.
-Movements are regular.
-Combat is boring IF you don't tolerate bad and long casting animations.
-Game doesn't explains vocations system and you can really screw up your character .
-NG+ is just rinse n repeat. No real benefit on playing more.

Although , Story is great, i loved ranger and at times hard mode was a bit challenging.
Overall a Solid 7/10.

I'm not really sure where the fervent praise comes from, even after finally beating* it after 3 attempts. 

*I killed the dragon, explored the Everfall, and tried Bitterblack Isle before throwing my hands and calling it finished. 

I dunno man. Was it because this originally released around Skyrim, but had better combat and hating Bethesda games started becoming hip? Did people not play Monster Hunter at that time, so the combat felt more unique? Does picking up and throwing people go that far? I can't really pinpoint why this game is as fervently loved as it is, but I didn't hate it. I enjoyed it enough to finish, at least. 

I found the generic fantasy setting to actually be more refreshing and charming in 2023 than when I originally tried this game many years ago. Battling chimeras while your pawns speak in Olde English makes for a cozy setting, something that reminded me of '80s fantasy movies but without the synth tracks. Being a massive Middle-earth guy, I feel like we don't get enough "down to earth" fantasy settings nowadays, even if the post-game armors can get very Monster Hunter, which I still loved. 

While the story wasn't amazing, the actual writing was leagues better than I thought it would be, and the lore was fairly interesting. Smashing goblins with my giant fuck-off sword and stunlocking dragons was the highlight of the game, and the setting and competent writing only made it better.

But after a solid 30ish hours on this final playthrough... god. How many enemy types are there? Seven, maybe, not including shared models? Goblins, wolves, chimeras, cockatrices (which share a skeleton with chimeras), amber dragons (which are ripped from Monster Hunter, maybe a Gore Magala skeleton), skeleton warriors/mages, cyclops, golems (which share a skeleton with cyclops), and ogres (which share a skeleton with cyclops)? I was shocked at little substance there was as I progressed, with each quest being escort a person, kill these things, talk to these people (which have "schedules" btw, good luck figuring out where they are). That's pretty much it. 

So we have an okay story with good writing, great combat, and a small world to explore with inconsequential quests. Is this really what got people's goats in 2012/3? 

Again, I don't hate this game. I think it's worth a playthrough if you're in the market for a fantasy game with great combat and a charming setting. But the way people talk about this game, you'd think it's the world's most underrated gem Of All Time, and that's a feeling I couldn't shake during my whole playthrough. Unfortunately, that's a splinter I couldn't get out of my head and one that eventually soured the whole experience, as overall I just found the game to be okay at best. Some highs, but a lot of middling- to low-lows. 

If we're comparing this to games that came out at the same time: Skyrim had superior exploration; Dark Souls had the more interesting lore with a more fun challenge; and Monster Hunter had the more exhilarating boss fights and deeper combat. This games tries to combine these experiences into one setting and it doesn't quite pay off the way I was expecting.

I just hope Dragon's Dogma 2 comes out way more content rich, cuz if it's just more of the same, we have a problem.

I've only played for 4 hours and I feel like this game is everything I've wanted in a fantasy RPG. 

Create your own character; choose a class. Meet "Pawns" which are your followers/party members. Customise your main Pawn; choose their class. You may recruit 2 other Pawns, and you get to choose who you want to join you based off their class and looks. Pawns talk and react to things you do and are smart enough to know what's going on during the quests you're doing.

This makes the game more immersive than any other fantasy game I've played. Being able to put together a party like Dungeons & Dragons or a Lord of the Rings fellowship. With how unique this game has been so far, I feel like I don't know what to expect and that gives me that feeling that gaming once did. Fantasy MMOs have become predictable and boring. All having similar combat and systems and restrictions. Dragon's Dogma gives me that feeling I had when I first played WoW and I was excited to explore the world, being completely oblivious to what it had to offer.

It's one of those games I've been asking for for years, and to my surprise it's a decade old. I guess I never really did give a lot of single-player games a chance. Dragon's Dogma 2 is being developed currently and that's how I discovered this game existed at all.

Okay, let's be honest here, Dragon Dogma starts off a bit like your below-average, run-of-the-mill RPG. Slow and almost painfully so. It's the kind of slow start that might have you questioning your life choices, wondering if you should refund it instead and go outside to fight some bears like Rogan. But hang on, don't quit just yet.

Now, here's where it gets good. The real gem of Dragon's Dogma lies in its innovative pawn system. It's like a light at the end of a tunnel, and boy, is it worth the wait. Once you go through the initial crawl and reach Gran Soren, you'll discover a game that's nothing short of magical, thanks to the pawn system.

Picture this: Even if the game is a single-player game, you're not alone on your journey. You have a team of AI companions, your bro pawns, ready to assist and follow your every command. It's like having your personal entourage of badass adventurers. Need a healer? You got it. Prefer a ranged attacker? No problem. You want a tank? Sure, why not. The pawn system is a game-changer, and it's where Dragon's Dogma truly shines.

As you delve deeper into the game, you'll appreciate the strategic depth that the pawn system offers. You can customize your pawns' abilities, behaviors, classes, and even their appearance. It's like assembling your dream team of fantasy heroes, and the synergy you can achieve is nothing short of pure awesomeness.

But Dragon's Dogma isn't just about your pawns; it's also about you, the Arisen. The battles in this game are pretty epic. Whether I was taking on a towering ogre or a ferocious griffin, the fun never really gone, at least until you got so over-leveled that everything became too easy, like any other game.

Now, let's talk magic. Playing a magical class in Dragon's Dogma makes you feel like a wizard on steroids. It's magic in its purest, most explosive form.

So yeah, I'd say this is quite the masterpiece. Even when all of those things I already mentioned are amazing, there are many other aspects in which this game excelled. Like the lores, the story, the replayability, the fact that every class in the games is just well designed, and many other stuff.

Go buy it now.

THEY'RE MASTERWORKS, ALL. YOU CAN'T GO WRONG!

[h3]Is this game good? No, it is amazing! [/h3]
[h3]Would I recommend it to anyone? Hell no! Here's why: [/h3]

[b]Overview:[/b]
- This is a very old game. Don't expect it to live up to today's standard of gaming, in terms of graphic and mechanics
- Title is very misleading. There are no dogs in this game.

[b]Pros:[/b]
- Graphic and animations are not bad, even for today's standard. 
- BGM/SFX/Voice acting are above average. Not too repetitive or annoying.
- Character customization are fantastic. You can dress to impress without worrying much about stats. 
- Playstyle for different classes are unique and offers a refreshing experience
- Sorcery system in this game is done perfectly. Not to overpowered, not too tedious. Positioning and timing matters. And most of all, the animation is fantastic!
- Your AI companions are not completely useless or underpowered. 
- True open world. You can run to literally anywhere on the map at the very start of the game (except a few story scripted areas). 

[b]Cons:[/b]
- The game is incredibly punishing at early game. Almost anything including random bandits can one-shot you.
- Traversing the map is a joke (esp in first playthrough). Imagine Elden ring, with no grace, no horse, and a stamina that depletes when you run even when out of combat. Yes, it does feel like an adventure at first, but when you realize majority of the quests requires you to travel from point A to point B, C, D then back to point A, that's where the frustration begins.
- Unnecessarily complicated dungeon layout with mazes, puzzles to fu-k with the player. Design like this adds 0 value to the gameplay as all it does is artificially lengthen the time to reach the destination.
- Most side quests and even main quests are boring and not rewarding. They feel like fillers instead of necessary plot progression.
- Enemy variations are limited. Eg. Wolves, goblins, harpies are everywhere, with different colors to make them unique. 
- Boss fights are refreshing on the first attempt but it becomes a button mashing fest once you learn the exploits. 
- Weapon variations and choices are very limited. Moveset of each weapon are the same too. Hence, the player will always go for the best weapon for that class. 
- Grinding is optional but if you chose to do so you'll be having a very hard time. Not only drop rates are abysmal, trying to get one specific boss to spawn is near impossible.
- Jail system is bullsheet. It does nothing but to punish players for input errors. 
- NPCs are... weird.. You can romance literally anyone, including married one. 
- There's even a scripted NTR scene in which you pork the wife and the husband is cool with it.
- Main story is too short. Feels rushed and unfinished. Ending is also... really weird.. 
- DLC is underwhelming. To summarize : Move the goalpost - by making enemies real hard, while giving you option to further enhance your weapon.
- Crashes/ Game Freezes. Throughout my 60hours+ gameplayed, it happens for at least 5 times. No major progress losses for me, just annoyance.
- Only 1 saveslot. Autosaves are not timely or reliable. Hence you gotta spam saves every 2 mins just to be safe.

[b]Conclusion:[/b]
- 70% of the time I spent running around travelling from point A to B
- 25% of the time i spent doing makeover and fashion show
- 5% of the time I spent doing actual fighting and progressing the plot
- I had a good time tbh but I can't look pass the flaws to give this game a thumbs up

Haven't beaten the game yet, but so far I would say that it holds up  for being somewhat of an older game! Favorite parts so far are the exploration, freedom to pick and change your class (vocation), interesting "pawn" system where you can have up to 3 companions at a time to round out your party, and other smaller pleasant surprises like a crafting system that I enjoyed, inventory management, simple dungeon puzzles, and a unique fast travel system that has you collecting magical crystals that you can pick up and set down to serve as fast travel points. 

The cons: 
Combat isn't quite as good as the Souls franchise, though fun in its own way. There is no way to "dodge roll" unless you are a dexterous class such as your typical hunter/rogue archetype. I'm playing mostly as a sorcerer and feel like most of the time I just have to stay back and spam fireballs. Most of the challenge is not getting hit and eating health items if I do. 

The story so far to me is pretty meh. You're a Dragonborn -- I mean an Arisen - and you have to kill monsters and slay the dragon and save the land from evil. Maybe it gets more interesting, but I haven't been really pulled in. Regardless, the setting is still very nice, and the graphics are pretty good considering the age of this game.

If you're a fan of fantasy games and love swinging a sword, shooting a bow, and/or casting magic spells while delving into dungeons and lands over-run with bandits and goblins, I would recommend! Especially if it's on sale!

This game could have had a lot going for it. 

Instead, it fizzles out. 

The game can be described as FABLE meets SKYRIM meets A PILE OF GARBAGE.

It feels like it's trying to inject the best things from those games, but gets them all wrong.

First off, the controls are crappy. 

You spend more time fighting with the controls than fighting the monsters.

There's just too many "special moves" but not enough "buttons" for them. Instead of just binding those moves to a key (like in an MMO), you have hold down a button or key, then press another one. 2 generic attacks, 3 special offensive moves, 3 special defense moves. However, the enemies and their tactics vary so it's a fumbling mashing mess to switch gears to mash different things to be the most efficient.

Instead, they could have just made those moves as something bindable to the keyboard.
Maybe they wanted to make PC gamers know the terrible horrors console gamers go through having to play 3rd Person or FPS games with a silly console controller (hahahah).
If it was bindable to the 1-9 keys, we could just PRESS A SINGLE BUTTON, just like in many RPGs or MMOs. 

My character in World of Warcraft can execute all types of moves by pressing 1,2,3.
In Dragons Dogma, you have to hold down X, press right mouse button, then hold down E and spam-press left mouse button, then you have to hold down X and then press F, then press E to jump then press R, then left cilck because if you accidently right cilck, you fall the fracken hell down and die.

Terrible. The UI interface controls are equally atrocious.

Graphics for a game this age vary from standard to above standard. The character design is great, there's a HUGE TON of choices and it's easy to understand what you're able to change. The controls for that suck too but the artists did a great job. The main downside is the textures are detailed in some areas and low-res in others for some reason. The character animations are fantastic. They use the in-game graphics for the epic cutscenes. It looks like they motion-captured the animations, so everyone walks, runs, leaps, fights crazily fantasy-ARPG-style...realistically. The action is very fluid and smooth as well.

The music is very good, it's very "soundtrack-y" and used to great effect when showing the cutscenes. The downside is when you run from a battle, the generic "action" sounding music keeps playing. That's annoying.

Save system is junk, it auto-saves. You have only ONE SAVE. So if the game saves at a very bad spot...YOU'RE SCREWED. You also cannot reload because you save/quit or save/continue. Get stuck in jail without money or special key?...you are literally stuck there. You cannot get out. In a dungeon getting thrashed by ridiculous swarms of OP'd monsters can't escape from? SCREWED. There's no "past save". DON'T SAY I DIDN'T WARN YOU!

Like a Groundhog Day...from Hell. 
Reload...OH LOOK STILL TRAPPED! 
It's a uber-cruel defacto-permadeath/stuck/screwed system.
RESTART OR REFUND. 

Gameplay is brutally linear in the beginning, oozing with waaay too many cutscenes.
You walk like 10 steps, and CUTSCENE and a forced sequence. HOLY MOLY when does this game actually start?!....or is THIS the game??

About 1-2 hours later, you'll find you can run around without too many forced cutscenes or sequences, but the world is sealed off because...YOU HAVE TO DO A TASK to continue.
UTTER LINEAR GAME HELL. For the first few hours. It's a slog, it's boring, and you'll start looking online for help asking yourself: "Am I Doing Something Wrong"? 

A total on-rails game at first, and for too long.
Now, after you grinding-ly slug it out to the capital city, everything goes OFF THE RAILS. 
Badly.

Prepare to DIE. LOTS.

That is all there is to do in this game. 
For all the skills you can get, your character is massively underpowered...even on the EASIEST difficulty setting.

It takes like 20 strong hits just to kill a fricken armor-less Gollum-esque goblin.
Every trash mob fight is a 15-20min affair the game treats like an "epic battle". Win. Run in any direction for 5-10sec. and get attacked again. Wash, rinse, repeat. Sound like fun?


It's like playing the Gothic game series using only a wooden branch as your weapon the entire game. Your armor feels more cosmetic than actually protecting you. Play as a warrior and put up that shield? Many enemy attacks go through it and uber-strike you. The game lets you jump on giant monsters and crawl all over them...but it does no good. Your direct attacks on their head don't appear to do any extra damage whatsoever. Instead, they can throw you off and you end up taking a ton of damage, discouraging future attempts. Even the best gear you can buy is laughably useless.

The game is broken in that any dungeon/cave/ruin is loaded with OP creatures right away who will utterly destroy you. Get used to the "Retry" screen.

Anyone who says "NAH, I DO FINE" probably stopped playing early or is using CHEAT MODs. (look it up)

Leveling up is useless. You get a few more HP each level. It doesn't make a difference when a snake monster blasts you for 200 dmg and DOTs you with fire. Those measily HP gains melt away VERY fast.

There's no dodge skills in this game, but just pressing jump and aiming in a different direction.
The enemy seems to have heat-seeking ranged attacks so your only hope is to hide behind something and snack on plants.

You can't run very far because you burn through stamina like crap through a goose.
Your character will actually stop where they are and start panting while it regens.
Even at 1/5th of your stamina back - due to an "invisible minimum", so you're still waiting and waiting, and then some enemy totally roasts you or picks you up and smashes you to bits. 

Stupid design.

"Pawns" are a joke. So basically, there's this gimmick of everyone getting an NPC follower and being able to share online. They're useless in that these NPC "helpers" fricken NINJA LOOT stuff and you can't take it from them because...it goes to the owner of the pawn. Buying good gear for them is a waste of money because it's "gifted" and cannot be "returned" (who thought of this crap?). Even in full-offline, this is in effect. You can get 2 "other" Pawns and 1 of your very own. Only for your very-own, can you move their gear. So that's good. But for the other 2, what gives? Gimmicky.

The AI is okay for the Pawns but they don't heal themselves when they should.
Similar to Clive Barker's Jericho, your "followers" get their butts kicked ALOT, and lay there dying. You have to run around to each one to rez them. You spend most battles fighting with the crap controls and rezzing downed followers. Is this a game? Or Fantasy Medic simulator?

If you don't heal them in time? They're dead and leave the game, and all the nice gear you got for them is gone...forfeit. There goes all your investment. Best to die too and reload.

The game should be called "Futile Dungeon Medic Simulator".
Even the starting caves and dungeons is like a Level 1 going after End Game Content.
You have to hit everything 200 times to dent it. It's just annoying...but more importantly is incredibly BORING. There's no special skill or strategy whatsoever to fighting large monsters or the various creatures (look it up), except: "HIT IT 'TIL IT DIES!"

Your only recourse is to run around the open world killing rabbits and boars to grind levels, at least enough so those giant enemy attacks that burn away your HP allow you to last at least another 2-3 seconds before you succumb. 

Finally, the weapons/armor choices are very limited. There should be way more choices. It seems 99% of it can only be bought from vendors, almost never drops at all, and if it does, it's a trash item. Hugely disappointing. 

Anyways, that's "Dragon's Dogma Dark Arisen". 
More like "Dragon's Dogcrap Bark A Reason"

Dragons Dogma is a deeply flawed gem that is incredibly fun but has a multitude of issues which hamper a very unique and fun gameplay experience.

This is in my top 10 favorite games I've ever played, I have played on Xbox, switch and finally PC. It took me three different tries to really get into this game, and on the third try it clicked very hard, where I reached a major focal point in the story and I have been in love ever since. It is a great story told poorly, with so much so easily missed, and a great deal that is confusing unless you pursue side missions. But once you understand, you get to enjoy a nicely thought provoking and immersive story with (in my opinion) the greatest dragon boss fight in all of gaming. This game massively shines in the monster combat. Monster attacks generally feel weighty and impactful, the many ways of dealing with them from magic to climbing and attacking them to teamwork with you and your pawns and many status effects as well. But combat with bandits, with other humanoid or small enemies is generally fairly weak, combat generally feels far less impactful and enemies are far less responsive to attacks than monsters. As well they can be far more dangerous than actual monsters which partially ruins the sense of power you get from said monsters. 

Regarding the expansion where I spend most of my time in the game, it is a very alluring setting, the tone is very consistent and utterly dreadful at times. Almost feeling as if you are walking between hell and ruined splendor, the ambient sound design fits very well and the soundtrack accentuates the tragic backdrop of it all. I love almost all of the monsters added, whether they be far more dangerous variants of previous monsters, or entirely new hellish monsters to fight. Also the final boss is such a blast to fight, the raw power, grace and arrogance shown through how they fight and talk is awesome and was a fitting "end" after fighting through grueling combat encounter after another. But as many times as the expansion is a treat, it is also incredibly frustrating with seeming little play testing for enemy placement, ai companion behavior in some encounters and insane difficulty spikes and drops at times. you will be forced on more than one occasion to fight very power monsters in unacceptably tiny rooms, where they take up a good chunk if not a quarter of said room, and have attacks that can hit more than or near entirety of said room. Fighting highly disruptive enemies that tend to fling you very far and wide on a narrowish bridge is a challenge but so unfun when you and your companions die instantly from the fall. One of the sub-bosses in the expansion that you must beat to progress, can either be a walk in the park or incredibly difficult based on your class and your companions, as well as if they decide to function properly. My last major gripe is the lack of clarity and telegraphing for a fair few monster attacks. Some will have virtually no telegraphing, whilst some spells that look nearly identical to other attacks are vastly more powerful. From being simply blinded, to potentially being insta-killed from petrification if you don't have the right curative. Overall adore the expansion but there are many things that cause great frustration.

lastly the AI companions or pawns. They will go from being absolutely insane berserkers completely decking everything that so much as looks at you funny, or being the greatest guardian angel constantly saving you from death. As well as buffing you with the right magic at just the right time, working with you and the other pawns so perfectly sometimes it's briefly feels like a human player. Or never casting their most powerful spells not healing you and the others, not buffing you, giving you the wrong buff which can completely compromise your DPS. As well as not using powerful combat skills, not helping you when your in a pinch, staring at the monster, wandering off somewhere a fair distance away (rare) and casting a dark spell on a creature that takes next to no dark damage CONSTANTLY. Or they will have no sense of self preservation and die over, and over, and over again. A partial saving grace is the ability to instantly revive at any and all times. All in all their AI. They will grab a dragon by the balls and squeeze so hard god feels it, or they will actively sabotage you through their immense ineptitude.

I love this game beyond words, it has some of the best magic in an rpg, the best monster combat in an rpg period a deeply resonant story for me personally and a world I can get very immersed into. It pisses me off, so so much sometimes, but I would be a fool to not say this isn't a brilliant diamond with barbed wire wrapped around it.
10 out of 10

I wasn't sure what to expect. But it's Capcom, and this plays a lot like Monster Hunter. That's a good thing, by the way: The controls are tight, mechanics are uncomplicated, the maps are fun to explore and it's well optimized. All the normal MH mechanics seem present here. Fight monsters. Hoard crafting material. Upgrade your gear. Your gear looks cool. You like getting new gear. There is a lot of gear it seems. 

So ultimately I'd say this is Monster Hunter, injected with Skyrim DNA, for a semi-compact open-world RPG-adjacent experience with some online aspects mixed in. 

I can't yet find much I dislike about this game. I'd be complaining about elements too miniscule to cast any real shade on the good that is here. This seems a damn respectable action-rpg, not to be missed by anyone who likes to whack things with a sword.

Already dumped 500+ hours on this masterwork back then on the PS3 and yes, you should buy it.

Surprised I never wrote a review for this. My hours played aren't truly reflected accurately because I owned this game ever since it first came out on the PS3 forever ago. So couple a few playthroughs on the PS3 with the Steam version and it'd be A LOT more than what you see. What else is there that needs to be said? this game is an underrated cult classic gem if there ever was one. So many people own the game but barely play it to the point where achievements have such low completion percentages (despite mods not disabling achievements). 

In the end this game is basically what a Berserk RPG would be like, with Shadow of the Colossus grapple mechanics and a unique story with a nice world to explore and immerse yourself in. I've always loved Dragon's Dogma and I was in awe and amazement with my fellow fans when the sequel was FINALLY announced after a decade of constant begging. Here's hoping the Dragon's Dogma Online game comes out, but if now I hope you guys will pick up this game and get yourself hyped for Dragon's Dogma 2 so we can show Capcom that Dragon's Dogma deserves the same love and respect that Dark Souls had. Imagine a new genre of "Dogma-likes" where we get rich rpg experiences with fun combat and unique AI! I'm all for it!

Perfect game disguised as bad game 10/10

I didn't played this game that much like some people did, but I can say that it's actually very fun. You can climb monsters, grab NPCs and throw them, you can grab your party members and throw them away too, the magic is over the top and so fun to use (specially the tornado, that is fantastic), the classes are very good too, they work well and you feel that you and your party are doing something, the party feels like a fellowship of the ring, choices matter and the game look kinda good for it's age.
Besides all that, the main map is kinda small, the stats system is bad since you upgrade your stats based on which class you level, so if you level up as a fighter until level 100, for example, and decide to switch to sorcerer until level 150 and then switch to rogue until level 200, your stats will be kinda messed up, it does not really matter if you're more casual, but if you care about doing a "perfect" build, it will ruin it for you, also, you can only make one character per account, so if you decide to level another character, you would need to delete the first character you made and create a new one(there are mods for multiple saves tho), the inventory system is personally bad (I don't like weight inventory systems), the main campaign is kinda short and the beginning of the game may be hard, but it become a joke later when you get stronger (the real difficulty is in the DLC).

Overall I would say the game is a 7/10, it's good, fun, probably one of the best "Berserk games" we have today, but have it's flaws not only for some bad decisions the devs made, but because they got paid like 3 chicken nuggets to make it. 

By the way, play the game by yourself first then play it again with a guide to see how many quests you missed, I bet you gonna lose your mind.

Anyway, try it and have fun!

dragon's dogma is what i'd like to call the blueprint for the best game ever made; which is why it's one of the most fun games ever played. 

it's clearly unfinished/unpolished due to development cuts, but it is still so, so incredible. my steam hours don't take into account the over 500 hours i had on the original playstation version (before dark arisen dropped!). i've exhausted this game several times over and i still cannot get enough of it. if you're looking at dark arisen because you're interested in the sequel, i HIGHLY recommend giving the original a shot! 

combat wise, the game can be a bit tricky to get into/pick up, but once you do you'll find it flows so naturally. there isn't a way to lock onto enemies, but you'll find that the combat is comfortable without it as you get deeper into it. 

story wise, you can tell when exactly budget cuts were being made. still, if you're willing to offer a little patience and imagination it will meet your expectations. because of the budget cuts, i find that dragon's dogma offers a more personal story than they originally planned (yes, even if you know how it ends)--which isn't a fault! personally, i love stories that are more grounded. 

the graphics are the perfect mix of semi-realistic and stylistic, meaning this game will never truly age out or feel "too old" to play. i've been playing this game since 2012, and i can honestly say that even in 2023 it exceeds my expectations. ESPECIALLY if you pick it up on sale, you're more than getting your money's worth even if you end up only doing half of a playthrough.

This game has aged like wine. Great Action RPG with many options to deal with any trouble. Vocations, while few, offer vastly different styles of combat, and the pawn system is really good. Graphics are very good for a 2012 game.
Can't wait for Dragon's Dogma 2, which looks to improve on everything this game achieved.

In short not even worth 5 euros on discount, boring time waster.

I am a 58 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 40 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching Ukrainian men French kissing canines on YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Only about 40 hours logged on Steam, but I logged probably 250-300 hours when I was playing it on PS3.  One of my favorite RPGs of all time, one of my favorite games of the last decade.  The graphics are even more meh than when this released in 2012, but it has amazing gameplay, a great world to traverse, a plethora of different enemies with different strengths, weaknesses, and tactics, and a story that isn't too shabby.  The different vocations("classes" for this game) mostly play pretty independently of each other, with a little bit of overlap for hybrid vocations, but I've tried them all and I don't think I would say even one isn't fun.  The pawn system is also quite a highlight, both your custom pawn and pawns you hire.

At a $40 price tag, I would recommend this still.  At a sale price(which this often is on sale, at the time of writing it is for $4.79), I would DEFINITELY recommend grabbing it, and maybe a second copy to gift to a friend.

Shadow of the Colossus + Dark Souls + Skyrim = This game

Pros:
+ You can climb EVERYTHING including monsters
+ Satisfying and challenging combat
+ Intense fights against epic creatures
+ Responsive controls
+ The online Pawn (companion) system works really well
+ Infinite replayability thanks to NG+
+ Rewards exploration
+ Every class offers a completely different play style and you can switch classes at anytime
+ Interesting story with a few surprises towards the end
+ Bitterblack Isle is like an entire new game
Cons:
- Some important side quests will fail if you rush through the main quests (you can always re-do them in NG+ but still)
- Some cutscenes and story moments are weird and cringy
- The game doesn't really tell you everything you need to know, you will need to use the wiki a lot

If you like action based RPGs that rewards skilled play and exploration, get this game, you won't regret it.

2023 EDIT: After 11 years Dragon's Dogma 2 is real and coming out soon, so do yourself a favor and play this absolute gem of a videogame, you won't regret it, the visuals are a bit dated but the gameplay aged like wine.
RPG game with probably the best combat I have ever seen, definitely buy it before the 2nd part releases.
WE ARE SO BACK DRAGONS DOGMA 2 BABY
The best game ever play

If in these days you loved to play MMORPG games like Terra or Guild Wars 2 but you'd rather to play it Offline (Literally), This Game will suit your Play style.

What is Good:
- This is basically an Open World RPG like Skyrim (but 3rd person camera only).
- You can create and customized your own Companion (Main Pawn)
- There will be 3 Basic Vocation, 3 Advanced Vocation and 3 Hybrid Vocations. Vocation is Class or Job (based on Ragnarok).
- The Quest is really similar with the known MMORPG games like Escort or Killing a big monsters.
- At the first time, you need to learn some items, especially the items that could heals or be combined.
- The games is pretty balanced and you can grinding your Character and Your main pawn (Companion) really well.
- Climb a big Monsters is a plus, this was reminds me of Shadow of the Colosus game.
- You can pick up any NPC's and bring them to wherever you want. (A details that will never exist in another game)

Things that you need to Consider:
- This is an Old game, was made in 2012. the graphics will not too far if compare with Skyrim V.
- The beginning phase is tough and the enemies will not have the level indicators. So we may face the hardest skin enemies without knowing it.
- This game is using a Stamina system, same as MP.
- The Pawn (Companion) play style was not good enough to support me like MMORPG does(Of course, because MMORPG have real players, not using Bot).
- The Map is not huge but the quest will give you to the farthest route.
- Allowed Pawn (Companion) is only 3, 1 from your creation and 2 of them is owned by other player.
- There is an Online Feature, but only to recruit your friends or other Users Pawn.
- Confusing route or Map.

First hour:

It feels very old. It's from 2016 but it must have felt dated and console port-y already then.

No ultrawide support, if you have surround enabled, you'll have to edit the .ini
(C:\Users\yourname\AppData\Local\CAPCOM\ )

Keyboard/mouse seems to have been added as an afterthought, by an employee who resented the idea, and was about to get fired, so they wanted you to have a bad time with it.
Jerky movements, clunky combat, terrible menus with awkward button layout and fugly UI.

...what the hell am I fighting, a ...lion ...goatsnake? o.0

For some reason, someone thought that the camera shaking constantly was a great idea. I'm not actually sensitive to motion sickness, it's just really in-your-face annoying.
Cutscenes too, extremely jarring, fast cuts, shake shake shake.

Ok, I'm through the intro, made a character, I accidentally stab a fisherman while smashing up his home and stealing his stuff. Then I get my first fetch quest.

Maybe it gets better, there must be a reason people like it.. Right? 
I'll try stick with it, mostly because I bought it already (at some sale, I think, thankfully).

....but not tonight. I've had enough camera shaking for now.

I've meaning to plaything game for a while and finally got around to it, I'm closing in on the end of the main story for the first time (Plus the announcement of DD2 urged me to play) . I originally got interested because of the Anime and it seemed pretty neat. The game is pretty rough around the edges but it also originally released 11 years ago. Maybe if I played it at that time it would have seemed better. Kinda like how old Tomb Raider seemed like state of the art graphics for its time. I'd say this is pretty good graphics in a 2012 mindset. The fast travel system can be pretty annoying but it gives the fantasy world charm to it that its bearable. Great for people who like the idea of dark souls but don't want the grueling challenge and just want to chill and fight. You can feel like Guts, The Goblin Slayer, A shield bearer, or even Megumin with powerful spells. You can easily experiment with all and any classes, it's very accessible in that sense! I'm excited to see the conclusion to the game and to see how a great game is elevated in a sequel over a decade later! I would definitely recommend giving it a try, it goes on sale somewhat frequently for only $5!

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

This game is a hidden gem that has something for every player: great combat, great boss fights, character customisation, combat customisation, multiple classes, an awesome OST, and endless replay value. 

The dark fantasy atmosphere lends itself to the story and the many hidden lore details you may or may not find. You feel a part of the land, and you get to know it, walking around and exploring until you know every spot and what to expect. You learn, and your companions learn, helping you in all encounters and showing progression as a player. It’s a unique journey that you will never forget, even if you don’t replay the game. 

Some things to consider are the classes can be a bit unbalanced in terms of the value they provide in certain fights. The wiki and community posts have great tips for picking a class you like, but you can change it anytime. The only issue I had was that I wish all classes had a dodge, but it is nothing major, as each class has strengths and weaknesses that you can balance with party composition. 

Looking forward to Dragons Dogma 2

‘They’re masterworks, all. You can’t go wrong.’

Gransys is a beautiful world filled with all kinds of flavor. Enemies stalk the land, and as Arisen you must slay them even if it means climbing a 30-foot cyclopes and poking his eye out personally. 
There are a wide variety of enemies to fight, an in-depth crafting system, a unique party system, lots of lore to discover, and a very fun combat system that allows you to grapple enemies, scale enemies larger than yourself, and struggle to kill those damnable metal golems if you aren't a strider.

Not to mention, with the announce of Dragon's Dogma 2, what better time to get the first game and get invested in what will hopefully remain an incredible series.

After 200+ hours. 9 playthroughs, 100% completion and Ur Dragon - Bitterblack loot grind, i can safely say that Dragon's Dogma is one of the best RPGs i've ever had the pleasure to play in my life. 

From the Dark Fantasy aesthetic to one of the most singular combat mechanics on the market, DD manages to stand out in its uniqueness even after 10+ years of it's original release. So much so that to this day, there is no other RPG similar in combat and/or style. 

Although short and simple, its story is able to effortlessly hold and surprise you with it's final twist, answering it's proposed question while also leaving space for wonder. 

It feels me with immense joy to see this masterpiece get a sequel/remake, and i higly recommend it for those who are interested in getting into it before the release of it's 2nd game. ✿

TL;DR: A hidden gem that should is mandatory for lovers of single player games and the Action-RPG genre in general.

In a world where the most popular games are full of microtransactions, freemium predatory models of monetization and lack of love for the product itself, Dragons Dogma: Dark Arisen is a hidden gem 2013 gem that deserves begs to be played, replayed, and replayed again.

It doesn't have nice CG's, since it's an old game, the plot is good, but not well developed mid-game, some mechanics are questionable, but hell, this game is fun. The combat system is amazing, the online mechanics with Pawns is something that needs to be implemented in other games, and the replayability is vast due to the NG+ and Bitter Black Island (BBI) addition in the Dark Arisen.

Unfortunately, the game has some problems that can't be ignored, some classes are not well-balanced, the most notable example is the Warrior, which for some reason is not able to equip the same amount of skills as other classes, on the other hand, the hybrid vocations like Mystic Knight and Magic Archer are a steamroll when it reaches certain point on the game, and some other minor problems that you can encounter while playing. 

But overall, the game is amazing, it's not uncommon to see people who replayed a NewGame+ dozens of time, because the game have so much sidequests that you're gonna fail or not even know about their existence in your first plays, that you're gonna want to replay just to help certain NPC, and with the announce of the second game, playing the first game is a worthy experience to contextualize for the second game, and even transfer progress, since the game's plot makes you think that Dragon's Dogma 2 is the perfect game for a progress transference.

8/10

An action RPG that sees you unleashed into the medieval fantasy world of Gransys to face all the threats lurking within its wide open world, with the ultimate goal of slaying the mighty dragon. The premise is as typical as it sounds, until the game becomes completely insane in the final stretch in any case. Characters are not anything special, you might find a few you like, but a lot don't stand out. Main and sidequests can be intriguing and are decent justifications for your combat expeditions.

The main star is definitely the game's combat. It's heavily class based, with the weapons and skills usable depending on classes. There's 3 main classes of the usual archetypes (melee and shield, melee and bow or magic), and 6 others that are either more specialised and powerful versions of those or hybrids of two of them, and all 9 feel different to play. Basic melee combat has good feedback, and the multitude of skills available are fun to play with and picking and using them at appropriate times is vital to make it through encounters in one piece. Bows are also pretty fun to use and let you target weak points like you expect, and magic users can enjoy increasingly powerful tiers of spells, with the most powerful being incredibly devastating and fun to use.

In terms of enemies, you have the game's own takes of the usual fantasy creatures with impressive designs and a level of deadliness seen in few other places. Minor foes can overwhelm you with ease if underprepared and major foes will need all but the most powerful characters to take advantage of the game's mechanics and find weaknesses to exploit. The game's mechanic of climbing onto enemies comes in when facing larger foes, allowing you to reach and hit weak spots with melee attacks much easier.

You'll usually face the game's challenges with 1-3 AI-controlled companions in tow, recruited from other players usually. They are important for supplementing your chosen class in ways it may be deficient or just for the additional damage, and they do mostly work well, but the AI is far from perfect and it can be more than a little frustrating to see them idle or distracted when you seriously need their help.

A note on the Dark Arisen expansion content (included in this edition): What's said above applies to it, the main difference being even less direct plot and character interactions (though what is there is darker), the area being a really large dungeon with multiple segments (that aren't all completely unique unfortunately) rather than an open world, and a wealth of extremely deadly variants of the base game's enemies. The area can often make the worst the base game throws at you look like a tutorial. Harrowing but rewarding to get through.

Overall, it's a must play if you're looking for an action RPG with combat both challenging and satisfying.

I went in really hoping to enjoy this game. I spent a fair bit of time playing and it felt like most of the time I was waiting for the last piece of the puzzle to fall into place.

Everything feels like it's just almost there, but not quite:
- The grappling system for climbing on larger monsters is an awesome idea, but it can feel like you're fighting the controls/camera at times. It works okay on some enemies at least.
- The combat system might've been good back when the game came out, but I feel it really shows it's age.
- Boss/encounter seems to mix between annoying scripted events removing all player agency and/or just using a few interesting gameplay mechanics against a HP sponge.
- The class/vocation system is disappointingly narrow with the balance between abilities showing clear winners and you get funnelled into the same cookie cutter builds with uninspiring passive augments with minimal variance.
- NPC/Pawn AI is not really that great and the inability to direct your party members in any meaningful way is a frustrating experience.
- I personally found the story pretty lacklustre, which surprised me given how much some of the community seemed to praise it. None of it seems to really matter or go anywhere. Maybe this is an area that suffered due to the development problems?

The reality is that whilst this game might've been impressive back when it was released, these days you can find a better experience elsewhere.

I've been picking up and putting down this game over the years and never really beat it, but recently it really hooked me, from the combat, to the world, the depth of some mechanics and the interaction between pawns and players, I gotta say, this game is amazing, and with the second one on the horizon, there's not a better time to start playing this gem than now.

I beat this game purely and utterly out of spite. Everything Dragon's Dogma has to offer as an adventure-fantasy-RPG is squandered by its own technical laziness, sloppiness or otherwise. The main appeal this game has to offer is an A.I companion system called "pawns" and just like their soulless counter-parts, so too is this mechanic. Pawns barely function and are egregiously annoying to work around. God forbid you decide to play a non-magical class and have to depend on these spaghetti-coded bots to assist in a fight. 

The story is basic, the world offers 3-5 interesting npcs and the quests very quickly become boring chores to distract from an already boring main story. And on that note, quests cancel or fail themselves without prompt and because DD only has one save file, there's no going back. And the game saves over itself quite a lot. 

I can't even imagine playing this game without the DLC eternal ferrystone. Quick travel was the only thing making this game tolerable because every 2 minutes you are flanked by goblins, bandits or harpies. Remember, their kind ill likes fire. 

Anyways I'm gonna go play BG3. Don't play this game.

Dragon's Dogma starts off pretty strong. The world is interesting and the story is somewhat engaging, combine that with fun, monster hunter inspired combat and a day/night system, an emphasis on your custom army of followers, a decent craft/upgrade system, and you have a formula for success. When I was about 5 hours in, I remember thinking that this was going to be my next go to "open world time killer". However, the game began to show it's many flaws around this point.

For one, the world isn't quite that open. It's not very big and it's very repetitive and predictable. Not that this is always a bad thing. I had a fun time with games like KOTOR, Nier: Automata, and Final Fantasy XII, but this game just kinda misses the mark. It's just that the environments, while pretty at first glance, are pretty samey. The quests are incredibly boring: these are the fetchiest of fetch quests to ever exist. You will spend a ton of time backtracking through vast areas of nothingness, just to do some mundane thing for some unimportant person. Plus it's pretty buggy and unpolished. 

This has the makings of a great game, but the execution just isn't there. It seems like Capcom went with shooting for a strict deadline instead of taking the time to make a great product.

Picked this up on sale for 5 dollars. Since it's one of the few AAA games I've played and actually enjoyed I figure I'd give a very quick write up. It has all the stank of a capcom pc port: playable and few bugs/crashes due to port, but odd UI design and ux decisions. The controls don't seem to suffer much at all being on a keyboard.

Gameplay it's fantastic and refreshing for an action rpg. Storytelling is odd, mysterious, but in a good way. A good soundtrack. Don't expect Oblivion, it's more akin to a more arcade-y (and personally) more fun dark souls set a world not quite fallen so low. While there is npc interaction and dialogue it's certainly not the focus. The general vibe of adventuring and slaying monsters is what the game is about. You can grab and throw smaller enemies, grab and climb on larger ones, and most enemies have some sort of location based hitboxes that shake up strategies. There are 9 classes and not a one feels like it underperforms. The magic is absolutely brutal, summoning tornadoes and meteor showers at the highest levels with the lower level spells always maintaining use. I mainly played a mage/sorcerer and I loved the long cast times of the high level spells, the spectacle, and trying to get them cast in a hectic fight.

This game is a very easy one to recommend. Especially on sale.

A severely underrated fantasy RPG that even I myself overlooked for far too long.

If I were to even try to compare this game to another, i'd maybe say you were looking at something similar to Outward, except not even half as obnoxiously difficult. I say that because you're set into the deep end of a map with enemies that are potentially far stronger than you, and it's not like you can actually tell they are until you fight them because they don't have a level displayed above them. Aside from that, you still have a map you can use (and see your own location on), and the stamina usage isn't even nearly as painful as Outward was. Aside from those few similarities, this game i almost entirely in its own unique league. I can confidently say nothing i've ever played in 23 years comes close to the vibe of this game. 

I wanna say a few things I love and a few gripes I had, and hopefully this long-ass review lost in a sea of better reviews on an overlooked game will help you buy and enjoy it too. 

First off, this game has such a vibe that I haven't felt since I first discovered RPG gaming, was young and naive, and had some shred of joy left in my soul. Now as I play this I can at least say my husk of a human being got to feel the tiny spark of that same feeling I experienced as a young lad. I couldn't describe it further if I tired, but if you too share this declining lifestyle. I'm sure you'll understand.

I also love just how diverse you can be in this game, which is honestly extremely impressive for a game made in 2016. The combat is insane and personally I feel it rivals most newer games. You can climb onto monsters, crawl around to their weak spots (most enemies have at least one) and attack it. Even if that mf happened to be a griffon and takes off into the skies. You BET you can be clinging onto that creature for dear life trying to bring it down. You can also set up some insane combos, some of which aren't particularly designed to go together, but do so beautifully anyway. Just the amount of things you can do in combat is insane. You also have a very extensive list of classes you can become all of which can absolutely be changed at your own leisure. A feature that not enough games has (Seriously. I'm tired of restarting games just because I suddenly vibed with a mage build instead of my current sword and shield). 

The entire aesthetic of it holds up impressively well too. The graphics are a little behind (even for the time) and still it wouldn't bother you one bit. I actually enjoyed it more than some newer games. Sometimes less is more I guess. 

Now for my one complaint. Sometimes the party mechanics are just a little frustrating. Your companions are AI controlled and there isn't a single way to command them to do anything, you can set the behaviours for 1 main companion but I never really noticed the difference after doing that. They all kinda just do their own thing. They are effective at it, but more times than not they just fall short of doing the things I need them to do. I wish I could command them to focus on healing or maybe fall back and recover. Maybe even just not run off and fight things that aren't our concern. Even Dragon Age Origins, a much older game, had the ability to tell your companions to do / don't do certain things. That's just me though, maybe people enjoy not having to manage 3 other companions. 

Overall... Just play the game, it needs so much more recognition than it has. So slept on fr fr. I may even do a second run, screw it.

(PS. Be careful who you do quests for and how many you do for them, you may just inadvertently end up married to them without meaning to)

What a gem! Highly underrated for a game produced during the time where graphics are not as well developed as today. This game is more challenging as compared to Skyrim. Enemy characters have different weaknesses which can be exploited as opposed to mindless fighting head-on and getting wrecked. Lots of fun comprehensive active and passive skills that can be stacked. I look forward to Dragon Dogma 2.

Base game could easily be speed run and the story is as basic as it could get with the hero fighting the evil dragon trope. But that doesn't matter since DD:DA has:
1. Fun Vocation (Class) system which makes you wanna use all of them.
2.  Simple yet rich combat.
3. Neither easy nor difficult gameplay experience
4. High replayability
5. An Innovative Pawn System which makes you forget that the game is actually single-player because they talk to you throughout the journey. They're also really silly and funny for the wrong reasons (Listen to what they say after falling from a height). They're almost AI like and the game's been out for more than a decade.
6. Affinity System

While several cons don't affect the overall experience. the following should be considered: 
1. Escort missions lmao; helpless npcs tend to run straight into trouble when they're supposed to be escorted
2. The best content is actually towards the game's ending and the DLC area that's too difficult in the early levels despite accessibility.
3. Some DLC weapons are horrible and gated behind escort missions, making them a waste of time to do other than to experience the mission for the first time.
4. Affinity System lmao

Nonetheless, the cons are workable and even avoidable, and with all things considered, DD:DA mostly aged like fine wine compared to so many games these days. No wonder it remains a cult classic more than a decade after it was released in the PS3.

10/10 game, really looking forward to DD2 in 2025.

-Best pro-active combat and monster interaction in an Action-RPG.
-Great character creator for an A-RPG as even weight, height and sex affect the combat.
-Dynamic vocation switching allows for deep class exploration in a single run.
-The game has its own way of dealing with evasive moves instead of giving every vocation a dodge button: i-frames counter attacks, perfect blocks and parries, hyper armor, levitation and positioning, animation canceling, double jumps, etc.
-The Augments are vocation specific pasive skills that carry across all of them, promoting replayability.
-You can manually place up to ten fast-travel crystals anywhere in the world.
-The Pawn system where players can rent each other's AI companions online and form a party of up to 4 characters.
-In Dark Arisen, the Bitterblack Island expands on the game and focuses on hardcore combat, commonly refered as "the Dark Souls mode" for its structure and tone. It's also accessible from the very start of the game.
-Features a Speedrun mode.
-One of the first games to ever feature a photo mode since the 360/PS3 era.

The bad:
-Only one save file per account.
-Quest tracking and progression often unclear.
-Lacking default fast-travel locations besides Gran Soren and Cassardis in early game.
-RNG loot makes the end game a bit grindy.
-Scarce dialog choices.
-Slow main story pace.
-Pawn AI is very hit or miss and often learn the wrong lessons.
-Stat values and skill effects are often unspecified.

Solid 7/10

[h1] THE MOST UNDERRATED GENRE-MIXED GAME [/h1]

      [b] Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen [/b] is an underrated game with a marvelous hit feeling and skill diversity in 9 different playable classes. The game involves kind of details from the Elder Scrolls, Souls-like, and Monster Hunter game series. That's why, I entitled the game as genre-mixed. Hereby, let me describe the game in more detail.

     Dragon's Dogma is being fed by the NPC/AI companionship which is called as Pawns along the game. Pawns are customized NPCs that follow you throughout the game. Also, you can customize their behaviors and reaction attitudes against to issues and situations that you face. Additionally, you can enlarge your team in the interdimensional Rift Zone in the game. Rift Zone allows you to hire other players' pawns in online with Rift Coin (RC). Next, I would want to mention class diversity in the game with skills. The game consists of 9 different classes which can be unlocked with the respect points (RP). Indeed, all 9 classes have unique items and build systems. For instance, the mage knight has unique shield enchanting skills while the sorcerer has genuine sigil skills. All these details provide the RPG-based experience to the game. Moreover, fair enough foe species with different attacking shapes are looking to be inspired by Souls-Like and Monster Hunter games. Finally, the game story of Arisen apparently refers to the Chosen Dragonborn theme of Skyrim.

      Consequently, you won't waste your time in Dragon's Dogma in vain due to all these genre-mixed details were processed with the refined exertion of Capcom. I hope this review helps you to decide on the buying game.

Note: The game is not as hard as that mentioned in the comments section of Steam.

It started with the male citizens, but then the women started asking to be taken to ox pasture hay piles too, and then even the old and questionably young wanted "escorting" as well. Finally, it seemed like everyone had had their one grand adventure just twenty steps outside of their only city, but to my sore-bodied horror, the notice board started filling with requests from the burly guards. And when I "finished" the entire roster of the duke's guards, the board yet remained with six quests. The hostile bandits lined up like train cars for their services next. I dont want to talk about this anymore, but im starting to see the female bandits now too... I just wanted to fight a dragon that attacked my village, and All Ive done so far is cut off a hydra head. The notice board says six quests remain.

Fun gameplay with a decent-ish amount of variety, but with a number of dated and/or frustrating (even for the time) mechanics.

There's a number of things I really dislike about the game, but inventory management and traversal take the cake.
There's a ton of items to pick up, a lot maybe very useless but it's not rare not to know whether they are or not. Your carry weight is greatly restrictive too...
And to top it off, fast travel can be a bit of a chore if you don't have the right items. You'll be running around for the most part, with LIMITED STAMINA, and have to set up fast travel points if you want to help speed up your future travels. But you get limited items to set up travel points. I do appreciate the DIY approach, but it can get very infuriating...

Anyway, latching onto big beasts and bashing their skulls in is really fun, but I find it to be a tedious experience in between fights. Hopefully #2 will learn a few lessons.

For an unfinished game it has a lot of greatness packed into it, and even more potential.  I have probably purchased this game three times, from three different platforms because I just can't forget the thrilling adventures I've had playing this game.  Even now, in 2023, I have had a hard time finding games that give the same sense of adventure as Dragon's Dogma.  The controls are a bit stiff compared to modern standards and the unfinished feel of some areas are even more glaring today, but its still an adventure worth embarking on.

The game is well made and still holds up after all this time. 
There are still some problems that most people have stated, like not having a well established fast travel system, AI incompetence, and UI  problems. 
The combat and pacing are what really help the game out though. The big monster fights are stil some of the best in gaming and should get you excited for what they are going to do in the sequel. 
Overall it's a fun game with some mistakes that hold it back from being truly great.

This game originally came out in 2012 and I think that, at that time, this game would have been an absolute marvel. It has a MASSIVE, truly open world the likes of which I don't think would be surpassed until the recent Elden Ring. It was full of interesting places to explore, full of fantastic monsters and valuable rewards. Most of this map is there simply for the player's benefit, not fulfilling any quest objective of any sort. In my time with the game, I saw but a small fraction of the map by mostly just following the main quest path and would have seen far less had I not done the few side quests I did.

The game is also filled with tons of amazingly fresh ideas. From it's unique take on health and healing (magic healing can't completely heal you to full) to the game's spellcasting system (where multiple friendly spellcasters can join their efforts together) to it's monster climbing system (where you can literally scale massive beasts to get to their weak points). It also featured a robust character editor, both in terms of cosmetics as well as in terms of class/abilities.

But, sadly, it didn't completely come together. There were many areas that felt rough and unpolished. Great ideas hampered by very poor execution. And playing this game in the wake of more modern titles made this rough edges jagged and painful. Imperfections impossible to look past. Far too many to pretend they didn't exist. Almost every facet of the game is marred by one of these small, quality of life issues. And it's a real shame.

That being said, Dragon's Dogma 2 is on the horizon, and this game made me very excited to see what the team at Capcom can do with more time, money, and a fresh, modern eye to this game's exciting uniqueness. Here's hoping the sequel retains this game's fresh takes and interesting mechanics while sanding off those rough edges.

This is it... this is the fantasy game that let's me be me. I love the world so much. The characters, the story, the landscape! 
   It's a slow game that makes you take your time and does not hold your hand. Your actions are the answer often in quests. Simply attacking or being seen or even just being a man (or having one with you) decides the course of a quest. The obvious moral high ground is not always the best choice in the long run. It's a subtle game and not for everyone. 
   This is it for me though. This is the fantasy game that scratches my itches... The magic is slow and painful but, my god, when it goes off you just stand back and go "Yeah, I did that". The monsters are glorious their proportions and size mixed with a perfect camera  just make you go "you want me to fight that?!" 
   So if you wan't to play every class, have a band of ever changing and unique party members (pawns), no gods or holy orders bothering you, a whole village of cousins, whatever destiny you choose, packs of wolves that ill like fire, water that sweeps you away like an all night bender, the ability to pick everyone up, play catch the hog, dragons that literally just steal your heart, other dragons, an Island of bitter black death, a single save file that's kept in you appdata folder (wtf), a character creator that crashes if you controller is plugged in, the ability to play as a chonky character, physics based on your actual size and weight, then play Dragons Dogma!
P.S.
(Also there is a great ENB that makes it look stunning and modern Resonant ENB on Nexus.)
