I had played the original on ps3. So I thought I should try the dark arisen expansion after all these years. And I don't recall why I enjoyed this game after replaying it. The dark arisen just adds the most annoying and tedious endgame. I have seen in a rpg. 
Start with a some list of things that were okay.

Vocation/classes: 3 standard classes, 3 advanced version (kinda) and three hybird classes. A fair amount of skills and magic. Late game though you should probably just become a magick archer, best vocation.

Music: in a few fights they play some absolute bangers, besides that forgettable soundtrack

So now on to the cons
Story: Dogwater

Combat:  You get hit once. You will either have to watch something smacking you in a animation for five seconds and they you will fall to the ground and slowly get up. Or you'll have to wiggle your stick for 4 seconds to 15 seconds depending of what kind of grapple you get hit by (pawns can help here but they are more likely just to watch, they kinky like that). Well laying on the ground you are invincible, but during you standing up animation which takes 3 seconds you are fully susceptible to be damage and combo'd further. So I've had situations were I was stun locked for minutes at a time. But it's cool because you can just pause and use as many health items whenever. (I see this as a band-aid for shitty combat design) 

Travelling: Your stamina runs out after 10 seconds of running, which you'll get 20 feet. Then takes 40 secs to refill your stamina while your character does the most half hearted jogging (the speed is closer to walking then a jog). And if you run into enemies while low on stamina you get to use one or two skills during the fight.
You only get two standard fast travel spots, but you can get 5 portcrystal's which you can place anywhere on the open map. Problem though is you will be going between 10 plus places constantly, so no matter what you're going to just be running to the same place again and again.

The pawn A;I: Your friendly a.i is there to troll you and just be a distraction for the horde of enemies. They will constantly just stand around in fights not doing anything while you get mobbed, then do one thing and say they good for the next few minutes.
Walking close to edges or narrow walkways is a gamble whether your pawn will randomly commit sudoku. You'll know buy seeing/hearing them say "What a gaffe..." Get use to seeing that every 20 mins. So you'll be down a pawn or three for the rest of the mission. hopefully you don't run into a enemy that can only be hurt with magic after your mages sudoku.

Mages A.I: Yes they get there own section. They love running under large enemies to cast spells that take 10 seconds to charge and act like they won't get interrupted every time. Unless you have killed like a 100 of that enemy and they have max knowledge of a enemy they will not use the most effective spells against a type of enemy. Even if it's the only spell they have. (like we fighting a bunch of cursed enemies want to enchant our weapons with holy, no?) Your mage has a healing spell. only one they will use in combat. cause someone will always have some white health. 
They will be most done casting a spell then just stop and run 5 feet and start casting again.

Dark arisen/ the expansion: The only positive thing to say about the expansion is the final boss music is fuking good. Besides that is the most most tedious and grindy endgame. Having the second strongest weapons and being max level. I do fractions of damage to most enemies in the expansion. The fights are tedious because you are doing less then 10% of they're health bar every few minutes. P.s most larger enemies have a minimum of 8 health bars. How do you get the strongest weapons, of easy you grind chest's (4 in total, but two can only be accessed briefly after beating the final boss, but that will restart the expansion in a sense) that have a 2% chance of giving you the bitterblack weapon lvl 3, then you have to get it purified and role a chance to get a weapon your class can use. I gave up after getting 5 that were ones that nether me or my main pawn could use.

Great feature of doing too well in the dlc will spawn a super powerful enemy by you, doesn't matter if you are fighting a bosses or large group of enemies. And death may randomly pop up during that as well.
I swear everything in this dlc is just made to instant kill your pawns. Not like oh you pawn ran outta health go revive them, just of your pawn got hit by this one thing. So go recruit a new one, cause he dead as a doorknob.

[spoiler]The dlc story is worst then the main game. Oh this Arisen instead of choosing one of the two chooses of the dragon, told him to go fuk himself and now he cursed.[/spoiler]

I am here to echo the sentiment of this game being very underrated and slept on. I came from hundreds of hours of Skyrim, Witcher 3, Elden Ring, and Breath of the Wild. Dragon's Dogma seemed right up my alley. I am happy to report that I wasn't disappointed at all. 
Dragon's Dogma released in 2012 for the PS3 and Xbox 360, and it likely got overshadowed by Skyrim and Dark Souls. But the game is absolutely worth your time, and in many ways it does feel like an Elder Scrolls game if it had actual, good combat. 
The combat and pawn system are the biggest selling points of the game. The pawn AI is generally very good, and though their dialogue can get repetitive sometimes ("WOLVES HUNT IN PACKS") there is a charm to it, in no small part thanks to how good the voice acting is. 
You know that feeling familiar to the LOTR films or kids playing DnD? That feeling of being an actual party of adventurers facing peril together in a fantasy world? With the nerdy camaraderie and sense of adventure, like you're a bunch of kids dressing up like knights and wizards? This game (and potentially Elden Ring) is the only game I've played that has actually captured that feeling in the most authentic way. The interactions with your pawns during combat, and the thrill of climbing a huge monster while your mages pelt it with spells is incredible. 
The combat on its own should sell most people on the game. It has the same satisfying nature to it familiar to anyone who uses greatswords in FromSoft or Monster Hunter games. There is good hitlag and emphasis on timing and positioning. Paired with the climbing system and the incredible music, it lends itself to some truly Lord Of The Rings-feeling moments throughout the game (specifically, it may remind you of when the Fellowship took down the cave troll in the Mines of Moria). The lack of convenient fast travel, besides the few portcrystals they give you is one of my biggest gripes with the game - as well as the lack of variety in scenery in many places. But these aren't things that should dissuade you from the game.
I am only 32 hours into the game and yet to finish it, but I cannot stress enough how much this game needs more of your attention. It quickly became one of my favorite games. I am having a blast and I cannot wait for the sequel which was recently announced.
Maybe the real Dogma were the Dragons we made along the way.

How to say this, grabbing is something I never thought I'd need in a game. But the whole gameplay got better just by the addition of grabbing. My pawn saved me by jumping on another pawns shield and grabbing me midair when a harpy dropped me. That whole scene was epic, too bad I don't generally play with recorder on.  
Also grabbing makes escort quests super easy. You can just carry the idiots when they get stuck. Never have I enjoyed escort quest as much as this, even though the clients are silent and there's no banter, which is a major plus point for me in any quest.
The dialogue and characters of the world seems bland, the story is nothing to boast about, graphics are ok, but the gameplay alone is worth it. 
From traversal to fighting, it's a joy. And with so many miniboss fights it's never boring even though they tend to be easy enough at high levels. 
My sole gripe would be that it's too easy to level up. Money is not a concern. With the fighting focused on skills rather than typical item damage, purchasing items isn't worth it. But on the plus side it means you can go for fashion instead of stats and perks. I guess people play with just their main pawn, where as I play with all three. Maybe that's why it's so easy for me. 
But the early games were truly a nightmare in nighttime when 3 ogres or chimeras attack at once.
And this game had the best Dragon fights out of all the games I've played. Be it Skyrim, Dark souls, DAO, Witcher or whatever you can name (Midir being the sole exception, but even then, if you can solo a Dragon, is it truly a dragon?). It requires strategy and a solid team work, as well as knowing where to strike.. Unless you are high level and have loads of stamina potions (which is a minus point for me in every RPG)
Fighting bosses and even normal enemies become fun when you're not just fighting to win, but trying to attack a specific body part so that it would drop that loot you need. Like attack the tusk of a cyclop to get a broken tusk or target the horns on a Dragon to get the dragon horn. All this means, even when the enemy becomes repetitive in high level, it still makes it fun to fight them. 
I don't know if there's a Mod like SKyrim Legend, that lets the enemy level up with you. If so, this game would never be boring.

I've spent 100+ hours on something that is a glorified MonHun clone. 

Story is super barebone, cutscenes have classic Capcom quality in both directing and acting - like original RE classic. Ending is mediocre. Most quests are simplistic fetch/kill quests, even mainline ones. 

Game really wants to waste your time, too - there's extremely limited fast travel (you get 5 beacons to place on MASSIVE map full of enemies in a first playthrough, 5 more later and that's it), you can't run for shit without running out of stamina all the time or slowing down to a crawl because you're overencumbered again, and it requires grinding for levels, support items, random drops for enhancement and so on. 

Another my complaint is that in its infinite wisdom Capcom decided to lock out most classes out of dodge roll and double jump - those are only available to a dagger-wielding classes. Amazing. Without those mobility options game becomes three times as annoying.

What I actually liked is pawn dress up and exploration - other than crossing wast swaths of land on foot it was pretty fun to climb and jump around the Gran Soren or Bluemoon Tower. And Bitter Black Island, that one had a bit of Dark Souls feel to it, even if they absolutely cut corners by copy-pasting half of the rooms in that one.  Why did I spend so much time on it if I didn't like it that much?

Final note: 8/10

[h1] A Japanese style 'action' RPG [/h1]

- Not your usual hand holding western RPGs
- Some mechanics aren't explained but aren't a worry to casual players
- Pawn system is cool (Basically a companion system you make your own and take up to 2 other player's pawns if you want to). It's more in-depth but cba explaining
- Quests are come and go, some quests are not shown meaning you have to explore the map with certain npcs to see if they have a quest available
- There is a 'romance' system but its very information lacking to the player without external information
- Ur-Dragon can be done Solo (Offline) or Online but damage done is accumulated with other people doing it in their domain (You cannot 'actively' play with other people in the online version, basically the online Ur-Dragon shares the same health pool with everyone connected online)
- Very niche style of game play somewhat old school
- The masterworks all you can't go wrong
- Day and night cycle changes the spawns of the map
- Acts/Chapters within the game are not told to you
- When you complete the game you will be allowed to change your character appearance
- Only 1 save slot but completing the game again (2nd time) puts you against your previous character if you make a new one
- I found the Anime terrible

Get it on sale if any of those points convince you

One of the most underappreciated capcom games to exist, this game has some of the best action combat I've experienced in a RPG ever with its crunchy hit-stopping melee, badass spectacle magic that I haven't seen any game top, interactive online pawn system, environment manipulation, climbing mechanic,WIDE class variety and depth, great DLC and endgame content.

Only downsides in this game are that the RPG elements are severely poor with what you expect of the genre. Roleplay options and a good story, the narrative is non existent, starts good then disappears for the whole game then peaks again at the very end, narrative is very weak in this game (the front cover dragon is only good part), same with the player choice aspect, it just doesn't exist its very linear and kinda predictable you make no meaning full decisions that can impact the story in anyway or alter questlines (this game is notorious for being unfinished and it shows in the aspect) 

AND also the terrible,terrible, TERRIBLE choice to exclude any form of a normal fast travel system or mounts in a game with map that isn't exactly small. You're going to be mostly walking and running around for awhile if you dont find/figure out the unorthodox travelling system, so keep that one in mind, turns alot of people off early on sadly (hopefully Dogma 2 has mounts.)

GAMEPLAY is king in Dragons Dogma, and should be the sole reason to check out this game, its the highlight by far and sets it apart from its release year counterpart Skyrim. Extremely looking forward to see how Dragons Dogma 2 pans out now with a much bigger budget to toy with and alot of the cutting room floor content being restored and realised in the sequel cant wait! this game is deffo worth buying goes on sale all the time for £3 quid lol just buy it.

Criminally overrated.

Seriously, I've heard so many great things about the game - that the combat is great (it's neat), that the vocation system is great (it's terrible), that the pawn system is unique (uniquely terrible for the most part). I wasted over 40 hours on this mess only because the combat was somewhat enjoyable, said enjoyability waning as the same couple of enemies were being slain over and over again. 

The map is bland, static and needlessly big for the stamina system to work properly (yeah, the stamina sucks too). Quests are a joke. The weight system is an even funnier joke (why the fuck is this a thing). The vocation system is neat at first, but it quickly becomes a chore as you need to grind levels with specific vocations in order to get a decently built character. Most skills are obsolete as there are a few that just break the game (brain splitter, for example) making the combat very repetitive. The climbing looks cool, but it very janky and most vocations suck at it (which is a terrific decision considering that it is one of the main selling points). The difficulty is hot mess consisting of fighting a chimera for 20 minutes straight (my first one) and then killing it in a matter of seconds dozens of hours later (my 50th one, I guess). Oh, and who can forget the worst equipment I think I've seen in a videogame - extremely clunky, slow, and powerful. You can easily pause the game at any moment and heal to full HP after clicking on the same item for like 20 seconds. If you want to use a throwing bomb you have to select it, wait for the animation (you don't have to do that if you heal, by the way), use the item, and then select it again (XDDDDDDDDDD).

The worst part is that I was actually enjoying the game for a brief moment when I was still leveling up my vocations. Despite all of these issues there is a good game there somewhere. I just wish the fans of the game didn't have to lie in order for it to look better ("It's like Dark Souls", where? I'm genuinely asking, it's nothing like the game.)

It's like a plate with a splat of solid action game mixed with a greasy goo of terrible RPG mechanics.

I enjoy action RPGs with more skill-based combat and Dragon's Dogma doesn't disappoint. Along with Capcom-style fighting (good) you do get Capcom-style menus (very bad), but it's worth bearing with as the game has two genuinely novel features. Pawns, allowing you to recruit other player's custom-built sidekicks into your party. And my favourite, monster climbing. To kill a cyclops, it's ineffective smacking its ankles with your sword, you have to jump on, climb up and get stuck into its eye. So slaying monsters is more involving and each a mini-adventure on its own. I recommend playing on Easy difficulty or Hard Mode, because in Normal difficulty many enemies can still one shot you but you don't get tons of XP and gold like you do in Hard Mode. "Normal" seemed harder to me!

Really enjoyed this game. The pawn system is unique and not like something I have seen before. Thought it was great you can have one that you customise yourself and also hire another persons' and or your friends' pawns.
Even though the game is a bit dated graphics wise, you can look past that due to the interesting story line. One of the main parts I consider essential to an RPG is having different endings, and this game delivers. I wasn't expecting it and I am glad I got different options to end the game. 
I thought I would just mention that the option to fill empty flasks with oil to re light your lantern and the realism of your lantern extinguishing if you go into water was a really nice touch. 
Furthermore, I am glad I got the dark arisen version, I wouldn't be able to stand all of that travelling without the fast travel options of the port crystals (an item that you cast into the ground and you can teleport to). Even then, I would like a few more because it can feel a bit like a walking simulator at times - considering how long it takes to get places and find port crystals. Still, I guess it's also a positive because it gives you the chance to encounter enemies and level up your character - UNLESS the enemies are far stronger than you, that sucks.
I don't know if its like this for all of the characters, but a main gripe of mine was the stamina level for a mage. I decided to play as a mage arisen, and the amount of times I ran and then kept running out of stamina (despite not carrying a heavy load) was really frustrating, especially when you want to get somewhere quick or dodge an enemy in a big fight.
ALSO give us multiple save file options and better romance mechanics! I'm sad I can't really re visit my old character and also I maxed Julien's affinity but made the mistake of doing Aelinore's personal quest, which - [spoiler] suddenly made my character and her in a relationship and kiss, which to me made no sense. So I ended up with her in the end when the dragon takes someone you care about, DESPITE ME GIVING THE RING TO JULIEN. This is apparently if you max affinity a lot of people, it then decides who the dragon takes in alphabetical order?? The game should make who you give the ring to actually important, by then having it guaranteed they will get taken by the dragon - otherwise that whole item is kinda pointless imo.[/spoiler]
Other than that, I already want to replay it and made another character lol. Excited for Dragon's Dogma 2!

One of the best games I've ever played!

I've owned 4 copies of this game since the original release on PS3 and every time I come back to this game, I enjoy it more than the last time.

Story:
While the story is has a very unique and interesting concept, it somewhat fails in the execution. There's nothing wrong with not having a voiced player character, but without many, if any, dialogue options, many of the story beats fall flat. An NPC will say something and my character will just stare at them with a blank expression. I like how New Game+ can be considered as a canon continuation of your initial playthrough as you attempt to break the "Eternal Cycle". While the game world is cheerful and sometimes goofy, the story is actually quite deep and depressing but in a good way.

Combat:
This is where the game truly shines. As an 11 year old game, the combat still holds up and even outperforms many more recent action RPGs. It's the main reason I keep coming back to this game. It's a shame more RPGs haven't emulated or been inspired by the combat in Dragon's Dogma. For the time, it was innovative, and more RPGs could have benefited from having similar mechanics implemented.

The Boss fights are always fun with Dragon's Dogma climbing mechanic where you can scale bosses and attack specific weak spots. Nothing more satisfying than thrusting your dagger into a cyclops' eye!

The animations, specifically for spells, are incredible and make you feel way more powerful than mage/sorcerers in other RPGs. All the classes, even the basic ones you choose at the beginning of the game, are fun to play as and sometimes preferred over more specialised classes. The only class that isn't as great is the Warrior vocation as you can only use 3 abilites whereas every other class can use 6. It's still pretty fun to use despite this.

My favourite classes, the Mystic Knight and Magick Archer combine, fighters with mages and striders with mages respectively, feel pretty unique and I encourage any new player to experiment with all the vocations instead of sticking to one as they're all great!

Gameplay:
I think this game fails as a true RPG and I believe it's more appropriate to call this an action game with RPG elements, though it's a very good action game. It can be very difficult at first and stamina management can be an issue early on but if you can stick with it the game becomes a lot easier as enemies don't scale. This does unfortunately mean that some parts of the game can become too easy, but the post-game and the Bitterblack Isle expansion can provide more of a challenge later. I recommend playing on Normal (not Easy) on your first playthrough and then on Hard in NG+ to give yourself a reasonable challenge. You just have to get through the difficult early game.

Unfortunately you're limited to one save, presumably so the servers aren't bloated with too many pawns from multiple save games, so make sure you get your character and your pawn right in character creation! You can only change their appearance once in a single playthrough and won't be able to again until NG+. There is a barbershop you can also use, but the changes you can make are limited.

Pawns:
They are hilarious, adorable, and give this game so much personality. They don't stop talking but this is a good thing. They're quips are iconic and I could hear 'Even in numbers, a weakling is a weakling still.' all day. You can adjust their personality though it takes some work and all of them are funny. Other players' pawns populate your world and you can recruit them on the road or in the cities as well as in the Rift, the place they come from. Likewise people can recruit your pawn and you can earn an in-game currency from it. Sometimes you may get racist or offensive pawns, like young children in thongs, in your world and it's a shame there's no way to remove them or report the creator. If you are easily offended, it may be best to play this game offline and use the default pawns that populate the world instead, but I hope you won't let that get in the way because there are some incredible creations.

Character Creation:
For me, this is one of the best character creators. You have true freedom with their body type and can even make a child if you want to play as one. While it can be hard to make as visually appealing a character as modern RPGs, the freedom and sheer number of options from hairs, faces, arm, body and leg shapes is appreciated, all without the use of finicky sliders!

Conclusion:
A flawed masterpiece that built an incredible world that I can't wait to dive back into with Dragon's Dogma II. I can't recommend this game enough although I acknowledge it may not be for everyone. It may be too easy for fans of soulslikes and may be too barebones for RPG lovers but Dragon's Dogma had something special here. For the price I'd say it's at least worth a try. You might end up loving this game as much as I did and still do 11 years later!

One of my favorite games of all time. Flat out., top 5. It's also, kinda trash.

The writing is kinda shit and feels like bad Shakespeare most of the time (except Grigori I love him), the combat is incredibly imbalanced and at times can be impossible but also easy to break, none of the classes are remotely balanced with each other, the pawns are heckin' stupid at times, exploring the main game isn't all that fun, the quests are meh and the sidequests especially are dogpoo... So why do I like it?

Sheer, unbridled fun and charm.

The character creation is single-handedly THE most in-depth character customizer ever. I have never seen another come close to the breadth of options you have here. Not just in hair styles, but you can make your character any size or build you want, from a tiny 3-foot tall gnome, to a 7+ foot giant. From a brick wall of muscle, to the lankiest elf possible, to a morbidly obese dude. And the height and overall weight of your character even affects certain aspects of their stats!

And while combat and classes are unbalanced, they went ALL OUT in making each class go absolutely apeshit bonkers by the end. At the start of the game you'll feel kinda bad at everything no matter what class, but just wait until endgame. Every class is somehow broken in their own way (except mage lol, just pretend that's only for pawns.)

Fighter? Dragon's Maw spam, just become a whirlwind of DPS.
Warrior? Get yoself that Arc of Oblieration. THIRTY SECONDS charge time in a fast-paced action game is an eternity, but you know it's fun when you have to measure the damage of a single hit in how many *healthBARS* you wipe out.
Assassin? Become literally invincible because lol, lmao, and just do infinity DPS on any big dude.
Sorcerer? Summon tornados and meteor showers. Not cutscene spells, no. And these aren't small baby tornadoes. You can just summon a damn 50-foot-tall F5 maelstrom of a tornado that launches enemies so high into the air they'll die of fall damage if they don't get obliterated before it runs out. And those meteors? The size of dang semi trucks. In a game that vaguely plays like a souls-like! Dark Souls doesn't let you summon tornadoes.
Strider? Sonic spindash go brrrrrrrr
Ranger? See Warrior, except you kill a pawn to deal 5 healthbars of damage in one homing arrowshot from a mile away because why not.
Mystic Knight? Just spam magical turrets and watch enemies get dissolved. Or like, buff your pawns so they can do the cool stuff.
Magick Archer? You basically become a one-man fireworks show, assuming you don't just set yourself on fire and hug everything to death.

Highly recommend, especially if you have a love for somewhat janky but very fun and charming games with their imperfections.

Dragon's Dogma is my all-time favourite game. In my eyes, it has been a bit of an unsung masterwork. Hopefully it won't stay that way now that Dragon's Dogma 2 is in the works! 

- [b]The Combat:[/b] When I first picked up Dragon's Dogma, the combat is what drew me in. To this day I cannot get enough of it. Although I adore soulslikes such as Nioh and am very fond of the Monster Hunter games, none of them scratch the action-combat itch quite like Dragon's Dogma does. Every vocation (class) feels fleshed out, particularly the Mystic Knight for its powerful and satisfying counter and the Strider/Ranger/Assassin vocations for their speed, dodge and movement based attacks. All of the vocations were tons of fun, but those listed above quickly became my favourites. I must note that the game lacks a lock-on mechanic, but this gives the combat more freedom and an extra layer of difficulty/mastery. Players are encouraged to place their moves carefully and opt for favorable positions, whether it be on the ground or hanging from a chimera's tail.

- [b]The Pawn System[/b]: Bolstering the game's meaty combat is the pawn system. "Pawns" are NPC allies created by fellow players. You will be given your very own pawn to customise and use during your adventure. You may choose their class, speech pattern, weapons and abilities. As you level them up, their prowess will improve. While sometimes goofy, pawns are generally a great help and make for good company! Before you know it, you'll have developed a bond with your otherworldly companion. 

- [b]The World/Story[/b]: Gransys, the game's setting, and its creatures are both awe-inspiring and intimidating. The map is laden with strongholds and temples of old, all beautifully crafted with greek and roman inspired architecture. It becomes clear that the world of Dragon's Dogma is ancient, and that much knowledge and history has been lost to time. Might you be one of the few souls capable of accessing the secrets of the universe, of taking up arms and confronting the Dragon? Your trial awaits, newly Arisen!

I have played the PC version of Dragon's Dogma for over 400hrs, and roughly 50hrs on the Switch version at the time of writing this review. This game stole my heart, and now I get to have it stolen all over again when Dragon's Dogma 2 drops. If you like action RPGs, consider giving this one a shot!

Story was kinda ass, but the combat, classes, and the pawn system were cool. I look forward to DD2 because the foundations of the game are good and a more modern take on it will probably be great.

Dragon's Dogma Dark Arisen - An Epic Odyssey of Adventure and Freedom

Introduction:

Dragon's Dogma Dark Arisen is a masterpiece that has left an indelible mark on my gaming journey. From the very moment I stepped foot into the vast and breathtaking world of Gransys, I knew I was about to embark on an unforgettable adventure. This game, developed by Capcom, is a testament to the power of storytelling, thrilling combat, and the boundless freedom it grants players, making it an unparalleled and powerful gaming experience.

Epic Fantasy World:
Gransys is a living, breathing world teeming with secrets, danger, and wonder. From the sun-soaked plains to the hauntingly beautiful forests, every corner of the map exudes an unparalleled sense of awe and intrigue. Exploring its vast landscapes, uncovering hidden dungeons, and facing the dangers lurking in the darkest depths was an immersive experience that made me feel like a true adventurer.

Unique Pawns and Dynamic Battles:
The innovative Pawn system in Dragon's Dogma Dark Arisen sets it apart from other RPGs. I had the freedom to customize my main Pawn and recruit others, each with their unique skills and personalities. The AI-driven Pawns learned from my actions, adapting and evolving as I ventured deeper into the adventure. Battles were dynamic and intense, requiring strategic thinking, quick reflexes, and mastery of the game's deep combat mechanics.

Freedom of Exploration:
This game truly embodies the essence of freedom. Whether scaling towering cliffs, battling colossal monsters, or delving into ancient ruins, the sense of agency over my actions was exhilarating. The non-linear progression allowed me to follow my own path, and the choices I made had genuine consequences, leading to a sense of ownership over my character's fate.

Fearsome and Majestic Creatures:
The thrill of battling the colossal and fearsome beasts that roam Gransys cannot be understated. Each encounter was a pulse-pounding experience, testing my skills and tactics. From the terrifying chimera to the awe-inspiring dragon, every encounter left me in awe and on the edge of my seat.

Lore and Intriguing Story:
The rich lore and captivating narrative of Dragon's Dogma Dark Arisen drew me in and refused to let go. Unraveling the mysteries of the Arisen, the Dragon, and the world's history was a deeply satisfying experience. The game's atmospheric storytelling and intriguing characters kept me engrossed, urging me to uncover every secret and piece together the puzzle of Gransys.

Lasting Impact:
Even after completing the main quest, Dragon's Dogma Dark Arisen beckons players to continue their journey with challenging post-game content. The sheer amount of content and replay value is a testament to the game's depth and ability to keep players engaged for countless hours.

Conclusion:

Dragon's Dogma Dark Arisen is a powerful and unforgettable gaming experience that has carved a permanent place in my heart. From the sprawling fantasy world to the dynamic combat and freedom of exploration, every aspect of the game oozes passion and dedication from the developers at Capcom. This epic odyssey captured my imagination, making me feel like a true Arisen on an extraordinary quest. It is a testament to the power of video games as a medium for storytelling, adventure, and the ability to leave a lasting impact on players. Without a doubt, Dragon's Dogma Dark Arisen stands tall among the greatest RPGs of all time, and I wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone seeking an awe-inspiring journey into the realms of fantasy and adventure.

The sequel can't come fast enough.

Spoiler free review. An extremely interesting game. A lot of fun, but it feels very dated and old. Overall recommend. There are a lot of pros and a lot of cons, but I spent 90 hours on my first play through (I really tried to do everything) and do not regret it. My con list may be longer but I believe the pros **way** more than outweigh any problems. The game was simply very enjoyable and had a good game play loop formula. Those with little tolerance for old games or poor game design may find themselves frustrated and annoyed.

Pros:
- Unique combat and rpg experience
- You can climb on the giant monsters. It looks a little janky at times, but it results in some awesome moments.
- Pawn system is something I have never seen before and extremely interesting, if sometimes a little frustrating.
- Each class is a completely unique experience. Even something like mage to sorcerer (which is mostly an upgraded mage) is a surprisingly different experience. Melee, Ranged, and Magic are COMPLETELY different from eachother and use completely different mechanics. Classes have great identities. I really felt like I wanted to play a melee class just to see everything that was different.
- Combat is varied and enjoyable
- Giant monsters are awesome
- The dragons are actually awesome, yes actually this time! (looking at you skyrim)
- The story is actually really good but it is basically not there at all for 90% of the game.
- Some quests are actually very thoughtful and have a lot of heart. A lot of them caught me off guard as they are mixed in with empty, boring quests.
- The final dragon fight is exceptional.
- Some of the music is eh, but a lot of it is really good. It makes combat feel very grand.
- All of the three "Ending sequences" are very satisfying.
- The end credits for the final ending is really cool.

Cons
- the monsters are very pretty (for 2012) and the monster animations are frequently very fluid and surprisingly natural looking (again for 2012) and lots of the spell effects look good, but other than that the game is frankly ugly. Lots of grays and dark colors. Even the supposedly black pieces of armor are gray in color, which is sad because I think the game could be extremely pretty. The grpahics were dated the moment it released in 2012, a year after skyrim which is no art masterpiece, but looks much prettier than this game.
- There are so little mods from lack of modding tools. Lots of the problems with the game can't be community patched out. You have to deal with them.
- Lots of the quests are just as soulless as skyrim's and many are more annoying.
- Some quests or actions are completely unintuitive. For example, there is a griffon you are hunting and the quest gives you some vague instruction of "Lure the griffon down" but what it wants you to do is kill some creature, pick up its corpse (you have never needed to do this before now btw) and carry it to a marked area to bait the griffon. Another quest which annoys me greatly is one called Idol Worship where effectively you are asked by some merchants to get a token. There is no indication of what the correct token is, or any indication there are multiple types of tokens at all. So you could very likely be like "Oh I found one of those idols I already have it I can complete this right away! :) but actually you just handed in the fake bronze token which gets you nothing and does not expand the shops inventory. If you find the true token later, you don't get to hand it in. The quest is over, you completed it the wrong way. This kind of bad game design unfortunately encourages wiki diving which will spoil a lot of cool things and did for me.
- Lots of just bad or dated game design choices like the quests I just mentioned. For one, the high level DLC area (Dark Arisen content) called Bitterblack Isle is presented to you right away. You might think this is because you are supposed to do it, but this is actually something you do in "Post Game"
- Lots of points of no return. For the most part these are clearly marked and communicated but it can be unclear if the game really means it closes all your quests or if its just exaggerating (it isn't exaggerating, finish your quests first). The final point of no return in "Post Game" is not clear at all and locks you out of a particular dungeon. When you get a quest to hand in 20 Wakestones to someone *that is a point of no return* do not finish that quest until you want the game to be over and stop playing. There is no recovering from that point.
- It is sometimes unclear if you are doing something wrong or not geared enough for an area. This is especially the case in Bitterblack Isle where the monsters are quite strong. The damage calculation is linear, so if an enemy has 1000 magic armor and you do 1000 magic damage it will take no damage, but then every bit of damage extra you deal is straight to their health. This often results in you either being unable to touch a boss, or completely bouncing off of them.
- Magic immune enemies in particular are very unfun if you are a caster. Ironically, there are physical immune enemies which are not a problem for physical characters. This is because a simple enchanted weapon deals magic damage. Thus a melee character can just use one of those weapons and fix it. The casters solution is this: if you are a sorcerer, Giciel and Bolide deal tiny amounts of physical damage. If you are a mage, you got nothing. Other than that you have to rely entirely on your melee pawns to do it which sometimes works alright, but mostly is infuriating while you stand there waiting for your pawns to kill sometimes for you while you do nothing at all.
- End game Bitterblack isle is just unfun (at least for me as a sorcerer) there were a lot of magic immune enemies and other enemies with huge health pools which can one shot your squishy butt. One at a time these enemies aren't the worst but end game BBI likes to throw these enemies two or three at a time, forcing you to cheese them or take forever to chip them down. It really encourages just running past everything. This also combined with most of the BBI enemies are weak to Holy and most characters who aren't melee characters have very few options to deal holy damage. As a sorc you will end up spamming Holy Focused Bolt more times than you can shake a stick at. 


For all of these cons though, I loved the game and thoroughly recommend it.

DD:DA is an open world RPG, if you didn't know. [spoiler] It is also an unfinished masterpiece. [/spoiler]

I'll keep it somewhat brief and say the combat is excellent and feels really good regardless of the vocation you're playing and offers enough playstyle variety to keep it interesting for multiple playthroughs, or if you get bored easily.
There are many large (and small) creatures to fight with a grappling system that sometimes feels really good, other times may leave a bit to desire.

The pawn system is really fun, customizable and interesting. One of my favorite parts of the game [i] and generally team based mechanics do not interest me.[/i] Having one pawn along with you at all times from the beginning of the game feels really cute and fun. 
Building the right kind of team for a tough mission or just figuring out whats coolest aesthetically is really an enjoyable experience.

The world while at times can feel empty often has many little secrets hidden away in weird corners of the map and actually ends up being pretty fun to explore at times. Backtracking can get frustrating at times but there's ways around that in Dark Arisen.

The sound design is solid and the game still looks good.

The writing is overall solid. It certainly improves as the game goes on and by the end had me fully invested.
This is goes into where I think the biggest issue with the game lies, it was released without realizing its full potential. 
That said, I don't want that to be something that steers you away, this game is 100% earns a recommendation from me. So long as you can stick through a slow beginning I have good faith that the majority of people interested will find something to enjoy here.

Buy it, take your time, be patient, get creative and realize the game is more open ended and detailed than you realized initially, and fall in love. :)

A friend of mine spent 10 years telling me this game is amazing. It is. I went into it, finally, thinking that it would be too outdated and, yes, there is things that are long gone from that era but what they built is very solid to this day. Combat is simple but extremely fun, especially the selling point of climbing on monsters. It not a difficult game but you can still fail if you are not careful. The story is interesting for what they were going for! While everyone was under the wings of Skyrim still when this came out (I am one of them) I do feel bad that it did not got the spot it deserved. I would criticize some mechanics like having stamina and carry limit but even “modern” games still do this and for that it holds some charm (while being a bit frustrating at times). I was glad to have experience it and just like my buddy I became a zealot for more.
A diamond in the rough. Don't sleep on this game.

This game was recommended to me as a great RPG however I fail to see what's great about it other than the unique pawn system. When one of the first missions in the game is you following a cart and protecting it while really slowly traversing a mountain pass then I think you're wasting the players time, I cannot describe how mind numbingly boring most of this game has been, it takes ages to get around the map. 

I also should have done more research on the game itself in that it has a Monster Hunter type combat system which I find to be extremely jarring and tedious.

I just managed to play this game. Personally, I am crazy about RPG and open-world stuff, and I was very upset that it was taking me so long to play DD: Dark Arisen! But now, why wouldn't I recommend this game? I had two reasons for not recommending it. First of all, there is no option to load the specific save data you want. You can't have multiple saves, and it must be a role-playing game. A cheap copy of the Elder Scrolls series. The next crazy thing is that you collect so many materials during the game, and you can even mine some stone. But guess what? There's no crafting system at all in this game. No, wait, there is... but it's from the Resident Evil series crafting system. You have to combine only a special series of items, not any type of item. For example, you cannot forge a sword or armor by combining some metal. However, the game also has interesting features that are overshadowed by these shortcomings, such as a unique fast travel system and some mini-bosses. But they are not important. I think the creator of the original Resident Evil 4, when they felt bored, just decided to make this game. It's usual Japanese stuff.

Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen, from a design perspective, leaves much to be desired. The game's assumption that players would willingly endure elements such as minimal save points, inconsistent level scaling, and lackluster character development is, to put it plainly, laughable.

One of the most glaring issues in Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen is the lack of indicators regarding enemy strength. Players are left to navigate a treacherous landscape without clear information on the potential dangers they may face. The absence of such vital cues often results in sudden and frustrating deaths, or prolonged battles against overpowering foes. Even seemingly trivial adversaries, like rats or wolf cubs, can wield fatal blows without warning. The juxtaposition of low-level enemies in close proximity to significantly stronger ones raises questions about the game's open-world design, leading to exploration that can yield disappointment. This lack of foresight may find leniency among nostalgics and RPG enthusiasts, but it proves less forgiving for the average player.

The game's storyline and character portrayals suffer from a notable lack of depth. NPCs appear merely as background fixtures, serving either as props to fill scenes or as sources of quest-related information and shallow lore. The narrative, regrettably, fails to engage players on a meaningful level, leaving them with a sense of detachment and indifference. The characters, though present, possess little substance, offering little more than the feeling of consuming cough syrup—bland and unremarkable, but with an added bitterness.

With the passage of time since its original release, coupled with the waning of nostalgic sentiments, Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen reveals itself as a product with diminishing appeal. The unimpressive game design and uneven difficulty scaling contribute to its limited enjoyment, leaving it reserved mainly for the most ardent of nostalgics and die-hard RPG fanatics. Casual consumers, seeking captivating gameplay and engaging experiences, are likely to find themselves disenchanted after a brief hour of play. In many instances, players may even feel compelled to seek refunds, unable to bear the tedium and lackluster offerings any further.

Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen falls short of its potential and fails to garner applause from discerning players. Its design choices, ranging from gameplay mechanics to narrative execution, undermine the overall experience. While it may have its merits for a niche audience of dedicated RPG enthusiasts, the average gamer will likely be deterred by its deficiencies. As such, this title may best be approached with measured expectations, mindful of the challenges it presents for those seeking a more immersive and gratifying gaming experience.

So I have played over 400 hours at this point (and more offline/off steam) and I finally feel confident enough to write a proper review.

Dragon's Dogma is perhaps the best party-based Action RPG I've ever played, but definitely suffers from lots of frustrating flaws, far more than just quality-of-life issues; crappy balancing, terrible romance, pawns being brain-dead, losing control of the fucking camera, and RNG (DLC purification, basically a lootbox). Yet the over the top, movie-style action and combat strategies kept me coming back, when these flaws weren't present.

Since everyone has already spoken praise, I will mainly be discussing things that haven't really been said before. 

First, the flaws. These issues seem to feed into one another.
First of all the balancing - most of the issues I have with this comes down to the way damage is calculated. One of the most common complaints I hear from new players is that every enemy feels like a damage sponge. Every point in defence seems to reduce damage by that amount; so if you do 700 damage, and the enemy has 700 defence, you will do LITERAL decimal amounts of damage, and enemy health is often in the tens of thousands in this game. You CAN perform heavier attacks or find new weapons, but new players don't know where/how to get these, and it isn't exactly stellar design if you have to consult a game wiki so that you can kill the first goblin in no less than fifty attacks.

The second thing that feeds into this is the world's enemy placement. There is no level scaling and I actually love that there are tougher enemies in the starting area - go off the main paths and you're bound to run into them, even close to the beginning area. You'll have to grind levels and find good gear before you can face them - however there are few places to grind early game because low level enemies are very few, and no good places to buy better equipment unless you know where to go which is something new players will likely not know about. It is especially frustrating if the next quest is locked behind a group of bandits who can only die after a thousand cuts.
This doesn't last long however as once you make it to a certain level you're so overpowered that nothing in Gransys can challenge you anymore.

This brings us to the third thing, Bitterblack Isle (BBI) from the Dark Arisen DLC. Admittedly without it, I wouldn't have replayed this game so much. However I only really look forward to certain parts of the DLC if I am being quite honest. The first third of BBI is something I always enjoy - it really feels like it's balanced towards late-game characters, fights never take long and make you feel like you're wasting your time, but they are still challenging and lethal. It even has a type of surprise encounter in some areas, which remind you of how you felt in Gransys when you ran into a Chimera at level 17. However all of it goes to shit after you beat the first boss of the DLC, because now we have the REVERSE problem that the base game has.

The second part of the DLC introduces enemies with absolutely BLOATED stats, such that even if you were using a damage type that they're WEAK against, it feels like it takes ages to kill them. Many of these enemies are also just reskinned enemies from Gransys too, scaled a bit larger, so they feel so boring to fight against. 
The cherry on top is that many of these enemies can one shot you in the cheapest ways - spellcasters. I'm not against one-shot attacks so long as they abide by a single rule - it is either telegraphed and avoidable (such as death's scythe or exequy) . Spellcasters in BBI however, are just bullshit enemies, who spam these spells almost instantly, even if it takes the player/pawns 10+ seconds to charge the same spell. It feels like the devs are directly going AGAINST their own design, as the director has stated in interviews that powerful magic should take a very long time to cast and drain a lot of energy. Now, there are a consumables to make fighting these enemies much easier, but only to the degree that they remove all challenge. These issues are represented the most in the second form of the DLC's final boss - his health is nearly doubled, and his defence is unbreakable even when using magic he's weak to.

This is where I discuss the purification system. I would like to believe the devs were just buffoons who don't know how to balance shit but sadly it is probably much more insidious than this, and I find it strange it's not talked more about.
In the original Dragon's Dogma - the 2012 release on consoles - Rift Crystals (RC) were pretty much premium currency. One of the key friendly NPCs in Dark Arisen had a dialogue option to literally bring up a store page where you could buy RC, which just so happens to be the currency you need to get a DLC weapon on top of upgrading it. These weapons are incredibly powerful, and borderline required for the second run of the DLC. Keep in mind it is random what weapon you get, so you might not even be able to get a weapon for your chosen vocation, practically forcing a player to play a vocation just so they can use the weapon and farm for more chances at getting their desired weapon is nothing short of mobile game bullshit.

Some other things I hated about this game were things like poor translation, upgraded versions of skills being situationally inferior than their base ones (like Compass/Fullmoon Slash or Escape/Exodus Slash, with no option to use the base version many resort to never upgrading certain skills), and the pawn AI (not being able to force them to consume items, issue commands such as ranged attacks when it's the only way to damage something, or change their inclinations)

Now for some of the better things about this game.
Contrary to most people, I do not find the world boring, just different from what I initially expected. Many first impressions are that the world is huge, but people later discover it actually feels quite small. I don't particularly mind this as there's still materials to collect or enemies to fight, but it does get boring once you've fought every enemy.
Many people don't feel the world is varied enough and I'm inclined to disagree. There are tundras, mountains, crags, plains, hills, old ruins, and foggy forests. Look at any screenshot and you can instantly tell where in Gransys it is, and evenbefore I even watched dev interviews I could tell it was inspired by the English countryside. The colour palette is also green, which I find refreshing to brown 2010s games

The game's take on generic fantasy is also fascinating to me. It takes more inspiration from real world origins of these myths than Tolkien or Dungeons & Dragons, yet it is full of classic Hollywood familiarity. Many will also note the people, language, clothing, and architecture of Gransys indicates a lot of effort in researching broad middle ages culture, from small things like the prevalence of town bells to the names of certain items, referencing their contemporary terms.

I also do not think the story is particularly bad- many seem to exaggerate it, some even calling it "largely gibberish." It's certainly poorly executed due to development constraints. The story, mostly takes Buddhist and Nietzschean philosophies and wraps it up in a neat fantasy package. As I was raised Buddhist, I can tell you Dragon's Dogma really made me think a lot about the similarities between these two, and the ending lead me to speculate on our nature as humans and our relationship to religion and free will. This wasn't just pulled out of nowhere; the game throws anime opening level spoilers at you. Does "finish the cycle of Eternal Return" sound familiar? It is a reference to the Eternal Recurrence.

Game may have been amazing years ago, but lots of poor decisions.

[h1]But[/h1]
All that being said, the combat is very fun. You can grapple enemies, your companions and enemies can do the same. You can customize your Main Companion as much as your own character. If you grapple large enemies you can cling onto them and stab them etc. something that other games only have as cutscenes or set animations. 

You can i.e. jump and shoot your bow midair. Not a lot of games give you that kind of freedom of Movement and Combat. You have your Basic Attacks like Light and Heavy Attack and then another two sets of Attacks that you can bind Abilities to and combine them with your Movement Skills like Sprinting and Jumping.

I think if they improve these Flaws in Dragon's Dogma 2, it's going to be an amazing game.

[h3]Dragon’s Dogma: Dark Arisen, despite being more than a decade old, still holds well in terms of gameplay, aesthetics and feeling. There are still technical limitations and highly questionable design choices, but from the story to Pawn interactions, it’s still a pretty wild ride. Overall score: 7/10. Highly recommended if you’re looking for a solid RPG with satisfying combat and decent story.[/h3]

[code]
+   is positives
+/- is informational or neutral
-   is negatives 
[/code]

+ The combat is top-notch once you get used to some of the clunky aspects. This applies especially to vocations that use “magick”, since casting times are very long for the strong spells, but they are devastating when you match elemental weaknesses. Wiping an entire room out with one spell or one-shotting a monster with a well-placed sword strike is a common thing if you know what you’re doing. Magic classes like Sorcerer and Magick Archer are designed, play and feel fantastic in particular
+ Sound design is utterly unmatched, despite the game being more than a decade old. I have never played a game where sound design included every single little detail to a meticulous degree. General ambience and sound layering are outright done in flawless fashion
+ Hard Mode actually rewards you for the suffering it causes. However, you might get absolutely wrecked by any random hit if you play a physically weak class (like Sorcerer)
+ The Pawn system in its entirety is masterfully designed. Pawns can learn about quests, enemies and locations and give you and other people who hired them information on aforementioned things. They can learn about things and return with knowledge when they are being used by other players, as well 
+ The story cranks up to 11 and then 12 past certain points and the endings are satisfying and fit to the setting
+ You can climb on enemies to strike at their weak points. It’s a little janky, but it’s a lot of fun once you get the hang of it
+ Decent enemy variety. You need a different approach, element or strategy for every single large enemy in the game. For example, golems are completely immune to magic and very resistant to physical attacks but die instantly if you destroy all the “plates” they have on them
+ While there is no direct tutorial, the Pawns you have alongside you teach you how to deal with enemies, hazards and quests. The way the game teaches you how to play is organic thanks to the way the Pawn system is designed
+ Day and night cycle actually matters instead of being a simple visual change. Lanterns are mandatory in dark places and in the night. Different enemies spawn in the night and some quests have to be done at night or day
+ If you don’t like something in the game (like the oppressively limited weight capacity or the jump height), you can use mods to make it more fun or accessible

+/- The only online aspect is the Pawn system, but it’s done in a way that not only makes sense but is fun to deal with. You pay more Rift Crystals if you want to hire a high-level Pawn, but if you are friends with someone, you pay nothing. Your Pawn data is uploaded to the server every time you sleep at an inn
+/- You can send an item as a gift or swap out hired Pawn gear to give most gear and items to another player, which basically qualifies as “trading” despite the game being a single-player in its core
+/- Your character’s height, weight and bulk all affect their capabilities. Smaller characters can carry less, but can fit through some small and otherwise hard-to-access places in some maps and also be carried easier. Tall characters hang their lanterns higher (since their waists are higher) which prevent the lantern form going out when you get into waist-deep water
+/- Voice acting is pretty decent, even though it can get immersion-breaking if you find a pawn that has an oddly-pitched voice
+/- The map isn’t very large for an open-world, but the contents are packed densely
+/- Some animations are great, while some are either stiff or nonexistent. For example, combat animations are great but lip-sync animations are bad/nonexistent

- Unfortunately, close to 60% of the game was cut during development due to time and budget concerns. Even though the game is great as is, one can only wish they didn’t have to cut more than two thirds of the entire thing to ship it. Despite its strengths, the game is still practically incomplete.
- The save system is abysmal, and is a fully valid reason for a lot of people to not recommend the game. You only have ONE save slot, no easy way to manually save and arbitrary autosaves. This means you are pretty much required to back your save up manually if you value your time and progress. Additionally, if your game crashes during a zone transition or mid-save, your save file can be permanently corrupted
- Your Pawn data is uploaded to the server every time you sleep at an inn. However, according to my experience, I rarely could sleep just once to upload it, because it fails at least once or twice every time I tried despite my stable connection
- The infinite consumables and the abundance of money in Hard Mode makes you borderline unkillable unless you are very fragile or made a stupid mistake mid-combat. Even worse, most items are used instantly without any animations or other downsides
- You can deal devastating damage if you use a stackable item that multiplies your damage. While this isn’t an issue by itself, it can make many encounters trivial when used at the right time
- Pawn AI sometimes sucks big time, and they quite literally are incapable of dealing with some enemies even at max knowledge (like how they don’t or can’t dodge Death’s attacks in Blackback Isle)
- You can fail some quests or make them unavailable for the playthrough after certain points, and some of them are not indicated well enough
- Due to the game being a console port, it has some egregious design choices like menu transitions being too long, or having too many menus. Some other things like buying items in mass amounts, forcing you to hold a button also doesn’t help. You even have to go through TWO menus that prevent you from spamming, just to start the damn game (which takes like 10 seconds every time, but feels like 30)
- Stat system makes min-maxing far too tedious. Basically, you get different stat increases per level when you level up as a specific vocation. This means you can make yourself absurdly strong as one vocation while another would be handicapped if you switched over, due to your stats. You can compensate with gear for the most part, but you can’t respec and play as another vocation without using a save editor
- The Pawn Inclination system is too tedious due to you not being able to filter hirable pawns by inclination or forcing your Pawn to stay in one inclination. You can use potions to affect the inclination points, but you can never stop them from changing gradually
- Most items have identical/reused/recolored icons. Instead of 10 different variations of the same item, maybe they could have made them more unique both in function and looks?
- Item descriptions are extremely vague 90% of the time. This includes key items that are necessary for quests or passive bonuses obtained from some unequippable items
- Some voice lines repeat too many times. A notable example is shops (or any important NPC that lets you choose more than one option per dialogue attempt) repeating their lines every single time when they show up

[h2]Other Notes:[/h2]

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Dragon’s Dogma is a blend of ideas from different western RPGs combined with some traditional JRPG tropes. The focus of the game is a good combat system with 3 major classes that play differently enough, huge monsters that you can scale and a variety of switchable attacks. Sadly, all other aspects of the game appear dull in comparison and mostly reminded me of the original Neverwinter Nights campaign, and the world felt more like a set of locations for gameplay to happen in – it’s a far cry from what Bethesda’s and Witcher’s players are accustomed to. There are some well-directed moments in cutscenes, but most quests and dialogues are far from impressive. The pawn system isn’t much ahead of Skyrim’s companions, yet customizing your own pawn to fit combat needs of your character and recruiting other player’s pawns felt somewhat new.
Overall, Dragon’s Dogma is a journey worth taking – with solid gameplay and a plot that manages to justify it. I was annoyed by constant backtracking due to a very limited fast-travel system and repeating battles, but I still enjoyed the game.

[h1]The Arisen returns.[/h1]

When Dragon’s Dogma first released back in 2012 on last generation consoles, not many knew what to expect from the brooding title boasting a true challenge. Demon’s Souls and Dark Souls at the time both proved to be incredibly popular with their highly demanding takes on action RPGs, yet they relied on closed, overbearing atmospheres to deliver their key sense of dread. Capcom’s Dragon’s Dogma was wide open, and free in a way that neither of those two games could be.

What resulted was a game that managed to retain the same looming darkness over a vast, open world full of life and possibilities. The title grew further in 2013 with an enhanced version of the base game titled Dragon’s Dogma: Dark Arisen. This introduced a new area, new quests, new armor, new NPCs, and basically added to the overall dark vibe of the game. It took a solid base and created an even better experience, and now that package and all its glory is finally available on PC.

Before we get into the nitty-gritty of whether Dragon’s Dogma: Dark Arisen on PC is any good, lets get some base details out of the way. You are the Arisen, a human imbued with an incredible power after an unsuccessful stand against a dragon that happens to be the harbinger of the end of days. It’s is up to you to put an end to it.

How? Well see, Gransys, the land in which Dragon’s Dogma takes place, is a mysterious one. One of its many enigmas is a small army of mercenaries who walk the rift. They answer to no one but the Arisen, and you can wield them in your battles against the darkness. This is the Pawn Legion, and the battles they fight by your side help give Dragon’s Dogma: Dark Arisen its singular identity.

These throw-downs are fast paced, but far from easy. One second you’ll find yourself picking harpies out of the sky with a bow, only to find some insane mercenary charging at you with a sword the next. When you think you’ve just gotten a grip on your surroundings, you face some sort of hulking cyclops, terrifying griffin, or huge dragon. Discovering and exploiting the weaknesses of  Gransys’ many beasts will demand coordination and a touch of fearlessness.

The combat system allows for one notably unique feature; your hero is able to grab enemies, sometimes heroically grappling the neck of a chimera, and other times desperately clinging to a cyclops’s legs hoping somehow this will help. For larger creatures, you’ll find yourself climbing across the expanse of their bodies, which is a lot less sensual than it sounds. There’s plenty of excitement to be found as you find yourself scaling one of the many necks of a Hydra, aiming to chop of one of those viscous heads.

Another dose of exhilaration comes from the tension and wonder before grand battles even begin. There is a lot to explore in Dragon’s Dogma: Dark Arisen, and the developers did a great job of fleshing out every corner of the world. Dark caverns, twisted ruins, old houses and cities, sprawling fields, and treacherous mountains each have their own signature feel and always keep you on your toes. Enemies lurk in shadows and overhead, and some stand right out in the open, daring you to test your mettle against their brutality. This world pulls no punches, and your invitation carries no pretense of safety. From the very beginning, you are told only death awaits, and you will fight tooth and nail to disprove this prophecy.

Capcom created in Dragon’s Dogma: Dark Arisen an adventure with the heart of Dark Souls but the size of something much more expansive. Creating a character and exploring this large, beautiful world full of dangerous beasts is nothing short of a spectacular experience, as was true for the original PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360 release. It is now two years later, and the dragons are stretching their wings on PC. For some, that may seem like a very late arrival, but luckily, the PC version does enough to warrant its existence and then some.

First and foremost is upgrades to visual fidelity and performance. Dragon’s Dogma: Dark Arisen was always a pretty game, but the shift from last gen to PC has definitely delivered a welcomed facelift. A full range of options are available to your particular rig, including 4K support and up to 150 frames per second (talk about silky smooth). Along with these options comes support for the 360, Xbox One, Steam and DualShock 4 controllers as well as Steam amenities like Trading Cards, Big Picture, Cloud save, and Achievements.

Adding to the package is the removal of microtransactions, meaning every bit of DLC including retail specific content will be available day one. No gimmicks, no wondering if you got everything, no questioning if you pre-ordered with the right store – everything is in there.

What you essentially have here is a definitive edition of one seriously amazing action RPG. Dragon’s Dogma: Dark Arisen manages to live in the same vein as the Souls, sporting the darkness and challenges so many players have come to desire, yet forges an identity all its own. Dragon’s Dogma: Dark Arisen doesn’t adhere to a formula, it creates a sweeping experience, one whose strengths you won’t find elsewhere. The title’s move to PC, even three years in age, has made that fact shine once again.

[h1]Summary[/h1]

[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
  [*]Solid gameplay that is both fast and challenging.
  [*]Huge open world ready to be explored.
  [*]Plenty of enemy variety, each requiring strategy.
  [*]Upgrade to PC managed to make the game more beautiful and immersive.
[/list]
[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
  [*]Newcomers beware, the game is tough.
[/list]

After having more than 1000 hours in this game over multiple platforms since the ps3 days I have to say this might just be my favourite JRPG ever. The main game is solid, the class system is one of the best out there allowing you to swap your class whenever you feel like it, there are 9 classes total, 3 basic, 3 advanced and 3 hybrid and all of them fun and viable even if some more broken then others.

And while it was the gameplay that kept me hooked the story is there too even if implemented slightly unorthodoxly. Some berserk influences on the story are visible with all being centred around causality even if the presentation is not as brutal as berserk.  The game is open world even if it's not the biggest nor most varied in environments out there. Graphics are slightly dated by today's standards especially in regards to some textures but the enemies still look great!

But let me get to the main reason which made me come back to the game time and time again and that is the almost infinite replayability of the DLC. The DLC has it's own story, location and monsters too. It is a downward spiralling dungeon and while some environments are reused it never feels the same. The dungeon is self contained it gives you heals, gear and npc's needed for pretty much any transaction you need. The best gear in the game can be found in here.

My favourite way to play this game was to jump right in to the DLC dungeon after the hydra encounter at like lvl 5 solo no pawns and just get through it on my own. The dungeon gives you everything you need so this is totally doable even if difficult in the beginning. Pretty soon this became the only way i played this game and I devised my own strategy on how to get through the dungeon and it almost never gets old.

Even if I stayed for the DLC the main game deserves at least one playthrough the game is just too fun to play. With that said if you like RPG's with great battle systems, monster hunter like loot and enemies, unique story and some memes you just can't go wrong here, it's a masterpiece in my opinion.

After a recent playthrough where I did not even touch the main game, ONLY the DLC I can say the game does indeed shine in back-to-back combat encounters & difficulty ramping up quickly and hits a solid 8.5/10 for me ... I think the open world nature of the main game is quite weak, big & empty, almost zero variety in encounters (You backtrack through a place 8 times, It'll be the same bandits in the same spot every time)... That said 5 bux on sale is worth the DLC alone, main game is definitely fun a few times through though - This drags the overal score down a bit but this is a definite must play for third person action gamers + mostly stat&gear-based &  RPG progression enjoyers.

Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen is a shining beacon in the realm of action RPGs, a game that harkens back to the golden age of gaming while simultaneously pushing the boundaries of modern game design. It's a thrilling journey that combines the best elements of classic and contemporary gaming, resulting in an experience that is both nostalgic and refreshingly innovative.

From the moment you step into the vast, beautifully rendered world of Gransys, you're immersed in a richly detailed environment that feels alive and dynamic. The game's open-world design encourages exploration and rewards curiosity, with hidden treasures and challenging foes lurking around every corner.

The combat system is a standout feature, offering a depth and complexity that is rarely seen in modern games. Each of the nine vocations has a unique playstyle, and the ability to switch between them adds a layer of strategic depth. The battles are intense and require tactical thinking, especially when facing the game's formidable bosses. The inclusion of the Pawn system, where you can recruit AI companions and share them online, adds another layer of strategy and community engagement.

The story, while not groundbreaking, is engaging and filled with memorable characters. The quests are varied and often present moral dilemmas that can affect the game's world and its inhabitants. The Dark Arisen expansion adds even more content, with a new island to explore, new enemies to defeat, and new equipment to discover.

But perhaps the most impressive aspect of Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen is how it captures the spirit of classic gaming. It's a game that isn't afraid to challenge its players, to make them earn their victories. It's a game that values exploration and discovery over hand-holding. It's a game that respects its players and their intelligence. In an era where many games are streamlined and simplified, Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen is a breath of fresh air.

In conclusion, Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen is a must-play for any fan of action RPGs. It's a game that is challenging, rewarding, and above all, fun. It's a testament to what video games can be when they're made with passion, creativity, and respect for the player. It's a call back to when video games were good, and a reminder that they can still be.
