[h1]Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen[/h1]
Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen is a fantasy RPG developed by Capcom studio, known for the Resident Evil and Monster Hunter series. As I write this review, the sequel has been announced. I haven't completed the game 100%, but I believe I have enough information to give a solid perspective.
[h1]The Plot[/h1]
If I had to compare this game to anything, it would be a pretty old movie; Dragonheart. It's not a copy-paste, but I think the developers took most of their inspiration from that specific movie. The overall idea of the plot is that while fighting a dragon that attacked our village, we get marked by the beast, thus becoming a typical chosen one with a great destiny, and that's pretty much it. The game is very open-ended with very little story focus, so we can do anything, and the main quests aren't that different from the side quests. This is a positive thing, because we can approach the story however we want, and also by making some story decisions that the game allows us to make (mostly at the end). A nice detail was also that completed side quests can affect the main quests. I remember that during one major mission, a random NPC from the city just came to my aid in exchange for help in the past. However, there's also a downside to this kind of storytelling. We can't get attached to any character because they're just not important in the eyes of the game, which doesn't give them time and dialogue to develop. Unmarked main quests are another problem that makes us inadvertently skip content in other chapters of the game, and since they don't stand out much, each mission is typical and boring; "go there, kill it, take it, come back here." The openness of the story also leaves us with no explanation for what's going on, so while most of the game I more or less knew what was going on, the ending comes with a sudden spill information, which made me feel like I was on some strong hallucinogens. It also doesn't help that our protagonist is mute, so you can't hear him at all, and coupled with the fact that we can't even choose dialogue options, we can't ask the simplest questions to clarify the situation (even much older games had this mechanic). It's a terrible way to tell a story that makes sense, but the openness this game provides is very refreshing.
[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Perhaps the most commendable mechanic is the combat system, which is really fluid, and with the plethora of weapons, armor, and classes, so you can replay the game multiple times and experience something new every time. The design of the monsters is amazing, the smaller ones are typical fantasy monsters, but the bigger ones carry an original look and mechanics, which allows us to use their weaknesses, e.g. by climbing on them and attacking weak points. Perhaps the biggest problem with all this, is that climbing is very clumsy, our hero often gets stuck, and the camera is a bigger enemy than the monsters, so we can't see what we're doing in most cases. The locations are mostly original and well designed. But the most important mechanic of this game is the recruitment system of pawns, i.e. people who are completely dependent on us. If anyone has played Middle Earth: Shadow of War, it's just the Nemesis system, only in a much more stripped-down version, where our characters have virtually no characterization or ability to interact with us (we can recruit three of them to our team). Even the game itself doesn't want us to get attached to them, because giving them equipment is pointless and they are trapped with the same level and skills, so in the end we just have to replace them and since they can look pretty stupid and their voices are sometimes very strange, it is tiring to select the right pawn. However, this does not apply to our original pawn, which we can create ourselves, in the same character creator as at the beginning of the game (which, by the way, is very solid and extensive, giving us a lot of options and information about the character). Before I move on to the next section though, I have to criticize the way we navigate the world, and while the map itself is really well done, we have limited fast travel options and our stamina is so limited that traveling is long and tiring, and the fact that enemies after some time just respawn, also does not help to improve the situation.
[h1]Technical Matters[/h1]
I have mixed feelings about the graphics. On the one hand, half of the textures and effects look surprisingly good, and it's all great to watch, but on the other hand, the other half of the textures are of such poor quality that they look like smudged shit on a rainy day. Although it annoys me a bit, the game runs very smoothly and stabely, and in the end, that's the most important thing. As for the voice actors, they did enough work, but they didn't get much to do. However, if we are talking about technicalities, great music makes the game much more fun. I will tell you about one more thing, which in theory can be included in Gameplay. What I mean, is that the UI is ridiculously awful. The buttons often don't work, and there is no such thing as hotkeys in this game, so we have to select everything manually, preferably going to the main menu. Probably the biggest problem here is the inventory window. Some genius figured out that he would divide the inventory into two separate panels, which differ only in that they look slightly different, and only one of them allows us to use armor and weapons. I really don't understand why you decided to make your life harder, by splitting one system into two identical parts.
[h1]Summary[/h1]
A really intriguing game with very refreshing gameplay, and not too crazy storyline. Despite its minor problems, DD:DA in its simplicity is a wildly addictive game, which can be a dream come true for fantasy fans, and probably even more so for D&D fanatics.

I just got all the achievements after 180 hours and here is my review of:

[h1]Dragon’s Dogma: Dark Arisen [/h1]

Pros
Combat - Probably one of the best combat systems in games. Your actions are very fluid and different vocations have different ways of approaching combat. You can be stealthy with dodges as a ranged class, practice i-frames and blocking as a melee class, or levitate out of battle as a magic class. I will commend how spells are done in this game as you really feel their power and scale(summoning tornadoes, and meteors that kind of scale). There a lots of anime-ish, flashy looking attacks as a non-magic class. You can climb large enemies and pinpoint their weakness which I feel is a huge innovation in combat. I know Capcom also implemented climbing in newer Monster Hunter games but the climbing here feels more gritty.
Pawn System - You get to make another character to tag along your adventures(although you can dismiss them). The pawn AI gets better as you progress. Also there are alot you can research about pawn optimization if you're interested. There are lots of memes about how dumb they are sometimes but that's just part of their charm to me. Aside from that, pawns can be summoned by other players[spoiler]  as the game lore has multiverses.[/spoiler] Other players can gift items and rank your pawns when they send them back to you. Pawn sharing is my favorite feature of this game. It's rewarding when your pawn returns with lots of stuff and positive reviews :) My pawn personally feels like a starting pokemon, were I feel like I should train them to be the best.
Community - The Dragon's Dogma community is very friendly and you can often request items from them. Lot's of vets are kind towards new players and will teach you what you ask. You may think that for a decade old game the community would be gone but shout out to Karathrax for keeping the community together :)
Art Direction - Dragons Dogma has this beautiful realism to it's world. It has a small game world but I love how cohesive the locations look. The settlements in particular are the one of the most detailed in games. The main town is a realistic looking castle made of multiple districts. The castle defenses, markets, farm fields all look realistic and practical. The starting town is also a thing of beauty - a seaside settlement that looks like a tourist destination. You also got lots of forts, encampments, and ruins. I only wish there were more large settlements. The monsters in this game take influence from traditional fantasy and are designed generically however, their designs are absolutely gorgeous and proves that you don't need to be unique to stand out. This game is also heavily influenced by the Berserk manga and you will see a similar vibe when playing this game. There is a character inspired by Casca which is a big plus.
Character Customization - Again, one of the best in gaming specially considering the age of this game. You can be very specific with your height, weight, body proportions, and face of course. This is the only game were I made a character that looks like me with the same height and weight as me.
Weapon and Armor Design - There are a wide variety of weapons and armor designs ranging from realistic to fantastic. You can tell that the team studied historical armor designs with how realistic some pieces look. There are also skimpy bikini armors, demonic looking armor, and idk, all kinds of different looks. Fashion's Dogma is the real end game.
Day and Night cycle - The game's night is truly dark and lanterns are pretty mandatory if you want to explore during nights and inside dungeons. Enemies will differ also depending on the time. Night time typically has harder enemies with undead and necromancers. Add that to the darkness and you have pretty intense encounters.
Replayability - The game is insanely replayable as it encourages players to have multiple playthroughs. Replayability is mainly influenced by item grinding but it is actually fun because the combat is fun :)
Difficulty Curve - It's very rewarding when you level up and get better gear in this game. Some areas are inaccessible because of how strong enemies are. Running away from enemies is a valid choice and the game does tell you about this. You can however comeback to areas when your strong enough and feel like an absolute beast as there is no level scaling in this game. You can be overpowered and still find it difficult to deal with certain encounters. There are some ridiculous encounters the game throws at you but it's ok because you also can be ridiculously broken with proper planning.
Post Game - Post game is were the real game starts, particularly the DLC. It really takes the pros of the game(combat) and plays it to its advantage. You can easily add multiple hours doing post game content here. You will need to really grind out your equipment to face the stronger foes, but as I have previously said, grinding is fun here because of the combat. Most of the cons which I will talk about next is also fixed in the DLC. Most of my playtime is actually spent during post game.

Cons
Unfinished - This is a game that really suffered from budget cuts. Some parts of the map are not explored if you only stick with the main quests. There are dungeons with reused assets(although there are lore reasons why),and the story was severely watered down. Most of the cons will actually be about these issues.
Story - The story is short and not as cohesive as one would hope for. Characters severely suffer from cut stories that didn't make it to the game. Some character motives don't make sense because it feels rushed. There are parts were character decisions don’t make sense. Lots of the parts of the story will only be understood when you finish additional questlines. Not a lot of strong characters in this game. As previously stated most suffered from budget cuts.
Small Map - The map is small and a large portion of the world map is unused which gives the theory that there are areas that didn't make it to the game. As beautiful as Gransys is, one would wish for a larger area with more varying enemies.
Few random encounters - Speaking of varying enemies, the enemies in the main game will be the same throughout your playthrough. They spiced up the DLC and added different groups depending on RNG.
Quality of Life - I feel like this will be the biggest deal breaker of this game. It truly is horrendous how some feature in this game is implemented. Some maybe a product of its time though. There is only one save file and you gotta backup the save files yourself if you want to be careful. And you do have to be careful as some quests will fail or automatically lock you out if you progress through the main story main story if you are unaware of said quests. I had to restart around 15 hours of gameplay because I skipped a quest that is a quest chain to multiple other quest chains. Skills/equipment etc. have vague descriptions and you gotta go to the wiki to understand what they do. Some descriptions are also straight up wrong. It's hard to identify certain enemy weaknesses and your pawns will continuously tell you about some weaknesses but will not comment on other creatures. If you are not active in the community or read the wiki, expect alot of unpleasant surprises.
Romance system - Your romantic interest will play a role in the story however, the game is very wonky when selecting who your love interest will be. It is a common occurrence were your love interest will not be the one you want even if you feel like you have secured them.
Menu - Cycling through your inventory, equipment, skills could have been optimized and arranged better.

This was fantastic and has me super excited for #2

Some very broken mechanics in the game tho: rezzing teammates had no downsides/diminishing returns and it was instant, like what. You could literally cheese any fight that was too hard thanks to that.
Weren't really any cool builds you could do, it was just simple spells/skills that didn't have much synergy.
Enemies were bland and the entire game was a total cake walk, even on hardmode or w/e it's called.
Wasn't any real reason to explore because you just get all your items from the town hub, and there werent' any really good legendary items to hunt down.

Again tho, positive review, this game had some of the coolest fights I've seen; where I could smack an enemy to daze them, pick them up and chuck them into my teammate who would bat them with their massive 2H mace. Very cool and satisfying

Strength in numbers, Arisen.

On a more serious note, I find it to be a pretty good game. Its main gameplay loop is pretty addictive, as I've played nearly 35 hours within two weeks. The game does have a fair bit of jank related to the menus' UI and weird K&M controls due to its age and the game being a console port, but it could've been worse.

The game has a few interesting mechanics, such as the pawn system. They are followers that each have their own appearance, personality, battle tactics, and classes/stats. One pawn is your main pawn that you create yourself, and gains XP just like your main character does. The two other pawns are recruited pawns, which are actually pawns created by other players which get synced to the server each time the player sleeps in an inn. You can recruit them for free if they are your friend's pawn, or if their level is equal to or lower than your character's. If they have a higher level than you, you have to pay with a special currency and you'll have to pay exponentially more for each additional level. These secondary pawns do not gain XP, and you cannot change their skillset. When you replace a pawn with another one, you can thank the player that sent them by rating the pawn and giving them an item of your choice. The player will also gain some of that alternative currency that I was talking about.
Your pawns can be talkative (you can change your main pawn's talking frequency) and when all of them are very talkative it can become pretty annoying. The voice lines kind of lack in diversity, so it can get old quick.

Combat is this game is relatively fast-paced, but simple. You have 1 or 2 weapons depending on your class, and each hand can have 3 spells/skills for a total of 6 spells (except for some 2 handed weapons which have 3 spells period). Melee weapons have a light attack which is a combo when repeated, and a heavy attack. You can't really chain light and heavy attacks together, which is a shame, but I found that using your light attacks with varying delays can lead to alternative combos. Everything is stamina based, so sprinting and skills/spells chew up the same stamina bar. If you empty completely the stamina bar, you end up out of breath and cannot do anything for about 8 seconds.

You can also grab smaller enemies to make them defenseless and let your pawns attack them (your pawns can also do this depending on their class and personality). You can also climb up large enemies to hit a weak spot, which looks really cool but it eats up a ton of stamina.

The game's story isn't amazing or anything, but it gets the job done. There are actual cutscenes which are pretty well animated, and there are generic ones that have very robotic motion. Your character is silent, so you'll never hear them talk apart from a few grunts and such. The story has multiple endings, and I've only reached one as of writing this review, so I don't know all the ins and outs of the game yet.
The game doesn't tell you where you can find quests, which can be annoying for some, especially since some optional quests change the outcome of the story. A guide might be necessary to reach certain endings.

The game is very New Game + oriented. When you finish a playthough, it is [i]really finished[/i] and you cannot come back to that save file. You have to start a new game, and all of your stats, classes, skills, items, etc. get transferred to the new save file.

There are several endgame mechanics, such as a sort of infinite dungeon thing where you can fight against really powerful bosses and drop lots of endgame materials and items. There is also the Dark Arisen DLC part, which can be accessed early on in the game, but is much too difficult to tackle at that time. It is target towards NG+ characters. I haven't played much of it yet so I can't really give a very in-depth opinion of that part, but what I've seen until now seemed interesting. You have a really large dungeon with preset rooms but with seemingly randomized loot and enemies, and you can drop cursed equipment which have unknown stats until you identify them with a special currency (the same one you use to recruit pawns). There are missions and a story related to this dungeon, but I've only played the first mission so I can't say too much about that yet.

At the graphics level it's a 2012 game, so by 2023 standards it's not amazing but it does the job done. It looks good enough for me.

In my 60 hours of playtime I had a pretty high number of random crashes though, and it seems to be related to playing at the game's maximum allowed framerate, which is 150 FPS. Since the game auto-saves pretty rarely (each time you enter a new zone) I often lost some progress when it happened.
I also had one of the ending cutscenes consistently crash because of the framerate. Once I enabled the in-game framerate limiter to 60 FPS, it worked like a charm. Some enemies seem to have jittery animation (such as golems and sometimes skeletons), but I'm not sure if this is caused by the high framerate as well.

There is also one thing that really annoyed me. Skill descriptions will only display what their latest upgrade does. For example, if you have a skill called "Dash", its description at level 1 will read "You dash towards an enemy and strike them". But if you upgrade it to level 2, its description will become "The range and speed of the dash is increased", and it becomes impossible to know what the skill originally does. It's really annoying when trying to recruit pawns that have spells that you don't know the use of.

This won't concerning english players, but when I played through the game in French, I've found that the localization quality is pretty meh. I found several typos and subtitles sometimes really dumb down what the characters are saying, so it kinda loses its flavor.

I would've really liked if they added an online co-op mode. You could make it so that the second player plays into the first player's save file as the main pawn or something.

All in all, I really recommend this game, I had a great time with it if you can look past its older console game jank. I'm really excited for Dragon's Dogma 2! Too bad it's also solo-only (as of now).

Let me now explain why and give some history here of my experiences with Dragons Dogma.

Started playing this game over ten years ago back when it was released on the Xbox 360. Fell in love with it. With out explaining much, it takes Dark Souls and mashes it with Monster Hunter. On 360 I have endless hours on this game with a perfect achievement score. 

Fast forward few years. Picked the game up on Xbox One and now steam, working on currently 100% the game all around. In short the game has a lot of replay value. Part of the core game is based on replaying the story. Now it might sound like a job but I promise it isn't and is worth it. 

Dragons Dogma I will say is somewhat dated in the graphics department but that's expected. It's an older game but it's a game worth experiencing. 

With the announcement of Dragons Dogma 2, I very highly recommend people checking this out.

As I stated above, Dark Souls + Monster Hunter. Early game is very *don't get it, dodge and duck, run* because the enemies hit hard and some make you think on how you want to proceed. The game teaches you to save often and do gear checks. Base game will start off hard but gets easier and for those who want a challenge the Dark Arisen DLC area will indeed be that challenge.

Despite having only scratched the surface of Dragon’s Dogma, it’s quickly becoming one of my favorite RPG experiences out there. Capcom’s westernized take on the JRPG genre was a welcome one but you can still tell it’s a Japanese game with all the little quirks they usually come with. Fantastic game for anyone who craves a nice open world RPG. This game has some really smart AI as well, it’s great to battle alongside your pawns and just destroy everything in your path.

[h1]Great Mechanics Trapped In A Mediocre Game[/h1]

Dragon's Dogma is a boring game filled with cool things.

I realize this sounds a bit contradictory, so let me take a moment to talk about the three coolest things in the game:

[b]1) Skill/Class system[/b]

You start by being able to choose one of three classes, the traditional Fighter/Rogue/Mage choice. Each class has 9 ranks, and gaining ranks lets you learn various skills for your different weapon types. It also unlocks the advanced class for each of the three, Warrior/Ranger/Sorcerer. And once you've mastered those, you unlock three combo classes each combining two of the three archetypes. You don't lose any ranks in your classes when you switch away, and some of the skills you learn can be kept on other classes. It's a little like Final Fantasy V's job system, albeit not as cool, but still quite nice. You get to constantly change classes, and also change the classes of your main Pawn.

[b]2) Pawns[/b]

Probably the only truly unique cool thing in the game, the Pawn system is an interesting system more games might consider. Basically, you have your main character, and your main sidekick (called a Pawn, just to drive it home), and you can choose their classes and gear them out as usual. But for the other two slots in your party, you get to summon other Pawns. And the cool thing is, they are just all the main Pawns of other players of the game. You automatically have access to Pawns of your friends, otherwise you just choose from Pawns that are around the same level as you. Unlike your main character and your main Pawn, these Pawns from other players never level up, so once you outlevel them, you send them on their way (with a gift and a note for the owner, optionally), and then recruit two new Pawns. It's neat! It's different! I liked it!

[b]3) Climbing on Epic Minibosses[/b]

Even the miniboss fights in this game can be massive enemies many times the size of your characters. So rather than just whacking them in the toe, you can jump onto them and climb up them to strike at various points. This is a lot of fun and makes combat feel more epic. I climbed a cyclops's arm and attacked it to make him drop his club! I climbed the ogre's back to knock off his helmet! The ogre jumped backwards into a wall and killed me while I was on his back! This was all exciting, as you can tell from the copious exclamation points.

...

All good stuff. Unfortunately, it's lost amidst a soup of who cares. The characters are pretty much all uninteresting, with the exception of the dragon. The one or two other interesting characters have one or two tiny scriptscenes and then never go anywhere. Nothing really goes anywhere, because the story is also mostly uninteresting. You trudge across the open world landscape slaying some wolves and bandits on your way to clear the undead out of the quarry passage, or stop the evil cult hiding in the catacombs, or visit the witch in the foggy forest, but it all feels exceedingly humdrum. While the final battle against the dragon is suitably epic, you beat it and then it's more who cares; the game just whisks you into the postgame DLC.

Arguably, this would have been a place for the game to shine; it's bad at story and characters anyway, so screw all of that, just run players through a giant dungeon having them do combat. But there's no real reason for it, and I found my motivation lacking. (And it didn't help that my weapons barely damaged the big bosses, which the Internet suggests means I'd need to grind dozens of levels to fix.)

I hear there's a sequel coming out, and I hope the sequel takes those three cool ideas mentioned above, and puts them into a well-written game with a compelling story and interesting, fleshed-out characters. That would be a great game.

Probably the most unique and experimental RPG I've played. It's like the bastard son of old school CRPGs Devil May Cry and Monster Hunter, truly a marvelous experience. 

No handholding on sight, interesting and deep mechanics, 9 unique classes to play around with, great ost, rewarding exploration, combat and progression systems. Towering among all this pros is how much it wills to step out of the bucket and create its own unique experience, which in my book, lends it a lot of artistic value. 

Do you want to complete a fetch quest and keep the magic item you were supposed to acquire? Create a counterfeit of said item and keep the original for yourself. Did you get a character killed and cannot progrees their questline? Revive them with a wakestone and all done. All of this, mind you, without the game ever really telling you that you can do these things, you learn it on your own as you play, reading descriptions and experimenting with the game mechanics. 

Plot is a bit weak though. Nice and interesting themes are explored and symbolized in the main questline but it does feel quite undercooked. Still, the game is tremendously enjoyable just from the rpg systems, combat and exploration.

Wanted to see what everyone was talking about since the announcement of the sequel, so I got this on a sale.

And I definitely saw what everyone was on about, but - oh boy - this is kind of a bad video game.

It has a lot of ideas that still to this day are incredibly unique when it comes to the genre:
-mantling and ledge grabbing in world traversal, you can actually find really useful stuff by climbing everything you see
-scaling enemies to stick your knife into them as a central combat mechanic
-magic is essentially a weapon of mass destruction, very cast times but devastating effects for both enemies and allies
-high focus on party synergy

There are a lot of other large or small ideas this game has that I'm kinda bummed did not catch on in the years after this game released.

And now comes the very large BUT, unfortunately the vast majority of just about everything in this game is so badly executed that I just can't recommend this to anyone. Even giving this game a lot of slack since it's so old and it's a bit unfair to judge solely on modern standards of the genre, this still is an atrocious experience. Major annoyances include:

-Atrocious gearing system; item progression is essentially nonexistent, I played through the entire game without finding any accessories that were useful for example, all armor and weapons are just boring stat upgrades which you buy from vendors
-I played Sorcerer, which was probably the worst mistake you can make on your first playthrough of this game, the positive I described concerning  the magic system starts being really f******* unfunny once enemies start appearing that are flat out immune to magic or have very short damage windows to incapacitate them and the shortest spell you have is a 5 seconds fireball or something or enemies just keep knocking you on your ass 24/7 since essentially all magic is offensive in this game and you depend purely on your NPCs for protection
-The fact that about as many people have the steam achievement for opening Madeleine's shop as they have the one for killing the final boss (which not a lot have, since this game has a comparatively low completion rate) tells you how awful the side quest clarity is in this game. For the record, Madeleine is literally the first side quest chain in this game and you can open her shop after after only a few hours. I'm not going into too much detail here since it would take an entire essay to talk about the side quest system, but it is horrendous
-The game's technical and mechanical state has to be seen to be believed, the port is a complete dumpster fire. borderless window mode does not exist, tabbing out of fullscreen mode regularly crashes the game, the game is unplayable on default KB&M button mapping, the auto targeting system keeps targeting random rats behind you while a dozen zombies are sticking their knives into your ass, the save sytem is an april fools joke, etc...
-The story manages to be both nonexistent and stupid at the same time, you could cut the middle 80% of the main quest and would not lose anything of value
-The final quest of the game is, I kid you not, "grind the same mobs you've been killing for the last 30 hours until you have enough stones so I will open a portal to the final cutscene"; we are not talking about 10 minutes of grinding here guys
-You depend so much on your NPC allies and this game has legit the worst AI I have ever seen in a game, unless you google for hours how to correctly set up your party and pawns, they are going to be a complete liability by the time you reach endgame; don't even get me started on the AI of the numerous escort quest NPCs
-The fast travel system is an actual insult to the player

I could go on for hours about dozens of other aspects how this game is hopelessly compromised in almost every way (which shouldn't be surprised since according to the devs it is very unfinished compared to what their original vision was), but I think you can get the point by now.

Funnily enough, despite this game being so atrocious, I'm following the sequel all the more, since the ideas certainly are all there, the execution was just way too bad to really enjoy this. This has all the marks of an actual masterpiece and I really hope they get it right next time.

This game was very close from pulling me and getting me "addicted" to it, but it just fell flat everywhere that matters to me. It feels to me like they left the polished aspects to things that aren't really that prevalent, and the main commonly used systems and progression of the game feels dated and doesn't age well at all relatively.

I'm playing the game and enjoying it nonetheless. However, even though this game has a better atmosphere and distinct qualities of its own; It has a few major flaws, ordered by worst to bad:
1- The loot. Vast world, tons of boxes/barrels, however the distinct amount of things dropping from those are very sparse. In general, I found dungeon loots also very disappointing, I really wished there was a loot mod alike skyrim's armor/weapon sets. If it is available and I somehow missed it, please don't hesitate to throw a reply.
2- Think of a comedy show; one of the qualities that makes a good comedian is determined by the density of their quality jokes.  You can listen a comedian and get a joke or two to make you smile in a whole minute, or you watch another one keeping you out of breath every 10 seconds. Skyrim is the latter example, DD is the prior one. The world is full of spawned creatures, etc, yet it feels "empty". Killing them doesn't leave a satisfactory feeling. They can be tough at times, but they're only for grinding. All of those creatures are there to fill the enormous gap between a few dungeons of this HUGE world.
3- Travel system: SUCKS. There is a stone and a paired portal stone. If the stone is used in the inventory, it portals you to capital. If portal stone is put somewhere int he map, the stone, this time, portals you to the location of the portal stone where you put it. So, you can only portal to one distinct location at a time.
4- Map: The map is huge, because player is forced to "walk" it. I haven't encountered any vehicles/tamed animals to transport me so far, so I assume this is the way. You have to walk everywhere. The lack of fast travel in this game is actually by design mechanic. You walk, so the pawns (other npcs in your party) can learn the world. So, by design, the game is boring in this regard. Exploration would be fun only if they put more "lively" content in it, not only dull mobs all over the place.
5- Why limitations?: 6 skills/spells is actually limiting the fun factor. Devs implemented a system for giving player a lot of spell/skill choices, but only allow player to use a few of them.
6- Long term player-base availability is not well thought. This is an offline game with online perks. However, the more game ages, the lesser active players, therefore the pawns system becomes weaker. The remedy: Let the pawns level in offline mode. (Or let players have 3 pawns as main pawns instead of one). I think this would make the game very enjoying.

Overall, I am trying to enjoy the game, paying attention to my main pawn and trying to enjoy environment. But this is the 150th time that same rock rolls towards me in the same road by the same bandit mob I killed 150th time. Maybe there are mods that remedy these figures I listed, but if we speak about vanilla, then it is a little bit repetitive because of its mechanics.

I probably have over a thousand hours on this game on PS3, about 90 hours on the switch and a fair few hours on PC
Basically, I like this game.

Main Points:

My only con is it took them 10 years to announce a sequel (I can't wait)

What? I haven't reviewed this? Get this game, less than 5 euros for such an awesome game is a steal! xD. I played this game a lot on PS3 before its release on PC, and that's why I have only 1 save file of time on it haha.

TLDR DDDA is a cool, kind of merciless game with intense combat and all kinds of dangerous environments. Might be infuriating at start but personally I find it a lot of fun. Open World exploration too. There is a lot to do but if you know what you are doing and intentionally aim for it, the main story is actually pretty short. New Game+ makes the game almost infinitely replayable as you keep your character progression and items and reset the story and your choices. Game also comes with Hard Mode with faster leveling and a Speedrun mode, which gives you a clock to track your speedrun attempt.

This game has cool combat systems, small and massive monsters, interesting story and lots of cool and nasty mechanics to make darkness actually scary and turn water into a death trap. there are 3 starter classes for Sword/Shield, Daggers/Bow and ranged Magic/support and 6 advanced classes for 2H melee, daggers/longbow, advanced magic and their combinations for Assassin which wields all the starter weapons (except staff), Mystic Knight that combines heaviest defence with magical enchantments wielding Magick Shield and Mace and the Magick Archer which wield daggers and a Magick Bow for archery type spells. The classes allow many types of gameplay and certain classes are very bad at handling certain situations, like Fighter is almost unable to handle flying monsters. Assassin is indeed my favourite class, both because of the widest variety of weapons, gaining skills and abilities from both Fighter and Strider and having the highest Strength growth. Mages and Sorcerers are the type that can charge up and obliterate the battlefield or provide cool buffs and heals, but healing items are also abundant in both stores and in the wild. There is a limited amount of skill and passive slots however, so you have to decide which ones are worth the skill slot. Most classes have 3 slots for melee and 3 slots for a sub, for example the Fighter has Sword weapon skills and Shield skills, Strider has Dagger and Bow skills. The passives are interchangable between all classes, making leveling all classes a good idea on some level. Core weapon skills are tied to weapons and can be accessed by all classes using them, for example any class wielding Daggers can use the Dagger skill to Evade. Mages use all 6 slots for the variety of spells available.

There is a cool system of combining items, creating new healing items, buff items, usable tools and items like bombs and special arrows. Some sidequests specifically require items that can only be combined. Speaking of sidequests, this game has an amount of main quests, sidequests, item fetch quests and a number of mostly optional escort missions which are used to make friends with NPCs. Expect something fun at the end if you get close with one. 

The game has a fun mechanic of creating a party out of generic class NPCs and they come with their own items and skills, but there are a massive amount of them and you can find a Pawn of your liking if you search enough, especially in online mode where other player's main Pawns become available party members. Your main Pawn is a completely customizable secondary character and you can switch their class, equipment and abilities at will. Pawns dont get access to the combo classes however. You will have your Main Pawn the entire game with you and you can collect 2 additional pawns for a party of 4 from the Rifts in certain locations in the game or by finding them on the roads. The game has a selection of "offline pawns" but the online pawns created by other players are usually stronger, be it better skill selection or better equipment.

Combat slightly reminds me of Monster Hunter, except you have kind of limited options. If you attack, you cant move or evade or block if you dont use an attack that has movement as a potion of it or have an evasion skill or a shield equipped. Large monsters can and should be grabbed and climbed to reach all of their weak spots and sometimes to weaken them by breaking the section, be it a Chimera's snake tail or a Cyclops's eye. 

Some potential quest decisions are more hidden or obscure than others. Because each class has it's own level up stats and these stats are permanent, the worst mistake you can do for a save file is leveling up too much in the "wrong class" or even worse, as a Mage past Lv10. For some reason Mage has the worst level ups. There are also events, quests and characters you can completely miss if you play the main story too fast, the NG+ helps with that, because you start the game over as if nothing happened, keeping your character progression and all items. Character size and weight do have a gameplay effect. Heavier character have larger inventory weight limit while small character can fit places normally inaccessible, but those situations are always avoidable and few. IIRC taller characters are also faster by virtue of long legs. Some equipment is gender specific.

The expansion Dark Arisen added into the game the Bitterblack Isle which not only has the most difficult monsters, also contains the most powerful items and special class specific gear. IIRC The Dark Arisen content is completely isolated onto that island apart from some quality of life improvements in the main game. Btw the only teleport locations in the game are the Isle, the main city and the starting village, and the rest can and will be manually installed by you, the player, wherever you want on the open world, using an item. Dungeons, caves, underground locations and the forest are not considered parts of the open world. You can technically collect unlimited of these teleport point items via NG+, but you can place a limited amount.

My feedback:

The game downright has all the ugly warts that "mid 2000s rpg" have: Every little crap item has a weight, you go slower if youre "medium weight, heavy weight" etc, the amount of different items that all do a slightly different thing is overwhelming (feels like 200 or so different herbs, etc).
- You cannot control your pawns. They are downright stupid. - Dont play fighter or warrior. Someone at Capcom has a hate boner for plated melee classes. There are a lot of flying/floating enemies and even if your enemy is not; sometimes they toppel over but their weakspot you want to hit ist still above standing height for you. So you  jump around like a mentally limited rabbit and try to hit whatever littel weakpoint you can find while the enemy floats 20m above you and you must hope your pawns shoot it down at random.
- The dark arisen content tries so hard to be "difficult content", but only achieves it by spamming enemies with stun locks, stagger, and aoe.

This is a good RPG, one that follows an almost typical hero tale to slay a dragon. I remember playing the original back when it released on PS3 almost a decade ago and it's dark arisen edition. This version brings back that nostalgia, save the fact the berserk crossover equipment was removed due to license issues, otherwise most of the experience is there. One I can gladly recommend.

The game's renown for it's pawn system alongside it's character creation, portions of your character's and pawns limbs affect their carrying weight, movement speed, stamina consumption, reach, and generally their weight. All accompanied by the Vocations (Classes), which fall under the Warrior, Rogue and Mage Archetypes of other RPGs along with hybrid versions that cross lines in between such as being a Knight carrying a Staff and Shield. There are decent bit of playstyles and party synergies to play around with. Pawns are your companions, who can be useful allies once they learn your playstyle and go about it with their class, though they have moments where they can be derpy such as hitting a explosive barrel alongside crates to get loot. Yet, they can be smart at fighting some monsters and execute tactics rather well with right abilities and equipment. 

Combat is quite fun with all the vocations, mages have Wide area and support spells, rogue types have bows that can precisely hit weakpoints, Warrior types can take the punishment and deliver it, too.

The one downside to Dragon's dogma is it takes awhile to travel the map as it's pretty big and there are few ways of fast travel, Dark arisen fortunately remedy this with items you can get early on, saving time on trips that can span hours and putting more into slaying monsters.
Immediately got hooked. Normally not a big fan of rpg but this and Witcher 3 did it for me.
really boring game with awful combat

I come back to the game every so often. My time is actually about 30 or so hours higher because I created an alt account so I could play around with and have a decent, always-available Sorcerer pawn that I had control over the skills of at one point. I've heard other people complain about CTDs and save corruption but I've only ever had five or so total and never had a corrupted save. Maybe it's a hardware/driver thing? Not sure, but the game frequently goes on sale for about $5. Still very much worth it at $30. I originally bought it because of the character customization and fell in love with climbing monsters and the various ways to play. A few cons though:

Pawns are completely computer controlled. Early on this means they're dumb as bricks and can't target a weak point to save their lives. Later on, they can be absolute machines with enough enemy knowledge. It can and will lead to situations where you just wonder what the heck the CPU is doing though.

Stat growths are based on level range and current class. Because of the way late/post-game equipment numbers go up, health and stamina are kind of your more important stats. The game generally doesn't want you to min-max, but it really doesn't want you to min-max as a mage/sorcerer.

Glow effects are kind of obnoxious in the dark. Mods can fix that. In fact, since the game only really checks to see if your pawn is legal when you upload it, mods are pretty safe to use as long as they don't significantly alter your pawn (the big one is making sure they're not in a hybrid class since you normally can't put your pawn in those; definite insta-flag). A nice little allowance for the player.

Buffs are really important for big post-game/DLC enemies. They stack up to four times for some reason but the game's damage formula heavily favors getting over a hump in defenses.

Sometimes the game decides you don't have great footing while climbing and enemies will just flail all over the place, absolutely demolishing your stamina meter.

The post-game/DLC have a lot of randomness and asset reuse associated with them. The post-game areas are generally too large and samey. The DLC's (and, indeed, the game's) strongest weapons and armor are almost all locked behind what's essentially a gacha system of finding the appropriate leveled item (1, 2, or 3) and spending rift crystal currency. The game seeds your purified equipment list from the start of the game and the only way to advance it is to purify equipment of that level. The only way to influence the list otherwise is to set your and your pawn's class to one color before purifying since the list has a choice for each color and it rolls the color based on your current classes.

There's a lot of ways to approach combat encounters or mess around though. Don't be afraid to experiment or look up what some items do (looking at you, skulls). A favorite early strategy of mine, before you can deal reasonable damage, is to hit a human sized or smaller enemy enough to stagger then throw them off a cliff. Enemies who can't fly will take fall damage. It's quite fun. Even big bad DLC bosses can be taken down extremely quickly with the proper strategies and items. Also, the game has one of the coolest setpieces in its final boss encounter. The game is good and there's a reason I still come back to it.

IF you are just now considering this game, then WAIT for DD2. If you are a vet to DDDA then go ahead and play away (but you prolly already own the game).

DD2 is for all intents and purposes a remake of DD:DA but with actually completed development. There are simply a lot of QoL issues is DA that may turn you off to DD2. Mods can help, but I doubt many would want to go through all that hassle just to try a game out.

Some issues inlude:
- No Fast Travel
- All enemies (except certain bosses) respawn when you reenter an area (this includes everything from wolves to dragons and chimeras (it can get very annoying just to travel from one town to the next)
- Broken romance system 
- Lots of random bugs
- Ultimately DD was a product the publisher did not believe in and so production was cut short and funding dried up (must like Dark Souls 1)

Also, much like Dark Souls 1 this game is AWESOME!!! Seriously worth the hassle of modding away some of the issues, but like I said. If you never played DDDA then just wait for 2 to come out, as it should hopefully fix a lot of the problems the original had and add even more content!

I'ma just give this game a straight 10/10. You cannot tell me on how excited I am for the second game to finally come out. Let's  break it down into four different segments: Visuals, Game play, Sense of direction, and fun. So first we will begin with the visuals. Oh my lord, the game is just absolutely beautiful. The game still looks so good from back when it was released in 2016. 10/10. Next we have our game play. Now I believe the whole pawn system is super cool and Love how you can use other real people's main pawns as your two support pawns. They can get a bit tedious but I'll get back to that here in a little bit. So the overall gameplay is just amazing, I love going through the map's intricately detailed: biomes, caves, and all sorts of lands. Although the map isn't the biggest you've ever seen, but it makes up for it's smaller size with hugely adaptive and detailed levels and areas. Now back to the tedious pawn mechanics... Well I appreciate that the game gives us ai which usualy works really well but sometimes it just doesn't. Honestly they do become a responsibility and quite a burden. Listen, I'm not going to dog on the game for the pawns not listening to the Arisen (The pawn's master. A.K.A. you) and for doing some other annoying things. Although just listen here, The game was originally created plenty of years previous of the Dark Arisen version of the game. Even so, the game was still created in 2016. Anyway, issues aside. 10/10. Here we talk about in the third segment; sense of direction. Like any open world souls game, There should always be a specific goal at the end which includes something like a final boss or something of the sorts. This game pretty much strikes the gold. The quests do become quite long and monotone but when you think of there being a reason of doing it all, to farm experience, or to farm coins to buy the piece of equipment that you really want. That is really what it is all about. 10/10. Finally we have the overall enjoyment of the game itself. The thought of having an open world RPG, you might honestly be excited already correct? If you are like me and like the really grind-y games and/or concentrated tactic based games. This game is honestly amazing. You get a souls-like open world RPG that honestly isn't too expensive and is getting a sequel. How amazing is that! Anyway the absolute variety and game progression without you even noticing it is just mind-boggling. I give this game a 10/10 especially for the people who are new or experienced who are interested in the souls-like open world RPG based games, check it out.

I do have a number of serious complaints about the game, as the story does fall flat and the flying enemies just straight suck for melee users, the characters are flat and all the quests have this sort of "disconnected" feeling, as if they're there just to be there and have no impact at all, and many of the enemies feel repetitive.

And yet, for some reason, this has got to be one of the best games I've ever played. To put it simply: it's fun. While the world could use some filling out, and most definitely the story could be told better, the gameplay is fantastic. It certainly isn't an immersive RPG, lacking the characterization and choice necessary to achieve this, but it combines the gameplay elements of a beat-em-up style fight system with simple movement and fluidity, and it does it excellently. It's the gameplay that sells Dragon's Dogma, with a large number of flashy skills and magic that doesn't get old.

There is certainly some personal preference to be found here, the game has a large number of failings that can mostly be attributed to Capcom's decisions to slash the game's budget and development time, but if you're looking for an open-world RPG to enjoy casually, there are few better options.

Dont get me wrong, i find this game really fun at most times, especially fighting the giant monsters. However, unlike alot of other people who play rpgs, i don't "love" this game. The enemy variation is astoundingly low; the game tends to have only a few unique (unique meaning not a reskin of previous enemies but more difficult) enemies in each area. Some are really interesting, like harpies and trolls, but for about 1/4 of the games combat sections, the only enemies you will fight are goblins, big goblins, and bandits. There is a way to fast travel, but you are only able to get it far later in the game. But my biggest problem is the SIDE QUESTS. They range from pretty good to some of the most boring idiotic fetch quests you will ever do in any open world game. The story is also nothing to cry over either, considering I can't even understand it. Overall I can still say that this game is at the very most, "ok" but its got alot of problems that the community just refuses to address.

This game has a cult following I do not understand. The idea that its fans purport that this game is this incredible yet overlooked RPG is enticing, but it is so inferior to nearly every other RPG I've played in every facet other than combat. Which doesn't even get much points because it's not even the entirety of the combat, merely its style. Mainly how interesting it is to grapple onto large enemies. Everything else about the combat is mid at best. This game's fans tend to exaggerate how great the combat is in order to justify a game they like. The combat is fun, but that's the only decent thing about the game, it's not good enough to save it.

Everything Wrong With This Game:

1) The World is Bland:
The open world in this game is just a bunch of blank roads littered with empty structures with no rewards for exploring. There are occasional monsters, but they never change, so even the interesting roads where you find chimeras become hideously boring. The game tells you that the roads are shared by merchants and travelers, yet they are nowhere to be seen. You have to follow the main story to get anything to happen. 

2) Terrible NPC Interaction:
The NPCs in this game suck. The majority say only one phrase. These guys are supposed to expand the world, instead they are caricatures meant to provide the idea of an open world. The interaction with the more important NPCs isn't much better. Very few NPCs have anything to say or excite the player to do anything. By that I mean probably 1 of them.

3) The Cities are the Worst I've Seen
Gran Soren is so massive yet so empty, it feels exhausting to traverse. Every district is so unnecessarily large for what it is.  The other towns like the encampment, which is literally empty space, and your home town are not much better. It highly contributes to the game being a walking slog. Everything else I've found is just an empty broken castle with nothing to find. Why is this world so boring. 

4) The Pawns
The idea of a follower that gains intelligence to support you in combat as it supports other players online is very interesting. What isn't interesting is that they are soulless robots that speak the same few phrases all too often. Why would this game make your party members bland robots. No one wants to surround themselves with that. Not to mention the party system the game forces on you does not feel the greatest with how its ancient UI makes it a chore to check basic stats and skills. Enjoy doing that for 3 pawns. I would have much preferred having one robot follower, and perhaps my choice of available NPCS to have join me.

5) Monster stats
Their stats are static. This means that enemy stats are set at a certain value and never change. Why?? This creates such lame encounters where you either annihilate the enemy or are forced to run from an undamageable, one-shotting, threat that is placed between you and an objective, why design a game like that, especially with the lack of variety in tackling an encounter? There aren't available explosives or traps or anything you could use to tackle a much stronger foe, just run you idiot. Such a bad idea. The game tries to embrace this by telling you to run, but who wants to avoid all the tough encounters in games, those are supposed to be what make games challenging and therefore interesting.

6) The Monsters
Goblins, wolves, bandits, and harpies. For big stuff, chimeras and ogres. Rarely lizard creatures. Encounters get boring real fast. The only one they actually seem to have tried with is the chimera, with how you are supposed to fight it by breaking its pieces. Even that is a static process though, you can't choose to defeat the lion head first, or the magic goat. So bland.

7) The Vocations
These are just fighting classes for your character to choose from. This is mostly a decent part of the game. There are 3 basic classes, and 9 more variations that are mixtures or enhanced versions of the originals. But why just present them all to me when I try to change class. Why don't I have to try to master the basic ones to unlock a new class. Such a simple mistake makes mastering a class much more boring. You should have to work to gain more options in combat and a new class should be the reward. Just inherently bad design.

This game is not a must try, or a hidden gem. It's another rpg in a sea of them that are much better. All this game has going for it is a semi interesting combat sequence. Which is unfortunate because I wanted to play a good game. I could probably say much more, but this game isn't worth it. All the people saying it is good or even better than Skyrim are simply gas lighting. Play a good game like Breath of the Wild.
"Not for everyone" is the nice way I'm going to put it.  Make sure you know what you're getting into before you try it.

This is the most boring and frustrating action RPG I played in my whole life. The controls are designed for console and the lazy pc port kept all of them (using the mouse in the menu is really clunky, you try to manage your items in windows covering 4% of your screen, etc). The quest/world design is a piece of crap, especially the escort quests. I took an escort quest once I arrived to the first city, just to realize I have to take the NPC to basically the other side of the map. The path is blocked by creatures that I couldn't even damage, since this piece of crap uses damage reduction instead of damage resistance: basically if your level is not high enough you can't damage the enemy. At all. But with some GRINDING, the battle becomes very easy. After that noone f*ing dares to say this is a skill-based system. Back to the quests, I accidentally took another one, which needs to escort the NPC that I need to speak to for another quest resolution, but he refuses to talk about that. I met some bandits who gave me a quest to dispatch another bandit gang: the same ones I've killed about an hour ago. I kinda enjoyed playing as an archer, but then I took something I thought was a class upgrade, instead my whole attack pattern changed: now I shoot less frequently, but knockback enemies. Which sounds nice but actually make them last longer since their weakpoints are usually covered when on the ground. The inventory management and crafting system is a chore, especially the weights limitations. The quests are not rewarding. The battle system is basically just "click until the red bar disappears from the opponents head, if your health starts to drop just pause time and eat a f*ckton of herbs". I have no idea how can it be that so many people think this game is a masterpiece. I gave it several chances and even enjoyed small sections of it (like when I explored and found the water temple very early, and managed to kill the boss in it for good loot), but 99% of the game feels like tormenting myself with grinding and boredom. Too bad since some elements of the world is pretty nice, especially the creature design), and the skill/item/combat/pawn system has some REALLY nice ideas. I hate it for being this bad when all it needed was some extra work.

The gameplay design is aggressively boring. It has a vast open world filled with monsters just standing around doing nothing. There's barely any reward for exploring. There's a stamina bar that depletes when you run so you're constantly walking around empty plains very slowly. The quests feel like AI written radiant quests from Fallout 4. The level design consists of very long corridor after very long corridor. It's just plain bad. It almost feels like an MMO that somehow forgot to add the multiplayer.

This game rules and I like it a lot. The core mechanics and systems are some of the best in the action RPG genre. However, it also feels a bit unfinished which is a great shame. I've got high hopes for the sequel.

Some good stuff:

[list]
    [*] Combat feels really good in this game and you have tons of skills and movement options to play around with.
    [*] The pawn system is rad and hiring other people's characters to construct your party is a lot of fun. Embrace this mechanic! Playing with a big party is a lot of fun, don't think that you need to play duo or solo to be a cool authentic gamer.
    [*] Lots of fun vocations with their own things going for them. It's a really cool that you can do vocation tourism to steal all the really good augments from other vocations.
    [*] Sorcery is actually crazy. If you wanna spend 30 seconds practically summoning the apocalypse, you can.
    [*] The SotC-esque climbing mechanic is really fun and cool, climb all over big dudes and stab the weak spot. It's a good time.
    [*] Great character creator, and making your actual height/weight affect ingame mechanics is so cool.
    [*] Great sound design.
    [*] The dungeon crawler DLC area (BBI) is a lot of fun and it's cool that they let you take it on almost immediately.
    [*] Hard Mode is great. Enemies aren't tankier HP-wise, they're just harder to stagger and knockdown so you can't just spam things that do that as easily. You use much more stamina, so you have to conserve it. You take a lot more damage, so you need to play more carefully.
    [*] People complain a lot about the pawns talking too much but I like it, it's campy and goofy. There's an option to turn it down if you don't like it.
[/list] 

There is a long, long list of gripes though and this is only a few of them (there are like 30 whiny nitpicks I had to cull):

 [list]
    [*] The game just feels a bit empty on content/quests, after ignoring the filler.
    [*] It sucks that stats on levelup is vocation-based rather than picking it yourself. It saves you time but it screws over players that want to be optimal. There ought to be an option to pick it yourself. 
    [*] Getting handed a billion free DLC items upon reaching Gran Soren messes up the power curve for multiple hours. These should have been obtainable by other means instead.
    [*] Inventory management needs more QoL and a better organised UI to make it less of a slog.
    [*] Elder Scrolls-esque problem of being able to spam instant curatives in combat like nobody's business, so you have to put yourself on an honor system to not cheese every fight.
    [*] Many busywork padding quests that you need to just ignore for your own sanity
    [*] They did the Warrior class dirty by only giving them 3 skill slots (every other vocation has 6), and like no interesting core skills.
    [*] Gacha-esque BBI purification mechanic is cringe
    [*] The postgame weather is cringe (I just modded it out)
[/list] 

Give it a go. The start is a bit slow though, so try to power through until at least reaching Gran Soren.
10/10 combat

Here's what I will say: it's a classic RPG with the exception of being able to jump on bigger enemies. This makes the gameplay exceptional and immersive. I am still a little peeved that I got the blonde dude as my "lover", just because I saved him to get the shield. I did all of the princesses quests, I mean come on dude throw me a bone, sheesh.

The worst part about the game: the still-framed NPCs and lack of music. Like, it's pretty clear they had no intention on making the world something you care about, which is kind of disappointing because you're supposed to become its god. That aside, did I have fun playing it? Absolutely. One time I unleashed a cursed dragon on a gorecyclops with bait and they duked it out until death.

The game also desperately needed a "stay here" option for pawns, because whenever I was trying to take advantage of the gorecyclops, they attacked them like dummies and got rekt. Also, when is real life going to let me customize a submissive pawn? It has to hit different, that otherworldly peach.

One of the best games I've ever played! Some of the quests can be done differently. Throughout the game, you have a loyal pawn companion who levels up alongside you. Additionally, you can hire two more disposable pawns to fight by your side. The combat system is surprisingly diverse and engaging. You can change your character and main pawn's vocation, so don't worry about the three basic vocations you can choose from (fighter, strider, and mage). You'll have six more vocations to choose from shortly after. And what's great about it is that you don't lose any progression, weapons, etc., when you switch vocations. So feel free to experiment and find one that fits your playstyle. Some of the quests can be done differently and will have an impact on the ending, but don't worry about it if you're playing for the first time. In New Game Plus, your main character and pawn's appearance will be preserved, but you can modify them at the start or during the game. Don't forget to check out mods for this game. There are mods available that can enhance your gameplay experience, such as ENB (graphics enhancement), increased carry capacity, and spell glow adjustments to make the visuals more comfortable to look at.

Almost 30 hours in, I've only mastered two vocations, and I still have a lot of things to do. See you at the Union Inn.

With the sequel coming out I wanted to see if I was missing out, I probably am, I'm sure there's a good game behind these problems but to hell with putting up with all these bugs just at a chance to play the game uninterrupted. You'd think the developers would care enough to patch the first game with the sequel coming out, but no. It doesn't make me trust them to not release another glitchy port. Save your time and money.

One of my Favorite games of all time. I wish I had the same amount of time to dedicate to this game as i did back when it released. I write super long reviews so heres the TLDR: its Fantastic, a straight up classic. I dont love the story but its serviceable. Hard as nails sometimes, but forgiving enough to be approachable. the sequel is on the way but this is still worth your time. now, onto my rambling.

The story isnt really my thing, but it is compelling as a device for pulling you through the game. without spoilers: a dragon steals your heart, and you need to go fuck him up to get it and your mortality back. on the way you discover that not having your heart in your chest lets you order these little goobers called pawns around. it sounds silly but the pawns are actually a really neat system as you can share your pawn online and it can potentially give other people some quest or enemy knowledge. If you speck the pawns a specific way they can straight up carry you. 

the real place Dragons dogma shines IMO is combat. its hard to put into words, but i guess the fastest way to describe it is watered down DMC meets small scale shadow of the colossus. you can go from juggling some helpless little goblin to scaling a cyclops to poke at his eyeball seamlessly. More importantly though, the game gives you a really wide variety of classes to play. These range from sword and board, to big bow man, to super powerful mage, with many steps between. For me, the hybrid vocations are where the really cool stuff is at. magic archer gets a magic bow that lets you shoot lock on magic bolts, and also you can light yourself on fire. this enables you to activate goblin mode and light yourself on fire to crawl around on big enemies. Mystic Knight is sword and board with a much heavier focus on the board, specifically wanting you to use it to parry and send a big elemental ripostes back at enemies. and assassin...I didn't mess with assassin much, but i hear its insanely good. you can also swap between these classes in the main town. at any point in your play through you can just decide you want a new class, and go try it. However, i do recommend sticking to either physical or magic damage classes for your first run. This is because the weird way this game handles level ups and stat allocation. Basically, when you level up, your current class determines what stats you get. this is great in theory, because it removes the piddling around with your stats on a screen and gets you into more action faster, but the game barely tells you this, so if you play warrior for 40 levels and then switch to mage, your damage will suck. I could sit and just talk about the classes all day, but this is already more than anyone is going to read.

The big downside to all of this is that you will be walking. a lot. and your commute will never just be a simple walk. until later when you get some fast travel items, you will be seeing and exploring the world. but, to the games credit, the fast travel system is pretty neat. you can find port crystals in certain places that will allow you to travel to them. these can be picked up and moved, allowing you to set your own fast travel way points. Also to the games credit, the world is kind of nice to explore. for a game that came out in 2012/2013, it doesnt look Supremely dated. put another way: this game came out a year or two after skyrim. Skyrim looks way older than this game in my opinion.

So yeah, for $30 id say its worth checking out. If you do, some minor suggestions: If you like going for perfect block as fighter, try mystic knight. Its just my favorite class, the parries feel so good. If you like casting spells, i think Sorcerer will tick some boxes for you, but if you enjoy regular mage that's ok too because mage slaps. Magic archer in my experience is just kinda goofy, but its still worth trying for fun. and lastly, dont sweat too much and try to hardcore metagame your stats your first run. try new classes, experiment. all of the classes are worth at least checking out.

A truly unique experience, combining elements of CRPGs like Elder Scrolls with larger than life enemies that present a number of strategies. Do you target the twenty-foot cyclops' legs to bring it down low enough to strike its vulnerable eye? Do you simply shoot it from afar? Or do you climb its body while your party distracts it, daggers ready? Combine the clever combat with a surprisingly deep story and you've got one of the most memorable games of all time. Highly recommended.

A perfect example of overestimated/overrated game that is probably mostly being praised for the first few hours. It is definitely similar to Skyrim/Elden Ring, but mostly I got similarities with Final Fantasy series, and this is NOT GOOD at all.
 
First, some good things about the game:
- It's not long (I’ll tell you why its good later)
- Interesting mechanic with fights in climbing and monsters
- Straightforward story
- Good weapon and skill build choices
- You can kill children (Huuuray, this game has soul!)

But this is it with good aspects. Now cons:
- Horrible graphics 
- Disgusting quest navigation and travel 
- Horrible fighting system (who said that its like Dark souls should perish in Hell)
- Very bad balance in difficulty (tried only Normal and Easy)
- Ridiculous quests with a huge amount of boringness (go to the same location TWICE spending only on the road approx 10-12 minutes)
- Unbelievable stupid decision to prohibit control of your Pawns (companions)  
- Story is weak 
- The last boss is a joke

The fact that the game is short made me finish it. Because after the same quest which told me to go somewhere SUPER FAR WITHOUT ANY FAST TRAVEL - I almost gave up and quit. However, I overcame it and …. Yes, the game was almost got finished. 

I cannot recommend this game for those that truly like DS series, or Skyrim. Instead, go play Dragon Age or FF 12, seriously.

Good game!
It's no surprise that the game has a lot of similarities to the older Monster Hunter titles but to me it also feels like a better Risen-type RPG game which I love!

AI can be wonky at times but that is understandable for a 10 year old game... The combat is really fun and there are a lot of different skills and abilities to try out.

Now, this is a game feels much like the good old Piranaha games such as Risen and Gothic, with a dash of Elden ring. The game does have its differences from those games however; in those games, you went around as a lone adventurer, but here, you go around with a party of four - the PC and three Pawns. The game's also a little more linear than those games, which can be a good or bad thing depending on what you prefer, but at least there's some variables to it. Either way, you get about what you could expect from the examples I mentioned: a while island to roam, plenty of places to explore and monsters to fight and of course, a plethora of personages to help, befirend and/or fight and so on. The game has some mechanics and whatnot that I find unique for a game of this kind, such as jumping on and climbing the big enemies on order to get a better shot at their weaks spots. The game does have some things that I complain about, though I  think one shoud keep in mind that some of the problems/flaws comes fromt he fact that this is a game originally intended for consoles...:

- Support pawns not gaining levels. Now, I understand that the idea is them not being as good as your main pawn, but nonetheless, feels kinda disappointing that the only way to get higher-level pawns seems to be to ditch those you have with you and hire new ones.

- Only one savegame slot. For some games, this works well, bit here, I feel a few more would be good to have - should be at least three or so so that you can make one save game prior to starting a quest, one during thw quest and one after it This'd be better for when a quest may be a bit overwhelming for the player...

- I find it a problem that fighter/warriors get no ranged option(s). Normally, a lack of such is fine in most games, but most games I've played do not have a quest - the sidequest involving the Metal Golem - where you have to hit a target that is out of reach while a powerful enough enemy tries to kill you. This lack of ranged alternatives for a fighter/warrior player means the quest will at the very least take significantly longer than it otherwise would, assuming the enemies don't smash you to bits during the quest...

- I hate it when the pawns forces the player's attention to be on them, because I'm usually busy fightning some foe or another when they do this and can't really help - if anything, it causes me to lose focus and sometimes makes me botch my attack. So if there's ever a sequel - I'm all for the Pawns giving the player a shout if they want to offer an opportunity we might exploit, but no need for forcing the attention on the pawns when this happens...

- I hope there's some automatic targetting in an eventual sequel, because when I make certain attacks in the game, they're all over the place, like the 'run and stab' - it's a good one, but it often doesn't go for the enemy I'm aiming for and that is a minus...

- The whole 'climbing the monster' thing is cool and has potential, but is ultimately fairly messy, because it all to easily gets hard to steer where you climb - I've struggled to climb up a dragon or the like only for my character to climb downwards, or my character was climbing in circles around one of the dragon's legs when I was trying to go for it's chest... I can't tell how much time was wasted either because the battle went awry when my character didn't climb the way I wanted or was killed because he climbed into the wrong place... As I said, an interesting feature, but a messy one.

- I wish some of the pawn's behaviour other than battle could be customized as well. I'm all for 'em picking up items from the ground that I may have missed. But treasure chests... I'd prefer to open those myself and it always feels like my pawns rob me of the fun when they open a chest before me, so I'd have prefered if this could be altered...

Really, just a lot of problems I find with Dragons' Dogma comes down to pawns. They're the elephant in the room, really. Pawns acting stupidly in a lot of ways - carrying a downed pawn towards you when it's a really bad idea to do so (because everyone will get caught in the blast), not using arrows and other items you leave in their inventory in the hope of them using them against strong foes, not targetting the weap point of the enemy - this is especially a probelm against Metal Golems and the Ur-Dragon: the pawns will just mindlessly attack the enemy despite their attacks doing nothing whatsoever...

Pawns also needs one or two more commands, really. I've lost count of the times when I wish there was a "disperese/scatter!" or "Move away from the enemy!" command to use when pawns foolishy do things like jumping straight into a dragon's maw or fireball when they really should be retreating... Pawns need to be more customizeable, really. For example, for some reason, they as good as NEVER use any arrows I give them - in a playthrough of 150 hours only one arrow in a bundle of ten got used, despite there being lots of times when their usage would've been very much welcome. And they sometimes don't use cures I give them. And in contrast, they often use items I would rather they saved for another fight in considerably less important fights...

Whatever problems the game may have in regards to pawns and whatnot, I still found this a fun and engaging game well worth my time that I'd eagerly recommend to fans of the genre!

Combat isn't good. There's no way to dodge (unless you unlock some specific skill only available for certain classes), enemies are all way too tanky, and there are way too many of them in each encounter. Even with pawns, each enemy encounter is unnecessarily long and fighting enemies (which is a huge part of the game) gets really boring really fast. Pawns are extremely annoying when not in combat and often during combat as well- yes, if I don't know where I am, I should look at the map, please shut up. The story is far from interesting enough to make it worthwhile.

I really want to like this game, and I feel like if I got past the tough beginning, I would, but I doubt I ever will. Overall, I was initially hopeful for this game and I want it to be good, but unless you want Skyrim-level combat mechanics with story and general feel way below that of Skyrim, skip it.
