Here's the thing. You said a "wyvern is a dragon." Is it in the same family? Yes. No one's arguing that. As someone who is a 1k MMR feeder who studies dragons, I am telling you, specifically, in dota, no one calls wyverns dragons. If you want to be "specific" like you said, then you shouldn't either. They're not the same thing. If you're saying "dragon family" you're referring to the taxonomic grouping of Varanidae, which includes things from wyverns to eldwurms to drakes. So your reasoning for calling a wyvern a dragon is because random people "call the flying lizards dragons?" Let's get gyarados and charizards in there, then, too. Also, calling someone a noob or a feeder? It's not one or the other, that's not how taxonomy works. They're both. A wyvern is a wyvern and a member of the dragon family. But that's not what you said. You said a wyvern is a dragon, which is not true unless you're okay with calling all members of the dragon family dragons, which means you'd call eldwurms, drakes, and other flying lizards dragons, too. Which you said you don't. It's okay to just admit you're wrong, you know?

Dragon's Dogma is an exciting action RPG that allows you to explore a wide open world filled with monsters, magic, and adventure. You can also recruit pawns, AI-controlled companions who assist you in fighting and exploration.  The battle is intense, the world is captivating, and the plot is intriguing.  You can design your character and sidekick, as well as select from a variety of classes and skills. The game also features a unique online function that allows you to share and borrow other players' companions. If you enjoy action RPGs, you should certainly try Dragon's Dogma. You will not be dissatisfied.

I tried. I really did.
This game is terrible.

First off, this game goes on sale all the time and it's a federal crime for you to not buy it when it's 8 bucks.

Second, this is one of the greatest RPGs I played in all it's imperfect qualities.
Sure, no standard fast travel (without items) and a vast amount of the world feels like it could have more. Holy shit, I've never enjoyed a game so much. (Ignore the play time hours, I have much more on console.)
First thing this game punishes you in a fun way for not understanding it and GREATLY rewards you for learning.

Hands down coming into this new, a lot of enemies and quests will be head scratching. Which is fun. There isn't much hand holding so it is up to you to figure out where to go, what to do, and reading things to understand. That's for quests. Sometimes you'll actually have to pull open your quest log to figure out what to do next. That's nice.

Though, the whole thing isn't crippling and has a lot of casualness as well if you like the feeling of just walking around and pressing a button to swing your sword and kill things. There's this difficulty learning curve and drastic power spike where you go from using literal rusted weapons in potato sacks to summoning tornadoes at the snap of your fingers or winding a sword down with the power of GOD to one-hit bosses. You'll find yourself, after some hours playing, how surprising going against enemies again and again changes.

One hydra fight takes two years. Ten levels later, two seconds. There's so much to do. Even when you finish the base game, the DLC is there for some really fun end-game content. Not to mention it also has the perfect pet simulator where you train and build your little NPC side kick and make them the best friend in your party. (or worst if you don't know what you are doing.)

The NPC mechanic is strange. You have the full ability to set their abilities, class, appearance, and even grind out their AI on how they react to the world of their AI intelligence to enemies either through grinding or setting this basic scales that change how they function. You can also use other players and their sidekicks in your journey and rate them for how good they do. Which is nice. Though, not the simplest. The scales of Medicant, Mitigator, and whatever bullshit terms they have for how your NPC will act is not explained well and, when in tandem of others, have unknown results. I had to pull up guides online to figure out which ones are best for what you are going for. I'll be pretty damn sure unless you are a poetic quantum fuckin' scientist, you'll also be doing the same. Why is this important? So, some bad examples of AI are below if you are curious:

1. Depending on what your set, if you are running towards something, your party members will ALSO run forward and then stand infront of you after. Regardless of where. So, for example, you could run towards a chest on a cliff side and watch three NPCs commit suicide right there.
2. A healer not designed properly who will pop their magic EVERY time you get a paper cut but forget their magic when you are dying.
3. A warrior who runs away from a battle and goes back in only to run out.
4. Your mage will think going to pick up explosive barrels is more important than casting satellite fireballs and walk in to get killed.
5. Your warrior goes into battle, banging their shield as a taunt. For the whole fight and nothing else.

Even if you do look up information and take your time to understand these inclinations, you're wrong. Because they always work in very strange ways. This game is a decade old and even now most my opinions on inclinations is "It might work like this... half the time. but ONLY if you have it set like this, in this order, and specifically done for even stats you can't see.". A lot of what the game is obscure and unwarrantly obtuse about could use work but everything else especially the DMC styled fantasy combat is what adds to all these unique features and create a game completely unique.

Story is mediocre yet strange. It feels like there are things both stagnant and happening in the background at the same time. Also, without spoiling, I am not sure if this is intentional or bad writing/design combined with being dated. So, it's also good? Not in a way where you'll be impressed about reading a bunch of stuff. So for those that don't like browsing through a novel and closely paying attention in RPGs, you'll be satiated by this way of story telling because there is a lot of show and not tell. Many vague and unexplained things.

All that said, it's a wonderful game. If you are wanting to play, do a little understanding of the world map and take the time to learn the mechanics and what you want to do. Maybe read a guide for building your pawn. (Even though technically you don't need to as grinding can make this game become easy mode.) It's really fun. and the story is entertaining although wonky with plotholes and lack of depth at times.

One of the worst games capcom has ever released. Nonsensical story, bland, boring world, shallow combat, shitty gear-based progression with flat damage calculations rather than percentage reductions, annoying "characters" that are lampshaded with the excuse that they don't have souls, etc etc. 
This game has no redeeming qualities. Side quests boil down to "go to a location and kill a bunch of enemies" or "talk to a bunch of people in the game's singular city". Enemy variety is minimal, the combat is a button mashfest with free heals (you can carry hundreds to thousands of healing items which can be used instantaneously from the pause menu), and due to its utterly stupid damage calculation, has no room for skillful play and instead requires excessive grinding to boost your attack values above your enemy's defense values lest you waste hours of your time smacking away at enemies for 1hp at a time.
The game isn't even fun to explore in the same manner it is for skyrim or other open worlds with subpar combat; the world has nearly no environmental variety and is rather small, with only 1 major city and a pittance of settlements with little more than a merchant, not even side quests.

The most baffling failure of this game is the combat, which is why I have mentioned it multiple times. This game was directed by Hideaki Itsuno, the talented director behind Devil May Cry 3, 4, and 5, games with some of the deepest and most rewarding, skill-based 3rd person action game combat in gaming history. How this game completely fails to have even slightly interesting combat is such a mystery to me, I always have to wonder if something went wrong during development, or if Itsuno truly did direct.

The game tries to be many things and fails at all of them. Its continued cult classic status always baffles me, as none of the games fans have ever given me counterarguments against the game's overwhelming flaws, and many simply admit that they like the game for no reason and choose to ignore the flaws. Hopefully the sequel will fix all of the issues that this game has, but I highly doubt that it will, all the footage shown looks nearly identical to this game, without even updated graphics. 

1/10, waste of storage space, you couldn't pay me to experience any more of this game.

Side note: my steam profile says I only have 7 hours, but this is not representative of the amount of time I have put into this game. I played the game to completion on the xbox 360 in 2012, shortly after the game released. I've tried coming back to this game numerous times, attempting to see the good that others apparently see in this game, but every time I've only experienced boredom, disappointment, and frustration. The semi-postgame state where you run around invisible is funny though.

Cons: Outdated Graphics/Story, both are just Ok

The pawn system is one of the better ideas in ages and hasnt been replicated since, to my knowledge. Your create an avatar A.I to accompany you throughout your adventures. You can adjust their reactions to situations with a simple question and answer setup. These situations are unique to combat/Defense/resource gathering/aggressive nature. Once you have made them. You can then offer them into a database that others can search and rent your pawn from you as a helper. You can share them with your friends. Or anyone that has theirs made you can search buy class/price/lvl. This to me is where it shines. It has a way of creating a unique experience. pawns have such a range or differences that you never know what you're getting and its always fun to find out. Sometimes you get a healing mage that like to wade into the battle before the tank and war. Or your new ranger keeps wandering off to forage. Well these noobies have the ability to learn from situations. Rather its a quest and how to complete it, or the proper way to take a cyclops down in 10 seconds. They learn from their encounters of all sorts. you learn it together and they're able to take it back to their original account. And vise versa, if you're ahead of a friend in the game and they have your pawn. Your pawn will literally guide them through quests with audible hints and movement towards objectives. When you kill mobs. These pawns learn the proper way to kill them. Literally trial by fire. If you kill a wolf with fire and they go down fast. Your pawn learns that. Future fights will bring audible queues from them to use fire. They'll learn their hunting patterns. Some seem to use tracking skills such as smell queues and dropping to let you know of possible encounters near you in the dark. The pawn System deserves an inovation award in my eyes. If they want more single player games. They have to make systems like this.

Combat is Great. So many party possibilities between yourself and pawns. You can master ever single profession in the game through time and combat. Melee hits feel like they hit. Will not be able to explain it. Just have to be there. You or your pawns can scale larger foes such as the cyclops/ogres/dragons/hydras/Chimeras and attack during the fights. Pawns will do the same and some just seem to only do that once theyve learned enough knowledge. Had a rented Pawn scale a cyclops and straight murder him in the eye with his daggers. I got one telling everyone it hates lighting and this one doesnt say nothing. Just casually walks over, scales his back. Is up around his head getting comfy for a stab spree. He staggers him and down he goes. once hes down the assassin is jumping in the air performing jumping heavies on his face. the cyclops flails and gathers himself only to have ol' pokey on his back again heading straight for the eyes. i felt sorry for this thing, it wasnt a fair fight. The first time you come across goblins in the middle of the night, with only a lantern. Or get surrounded and devoured by wolves. youre going to die alot. SAVE OFTEN before engaging anything, walking near cliffs can lead to a slip and fall off the side taking 30m of work off your hands just to send you back to the tavern you started your day off from. Be bold in your adventures but SAVE OFTEN. For a great experience. Take on a healing role. Take your music all the way down and ambient sound all the way up. Grab you a Tank/Melee dps/Caster dps setup and go out into the dark and just wander around for some fights. If its not some of the best combat experiences of modern games ill be surprised. Im not a fan of the industry in general, but this game deserves more credit than it got.

Depth of classes plays right into it all to give you a great experience. Pawns may not branch past the basic classes but you will get branches from the basic classes into more focused versions. You'll retain basic attack combos and class benefits. But you'll change the class up. Rangers can go Longbow/assassin/Magic Archer. Fighter(tanks) see the Warrior/Paladin Mages get a little less variation But a multitude of skills that can make a team of 4 dps mages have some variations. For fun i once had all 4 members as and tried to find pawns that i could design around and we all had the same 3 major skills and all had utilities that could benefit each other. Its was awesome to watch 4 lighting whips being cracked at mobs in the dark. Meteors and Miasma pools everywhere on the battle field. Or watcfhing 3 tanks springboard each other onto a flying Griffon and take it down from the air. The variations are many.

The graghics are outdated but not terrible. Remastered looks great. You can just tell when it was made.

The story is just OK. It'll do

Absolutely loved it. One of the best Action RPG ever made, with unique game play i found only in this game, like having female party have it's own difficulty on a certain big monster. I recognize the foolishness in attempting to review a decade old game that is beloved by all who've touched it, but it is what it is. 

The first two thirds of this game are really good, if not somewhat short, rushed-ish. There were a lot of pieces that worked really well. The story is set up nicely, you end up in a politically interesting position, you have some limited choices to make with limited changes to the story (mostly about which shops you can/can't use), but ultimately it feels engaging. 

You're shown and engage with what you assume is the end-goal, this beast, this dragon of old, come to burn the world. He doesn't do a lot of burning. Or attacking. Or anything really. But you must stop him. So you work towards that, your date with this beast always on the horizon. And you do! 

He gives you a deal, a nice one. Let me just have this little snack and I'll head out for another century or whatever. You can have all the glory. Pretend you killed me. Do whatever you want. 

Or-- take me on. 

It turns out this is all part of the Great Wheel of Fate, the test to prove the will of the Arisen. 

The dragon is sent to find the one who would stand up to it. You do. You get marked. And all of this to fill the empty chair of God. 

It's really interesting. Unfortunately, from a gameplay perspective, everything after slaying the dragon is completely awful. 

You're given this quest to attain 20 rocks for reasons, and mostly it involves flinging yourself into horrifically unengaging monster battles. What was once a striking encounter now becomes Dungeon #9 full of the same high health bad guys and the eighth dragon you've killed since the big one. 

It manages to shortchange its best and most compelling feature, which is the combat. It really truly becomes a drag for the last quarter of the game all the way up until you finally get your rocks and go finish the very abruptly told conclusion. 

In all, the story was fun, somewhat fresh given the tropes it digs into (oh GOD it's ANOTHER medieval fantasy magic game set in a sadsack world), and until it became monster hunter but bad, the combat was challenging but rewarding and fun. 

I'm excited to see what the sequel can do to this world and this formula. What story there is left to be told. 

It's worth the price if just for that.

This game is the only game I've revisited and replayed every few years across multiple platforms and systems. Even at its current "full price" of $30, it's a steal. Combat is highly rewarding, with one of the most robust and visually epic looking magic combat systems of almost any game I've played. Your Pawns - the NPCs which you can recruit from other worlds that are player created - add an incredible amount of dynamic interaction. They call out monster weaknesses and strengths, learn tactics, physically grab and pin down enemies to give you time to charge your attacks, point out treasure, and other useful odds and ends, making you feel like they're a thinking member of your party rather than a bundle of code that gets stuck up on uneven terrain.

The story is engaging, and once it's over, you open up one of the more unique Post-Game experiences I've ever seen to keep you coming back for more. If you're ever on the fence about the game, wait for a sale ($5 until 6/20/23 is the biggest steal EVER!). If you like 3rd person fantasy combat, exploring a monster-filled immersive open world, using sick ass magic to fell cyclopses, customizing and growing a unique NPC companion, raiding dungeons, finding cool loot, and WAY more, you will not regret your purchase.

This game is a big surprise for me. The combat has really good ideas, climbing on giant monsters is really something I had not yet experienced in my gaming career. Some monsters can even take control of the allies fighting with you, and this surprised me even more. The char I'm playing has more layers of armor, mainly the chest pieces can be overlapped. Cool! 
The adventure is very slow to unveil, mainly because there is no fast travel, if you don't have some magic pieces that - at the moment - are quite rare. So, navigation through the world of the game is slow and often interrupted by various types of enemies that spawn always in the same spots. The world itself is beautifully crafted, with big and smaller cities that offer some exploration and (obviously) some side quests. Unfortunately, the world is developed mainly around a relatively narrow main track, with a few branches here and there to encourage exploration, so the "open world" is not so open, after all. The track that goes from the starting village to the main City of Grand Soren (and beyond, but I've not reached new areas yet!) is, as I just mentioned above, narrow and often limited by slopes on one side and mountains on the other, with explorable forests and beaches scatterd along it; but unfortunately if you want to go from point "A" to point "B" you have to walk (and fight) your way using one and only one track, no alternative routes are possible. It is not like Skyrim, in which if you want to go from Whiterun to Riften you can choose many different routes, absolutely as you please. This is the real downside of this game: free exploration is really limited. 
Dragon's Dogma is, anyway, a really good game that I really recommend, since it has very good combat and it has a really affordable price.

Easily among the best adventure games of all time, despite its few flaws.

Absolutely great action combat that goes out of its way to really fulfill the immersive fantasy. When you play a big hulking warrior swinging a massive sword, you feel like it. When you play an athletic scoundrel archer you really feel like it. When you play a fragile mage trying to cast difficult, complex and devastating spells, you really get the reward of feeling like it.

The dramatic gothic-romance of grim fantasy oozes from every pore. From desperately surviving your first encounters with goblins to heroically climbing upon a giant monster to stab it repeatedly while clinging for dear life all the way to the truly most-epic dragon fight in video  game history ... and beyond. I can think of only a few games which manage to give skeletons crawling from dusty ancient tombs the very real chill of horror and fear that they deserve. Alien nightmares erupt around you deep within the forgotten bowels of a mysterious dungeon giving an immediate sense of urgent confusion and the knowledge that sometimes the wise course of action is to flee from an overwhelming foe - if you can.

NPCs are a little bit perfunctory in some cases. This is not an RPG. The characters in the world are there to serve a purpose, not to develop a relationship with or to demonstrate their own personality. Some of them are far more interesting and charming than others, of course, but in the end dialogue in this game (although there's plenty enough of it) is not a major focus of development. Ironically, the soulless pawns that travel with you have the most to say about... everything. Their comments are helpful, insightful, informative or even just encouraging and supportive. Sadly, the "romance" system is not really for the purpose of romance, it's for the sake of an important plot point later in the game - one which was handled very... abstractly.

The bad? Well. They're more like complaints, really. The user interface is an archaic and clumsy mess. The game was created with limited controllers in mind, and this makes navigating menus for either inventory management or equipment comparison into a dreadfully tedious chore compounded by how harshly limited your carry capacity is (though this is necessary for gameplay balance reasons). At some point it will feel like you have plenty of options in terms of equipment to compare between, but often it will feel like there just isn't anything you really want to wear (an important consideration since dressing up your pawn is a major motive for exploration, and the camera is over the shoulder so you want to look good for your own sake even from behind). Overall, the itemization is a bit too limited and most equipment just isn't very different from any of the rest (though the few things that do stand out will become your favorites... and you'll never unequip it for the rest of the game...).

The most serious complaint, however, is that the world is ... a bit sparse. Which makes it feel a lot smaller than it actually is. This is difficult to really explain, though, because for the first forty hours you play, you'll discover some random new dungeon or weird little secret and it'll feel amazing - and it will be amazing. Eventually though, you'll realize that for every new little dungeon you discover, you've passed by three blank alleys in Gran Soren with absolutely nothing in them. You can wander around and constantly ask "why isn't there anything here?" for hours and hours and hours while exploring. There's nothing behind the cathedral. It's just a big open space where nothing ever happens. There's no point to the huge empty plateau, you only go there for one minor quest and it takes like ten minutes to run across it. Some games from a similar era of game development like the Elder Scrolls managed to pack way more content into worlds of comparable size. It doesn't need to all be on the "overland" map (where the drama of traveling to suddenly have to desperately fend off a bandit ambush is a major part of what makes this a grim low-fantasy epic story). But it'd be nice if Gran Soren were actually a city and not just three merchants with a five minute walk to get to the castle where The Quests are handed out.

Even so, any sequel could surely rake in mountains of cash if it were accomplished with even comparable quality.

This one still manages to very fairly earn its place among the greats. If you like Skyrim, for example, you absolutely owe it to yourself to play Dragon's Dogma.

Ooh boy, here we go:

I had this game on Xbox 360 a decade ago, but stopped playing it for reasons I couldn't remember. Seeing the game was on sale, I figured "why not?"
A few hours in, and I remembered *why* I stopped playing it.
The needless backtracking, the brain dead AI, and the lack of any real way to target your enemies (which made my character aggressively attack the air) were the main offenders in every play session. 

Pawns refusing to heal themselves or others during a battle (the main reason I always had a Mage in my party) and the single save slot system meant having to go to the main menu, *then* press another button to go to the "Main" main menu, then load the last save made almost every battle feel like an insult to my time playing.

When the game doesn't throw these issues at you, its a joy to play. Which is why this game is so frustrating for me. I can *SEE* the diamond...it's just locked away within a Rube Goldberg-esque box that hates you. Others seem to enjoy it and can get past these issues, which I can applaud them for. But for me, this game is just a disappointment.

SPOILER FREE REVIEW UNTIL WARNED OTHERWISE.

One of my three favorite games ever released alongside Elden Ring and Doom Eternal, except *this is the only one of those three that was released over a decade ago*. This game is a must play, especially when it goes on sale for as low as 5$ every so often, though I would still buy it at full price without hesitation myself.

The level design with strong parallels to Elden Ring (That likely inspired it) where you see great structures and landmarks far off in the distance in the vista that you can travel to on foot and explore as points of interest, and the possibility of running into grand bosses anywhere in the wilderness. The adventure to reach the location of a quest may end up being even grander than the quest itself depending on what grand beasts you end up running in to on the way. The combat throughout the game is also influenced by the day/night cycle as well as what point in the game's main quest line you are in, which means you can explore the same area multiple times and fight completely different monsters.

The combat and gameplay design is an easy 11/10. This is made by the same director and team that made Devil May Cry which is enough to get the idea across on it's own, but rather than making the player controls where the difficulty of the combat is, they took that incredible depth and put it on the AI while giving the player a simpler but still easily satisfying control scheme. Some of the simplest bosses in the game literally have about two dozen unique weaknesses that you can learn over time as you fight more and more of them, with AI depth that rivals the modern Monster Hunter games. And if you enjoyed Shadow of the Colossus, literally any creature bigger than you, you can climb. Want to climb a cow for no reason? you can climb it. Want to climb a Cyclops and stab it in the eye? you can do that. Want to climb a dragon while it's flying? You can do that, but make sure you don't run out of stamina or you might fall to your death unless you hurt it's wings to force it to land. There are also 9 unique classes you can switch between at any time, which also include magical ones with some of the most overkill and extravagant spells you have ever seen in a video game if you want to feel like Megumin from Konosuba casting Explosion. If you want a clearer example of the insane combat depth, go to the bottom of this review where I will post a spoiler about a early game repeatable boss. 

Narratively the game is also pretty good as at the high level the story is extremely well written and is very thematic. The one weakness the game has regarding it's narrative is a lot of the characters have more static personalities and lack character growth, but this is easy to overlook as the main focus of the story is your own character.

If I was to outline any weaknesses the game has, it is a 2012 game with a little bit of jank but nothing that negatively impacts the player experience, and for PC it's a little graphically outdated but it's easy to mod some higher res textures and a ENB in to put it closer to modern standards. Fast Travel is not immediately usable by design to encourage you to run into combat encounters in the wilderness, and to use Fast Travel you will have to place your own way-points using a item with limited quantity. There are a number of points of no return in the main quest line that cut off side quests and aren't always well outlined, so I would recommend prioritizing side quests when you find them. The game also is weak when it comes to tutorials, and primarily expects you to figure mechanics out on your own which can be fun but isn't for everyone.

Regarding the lack of tutorials, when you start the game DO NOT FOLLOW THE PURPLE QUEST MARKER. This is the DLC that is intended for the end-game that the game will immediately give you access to and encourage you to go towards without explanation, and it will put a bad taste in your mouth unless your into CBT because balance wise you simply aren't intended to be able to fight the enemies there at the early stages of the game. 

********************COMBAT SPOILER BELOW********************


To outline the insane depth the enemies in this game have, here is a number of unique ways you can engage a cyclops which is the 1st repeatable boss you will encounter. 
1.) Target the eye by either climbing or shooting to deal maximum damage and temporarily blind it. Watch out for the panicky swings he will do while he can't see though!
2.) Target it's hand holding his club, possibly by climbing it, to make it drop it's club and alter his moveset and lower his reach until he gets the chance to pick it back up again.
3.) Target his tusks to cut them off, gaining useful materials but also sending him into a rage where he will attack more aggressively and blindly, possibly being used to your advantage to kill other AI or lure him off a cliff. 
4.) While some of your party members climb one of his legs to put additional weight on it to set him off balance, target the other leg to force him to collapse, giving you a large damage window. Can also be done solo if you are fast at jumping off the leg and dealing heavy damage to the other leg. 
5.) Targeting the legs in general will gradually make him lose overall balance over time and may make him fall backwards or forward. If backwards, he is defenseless, if forward, he will use his arms to protect himself. 
6.) Climb his back and deal damage there where he can't easily access you due to the poor flexibility of his arms
7.) If the Cyclops is armored, you can trick him into taking his own helmet off by climbing onto his head and jumping out of the way when he goes to grab you. 
8.) If you are a magic user, Cyclopses while generally killable with all magic are especially weak to lightning, and this will paralyze him frequently. If a body of water is nearby, lure him in and get him wet to make it even more effective!  
9.) Dousing him in oil and using fire is also a pretty effective way of dealing so much damage he will fall over. 

The list goes on and on, I can probably make this list about 30 unique facts long but I don't want to spoil all of his weaknesses for you and my point is already proven. And this is the 1st, weakest, and one of the simplest bosses in the game!

Few pointers so far:

2. Make sure to release & hire new pawns that are around your own level. Check to see if the pawns you hire have skills learned & is a decent level in their class

Dragon's Dogma is probably one of my favorite games of all time. A reductive way to describe it would be to say it has the structure of an Elder Scrolls-type game with the combat of Monster Hunter. But even that fails to do it justice, because there is so much about Dragon's Dogma that's unique.

Firstly, the character creation. Dragon's Dogma has one of the best character creators I've ever seen. It's extremely versatile, and things such as character weight and height actually have subtle in-game effects. You can easily make characters that look good, or you can make some absolute monstrosities. 

However, in Dragon's Dogma, you actually get to make two characters: your main player character, and then a second character called your pawn. Your pawn is your main companion throughout the game, and never leaves the party unless they die, which is hard to have happen. You individually level and gear both characters, giving you a huge amount of control over how your party approaches situations. Additionally, your pawn even changes its tactics based on how you play, and can learn information about areas, enemies, and quests you encounter. The coolest thing about pawns, though, is that when you play online, pawns can be shared between players. This means that you fill up half your party with other characters made by other players, and that your pawn will be assisting other players who summon it. Pawns will still learn information while helping another character, so you may boot up the game to find that your pawn has brought you some items and learned about enemies or areas you haven't even seen, and will be able to give you hints about them the first time you see them.

The combat in Dragon's Dogma is probably its most memorable feature. You start out being able to pick between three classes; mage, fighter, and strider (rogue, basically). However, as soon as you get to the game's major city, you are given six other classes to pick from: specialized variants of the three basic classes, and hybrids of them. Each one of these nine classes plays differently and each one is viable to use. You can also change classes at any time for almost no cost, and even carry over some of your skills and abilities, giving you tons of ways to play. One complaint I have with the game is that the two pure caster classes aren't very exciting to play as, since casting spells mostly involves standing still while your character waves their hands around for like five to ten seconds. While the big "nuke" spells are very satisfying to pull off, this slow, stationary casting makes for very slow gameplay that can be annoying if you get interrupted. Luckily, you can make your pawn do the casting and get the incredibly powerful effects of spells while doing the more enjoyable hands-on combat yourself.

Fighting enemies in Dragon's Dogma is never not fun. Almost every enemy has unique behaviors and characteristics which make them interesting to fight. Most of the time you'll be fighting smaller-sized enemies such as goblins or bandits, but even they have their own special tactics and abilities. However, the combat really shines when you start fighting the giant enemies. For instance, the first one you'll probably fight outside the tutorial is a cyclops. Most cyclopes wear helmets that protect their weakest points; their eye and their legs. You can break the leg armor by hitting it, but your weapons will bounce off it most of the time. The helmet can't be broken, BUT! If you jump onto the cyclops and climb up its back, it will realize that it can't reach you because the helmet is in the way, and it will actually reach up and remove it, letting your ranged characters strike the exposed eye. You could also shoot at its tusks to break them and stagger it, or cause it to trip by having a particularly heavy character cling to its leg, or climb it and just stab it in the back a ton. There are so many ways to fight these big enemies, and the combat always feels fluid and dynamic. It is just so insanely fun.

The visuals and sound aren't the game's selling point, but it's by no means ugly. The world is realistically designed, with one major city surrounded by landscapes and small camps. The city is filled with buildings, people, shops, and has distinct districts. It is one of the few cities in video games I can think of where I could actually see how people would live there. The rest of the world is diverse, but realistically so. There's not going to be a desert right next to a tundra, but there are rolling hills, and caves, and forests, mountains, beaches, cliffs; it feels like a real place.

The story is pretty good. It's very back-loaded; the first part of the game mostly involves gaining favor with the duke so he'll let you go and do things actually relevant to the story. The 'final boss' is super fun, but the true actual final boss is an insane pushover that makes the game feel pretty anti-climactic. That being said, the meat of the gameplay lies in optional areas and the DLC, which both have fun and unique bosses. The DLC has its own self-contained storyline that shines a bit more light on the narrative mechanics of the world and has some new characters.

In conclusion, Dragon's Dogma is terrifically unique, and some of the most fun I've had playing video games in my life. I keep finding myself coming back to it, even though I've beaten it at least 5 times. It's by no means flawless - some of the deeper mechanics are pretty arcane to try and figure out - but it's so fun and memorable that those flaws are excusable. Fantastic game, highly recommended.

Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen is an amazing game. It has an exciting story, compelling characters, and an interesting world. The combat system is deep and satisfying, and the huge range of weapons, tools, and special abilities make it engaging and rewarding. The gameplay is smooth and challenging, with exploratory elements that are truly immersive. The atmosphere is sublime, taking you to places where you feel as if you are living there. The expansion brings an even more intense experience, with even more powerful items, monsters, and areas to explore. All in all, Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen is an incredible game that I haven't been able to put down. I am anxiously awaiting the sequel, as I am sure it will push the boundaries of this fantastic franchise even further.

I've played for six hours and concluded that the gameplay is overly complex, derivative, and not worth it. The graphics are boring and clunky. The spellcasting isn't worth it. I spent more time reviving "pawns" than I did doing any damage. You know how a novel is supposed to capture your attention and hold it for the first 50 pages? I had to force myself to come back to this game several times over two days. That's never happened before. This is a decently fun and unique game; but it has so many overtly bad design elements that I don't feel comfortable recommending it.


The combat is foremost where the game is strongest. There is a large variety to the classes, their abilities, and a very satisfying weight to fighting. One of the most distinct elements of the combat is fighting relatively large enemies that players can climb on. While this feature can be very fun when it wants to be, it's littered with frustration. Trying to grab onto a large enemy whenever they're moving often results in the player being displaced and grabbing onto a part they weren't aiming at. If players are grabbing onto a part of the enemy that they attack with, and they attack, players will take full damage even if the attack didn't actually hit them. The controls for moving along an enemy are extremely inconsistent and will sometimes invert to make movement entirely incomprehensible, or the camera will shift to a ridiculous angle where the player can't see themself; or the enemy will thrash so much the player can't function anymore. Yet for melee classes contending with this extremely unrefined mechanic can be vital as without it there is not much for them to do versus large enemies besides monotonously whittling away at their legs.

While the magic in this game is uniquely intense it is balanced by having players charge up each super spell they want to cast. If players are interrupted by anything the entire spell is cancelled and has to be restarted. Consequently magic gameplay is mostly running away from enemies, charging up spells, and only a portion is actually spent casting spells. Elemental damage is ridiculously imbalanced. A vast majority of enemies are weak to fire, to a comic degree, so the existence of spells that aren't fire is questionable. A non-fire spell may deal only a fraction of the damage a fire spell does against many enemies, so even though there are multiple elements they're mostly not worth using. And, because of the awkward weak spot locations on enemies; when a spell is unleashed the awkward hitbox may or may not actually touch that vulnerable spot as players can't precisely aim many spells. So the damage of the spell will vary arbitrarily.

Three classes in the game don't actually have an evasive or defensive action. So three classes can't actually do anything to avoid damage besides jump or run away. Not only is this boring, and shallow, it also means certain attacks are not actually avoidable when playing as that class. Because certain attacks simply come on too fast for manual movement to outpace them. And one of these classes is meant to be on the front-line. Some enemies and obstacles are even blatantly designed without certain class restrictions in mind, such as enemies with weak-points located so high on their bodies that melee classes can't realistically reach them.

The combat is also stifled by the asinine statistic build system. Each time players level up their statistics are automatically and permanently increased based on their class. So even though players can freely swap to any class, and are encouraged to do so for unlocking perks, each level up slowly dooms the player to have a specific build which will ultimately make them more or less effective at certain classes. And certain classes have explicitly worse statistic increases per level than others. Players can only have one save slot in this game by the way, one character.

The companion system is interesting, and like everything else in the game it is situationally fun and situationally not. Building a companion up is a nice experience but controlling and shaping their behaviour is pointlessly obscure and tedious. Companions will often speak to help the player but their dialogue is absurd. They will say the same thing over and over every time they encounter the same situation, they will often speak one after the other with no pauses inbetween, any semblance of realism is shattered by the total lack of refinement in their dialogue system. Every single time the player breaks off a cyclops tusk they will be reminded to pick it up, every single time they encounter an enemy weak to fire they will be told that enemy is weak to fire. Surprise, almost everything is weak to fire. It's baffling that the developers made such an overwhelming amount of enemies weak to one element specifically like this.

The computer behaviour on enemies and allies alike is awful. Sometimes they just won't fight, an enemy or ally will simple pace around their opponent. Sometimes enemies will perpetually run away for no reason. The pathfinding on some is atrocious, they will run in circles or go serpentine pointlessly. Companion mages are especially bad, they will often cancel their own spell charging or use inappropriate spells for the situation.

The world is largely empty. There are very little points of interest that are actually of interest, it's mostly just generic scenery and chests full of disposable loot. The game is absolutely inundated with consumables and pick ups which aren't worth the time to use. Between the lack of speaking animations on characters, the amount of enemy recycling, the emptiness of the world and all the unrefined mechanics this game feels like it was made under a distinct budget.

There is also a hard mode, which is similarly unrefined. Increased enemy damage merely means that players will potentially be knocked out instantly by maybe half the attacks in the game. The increased enemy resistance to stagger turns combat into a thoughtless damage race where strategic crowd control is entirely unreliable. While the increased gold and experience drops imbalance the game progression, and overwrite rift crystal drops which are eventually vital to upgrading equipment.

And of course this game is absolutely full of ridiculously sexualized clothing and obviously biased sexualization in general. Quite annoying that while the game gives players decent control over selecting a monogamous partner, certain quests force them into a romantic encounter with a specific character anyways.

The music is fantastic though. The story is decently interesting and unique, has some great twists and characters. But it's only told through scattered obscure quest encounters which fail to produce a comprehensive, consistent narrative even though a very consistent story is unfolding as the game progresses. Yet as unique as the overarching lore is, the rest of the game is extremely uncreative. Generic land mass of plains and woods full of generic enemies like wolves and bandits. Virtually all of the fantasy enemies are generic ones ripped from human mythology like cyclops and chimeras.


A large part of combat depends on the enemy grabbing mechanic which is extremely sloppy, inconsistent and frustrating to manipulate. Magic and elemental weakness are completely imbalanced. Atrocious ally behaviour that constantly rambles about either the same things or says things that make no sense for the moment; unrefined computer behaviour in general that results in enemies and allies alike not fighting or pathfinding properly. An empty world which offers little reward for exploration besides chests with disposable loot and extremely scant quests that can be completely missed. The story this world tells is actually quite unique, but players only experience it vaguely through a broken up series of quests that don't carry the narrative well.

Also it's worth noting that when the Dark Arisen expansion was released players were forced to purchase the whole game a second time if they wanted to get the new expansion; because the expansion was straight up only accessible through that re-released copy of the game. What an abhorrent scam.

Overall this is an okay potential game to spend time on for players that really enjoy role-playing experiences, but it just has a variety of lackluster problems that make it less than appealing from a critical standpoint.

Dragon's Dogma has been one of my favorite games ever since it was released. Though when it was first released around 10 years ago, the content seemed a bit lacking and I never finished it.
Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen adds a lot of content outside of the main story. The whole Bitterblack Isle plot adds greatly towards the lore already established in the main game. The relationship between Arisen and Pawn was made deeper and more intricate.
Dragon's Dogma was a pioneer in its combat systems. The vocation system, as well as the Pawn AI behavior growth makes playthroughs very different each time. Climbing huge monsters, unleashing amazing spells, and having team coordinated attacks are all amazing.
Where Dragon's Dogma suffers is the lack of content, monster variety (as a lot are only reskins), and a generally empty open world. This most likely was a result of the lack of time the dev team had, aiming for an ambitious project but not having enough resources to reach their vision.
With Dragon's Dogma 2 in the horizon, I have only great hopes.
Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen is a 9/10 for me. 🙂

This game literally came to me in a dream and bought it shortly after.

I was initially thrown off by the plain looking graphics at first.

Boy did I underestimate this game! Yeah there's a lot of grey towns and grey caves, but the combat more then makes up for it. The ability to crawl around on monsters and stab them is just raw fun!

The pawn system, for all it's flaws, does introduce some pretty cool lore, and it's surprising how much they can learn to help you. There are (a few) bosses that are either immune to physical or magical damage so you will need a balanced party to have a chance.

Not worth checking out.  I have read and watched so many people raving about this game, and I imagine it could be really good, but it makes playing it so terrible and frustrating that frankly I cannot be bothered playing it - I play games to have fun, fun with a challenge, but I shouldn't be being irritated at every opportunity by really poorly thought out game decisions and interface decisions (this has nothing to do with difficulty of the game, which seems to be pretty easy, though I accept I have really only done the tutorial and opening.  The "tutorial" is a really poor way to bring players into your game, you constantly keep getting in the way of and interfering with the player's ability to have involve themselves into the game and have fun.  In combat the screen gets locked every time one of your moronic AI team mates thinks to say something - I don't care what he says (it's not important and it never is), and interrupting my combat part way through constantly so I cannot relax and enjoy the satisfaction of the combat.  

You then forced me through what could have been a passable player setup back around 2010 (and maybe not even that late, it was dead before Skyrim arrived around 2012), with inconsistent keys being used to make selections - why have you taken a completely different approach to menus than basically everyone else - that can be a good idea if you are improving things, but you really aren't and instead you replace the familiar with an inconsistent unfamiliar mess.  Then at the end you tell me I have to choose one of three classes that will lock my ability to explore and enjoy this world before I have even gotten a taste of it - NO THANK YOU, this is not acceptable, it is not good enough.  If you wish to create a world for us to explore than you need to do it in a way that allows us to grow and adapt within your game, and I have no interest in wasting my time in a game that doesn't.  I hope that with the sequel you make better choices, and I will be interested to see what you have done, but if it suffers from these same failings, I will be a refund for that (I have not refunded this product, I could have refunded it but I am hoping that the proceeds will help towards creating a better sequel).

I wrote this long review to cover a number of details, mainly focusing on the pawn system which is one of the selling points of this game.

This game is from the Playstation 3 era. I originally played over 100 hours there. It's a fun action rpg where you fight mythical creatures. It stood out from other games at the time because of the pawn system (NPC hirelings) who you can put online (sadly you can't make parties with real people). If you aren't playing online the game will generate pawns for you which are close to your level. They can be found in the rift, or walking around in the game world as you travel (they will only stick to major roads and will not follow directions unless they're in your party).

You only get a single MAIN pawn - this is the one who you can fully customise and control the behaviour of. The two other pawns you hire have their own behaviour and physical appearance which cannot be altered, and are defined by the person who owns them - you can see details about them when hiring. Any weapons and armour you give them will be considered a gift which is gone forever. However, items you pick up off the ground can be given to other pawns for them to carry, and they might use them during a fight. 

These OTHER pawns don't level up with you like your main pawn does, so you will occasionally need to reform your party to keep it strong.

You can sit with your main pawn at a 'knowledge chair' and it will ask questions about its behaviour. The way you answer the questions will change its 'inclinations'. These describe how it will behave in battle e.g
- target strong or weak enemies first, 
- pay more attention to your safety or assist other pawns first, 
- make preparations before a fight and use healing items or let you be the one to support them. 

I found the names of each inclination confusing. They aren't explained in the official documentation, and the answers given by the pawns for each question didn't always explain if it had changed its behaviour in a way that would benefit you. 

It is best to read about the inclinations, how they effect pawn behaviour, and how they can be altered by your play style at the Dragon's Dogma wiki (this is useful info because you can accidentally change their inclinations with your play style even after telling them to behave a certain way).

If someone hires your pawn while you're not playing and takes it on a quest you haven't done or fights an enemy you haven't seen, it learns how to deal with that - e.g it might discover a weakness to fire or ice. When you come back to play, your pawn brings that knowledge to your game and will point it out to you when the time comes, and have voice lines to discuss it (though it might not mention it if you have told your pawn not to speak). 

If you decided to swap a pawn out of your party, you can send it back to its owner with a gift and message which goes to that player. Seeing different pawns people have made is part of the fun.

----
Crafting and combat:

There is a crafting and item combining system where you can make items from raw ingredients (collect herbs and mushrooms to make different potions, put raw meat and fruit/vegetables in sealed containers to preserve them, etc), so you need to carry some tools around, it's important to combine things for fighting powerful enemies because some of them might almost one-hit kill you. 

Tools you make can also be used against enemies e.g a pot of oil can be thrown on an enemy to make them more flammable. Pawns will also throw items at enemies if they have the right inclinations (I gave some bombs to a pawn, which he used, but sometimes he missed his target).

Another part of the combat is grappling. You can grab an enemy from behind while your pawn beats it up, they will also call out to you if they've grabbed an enemy. You can grab and climb larger enemies to prevent them from being so mobile, and some enemies can be pulled to the ground by grabbing their legs and putting them off balance. 

You can pick up smaller enemies and throw them at others. In one dungeon I picked up enemy zombies and threw them into a pit, which was easier than trying to 'kill' the undead. Enemies like skeletons are weaker against blunt weapons like clubs or maces, because their bones are broken apart.

----

Regarding your own character creation: 
There are skill sets called 'vocations'. You can switch between them at towns and can unlock the 'augments' from different ones. They include things like increased health, reduced fall damage, resistance to magic damage, etc. However, each vocation is locked into using certain types of weapons and armour. Your player character has access to special hybrid vocations that combine a mix of others (e.g The Assassin is a mix of Fighter and Ranger but has unique augments).

When building the physical appearance of your character, the weight of your character will effect how much they can carry, and how quickly their stamina regenerates (based on the wiki - lighter characters restore stamina more quickly but can carry less than heavier characters).

----

In conclusion, it is an interesting game with a lot of unique quirks. I have read a lot of the negative reviews here and people are frustrated by the AI, questing system and the empty feeling of the game world. Dragon's Dogma was definitely a product of its time (2013) and tried something that no other game had tried. When compared to similar to games today it does feel a bit shallow, and more like a prototype in something bigger. Dragon's Dogma 2 has been announced, so hopefully something much bigger and better is coming in the future.

This is how you do power growth in video games. You might start out fairly weak and fighting for your life vs cyclops and chimeras, but before long you'll be packing some levels and gradually acquiring better gear and suddenly those will no longer be a problem. DDDA isn't free of problems, but the passion shines through clear as day, the core combat is superb, and DD2 is a guaranteed buy from me.

Having more or less seen the vast majority of the game (only thing left is to finish hard mode story), here's how I recommend handling the game for newcomers, which is most of the reason why I always struggled to get into it:

Firstly, you can either min-max your build by focusing 3 different paths (full strength, full magick, hybrid) based on the final vocations you want to play, or not worry about it too much and play what you want because endgame gear is very strong (there is also a save editor where you can reassign your stats, if you really want).

Secondly, go through NG normal mode. You can pretty safely explore the majority of the map from the get go, but there are some harder enemies lurking that you can avoid early if you don't want to tango. Be sure to repeatedly hit up the quest boards, even the ones from the start of the game (these will update every so often with new stuff), and look for NPCs in the world that give quests as some are missable. Don't sweat it too much if you do miss anything.

After NG, start NG+ and run through that. You'll have a decent idea of what to do now, and you'll gain more port crystals, so this will go much quicker. Sometime before ending the game again, clear Bitterblack Isle at least twice through (most recommend level ~80+ to start).

Lastly, once you're done with at least 2 BBI clears, enter hard mode NG++. From here you can go back to BBI early and finish up your leveling very quickly since hard mode gives double XP. Hard mode isn't very hard if you're a decent level. However if you are struggling to clear BBI the second time through in normal mode, then I'd recommend sticking around for a bit until you're comfortable with the majority of it (except for a certain scythe-wielding maniac, don't worry about it too much).

Once you're capped then you're free to farm BBI, enjoy the vocations, style on everything, and watch Infinite Cringe videos in anticipation for DD2.

Best action rpg I have played. It has a lot of unexplored potential and nuisances (such as only 1 save slot, impossible loot/places reach for red vocations, no reset on stats and so on) but Capcom did many things right on this game: They made combat feels epic and magic is pretty; they create a unique interaction between players trough pawns. There is a ("weird"?) dating system where you can romance almost anyone in the game; The story concept IS interesting but could be more explored, as it is a casual player might not understand much about, miss a lot or doesn't really care to what's going on Gransys and most chat and relationships with npc are very limited. Endgame was so bad (Everfall) but they kinda made up for it with Bitterblack Isle. There are a lot of false/wrong descriptions and effects for skills and items but most of it got covered by the community. 

If they stick to the core ideas, improve what was bad by listening community feedback and keep exploring new unique ways of interaction, DD2 will be a blast!

For context, I'm writing this in 2023. I bought this game at 85% off because I saw all the excitement about the sequel announcement and I was curious. I actually think it has a lot going for it. The combat at least is pretty fun; it has a good core gameplay loop. My frustrations stem from how you're asked to move around the map. It's a big map, which I appreciate. The problem is the cumbersome fast travel system. You have to buy a consumable item to fast travel and there are precious few places to which you can actually travel. 

This wouldn't be so bad if it were easier to get around the map without fast travel, but it's not. Your walking speed is a snail's pace, so you have to run to get anywhere and running consumes stamina, so you can only run for about 15 seconds at a time before your character gets winded and has to pause to breathe. Seriously, my character is supposed to be a monster-slaying hero of legend and I apparently have better cardio in real life than they do. 

Even that wouldn't be so bad if you weren't expected to keep running back and forth around the map in every quest. I've found that most of my quests so far start in a town and ask you to run halfway across the map to slay one monster. 

All that to say, I think there is a lot of potential for the sequel to be great, but they're going to need to make some serious quality of life improvements. This game has good things to offer, but I find the slow and awkward travel too frustrating to be worth any more of my time.

Very unique and innovative systems which to this day I haven't seen in other games.

Combat is really the strong suit of this game. It's not only visceral and impactful but it's varied and just plain fun while also having what may be the MOST INNOVATIVE systems I've ever seen. Climbing on ANY monster like Shadow of the Colossus OR grabbing and holding normal sized mobs while you or a pawn critically hits them. Also things like being able to springboard your pawns off your shield to get up to the bosses head just to give another cool example.

The pawn system is also very unique and works flawlessly. They're not only "followers" but offer very interesting insight into things such as the zones and quests while also having very unique "personalities" or inclinations as they're called. Some are more talkative and helpful while some are more aggressive in combat and/or looting chests and crates etc...

Definitely worth a buy even in 2023 onwards and the sequel was just announced during the 10 year anniversary so now is a great time to experience the original.

The only issue I had was with my brand new AMD card it didn't run very well and had some UI glitches and artifacting even though I have a beefy card (which is common for the higher end newer AMD cards). However I found a simple solution...

IF YOU HAVE A NEWER AMD CARD DOWNLOAD DXVK FROM GITHUB AND SIMPLY PUT THE FILES FROM THE x32 FOLDER IN THE GAME'S MAIN DIRECTORY WHERE DDDA.EXE IS LOCATED AND IT 100% FIXES ALL ISSUES.

Basically the DXVK software allows you to run the game using Vulkan instead of DirectX 9. It works with any older games btw you have issues with and the game not only will run without bugs but also run super smooth. Keep in mind for the first hour or two you may have very minor lag spikes while Vulkan is build a cache but from then on it's very smooth.

Dragon's Dogma is an absolute gem of an action RPG. Its combat system is varied and rewarding: it encompasses nearly every single fantasy archetype you can think of while also rewarding player strategy. See that griffin flying in the sky? Cast a flaming meteor at it to burn its wings and bring it crashing to the ground. What about that chimera lurking about? Grab a giant sword and cut its snake tail off. And what of the giant cyclops? Shoot an arrow at its eye to stun it, then slash at its legs to make it topple over. Indeed, there are countless fun interactions like this from start to finish.

Moreover, the game has many inventive features, the most prominent of which being the pawn system: upon creating your custom companion character, other players may recruit them in their own worlds. Pawns become stronger and smarter as a result of helping other players in their journeys, which is an incredibly cool mechanic. The game is chock-full of awesome features like this.

That isn't to say that Dragon's Dogma is perfect—that's far from the truth. The game has many flaws, such as a crappy inventory system, a lackluster story, annoying damage calculation and a tiny world (relative to other open world games,) but if you can look past these issues then a truly one-of-a-kind experience awaits you. Happy hunting, Arisen!

This game has aged extremely well and continues to age extremely well, I could play this game over and over without getting bored simply because of how much variety there is in the classes and combat. No two encounters feel exactly the same. You can even customize your companion's classes and abilities so there's tons of different combinations.
The early game is a little slow but it's only for a few quests. Definitely picks up after you get access to the other classes.
You can optimize your build if you would like but I wouldn't recommend doing so as it requires leveling up as specific classes. This is mostly a problem with the "Hybrid" classes (Magic Archer, Magic Knight). Though there are mods to fix that. (There are some good mods for this game that make it even more enjoyable)

Overall I'd give this game a 9/10, the world doesn't feel 100% absolutely packed at all times but it gets pretty damned close. (I also don't like the fact that you can fail certain quests if you complete other quests too early)

The main thing to Dragon's Dogma is quests and taking on massive boss fights. You're going to find out how big and scary they are. Daimon, the devil I personally found hard. The story I love it... despite it being a little underwhelming. Very unique kinda game. The combat is decent... I mean, I like it at least. You can climb onto enemies, massive or small. There's 9 classes to choose from which are called Vocations. The fact that you get your own NPC pawns to be-friend during your most darkest times, that says a lot about Dragon's Dogma. I think the fast travel system is alright. Fast travel kinda sucks. Why? Well I mean, theres "portcrystals" you gotta place them around the map/world... Not sure what the limit is. Very unique, open world, fantasy game at your doorstep. I've tripled the amount of hours i have in this game compared to Skyrim, that says a lot. I like it more than Monster Hunter World. Oh and I suck at it and Skyrim LOL.

As you dive deeper into the game, you'll enter a place called BLACKBITTER ISLES. What is this place you ask? Well, my friend, It's where you find the biggest, the strongest monsters in the game. The first time I entered, I literally died constantly, in-fact, I still die even now. The game produces some decent soundtrack, decent dialog, decent graphics. Day/Night cycle is awesome, but at night you can barely see anything...to the discomfort of knowing that a giant cyclops may be staring you down from 20 meters in the air. [b] [u] Here's a list of some vocations/classes this game has to offer: [/u] [/b]

[b] Fighter: [/b] Equipped with a sword and a shield. Shield in another hand. Has access to any three sword skills - and any three shields. 

[b]Warrior:[/b] (MY Fave Class) Equipped with a great-sword or a big hammer, I honestly love this class. When you penetrate ungodly blows to the monster's it's so satisfying. Best class, absolute heavy hitter power. 

[b]Strider:[/b] Two daggers and or a short bow. It's a pretty good class for long range attacks which is awesome. Access to unlimited regular arrows, limited to special arrows. You can equip three dagger skills - three shortbow skills. 

[b]Ranger:[/b] Long bow and other long ranged weapons. I personally prefer a long bow rather than short. Ranger skills are mostly around sniping far enemies. 

[b]Mage: [/b] Defensive spells and offensive spells. The mage can fire magical bolts. 

[b]Sorcerer: [/b] Mostly produces offensive spells. (You get the idea, I won't list all the classes)

[b]Conclusion?[/b] If you like slaying monsters, climbing them, you'll like this game. You want to explore some very dark places with some spooks n horrors? This game has that. Dragon's Dogma has good replay-ability. It'll never stop giving you a challenge, my best advice to you is that you prepare for it. The game is well worth playing. Take up arms and fight. So, look, it's now or never, Arisen.

I felt the need to add some more: [b]The bad? [/b] The game doesn't really disclose where you can find side quests. I almost struggle with that every time. Or their location for that matter. You can only save 1 game file at a time.  It's tedious and frustrating when you have to do everything yourself. But hey, everything is about patience and learning! All about perseverance, friend!

I'm sure there are explanations for some of these dumb concepts/issues, but there is nothing in the "Manual".  Hell you can't even quit the game without going to the title screen, clicking any key, then waiting for the menu.  If I was this bad at my job I'd probably jump off a building, but Capcom is proud of this... thank god I only paid $5, still a rip off IMO.

One of the best games I've ever played. Does not get the recognition it deserves. Each vocation feels truly unique and great to play.

My only cons are:

-Travel speed: It's a big world and you get no option of a mount and fast traveling is very limited. You have to run around everywhere on foot. I love the teleport crystal system of creating your personal own travel points, finding them in a dungeon felt really rewarding as well. To improve on this issue in the sequel I would say either A) Infinite stamina while out of combat or B) Adding some form of mounts. The slow world travel is what turns most people off of the game which is really a shame.

-Improving the Warrior Class: Every vocation in this game feels and plays great, except for Warrior. The warrior vocation is very limited in what it can do as the number of skills you can normally equip is halfed. The hyper armor of your skills is also mediocre at best so getting your big hits in is really a gamble. Warrior certainly needs a rework for the sequel.

-Improved Menus: Dragons Dogma features a great variety of items you can use and a crafting system. The problem is that these systems are aggravating to use due to the inventory UI. A UI overhaul for menus and inventories could greatly improve the quality of life of the game and would encourage to further utilize the crafting and item systems that were overlooked because of it. The crafting system is also a bit difficult to use since you basically need to use a wiki or write down recipes. 

-Enemies not available until post game: A large variety of enemies can't be fought until the post game or in the Darkest Isles expansion zone. Per example, you can briefly encounter a hydra near the beginning of the game but you do not actually fight one until the post game. A lot of enemies in the main game are the same few ones recycled with different varieties

Other than those fixable issues most people in the community agree on. Dragon's Dogma is literally one of the best rpg's ever made. Wide variety of weapons and armor. (Almost) Every vocation feels unique and great to play. Enemies are fun to fight against and more. Please give it a try and may the sequel Dragon's Dogma II not only be just as good but also get the spotlight it will deserve

PROS:
[list]

[*] There are many combinations of skills, items, and vocations to choose from that'll give you several chances to figure out what play-style works best for you.
[*] Grigori's voice is enchanting and inspiring...
[/list]
CONS:
[list]
[*] The environment isn't much to gawk at.
[*] Enemy variety is scarce, especially in the base-game.
[*] The world could be bigger, maybe with more cities/towns. 
[*] Not entirely a deal-breaker, considering the pawn system, but: no true multiplayer/co-op.
[/list]

An underrated masterpiece that combines the best parts of Dark Souls, Monster Hunter, and Elder Scrolls into a confusing, engrossing, and addictive formula of discovery and buildcrafting. Absolutely a must play.

Dark Souls, but it focuses on being fun instead of finding every possible avenue to frustrate the player.
I originally played this game (a lot) on the XBOX 360 back when "Dark Arisen" first came out. It was a lot of fun back then, in spite of the performance issues that were present on the console at the time- (even back in 2013, the 360 was definitely showing its age).
The performance on this PC port is great- as it should be, given that the game is a decade old.
The keyboard-and-mouse controls aren't bad at all, which is sadly something of a rarity when it comes to ports.
("Real Yakuza Use A Controller" and all that jazz)

The visual upgrades honestly don't seem to be that outstanding, but that could be because I haven't played the 360 version since I was fifteen years old. I'm sure if I went back to try and play it on console, it'd be a noticeable downgrade.
The game as a whole has a very consistent style- somewhere between an anime aesthetic and semi-realistic graphics.
It has that early/mid-2010s color-scheme that every game at the time had: "Brown = Realistic" AKA "Everything needs to be gritty/dirty/ugly because muh Skyrim".
Everything becomes especially de-saturated after the story's mid-point (You'll know when.)
I usually prefer something more on the saturated side.
High Fantasy > Low Fantasy in my book, the real world is bleak enough. Give me some vibrant colors to go with my RPG.
That being said, in this case, I think that it fits. You can tell that the developers had a vision for the world and stuck to it- they weren't just muting the colors for the sake of making an edgelord's paradise.

The gameplay is some of the most fun I've had in an action-RPG.
Usually I gravitate more towards the classic turn-based style, mostly because most "Action-RPGs" boil down to "Dodge>Attack>Dodge>Attack", or in the case of Bethesda's RPGs "Attack>Heal>Attack>Heal".
No hate on games that do things that way, they definitely have their place in the industry. I likely have more hours in Bethesda RPGs than I do in any other developer's games, after all. They're doing something right.
That being said, every fight in this game rewards the player for actually using their brain.
Monsters have elemental weaknesses to exploit, critical-hit points on their bodies, specific behaviors to memorize and exploit as you learn their patterns, it's wonderful.
Being harassed by a flock of Harpies? Use some flaming arrows / fire spells / AOE melee attacks with a fire weapon to knock them out of the air, then finish them off on the ground.
Giant Cyclops spawn in the woods in front of your party? Jump on his legs, climb all the way up to his eyeball and start punching it until he falls over.
Bandits trying to plunder your corpse? Find a way to knock them over, pick them up, and throw them over a nearby cliff to finish the fight quickly.
There are so, so, so many ways to deal with fights. The variation in monster-types combined with the variation between classes and skills brings so much to the table.

The "Pawn" system- (it's the game's companion system)- is one of my favorite features of the game.
Basically, in addition to creating your player-character, you also get to create a companion that follows you throughout the entirety of the game. You customize their appearance, voice, and even their combat behaviors to an extent.
Everything that you can tweak on your own character can be tweaked on this companion. It's a brilliant addition that I'm surprised hasn't been used in more RPGs over the past decade.
Your pawn "learns" as you play the game, with a "Knowledge Panel" that slowly fills-out as you reveal more monster's weaknesses. This brings an extra aspect of progression to your pawn that makes them more and more useful over time.

The story is absolute dingus, there's no two ways about it.
I get that they were going for a "simple, generic fantasy" story, but come on. At least try.
The terrible voice-acting for some characters (English Dub) definitely doesn't help.
The "Bitterblack Isle" expansion is substantially better in regards to story- but only because they took a step back and left most of the plot-points implied- with exposition dialogue being kept to a minimum.

The music is... honestly, it's pretty forgettable. The main-menu's music being the one exception.
Everything in-game is very understated- to the point where most of the time you won't even realize that music is playing.
An Elder Scrolls Game, this is not.

"Why is there only one save-slot?"
Because this game is meant to be replayed *after* it's finished. It ties into the story itself.
I've never had any issues with my saves corrupting/deleting before, after having played nearly a dozen full completions.
You even carry over your armor and weapons from your previous play-through, which gets you past the introductory areas in about half the time- so it's not quite as much of a slog as you might think. I personally like to sell these carried-over items to buy new equipment for a different class- because who wants to play the same character over and over in an RPG?
That being said, if you like to meta-game and make your decisions irrelevant by save-scumming your way through every RPG you play, this might be a deal-breaker for you.
If you're unhappy with a decision you made / the outcome it brought, then do things differently in your 2nd run.

TL;DR
The deep game-play, progression, and companion system make this one of my favorite RPGs ever, in spite of a lackluster story and mediocre music. Also, Bitterblack Isle is one of the best expansions I've played, and I've probably spent more time there than I have in the main game.
