I played this originally on Xbox 360 so my hours into this game far, far, faaaar, exceeds what is shows on Steam. To this day, I've yet to find a game quite like Dragon's Dogma. Between the innovative and dynamic combat and the unique pawn system, this game is a true hidden gem!

The best part of the game is definitely the combat. You can climb enemies to reach their weak points such as scaling a Cyclops to jab your dagger into its eye, grab onto a Chimera's tail to cleave it off. You or your pawns can even restrain smaller enemies! Your strategies even change based on the class you play and the pawns you bring with.

The second most notable feature of the game is the pawn system. Basically it's a companion that you design and train how you'd like. You choose their appearance, gear, class, personality, and how they approach combat. Then you can share your pawn with other players or restrict who can see them. Other players can hire your pawn and bring them on their adventure. Your pawn can then come back with knowledge about the places, quests, and enemies that they encountered which helps them grow and be more proficient in combat and helping guide you! It's a very unique feature that, given it's novelty, is implemented quite well!

More on the combat: the enemies are also very unique and fit perfectly into this great blend of medieval fantasy setting. There's goblins, cyclops, chimeras, hydras, giant lizards, griffins, and many more!

The class options are also quite varied for you and your pawn. Each feel different and have a clear focus on what they bring to the party. There are eight classes in total: Fighter, Warrior, Strider, Ranger, Assassin, Mage, Sorcerer, Mystic Knight, and Magick Archer. Your pawn can be six of those; they cannot be the Mystic Knight or Magick Archer. They're considered hybrid classes and would likely cause imbalance if pawns could be them.

This would be even longer than it is if I went into all the classes but I would like to highlight some things that standout to me. Sorcerer truly feels like you're a very powerful magic user. From the animations to the spells themselves, if you've ever wanted to feel like a badass wizard, that's your class. Mystic Knight and Magick Archer are two classes I've basically never seen in any other game. Magick Archer being my favorite. It's as the name suggests, an archer that uses magic. Your arrows are completely magic and can track/hone in on enemies to a degree. They exploit elemental weaknesses and have huge utility and some support skills. Mystic Knight uses a tower shield and focuses on reactive, countering gameplay while enchanting their bigass shield to exploit elemental weaknesses. They also get a magic cannon where they lob magic orbs at enemies by hitting a magical sphere. It's pretty great.

While I absolutely love this game, it does have it's flaws. Many people will tell you it's the story and I don't really disagree. I think that Dragon's Dogma has some interesting lore and story, but I don't think it was executed very well. It's hard to pick up on and understand some of the setting and world building at times.

The other flaw I would highlight is the lack of details around building your pawn. Today, there's a lot of information online about how pawns work and how to understand to build them, but the game itself really does not explain at all what the inclinations mean or how they influence your pawn's behavior. I would recommend looking into it a bit so your pawn will behave more how you expect. They will never be perfect, but can absolutely be effective even on their own if trained right!

This was very long, but hopefully it finds someone who wasn't sure about playing the game and helps them to decide to check out this amazing, hidden gem! I recently played through the game again and had a blast! I hope that if you decide to play, that you find it as enjoyable as I do! Also, if you end up enjoying it, Dragon's Dogma 2 is actively being worked on and I am very hyped!

At first I thought the game gave off such a DULL atmosphere, the colors dead everywhere. MAN was I wrong when I thought I beat the game for the first time...
I think of it now and see that the dull colors add to the rustic medieval fantasy feel. I see it well done in this context. 

The pawn AI is actually helpful, most of the time, I feel like your pawn truly mimics YOUR play style. But also sometimes you find yourself shouting at them "NO! YOU USELESS PIECE OF-" "COME HERE!! WHAT THE HELL HELP ME" "I KNOW WOLVES HUNT IN PACKS"
HOWEVER- when I thought my pawn useless and I went on adventuring without them- I actually found myself wishing them back, they WERE helpful. The lack of pawn is very noticeable to say the least lol

The story is so good too when you read between the lines; the question of free will's existence, that, was done well in this game in my humble opinion.

I cannot recommend this game more. Pick it up, you shall not regret it!

Want to start off my mentioning I played most of Dragon's Dogma on console, hence the low playtime. Dragon's Dogma Dark Arisen is an action RPG game developed by Capcom. It is an open-world game that allows players to explore a vast fantasy world filled with danger and adventure. The game is known for its innovative combat system and unique mechanics, which set it apart from other RPGs.

One of the standout features of Dragon's Dogma Dark Arisen is its combat system. Unlike other RPGs, where players typically rely on a combination of button mashing and leveling up their characters to progress, Dragon's Dogma Dark Arisen requires players to use strategy and tactics to defeat their enemies. Players have to choose their weapons and abilities carefully and adapt to different enemy types to succeed. You have three classes to choose from, I had the most fun with the Archer class.

Another unique feature of Dragon's Dogma Dark Arisen is its pawn system. Players can create and customize their own pawns, which are essentially AI-controlled companions that fight alongside the player. Pawns can be customized in terms of their appearance, abilities, and personality. Pawns can also be shared with other players online, allowing for a sense of community and cooperation.

The world of Dragon's Dogma Dark Arisen is vast and immersive. The game is set in a medieval fantasy world filled with magic, dragons, and other mythical creatures. The game's graphics are stunning and the world is filled with beautiful landscapes and detailed environments. The game's sound design is also impressive, with a score that sets the mood and enhances the overall experience.

The game's story is compelling and well-written. The player takes on the role of the Arisen, a chosen hero who must defeat the Dragon and save the world. Along the way, the player will encounter a variety of interesting characters and factions, each with their own motivations and agendas. The game's story is told through a combination of cutscenes, dialogue, and exploration, allowing players to immerse themselves in the world and the characters.

One of my favorite aspects of the game was being able to climb certain emenies and attack ( or chop off) areas that make enemies weaker or less threatening.

In conclusion, Dragon's Dogma Dark Arisen is a must-play game for fans of RPGs and open-world games. Its innovative combat system, unique pawn system, immersive world, and compelling story make it a standout title in its genre. While its difficulty may be a turn-off for some players, it is ultimately a rewarding experience that is sure to provide hours of entertainment.

This has always been my all-time favorite game. I have owned it on every console it has come out on, sometimes multiple times, and I have no regrets. 

You are the chosen one. You are following a story where you are hunting down a dragon. The game has lots of free-roam and there is an aspect of collecting items that I particularly like. I enjoy replaying dungeons to collect loot to get better armor. 

The choices you make in this game matter and there are often times more than one ways to complete a quest. 

One really cool thing about this game is that you can climb onto the baddies and hack at them as you cling. It blew my mind the first time I scurried up a cyclops and he reacted appropriately when I hit him in the eye. Just an overall fun game and a massive replay value.

So, I'm giving this game a thumbs up entirely for the gameplay and other personal things i enjoy about this game:
1 - The swordplay is awesome, I really enjoy slashing around with the weapon and the attacks of melee classes.
2 - the aesthetics are wonderful, real medieval Europe look to the armor and weaponry. The clothes, especially.
3 - Generally it's beautiful. the monsters, the landscapes, the sky, the scenery, the buildings all look absolutely gorgeous.
4 - magic, while i've not fully explored it as of now, looks beautiful and varied, heavily elemental but it's tied to a weakness/resistance mechanic and so plays astonishingly well.
5 - you can turn off the speech lines of your companions. Trust me, this is a good feature.
6 - Monsters of lore are included in manners in which they are described through history - Chimera are literally three headed, hydra resemble serpents, wyrms and draconic creatures alike are all done justice to, truly
7 - there is a gear upgrade system which isn't too complex and exploring, even when searching for resources, is actually fun rather than a slog (ahem, AC Oddysey, ahahem)
8 - Enemy AI can be rather challenging, as opposed to a braindead model that has no idea how to take advantage of you.
9 - enemy types have individual strengths and weaknesses
10 - there is a mechanic in which wind tunnels are formed in the landscape, and your character can be caught in the draft. as in, pushed about. and their size and strength stat actually effects how well they can fight the forces of it. This is gorgeous.
11 - You can stagger enemies with attacks and, once staggered, grab them. if they are the same size or smaller than you (aka a human or animal or human size monster like a goblin or a harpy), you pick them up like an item. this includes bats, mice, rats, wolves, rabbits, goblins, hobgoblins, harpies, zombies, humans, etc. you can in fact then THROW them. the ultimate disrespect. Now, you can still grapple larger enemies - you CLIMB them like the absolute unit you are, and claw your way to their weak spots to dole out your relatively small fury with whatever weapon you wield! a cyclops irritating you? grab it's leg and march to that big beady eye! you are as badass as you want to be!
12 - even in death, you are a badass. I have died in this game and thought "that was so cinematic that i wish wholeheartedly that i'd been recording" - if you're wondering, i was launched off a cliff by a stone golem when i attempted to claw my way up it's arm.

9/10 from me - only flaws being that it's a single save file, which is overwritten whenever you save, it autosaves or you begin a new game. annoying but not a gigantic deal if you're cautious. that and the "pawn" system has some flaws - most of the pawns you get, being unavoidably AI, are rather birdbrained. some of them will even run off to grab things from the woods if you're travelling. I usually just go grab the fucker and toss him back to the path as a warning.

This is one of the worst games I have ever tried to play. No explanations, want your ai companions to stay close or far away? hope you answered some random questions correctly. Mine just hunts for crap off the ground instead of fighting. Select utility for every answer? lol no, none for you.
I guess the combat is ok but at it's heart this game will always be a terrible skyrim/souls rip off.

Dragon's Dogma first came out in 2012. I imagine that if I'd played it back then I might be a bit more forgiving now, but as it is this just feels like a typical clunky Capcom game with wonky controls and some typically dumb AI companions.

- Weird beginning. The key cutscene that lays out the game's premise doesn't have any words.... so I don't really know what's going on
- I don't like being forced to have AI companions, and their AI is bad
- AI companions constantly repeat the same voice lines
- As a mage, I feel like my attacks do nothing. Cast times are long for actual spells and my main damage spell takes maybe 1% of a health bar. Otherwise I sit there quick attacking which also takes practically no health off.
- There doesn't appear to be any way to aim my spells at a certain target
- Gave up when I got eaten by a scripted attack by a huge Hydra attacking the encampment. I was clearly inside it's throat, but I couldn't move or do anything, and I wasn't losing any health... so I assume it just bugged out.

This is a great action game, and one of the most innovative RPGs ever. The action benefits from the history of fighting and hack and slash games in the development team. The character customization, classes, and AI pawns give the player an immense amount of freedom in how he chooses to play the game. The high difficulty of the game makes the game rewarding to beat the first time, as well as the second time and every time after that. You're diligence in planning your character and min/maxing his stats actually affects your experience playing the game. On top of that, you have pawns, which cooperate with you in battle. Those can be min/maxed as well. Basically, the only thing that makes the hundredth playthrough easier than the first is your game knowledge and skill. The Dark Arisen update tests your abilities and knowledge further, as enemies there act faster, have new abilities, and have higher stats. You'll also come to love the world design of this game. It is an open world, but every area of the map feels like intelligent level design. You will see new enemies everywhere you go, from human bandits to griffons, and even dragons (multiple types of them). Overall, this game is one of the best hardcore RPGs ever. It has some flaws, for example its underdeveloped story and old graphics, but that's what the sequel is for. If the sequel can build upon this masterpiece and avoid mainstream pressure for forgiveness and quality of life features, then it has the potential to be even better that the original.

Asolutely no difficulty curve. just random cranks in difficulty, so you have to abandon your previous quest, go grind some more levels, tinker with the absolutely god awful shit ass fucking pawns, who are more worthless than shit on a shoe. Fuck this awful game.

Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen is an underrated action role-playing game that, unfortunately, got overshadowed by the juggernaut that was The Elder Scrolls: Skyrim. However, the game has a lot going for it, from its deep combat system, crafting system and its vast array of mythical creatures. And while the world may not be the prettiest, it has a certain charm to it. The AI companion Pawns are a great addition, learning as you explore and offering tips and assistance in combat. Despite the occasional dumb thing they do, they're surprisingly intelligent. All in all, Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen is an enjoyable and underrated game that deserves more attention. If you're not sold, it often goes on heavily discounted sales.

The combat system in this game should have been what games have evolved from these last several years. Great hack-and-slash with tactical combat abilities, grappling/climbing enemies mechanics, and aggressive enemy AI that attacks and reacts quickly, doesn't telegraph attacks, and can be genuinely difficult to defeat without progression. 
The grind can be pretty fun, and you'll want to because my one big complaint is how short the main campaign is. I've played before on console so I knew to try and drag out the experience (could do great with daily needs for the MC) and even so I could probably end the campaign in under 80 hrs in the main game. Bitterblack makes up for this pretty amazingly, getting lost in it and facing all variety of intense enemies is a whole game in itself. 
Inventory, equipment, and upgrades are all pretty cool, not over complicated but you really have to work to get the materials and meet the right conditions to max out. Items matter, they aren't over abundant but you don't have to farm them either, except for the higher level upgrade requirements and top tier gear. 
The world is very active and feels way too alive to not have more content integrated, but even so it's still a great world to explore and get lost in. The map feels huge while exploring it but leaves you wanting more.
Can't wait for the sequel.

GOOD GAME

It's the most kitchen sink and generic as possible game imaginable in presentation. Every single monster or enemy you fight is taken near straight from Dungeons and Dragons monster books.

And you know what? It's excellent. There's no nonsensical ambiguity, there's no elements that don't flow or work well. Everything belongs in the world and makes sense, because they focused on doing everything well rather than trying to be unique or special. This idea of surface level blandness is a facade to cover the depth of consideration and effort that went into the game in nearly every imaginable way. Whether it's the monsters, the aesthetics, or the gameplay itself.

There are precious few other games where your character's height and weight actually affects how you interact with the game world or how you fight specific enemies. There are precious few that have the ability to have your mage create gigantic ice pillars that you can then use as stepping stones to rapidly scale a cyclops or some other kind of wild shenanigans. 

For 30$ this game is a steal. It's Skyrim without Todd Howard lies.

[h1] Great concept, poor execution[/h1]1. Buffs are almost essential, yet managing them is tedious. Have fun refreshing buffs every 2 minutes.[hr][/hr]2. Spells are powerful but the cast times are ridiculous. Melee classes get nice upgrades without any downsides. Mages? Stronger spells, longer cast time. When a stray arrow can take more than 40% of your health. Why healing spells take more than 5 seconds to cast when you can carry so many potions? Spell casting doesn't feel fluid and the keyboard controls are very clumsy. Stronger buffs...longer casts times. See point 1.  Maybe magic buffs should just come...as a side effect[hr][/hr]3. Dumb party AI. Also, there is no way to configure it! You would rely on them for buffs, but good luck with that.[hr][/hr]4. Why can I hire companions (for free) with better gear than I can buy/find during a game stage? Your gear is kinda locked behind the story, regardless of level. Companion gear basically scales with your level (not exactly, but you get the idea).[hr][/hr]5. Melee combat is quite good but the lack of target locking is weird.[hr][/hr]6. Melee attacks that cost stamina are a bit too strong. Spam-able charge with knockdown!? Poor enemy mages/archers. It feels like some kind of whack-a-mole. You just use the charge skill to pick squishy targets. It looks silly (charge -> mage dead in 2 hits -> charge -> archer dead in 3 hits ->...) [hr][/hr] 7. Too much stat scaling - like in a MMO. [hr][/hr] 8. Overpowered consumables [hr][/hr] There are more issues, but it is not worth mentioning them all at this point. The game has some good points, but is very flawed.

This is not a game. It's a social experiment to determine the obsession necessary to complete the most frustrating non-game imaginable. There's no way this giant turd could have been made by accident. Every choice was obviously focused on the most aggravating gameplay. 1) There's 2 inventory screens. 2) There's no map button. You have to hit Esc to get to the menu to get to any page (quest, map, etc) and inventory because there's a key (I) to access inventory but's it's a slightly different inventory than the menu inventory. 3) The "light" takes the new world record for most idiotic light source. So it's dark most of the time; 50% of the time outside and 100% inside (tombs, catacombs, caves, etc). And most time is spent indoors. More than enough magic, actually too much, but not one reasonable, REASONABLE, magic source of light. You have to run around with a lantern that you must refill every 3-4 minutes of gameplay with oil that you must constantly be looting (insert looting simulator here) to keep it lit. Many places that require a light source, and I mean require because it's completely pitch black without it, also have pools and streams and falls of water, yes waterfalls and every instance extinguishes the lantern. Now, to turn it back on you have to 1) Hit "I" to open inventory 2) Click on "tools" 3) Click on lantern. If it's not on the first page you''ll have to drag scroll the page to find your lantern because the mouse scroll isn't configured or configurable with mouse scrolling (another gripe you'll hear about) 4) Click on lantern again to open the options menu 5) Click on "put away" 6) Watch character action of putting the lantern away (you must watch this or the next parts are unavailable) 7) Repeat all actions again to equip the lantern, so hit "I" to open inventory 8) Click on "tools" 9) Click on lantern 10) Click on lantern again to open the options menu 11) Click on "equip" 12) And now you get light again. Then you run 3 steps and the lantern goes out again. I  s h i t  you not this will happen 10-20 times in a row. More than enough to lose your  s h i t. A true test of self-masochism. Ok now 4) (because all of that was #3) Doors always close behind you. Small but still annoying. It's a pain having to turn around an open the door I just opened especially since there's a considerable amount and it's takes time and it's an annoying timely little action. You have to stop, the toon lifts it's hand, the door slowly opens and you can't even run up to it and open it, you have to stop moving completely while you're button mashing to open the door. Just another straw on the camel's back. 5) Every quest is a chore. There's no logic or reasoning. It's never simple. I have to google just about everything to the point where I'm using a walkthrough. Quest can be missed and all non-main quest can be  failed permanently. Many side quests consist of killing a number of certain creatures. If you like to explore, and chances are you do if you're playing this type of game, you'll get many quests after completing them by chance but not getting credit. So now you have to do it twice. There are instance that can lead to no more main quests. I finished a main quest only to be left with no more quests. I wasn't listening to another long cutscene. I was supposed to talk to a certain person but there was no record of previous conversations . I was in quest limbo until I talked with a certain individual. I had to use the guide to know what I needed to do. They really could have left it in the quest log. 6) Way too many categories in the inventory menu and way, way too many items that could go into category. What a clusterf uck! This one get's another world record. There are literally thousands of "Curatives", "Tools", "Materials", "Specials", and "Others". So many in fact that they didn't have enough icons to represent them so there are "Curatives", "Tools", "Materials", "Specials", and "Others" that all have the exact same icon. sometimes there are 10+ different "Curatives", "Tools", "Materials", "Specials", and "Others" that all have the exact same icon. This gets overwhelmingly confusing to the point where you just don't care about the game itself. It's a giant looting simulator on steroids. 7) Mouse scroll button is essentially useless. I believe it's used for one useless task. I used it once to discover how useless it was. 8) Your pawns are morons. These suicidal idiots will throw themselves off cliffs at every opportunity and it's a fuc king pain to get them back. You'll always lose them on your way to a boss with no way to retrieve them, or a giant run backwards to a riftstone just to revive them. Hoping to hell they don't find a hole to jump into on your way back. 9) This one is huge for me. There's only one save, ever. Only one game can be played and one save per game. You can manually save but it also auto-saves and you can't turn it off. So just about every action is permanent. The auto-save is terrible and will eventually fu ck your game. 10) Quitting the game is a pain. It's one of those bulls hit games that make you return to the title screen, then make you wait until it orders you like monkey to press any button to continue, because that's what I want to do when I want to quit a game, I want to continue. WTF!? So now it goes to the screen that allows you to "Exit". Basically this game is laughing as it's giving you the finger while buttfuc king you.

As a fan of action games, I'm very picky when it come to the combat gameplay, totally did not expect to like this game.
Everything looks so simple and yet you feel epic when you take down a giant enemy, being able to climb on to an enemy then attacking them until they fall is not something many game let you do and it feels great in DDDA, companion AI actually working, not dumb and worth having them around. The game is actually kinda hard, you're not gonna blast through the early game like other RPG, there's no level scaling in the game. The RPG aspects of the game aren't too deep, there are stats but you can't customize them like say Dark Souls, stats growth are fixed and depend on your class. The world is fun to explore, not too big, not too small, not empty like most open world games.
Underrated hidden gem, truly ahead of its time, can't wait for DD2.

You shouldn't really play the game for the story.
Decent character creation that has impact on what your class will be and what feats you'll be able to do like if you're tall, you'll be able to climb higher or if you're fat, you're a lot less mobile and lack stamina which this game has a lot of running to do unless you use the infinite ferrystone which you get at the capital, Gran Soren's bank.
Ferrystones are consumable items that let's you fast travel/teleport to areas with portcrystals or portcrystals that you place physically in the world.
Companions are the online aspect, basically you can use your friend's or random people's created NPCs to help you on your adventure.
Bitterblack Isle is an end-game area, don't do it yet unless you want a challenge. You get here from a quest a Cassardis at night-time docks.
Speed run mode exists.
Only 1 save file, so do not mess up.

The questing can be stupid because you do the smallest thing and you fail a questline so you have to read a quest guide. But I learned that you shouldn't really care about failing a few because you'll be playing New Game + anyways. 
Overall just read a  quest guide and most importantly do not fail the Lost & Found questline early on because it could lock you out of a region. I'd avoid doing the main questline because it's easy to complete and if you progress too far, you automatically fail side quests.

Here are quests that you should do based on Relevant Rewards:

[b]Stage 1 [i](Off With Its Head Quest- Before Delivering the Hydra Head to Gran Soren by Wagon)[/i]:[/b]

[/list]

[list]

 [*]Lost & Found [i](Do not fail this, Everfall underground spiral stairs. Do not examine the throne at the end of the dungeon. This quest will lock you out of a region and multiple questlines with Selene and Quina)[/i]
 [*]Dying of Curiosity
 [*]A Troublesome Tome
 [*]Chasing Shadows
 [*]Land of Opportunity
 [*]Escort Duty [i](Has prerequisite quests but also a valuable item the Gold Idol which you duplicate and forge. Do not make the little girl you are escorting angry, be quick with tasks, and do not push her. You get the reward by talking to her afterwards unless you do some cheating and parkour to get the item on a pillar)[/i]

[/list]

[b]Stage 3 [i](Before Come to Court)[/i]:[/b]
[list]

[/list]

[b]Stage 4 [i](Before Trials/Griffin's Bane)[/i]:[/b]
[list]
 [*]An Innocent Man
 [*]Arousing Suspicion [i](Talk to the Princess before trying to leave the court grounds or you fail)
 [*]Idol Worship [i](Giving a Bronze, Silver, or Gold Idol unlocks better gear for 2 merchants. Madeleine's (More female gear-orientated + weapons) or Caxton's Shop (gear + weapons). Make sure to duplicate/forge any idol cause they give shop discounts when in any party member's inventory)[/i]

A Japanese action-RPG set in an enthralling and terrifying dark fantasy world. Sprawling verdant valleys, nightmarish chimeric beasts, plundering bandit-usurped castle ruins by day and scouring wicked forests by moonlight. 

I could agonize and pore over the breadth of detail, groundbreaking "pawn system", gripping action, hybrid-classes and visceral visual/audial experience this game has to offer, but I will leave the mystery to you: If you love dark fantasy and all its old haunted magic, the thrills of the pursuit of challenge, and want to experience a sublime spin on the JRPG genre,

[b] buy this game. [/b]

Can't really understand this games ratings.

- Terrible balance. Enemy fighters are ridiulously overpowered compared to other enemy types. 
- Absolutely ancient save mechanics. There's only one slot and it gets automatically overriden all the time. 
- Awful ingame menus, overloaded with buttons. 
- Loads of quests that give you basically no directions of where to go
- Quest do not give you any information about the required level. You get some quests early on where you absolutely don't stand any chance against the enemies. Super fun!
- Annoying health system that forces you to rest at inns. 
- Fast travel system heavily overcomplicated and unflexible 
- Progress sometimes requires you to do perform certain actions. What are those actions? Well have a guess, game doesn't tell you. (Example: To get past the waygate to Grand Soren you have to have a rest at the encampment earlier in the game. Have fun finding that out without google.)
- Pawns, while being interesting mechanic wise, are totally brainless and die all the time. Also they make me feel like a slaver. Very awkward lorewise.

BEST GAME EVER.

Enemies varied and so alive.
Combat varied, responsive. You can switch your class whenever.
The movement is precise and energetic.
Character creation is unmatched.
The loot is non-random, some interesting stats besides your basic attack/defense make even early game gear still useful later.
The exploration is fun, even though the world is not too big.

Some problems. The UI is not the best. The story is not as good as it could be.

All in all, great game.

Edit a few years later: STILL BEST GAME EVER!

Dragon's Dogma Dark Arisen is truly a wonderful piece of work and a extremely underrated RPG game. I am in love with the vocation system and how each one has their own unique levels. I myself spent quite a bit of time alternating between the different vocation to level and just try them out. Each one is unique in their own way and most strive at one specific thing. 

The pawn system was an interesting approach and take on the idea of including a Multiplayer system into the game. A lot of pawns have been crafted by players to benefit the player in crucial ways, Whilst others are just kind of put together because they have to be. Sometimes it felt like I was babysitting my pawns having to pick them up a lot, but other times they do an insane amount of damage against downed monsters that makes a fight of 5 phases feel like a fight of 1.

The story was insane. The first time I played through this game I was interested but it kind of felt basic... that is, until you kill the dragon, Then man oh man what a strange turn that took. When I started playing this game it felt like such a cliche story line. You're a specially chosen Warrior or whatever destined to kill a dragon and save humanity. Cool right? Well then after me doing a bunch of stuff and quests and whatever 26 hours later I finally went ahead and killed the dragon. Died, a lot. But eventually pulled through it, and I kind of figured well that's probably the end of the game. Well, have I never been more wrong. Entering the Everfall was where I had become more interested in a game than I had ever been. Especially the second time. The phrase, "The ever turning wheel" makes soooooooo much more sense once you finish the game a second time, and seriously it had my jaw on the floor I was so shocked. Very good and very well put together story.

The combat in Dragon's Dogma is also fantastic. The climbing feature onto monsters double, triple, even 4x your size is a really cool feature. I killed many MANY cyclops in this game and it so fun to scale the creature  to his head and plunge a sword directly into it's eye and it feels rewarding doing such a thing. Even with Golems where you have to circle the entire creature to take him down, and the Wyrms are just a whole different story. Unfortunately I wish the final boss battle had a better climbing feature because trying to hit his heart as a Warrior did not work very well. My pawns ended up doing most the damage but every time he was down I was able to wail on him. But I've played games with worse fights.

Now for the thing I am not too fond of with this game. The story line the second time you play it is not that long especially with the side quests. By the end of my first play through I was a level 52. By the end of my second I was 67. Then I though okay, I'm going to go Bitterblack Isle. Yeah, still not able to do it. Most people recommend between 70-80 in order to do it, and yeah it's difficult alright. Which I am not opposed to but I'm not too fond of getting one shot because of one bad move. So I thought okay well I can't do this because I am dying way too often. So I went to fight the Ur Dragon, which I also can't do because I need to be level 100. Plus, I have to be a range character to even defeat the creature. Now, it's more so my fault I know because I don't really want to play the game through 2 more times just to get to the levels in order to do such a fight, so I think I'm going to just not do the harder content because questing, and killing monsters seems to not be enough to get to those higher levels without just Cheesing the leveling system. So yes, it's of course my fault for lacking the patience but I also am not that determined to do the those particular boss fights anyway. 

Overall, very good game very underrated and was quite pleased with my experience. Will surely revisit in a few years or so! - 8/10
This game is awesome. I have played it on other platforms and I keep coming back to it. The combat is really satisfying. Highly recommended.

Best combat in any rpg to this date. Story is intriguing but the pacing and delivery is off due to the game being cut down to 30% of the originally imagined content. The Pawn system is also great, though with how old the game is your pawn might not get rented out as much. Bitterblack Isle is a great challenge once you're done the endgame. That combined with the possibility of building your character in many different ways means that as long as you enjoy the amazing combat, the game has nearly infinite replayability. Highly recommended.

Dragon's Dogma ?
More like Dragon's Ligma

A sometimes obtuse and simple story is overshadowed by an amazing combat system with climbable enemies and class variety with a play-style for anybody. There's fun enemies and bosses to fight and a competent, but not over-designed, party management system make this extremely addicting to play long after the main story has run its course. Where other JRPGs often try to throw as many combat and party management mechanics at you as they can, Dragon's Dogma decided to focus on making each aspect of the game approachable, but with hidden depth for those looking to min-max. Definitely worth it at the sale price it is often at.

Recently, I've been stuck without a job, and combined with the usual lull of openings at the start of a new year, and an urge to get a big title off of my backlog, I finally committed to sitting down and, over the course of around 2 weeks (not accounting for a break I took midway through to avoid burnout), beating Dragon's Dogma.

Directed by my favourite game director and godfather to my children, Hideaki Itsuno, it felt more surprising it took me this long to get to it than anything else. Not to say I avoided the game; I bought it on PS4 in 2017 with full intention of playing it. The problem was, as an 18 year old in school, dedicating a ton of time to a JRPG, or several, if you have a backlog like mine, is tough. As a 23 year old who's currently unemployed? Much easier. In addition to my obvious love of Devil May Cry 3, 4 and 5, the explosive reaction to Dragon's Dogma 2 also served as the final push I needed to finally take a look and see just what the mad man's dream project was. Standing at the end of the game, I can say this.

Dragon's Dogma is the best "9/10 7/10" game since Devil May Cry 4. Fitting, given Itsuno directed both games one after another, and they were both subject to incredibly obvious time and budgetary constraints. But what do I mean by that?

A "9/10 7/10" is my personal term for a game that, structurally, is a bit of a mess. Using DMC4 as our example, the game's blatantly held back from being all it could be. Its level designs, especially Fortuna Castle and the forest, are messes that display blatant padding (to say nothing of the infamous dice game, easy as it may be to cheese), there's some aggravating enemy types and a pair of outright bad bosses, and the game's second half is the dev team running out of time and money so they had to make Dante run backwards through the game. To those uninitiated, DMC4 sounds like a tire fire of a game from that description. But it's the gameplay that serves to help me look past all that. Depending on who you ask, some may tell you DMC4's insane levels of depth and complexity still rank it above 3 and 5 for them, in spite of those games being more complete and arguably having more to them at first glance.

Dragon's Dogma is no different.

In JRPG fashion, the intro is a slow one, combined with a surprisingly steep difficulty curve. Stamina and weight play a huge factor across the game; the former being exactly what you'd expect, while the latter is a hard limit on the amount of items you and your party members can carry. A cool idea on paper, a nightmare if you hit the cap while exploring and have to do some menuing to trade things between party members to claim your spoils. An incredibly limiting fast travel system leads to a lot of walking the expansive overworld with a specific item allowing you to plant expensive fast travel points where you desire, and expiring side quests that the game makes no attempt to warn you about. All of these make for a game I'm sure many have dropped over the years.

And yet, Dragon's Dogma makes for one of the most enthralling JRPGs I've sat down to see through to the end. The pawn system makes for a great way of building community in a game thats still a single player JRPG and making every playthrough feel unique in a way I wish Xenoblade Chronicles 2, a game I also love to death, had gone with in place of its cumbersome gacha-lite system. While not up there with Itsuno's DMC works in terms of pure depth and complexity, combat between the various classes are a blast as long as you're well prepared for enemies you need to fight at a range and have a mage for healing, and it only furthers my opinion on the pawn system, as any you hire will gradually learn things like quests and ways to dispatch enemy types from the players who hire them, or casting magic in sync to power up a strike. Combined with the ability to scale enemies to provide a sensation of felling a giant beast in a way few other titles can replicate, a ton of moves upon each vocation, an expansive extra dungeon in the form of the Bitterblack Isle, and a fantastic soundtrack to cap it off (seriously, the first time the track 'End Of The Struggle'  blasts during the climax with a major boss is a life changing moment), you've got near endless amount of combinations to make a playthrough feel unique.

While its story is mostly window dressing and you can absolutely tell it suffers from the fact that Capcom higherups kicked down the doors and told Itsuno "Hey, wrap it up, we don't care if it's not ready yet", there's a likeable cast throughout (especially Mercedes, the indisputable best girl) and the ending to the postgame left me floored in ways I haven't felt since Asura's Wrath.

And yet, as much as I loved my time with Dragon's Dogma, to the point I'm close to nabbing every single achievement at the time of writing, I still see a mountain of potential. The power of current gen platforms, combined with the budget, time and goodwill that Itsuno has earned after Devil May Cry 5 was a smashing success, are doubtless to make the upcoming Dragon's Dogma 2 the equivalent to this title as DMC5 is to 4: Over a decade removed, but treated with every bit as much love and care as it deserves, and without losing any of its identity in the process, each serving as a true successor to woefully unfinished masterworks. I'm on the hype train, Itsuno. Bring it on.

While I can see the appeal for this game, I just couldn't get into it. Here's why.

The game visually looks okay for being made in 2013, but suffers from the blandest color scheme I have ever seen. I understand it's supposed to be some sort of dark fantasy atmosphere, which is fine, but the environments look so utterly boring that I struggled to remember where anything was. Dark Souls has the same color scheme yet still manages to look interesting environmentally, for a comparison.

The story makes no sense thus far, as my character had their heart ripped out for no reason by a dragon...which made my character undying or something. The side characters give no explanation of what happened, and the player's companions (Pawns) are blank-slated idiots who couldn't tell you what color the sky is.

Combat is somewhat fun, but I couldn't figure out a way to dodge attacks. The strategy seemed to be to not over commit or to stunlock weaker enemies. Either way, it wasn't extremely engaging.

Finally, the story missions were mostly frustrating. The only exciting part came when I fought an ogre thing and shot it in the eye for increased damage.
The last mission I played involved escorting an oxcart that moves at a snails pace, all while a legion of monsters tries killing it. This would be boring enough if the enemies posed a challenge, or if an unavoidable boulder didn't roll directly into the ox, depleting about 50% of its health. I lost interest after somehow completing this mission.

In summary, this game feels like if you mixed Skyrim's open world and Dark Souls' atmosphere/gameplay style, but only took the bad parts from both of them.
Enjoying the game so far :) It's great fun climbing the giant monsters to attack them

Pros:
- Gigachad Mystic Knight class lets you enchant your shield and let it explode in your enemies' faces. If you wanna be a battlemage, you should try this game
- Very immersive companion AI. They have their own personalities that shows in combat, but also have certain experiences and knowledge that they will share
- Badass combat/magic system.
- Game has large enemies and is designed for them. They move appropriately to their surroundings, not tripping up or getting stuck every two seconds, and you can even climb them during combat.

Cons:
- pathetic carry weight, paired with dozens of "miscellaneous" items that can be combined in various ways (but you have to guess every combination). For me it causes some headaches
- cryptic story and lots of riddles or lack of direction (gets particularly bad if you start playing after a pause)
- open world is pretty small and not very open

A few years ago, I had this game on the Xbox 360, I thought it was cool at first but I didn't manage to finish this game on the console, just didn't have the time to do that even though I liked it, well, until today, I managed to beat the game after 9-8 years of not touching this childhood gem lol, again, i'll do the category stuff, and maybe a small word for those 9-8 years

Gameplay: Challenging but not too challenging, of course, it may show it's age (a little bit), it's still functional, personal favorite was the climbing, something about just climbing up the Cyclops just to dice it into sushi is just...wow, not to mention that when you start the game, you are LITERALLY sent to the tutorial first, that being that and a prologue mission to the game really sets the mood (somewhat), let's not forget: Pawns, their mechanics are impressive (i.e: if you and your party of pawns created by other people charge into a boss room, the pawn's personailty will change to fit your style of adventuring) oh and character creation too, i think you'll know what to do when you see that, speaking of which, The Story.

Story: To be honest, it can be a little slow at first, As I did mention, the prologue mission sends you straight into gameplay, no cutscenes until the end of the prologue. then you get sent to the character creation stuff, blah blah blah. then after all that's done, the actual story slides back a bit, as usual, I can't really explain much about the story, but this one I really can't explain much but all I can say is this: Near the end of the story, things might get a bit crazy

Music: Banger, and this game gave me two personal favorites: Eternal Return and Into Free, it's a little bit of a mish mash of music genres between Hard Rock and Orchestral music (I'm pretty sure you could even hear someone shredding a guitar in the background while fighting a boss)

Note: if necessary, feel free to look at the DD Wiki, it can be helpful at times (just don't accidentally spoil yourself the story)

Overall, was it worth finishing the game after 9-8 years? Yeah, it just feels accomplishing, makes me miss my Xbox though lol, so in my humble opinion: 9.9/10, Thanks for the childhood memories, Capcom.

(P.S: Hopefully Dragon's Dogma 2 is this good aswell)

(P.S.S: Replaying the game multiple times is also encouraged, you'll see when you finish the game first time)

I have tried to play this game on 3 separate occasions, originally on 360, then on PC when it came out and again now. This game is so lame man, it has possibly one of the coolest introduction levels, followed by 12 hours of monotonous repetitive gameplay where absolutely nothing happens, enemies take 500 hits to kill, the combat has absolutely no punch whatsoever, while I agree the "COMBAT" is better than Skyrim, the rest of the game is not even on the same page. When I first played Dragons Dogma I only played a small amount of it, mostly spending my time in the opening village. I fell in love with the combat and the introduction to Gregory the dragon at the start of the game. I didn't get around to finishing it because I moved onto other titles, in my head I built up Dogma to be an entire game just like that opening. After over a year I came back to it and now have played way more, something I partly regret because now the fantasy of what I thought the game was has been washed away and underneath I see what it really is.

Dogma draws you in with a fantastic intro to a dragon who curses you and sets up perfectly in a way that makes you want to lean everything you can about it, it's power it's backstory, it's world and so much more. Too bad the dragon barely appears for the rest of the game. Instead enjoy running fetch quests for random boring NPC's that no one likes or cares about whilst other people stand around dropping exposition that almost never even has anything to do with the dragon. 

Whilst doing fetch quests enjoy running out of stamina every 10 seconds as you go from location to location. Don't you dare explore off the main path and try collecting items because your character will run out of space and you'll have to spend 5 mins passing everything onto your NPC Ally to carry after every fight. 

When this happens you'll learn the joy that is the menus which are clunky to say the least. For example to fast travel you'd think you could just click the location on the map right? Wrong! You have to go searching through your innovatory for an item that lets you travel and then it brings up a map. Then you still can't just click where you want to go. You have you scroll through another clunky menu. Why is it so overly complex for such a simple feature?

It really does feel as though the further into the game I get, the worse it becomes. Honestly gotten to the point it's so Janky that I'm struggling to even bring myself to see if Gregory comes back for a final boss or if it whimpers out on me yet again.

I remember there was a time where I hated this game. I hated its gameplay, its plot, its visuals and so on. I even when as far as writing a salty review on Steam.

As you can see by my hours and my now positive review, things have changed. The writing grew on me, the story turned to be much more interesting than I thought at first glance, I came to appreciate the artstyle for its genuine attempt at blending "fantastic" with "sensible", and the gameplay...Good lord, the gameplay.

Let me put it this way; Dragon's Dogma has the best goddamn combat in an action RPG. Not even the Souls games can compare. To this day, I haven't seen any other RPG that has even attempted to make combat as dynamic, fluid, exciting, and just f*cking sick as DG's. It starts clunky at first, but once you get used to the controls and unlock a few more skills, it gradually opens up in ways you couldn't have imagined when you first started playing the game. Battles are chaotic, methodic, brutal, and the best part is it doesn't have to rely on gimmicky pre-scripted scenes to make them look awesome. Warriors hit like trucks and manouvre just as bad as one, landing bow shots is satisfying as all hell, and magic is a spectacle to behold and stupidly overpowered, as it should be. DG's dragon fights make Skyrim's look even more pathetic.

Developers keep making and designing huge, gargantuan monsters to fight, and every time, the only thing you do is hack at their feet. But Dragon's Dogma says "f*ck that noise" and lets you interact with bosses in ways almost no other game lets you. The Cyclops has a helmet that covers its weakspot? Climb on his head and have him take it off. A Troll is kicking your *ss? Trick him into charging towards you and watch as he falls off a cliff. Gryphon about to take off? Grab onto it as it does and force him to land. And I haven't even mentioned the regular enemies. With so many options and ways to approach fights, rather than becoming a chore or something you dread having to do, combat is the meat and bones of the game. It's so, soooo f*cking good.

Play this game, seriously. If you can power through the lackluster early game, you'll find a diamond in the rough like no other. There's still a lot of things that could be improved, but the things that it does well, it does them really well. This game came out in 2012, and no one has learned anything from it, and that's a crying shame, because Dragon's Dogma is some of the most fun i've ever had with a combat system in an RPG.
Well, it feels pretty bad at the beginning in 2023 but you're getting used to it and the more powerful you become, the more fun you get. Also, the lore is good anyways.

TLDR; very fun RPG with an interesting AI system that can be abused from maximum enjoyment. Fast travelling essentially doesn't exist until the start of mid-game and is plagued with possibly the worst stamina bar ever. Dated UI and odd design choices for a few of the systems. Coupled with amazing combat and engaging enemies, it's an 8/10.

~

This game has so many things wrong with it. Funky fast-travelling system, an affection/romance meter that's odd at best and wildly jank at worst, possibly the most awful stamina bar I've seen in any real time RPG. Despite all this, Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen sits comfortably in my top 10 games of all time, all thanks to it's innovative combat, unique pawn system and a diverse set of enemies that will test your skills.

The gimmick that separates this game from other similar RPG's is the pawn system. A pawn is a companion that you create and will follow you, watching your every move and studying certain parts of the map. If the pawn notices you climbing onto a chimera's tail and smacking the ever living f*ck out of it, it will slowly start doing the same. At first, it's a little clumsy. However, keep doing it and with the proper gear and knowledge, your pawn could potentially take down dangerous enemy all on its own thanks to your teaching.

This game also has an online function. You can employ other people's pawn and view their entire kit, down to the rings they wear and skills they've equipped. You can also see how well they can take on specific enemy types, what area's they've fully explored and see what quests they've done. It's honestly a fun past-time to just go through other people's pawns and wonder who they came to that build. You can also witness how they operate in battle and if they take down an enemy in a way your pawn hasn't seen before, they'll learn from it and adapt it into their own playstyle.

Of course, the system isn't without its flaws. Sometimes, it'll follow your bad habits and spam a move that it really shouldn't, making the fight drag out more. With this system, your pawn can turn into a beast slayer, cooperating with your every move to take down enemies swiftly and efficiently. However, if the sysstem doesn't seem to work out with you of you can't be bothered working with it, you get... a normal companion like in any other RPG that has varying degrees of usefulness. The system, honestly, is just a win-win scenario in my eyes.

Very fun game. An interesting story (though nothing groundbreaking) with amusing plot twists, deeply satisfying combat and a fun system with your AI companion that can be min-maxed for your own enjoyment. Very solid 8/10.

~

Dragon's Dogma Darkness Arising in 2023 is a decent game other than a serious issue with it's save system, in a nutshell IT SUCKS! When you go to the game save location (Steam Library Folder> your user data (a number)>367500>remote> DDDA.sav) you'll see after playing around, you can do multiple saves during the game, but they all write to the current game save, in other words you wipe out everything before it for your current play session. This becomes a freaking bad issue when the game freezes during a save and the current save ends up corrupted, Then you are just out of luck for today's play session, there is no backup of current progress. 

You can see in the save folder there is one or more backup saves, but they will be for previous play sessions.  For myself after spending 2 hours in the game, I ended up with the game freezing, a bad save, the game now won't even start based on last current save, and when I looked in the save folder, the last save in there is at the end of my last play session.  This is not the first time I have lost large amounts of game play time and ended up having to repeat. 

Now there is DDDA Save Game mod available at Nexus mods. It is in fact an .exe, I have it running and it does not do what it is supposed to do. It's supposed to make a copy of every save you create-Nope. It infrequently makes a save., so instead creating a save for every time I told the game to save, the most recent save showing is from the end of my last play session, not any better than the game. 

Based on this, at this point, after being ready to quit, I decided  to try to make this work. Now after every significant point in the story, I select “save and continue”, tab out of the game, go to the save game folder and make a copy of the current save so I have sequential saves of it.  This is more work than you should have to do, but as I said the game is decent and I’ll cross my fingers this works adequately.

28Feb23 review update- My scheme of keeping my own backups has improved my experience a lot, and I can now recommend the game, combat is fun, I started as a fighter, but I'm not yet clear on cross training to other classes. So far just as a fighter, things are going well.

Hands down the best RPG EVER made. I play this game all the time even though it released back in 2013. There is just NOTHING like it. The classes in this game are so fun, No cap... I have fought a dragon in this game for 7 in game days straight and lost, and still had the most FUN I have EVER had in a video game. And that is just one instants. Taking down Chimeras by chopping off the tail, killing the goat, then bussing the lion in the face NEVER gets old. The game is chalked FULL of those types of encounters. If you like complete freedom over customizing your toon (I'm talking butt cheeks out pun intended); this game is for you. If you like dungeoneering with jump scares in the darkness. If you like being able to literally jump on, climb up and beat down huge monsters with just basic attacks, so thrilling!!! Monster Hunter, Elden Ring, Skyrim, Fallouts and quite simply any other game that has came out after it cant compete period... Seriously this is the game ALL action RPG games should be copying, NOT SOULS LIKES... There are mechanics in this game that never get mentioned or talked about because there are too many to state. You need to play it to appreciate all of them... And the Online game that just shut down should totally be picked up for the US. Now this is an MMO I would spring for a monthly sub if they would bring the ALCHEMIST class. If you think I'm lying just watch Steparu's Dragon's Dogma Onlines videos of his gameplay and tell me if you don't agree!!! Dragon's Dogma is not a hidden gem it is THE HIDDEN GEM of all video games...

I dont like this game i really dont.
at first glance it seems to offer everything i wished from a medieval fantasy rpg but it just annoys the hell out of me.
You see im constantly looking for games where i can swing a huge ass sword just like the guy from the hit chinese anime show berserkman (rip eiichiro oda) heck they even added armors from said cartoon
But meele fighting in this game just sucks ass. fighting small stuff like humans and goblins is ok but combat with big enemies as a warrior is just boring as shit, you either climb on them and punch them in their faces (which is by far the most effective but boring way) or punch their legs which might just be as effective as taking a piss on them.

the last boss of dark arisen for example is probably the most boring fight in the game as a warrior, just take look at it if you want [spoiler] https://youtu.be/W__uLPutbh4 [/spoiler] your personal experience fighting that guy as a warrior will most likely not differ much. (i cant explain the silly jump spamming in the 2nd phase its really not needed, just climb)
And the game is completely unbalanced, im not even saying its too hard (trust me it isnt) it feels like there is no middle ground between dealing basically zero damage and popping a damage buff item and killing every boss in less than a minute.

And then there are wolves... wolves exist in this game only too annoy the player nothing more. They deal barely any damage and dont have much health BUT they can grab your fucking leg and drag you which is just annoying enough too make me feel like removing every canine on this world from existence. (they can also spawn right next to you) 
The sentence "Wolves hunt in packs arisen" which you have probably already red multiple times in various exhentai comment sections will be engraved in your mind for the rest off eternity if you wont disable pawn commentary. (there is a similar line about goblins)

Also pawns (your followers) are introduced as beings lacking emotions and willpower which makes them the second most boring thing you could have as a follower in a game next to stones. Luckily capcom added a variety of cliffs you can use to remove pawns from your party in case they annoy you as much as me or you simply fear the touch of men like the protagonist from aforementioned chinese cartoon.

Then again i hear people say that the magic combat is really good in this game but sadly im not a girl

I never wrote this review, but when Hogwarts Legacy came out, it made me stop and think about this game. I had it on both the PS3 and PC, and it's by far one of the best of its kind. The character creation alone was and still is the pinnacle of customization. The gameplay featuring some character action mechanics was also nothing to sneeze at. I absolutely loved this medieval Monster Hunter back in the day, and every so often, I go back and play it. It doesn't even force you to concern yourself with character building really, because whatever class you play, it automatically starts optimizing for what that class is best at.

The only problem was the world didn't have enough to do in it and the pacing can be slow at times, but that's what people also said about red dead 2.

Climbing on monsters, and yes dragons too, was the most exhilarating part of the game, and the fact that character customization mattered to it was enough to make me play it so many damn times. Not too long, not too short either.
This is the game that make me love the fantasy adventure genre!
UI is clunky as F. WASD is quaint but outdated. Just not worth the time to learn.

Amazing game!! Was sceptical at first for trying a game I somehow missed years back, but boy was addicted soon after. This is game, if you are into RPG's, you have to play at least once in your lifetime. Very well made game for its time and still way better combat mechanics than most the RPG's I can think of.

This game is nothing but frustration. UI is teribble, and the game holds your hand in wrong areas. Your companion guides you to the inn to speak with the innkeeper for specific quest, but doesn't tell you that you can get side quests from the notice board of the inn. So I've missed a lot of quests, only to figure out that I could get them early on and finish them while I was gathering some stuff just outside the town. But since main story gives you some fetch quests, I was already feeling bored of the area, and I couldn't bring myself to get those quests and complete them. The thing I'm getting mad at, you either hold your players hand or don't. If you do something between, all you do is misleading the player. If the game wasn't holding my hand from the start, I'd go in and out of every building, speak with every npc, check out everything before I left the town, but since it was holding my hand, I've tought that the game would've told me if there was something doable there. I wouldn't mind starting over, since my progress is not much. But I guess, I didn't like the game enough to bring myself to start over, especially with the terrible UI.

I loved this game until Joseph Anderson tore it apart. Then again what game doesn't he do that too?
Jokes aside, Dragon's Dogma is...well, you'll love it or you'll hate it. Or both. There's a special place in my heart for DD that I absolutely love the game, but just as much I don't think I can stomach playing through it all again. I played the pre Dark Arisen version on console before purchasing this on Steam and was completely entranced by the experience. At the time (and maybe now), no other game gives a similar experience. And that's both good and bad.
To start with, combat. You're given a few options of your starting build to choose from and it really boils down to magic, melee, or missile. And which of these you choose is going to be how much you enjoy the game. Later you are given further options, which boils down to pairing two of those three options. Along with your pawn (an assisting NPC that you create) and what companion pawns you choose (you are able to add two pawns to your party that are from other players or pre-built characters from the game). Combat has a heft to it. I enjoy playing heavy melee characters in these sort of games and this was no exception. Striking enemies causes a momentary slow in the action, emphasizing the hit. You can cling onto larger enemies and crawl around on them, not unlike Shadow of the Colossus, and attack them. You can focus on key points of some enemies. Such as the legs of larger enemies to make them fall down or striking the tail of other enemies that makes them lose focus for combat and a bonus item to gather from them.
Battles can be very unforgiving, as can the rest of the world. You can stumble into areas that you're not ready for. Large enemies can roam around the map and attack you when you're not ready and under leveled. Day is more merciful than night, which you're warned about many times to consider sleeping until day. And the plot of the game revolves around a cold and uncaring nature for you and the rest of humanity as well.
The world has a certain quality to it that consistently feels old world and harsh. Characters largely speak in a dignified English and many have a haughty attitude befitting someone who has survived and done well in such a world. Other characters stand out well in their delivery and behavior. And there are a range of secrets and interconnected dialogues based on your decisions. You CAN miss quests easily in this game. Whether through starting a certain quest that continues the story and leaves behind what you missed or choosing wrong or through simply taking too long to get to it. And sometimes you have to actually think about your actions and do them. Mass Effect style of declaring everything you do before you are locked in and have to do it, this is not. And that all adds to a bit of realism and believable to the world. You're not the only one in it and others take their own actions, whether you are involved or not. 
Sadly the plot isn't as deep and enticing as it could be. It starts out well, giving you a reason to take your actions. But as you go along, you start to question a lot of the motivation and reasons behind what you're doing. There's also a few points in the game that are just...they make no sense. You'll also end up backtracking to old locations a couple of times, sometimes RIGHT AFTER you just got back from that location. It's like the developers forgot they used that location a moment ago and were ready to get it going again. 
There's a lot of variety locations, however. As much as the map makes it seem like the game world is huge, it's actually pretty restrictive. There's a good bit to explore and the world contains a lot of small secrets and tricks along the way, but mountains and other restrictions will keep you from a large portion of what the map seems to promise. 
A wide variety of enemies is also present and the way they fight is also varied. This is one of the best features of the game, especially in the enemies that you can climb on. From darting wolves to bandits that fight based on their own class to skeletons that shamble forward slowly, however don't stumble easily, you'll have to change how you respond to these situations. There's a lot of preset traps and ambushes as well. Which at first is a delight, however it wears off a bit after that first time.
I recommend the game, but consider it hasn't aged as gracefully as it could have. The various mechanics are antiquated compared to modern games in many ways, but holds a particular charm if you let yourself get caught up in it. The graphics and environments however, are still beautiful and pleasant to experience. That said, I strongly recommend waiting on a deep sale. Especially considering the game was released over a decade ago (2012) as of this writing.

"They're masterworks, all. You can't go wrong" - Caxton
It was dope, so many choices of play style, you can switch classes as you go, lots of gear to pick up and your choices matter. The main game story line isn't overwhelmingly long so you can play it little bits at a time or you can do all the side quests and all the side stories and play all day. The Dark Arisen part of the game is like one big maze dungeon with the best gear and strongest bosses, you can go into it pretty early on (if you like challenges) or right before you finish the game. (If you want to check out Bitterblack and waited till the end, go to it before the last jump down the Everfall after you collect the wakestones) Bitterblack has it's own little story based on  writings you find while exploring, but it's not crucial to the main story.  You can play this game like a hack and slash or you can customize your move set gear and augments to min max; it's cool that you get to choose how complex you want your character to be. After you beat the game you can load your save and the game will let you keep all the gear that was in storage, on your character and on your pawn, in-case you want to start off well equipped on a replay. Try the parkour! Farm xp! Make a Waifu pawn that goes with you everywhere! When you have to make a choice let the npcs die! Idk play it however you want, but it's definitely worth a play-through for you if you are still reading this far.

I really WANT to like the game.   In spite of the incredibly awkward PC port - especially with respect to inventory, buying and selling, sharing with other party members, etc, all of which is seriously clunky as hell - it still was holding my interest.  The character customization is good, the world seems decently deep and the story got my interest.  

But it's unplayably buggy.  At this point, my main character is literally stuck in the middle of the road unable to - the movement keys are doing nothing.  I've had nothing but trouble with movement since I started playing, but I was limping along with it, but I'm stumped as to how to fix this.

You will find fun, but also frustration.
There are times the game may pull hilarious, buggy, WTF moments from out of nowhere.

I got into a rough fight against a troll in a chamber. Unleashing his supercharge, he luckily missed me and my group. Fell off the floor level and ended up plummeting to his death. Gained +5000 exp points as I stared down below in disbelief, trying to process what just happened. (Not complaining though. He was tough.)

All jokes aside, this fantasy game is very challenging with it's Dark Soul styled difficulties and also has some great character customisation.

It's really worth it to wander for hours  through this "lifeless desert"  to find some challenge, loot and puzzles. And hey, CAPCOM :D, if you read this for some reason.. I am reviewing every game in my library and this is the 45th game. I have to come strong out of the gate with this one and call it a hidden gem. Personally I barely hear anyone talk about this game and I think more should. 

When I always see this game I feel like I played it just last year but in reality this game has stuck with me since 2016 which is a good while at this point. But even back then I never heard of this game, I think I literally just stumbled upon on steam and was like "the heck this looks cool af!" and bought the game, one of the best purchases I had made. 

The gameplay is great and smooth. You are the cliche "hero/chosen one" protagonist and have to save the world thus you get bunch of cool powers. Firstly you got the weapons, weapons are based on your class (which are called vocations in this game), so if you pick the base fighter class you go with sword and shield then you gotta spec into the warrior class to get a two-handed sword. So you basically have your standard Warrior rogue and mage classes. BUT here is a lovely twist I LOVE with this game. You can mix classes, so you can mix a warrior and a rogue and you get something different, mix archer and mage and you get something different, mix warrior and mage you get a mystic knight. Or you can choose to stick with whatever base class you had, so a mage goes to sorcerer or fighter to warrior. A lot of class choice and you can respec into anything you want to a lot of freedom in gameplay style.

But more on the gameplay and less on the classes. You basically got light attacks, you can jump and attack and you can grab stuff. Yes you can grab stuff. Meaning you can grapple an enemy for an ally to hit it, you can throw a barrel, if there is a huge monster you can jump on it and climb it to cut of a specific part or do damage to its head. It's super fun. Then you have a set amount of abilities you learn and can cast. So all in all the gameplay is very interactive and gives you lots of options. 

Now I mentioned allies before. In this game as I said you are the chosen one. As the chosen you have something called "Pawns". Pawns are a great mechanic in this game and serve as companions, you can have up to 3 of them for a full party of 4. And you get to create your own Pawn while later hiring other pawns from a "pawn library" where they get preset classes and armor. But you can change everyone armor. 

Secondly the world is great, it might feel somewhat empty at times in my opinion but in general it is very dense and populated. I feel like I come across some scary monster or a group of enemies here and there and wonder why they are there. It peaks my exploration when I'm going to a quest. 

Story wise the game is fine, nothing great nothing bad but I always enjoyed the cliche sort of storytelling. 

The biggest crux I have with this game is that it has aged a lot. UI is rough at times and quite clunky, takes some time to get used to and the game itself doesn't look the best. You probably gotta download some mods to smoothen the experience or at least smoothen the graphics. But if you don't mind dookie graphics then all you gotta do is get used to the UI. 

Ultimately I gotta recommend this game. It's wonderful, I've beat it a few times and had many playthroughs trying out all the classes and different combinations you can pull off. Go grab this game and have a good time!
