It’s difficult to reach a verdict about Dragon’s Dogma: Dark arisen. The fiction of the story is overdone  and the voice acting is mediocre. Most of the quests are boring. But combat and exploration are good; frequent and stylized fighting is similar to other third-person Capcom games and its fun. It succeeds in some important aspects of the genre interestingly so i had a good time while playing this game, despite of its flaws. Still, If you're looking for outstanding gameplay or graphics, this is not the game youre looking for.

Let's get one thing out of the way first: this is a really fun hack and slash action game about big, cinematic boss battles with some unique but occasionally baffling mechanics pretending to be an open world RPG. Basically everything that isn't directly related to combat ranges from mediocre to awful, but luckily, you spend most of your time stabbing things in the face, and almost everything that isn't related to combat is just an excuse to get you into combat so you can stab more things in the face.

The setting is incredibly generic and lifeless, the plot has exactly one moment of greatness that it immediately does it's damnedest to spit upon and remove any sense of accomplishment from, the characters are as deep as a puddle, and the art design and voice acting are pretty meh, but I kept coming back to it anyways, because the things it does well are just so damn fun. 

So what *does* this game that misses the mark on virtually every hallmark of a good open-world RPG do well?

-Combat is a perfect balance of tactics and satisfying, brainless obliteration of cannon fodder enemies. Difficulty feels right for the vast majority of the game, the animations are smooth and satisfying, and there's a wide array of skills, with almost none of them feeling like total wastes (at least as far as the player character is concerned--there are some skills pawns just generally suck at using effectively).

-Speaking of, pawns are fun. At the start of the game, you get to create a companion character to accompany you on your journey, who will gain class levels and abilities alongside you. Furthermore, to round out your party, you recruit two other pawns, with the option to use player made pawns. It's fun to see what sort of characters other people are adventuring with, and it adds a little more intimacy than simply playing with a variety of generic companion characters would've, and it also gives you the option of taking some rather silly characters on an epic fantasy adventure (I happened to defeat the main antagonist with Hatsune Miku in my party and I'm still cracking up about it).

-Pawn AI and tactics can be surprisingly awesome, it really just depends on the inclinations and knowledge levels of the pawns in your party. For the most part, the AI is competent, and while it can be hard to find pawns that work well together, when you do, it can actually be really shocking how smart the AI is, especially in boss battles. I've seen my pawns execute complex, 3-person tactical maneuvers to devastating effect, and even had my life saved by a pawn catching me at the last second when I was falling off a flying boss on more than a few occasions. The moments of brilliance aren't super common, but they're always satisfying. They also learn from your playstyle, and it can be really fun to watch them pull of your own maneuvers. I utilized jumping attacks a lot, and sure enough, my main pawn soon started seeking out high ground and leaping down onto enemies.

-Boss fights are great, especially the first go round. Each one feels unique (excluding a few, more difficult, reskins towards the end of the game), and requires its own unique set of tactics, and the scale of some bosses is really epic. They aren't terribly hard once you know what you're doing, and a few of the more common bosses may start to feel like a chore, but they generally remain quite fun and exciting through most of the game.

-Adding to this, the boss battle music is great.

-There's a Shadow of the Colossus style climbing feature for bosses, and while it's clunky, it still adds a lot and opens up a lot of new tactics. 

-Magic feels awesome and deservedly powerful. The effects are very well done, and it opens a lot of utility.

-The character creator is really solid, and height, weight and sex of your character all affect their abilities in minor but impactful ways, which is a little bit gimmicky but still fun. It also leads to moments of hilarity. I will never forget my poor, scrawny main pawn literally blowing away in a gentle breeze. 

-The game runs quickly and stably, especially for a console port. It's a shame the UI wasn't adjusted for PC, because it's clunky and tedious as is, and the textures aren't amazing, even for its age, but all in all, it's a very good port.

-The dragon is great, as both a character (dare I say, he's the only well-written character) and as a boss fight.

-A lot of the things that it does poorly are at least funny. Accept this game as a really goofy medieval fantasy experience with fun combat and you'll have a good time.
One of the best games ive played

The combat in Dragon's Dogma is among the best of all fantasy RPGs I've played with an amazing breadth of options to approach encounters and spec your character. Battles with giant monsters feel epic thanks to the ability to climb and attack different parts of their body and above all, the combat isn't afraid to let you have fun with wacky strategies.

Unfortunately, whilst the story isn't awful, I don't feel like it is told particularly well, and it ends just as it starts to get interesting. Characters are also all a bit flat with generally mediocre voice acting so it's hard to form any sort of connection with them. Most quests are also quite boring other than the main quests, and characters seem to just teleport around for plot convenience which is quite immersion breaking.

Conversely, the background music is quite good and the combat tracks can pop off, mixing electric guitars and choirs. It fits the tone and the few vocal tracks can be quite chilling. The map is also a decent size, but can look a bit samey and doesn't feel very rewarding to explore, though I do like how it is hidden before you explore it much like Elden Ring. I will add to this that I think the graphics aren't great for a game from 2012, but that's not a major issue.

I think the character creator is quite good, you can have a very unique look and things like your height and weight affect gameplay. There are also other cool gameplay systems here that most RPGs don't have, like the monster climbing, pawns and item combining, but also things missing that would have been appreciated, like a mount or artisan skills.

I had a few issues with cutscenes freezing and CTDs, which were quite frustrating as I missed key story parts, but they didn't occur too often.

Overall, Dragon's Dogma definitely shows it age in some areas, but is 100% still worth playing today.

Absolutely brilliant game. I bought this on Steam after having played it on the Switch a few years ago, and I forgot how excellent the gameplay is, despite the game's age. RPGs can have systems that are overbearing or outshine the others, but I feel that the class system, the inventory management, the combat, the level design, and the enemy/boss encounters are all well balanced among each other. Oh, and it's fun. It's not a walking simulator.

While I didn't actually enjoy playing this game, I feel like it did wonders for my gaming skills and opened doors to enjoying many other games. Before playing Dragon's Dogma I was mostly only comfortable with Skyrim-style button-mashing combat or styles that allowed me to pause and think about what I was doing. Dragon's Dogma actively encourages you to try out a wide variety of skills and abilities, and it introduces things at a nicely gradual pace so that you have time to learn them thoroughly before moving on to the next thing. It also made me much more comfortable with fighting huge bosses.

That being said, once I tried out all the builds I had any interest in I stopped, and I'm usually someone who plays games for the story in a fairly completionist way. But the limited fast travel and inability to wait/rest through the night got old, and the story, characters, and lore weren't interesting enough to make up for it. It was a good learning experience, but I probably wouldn't play it if I was already comfortable with, say, Dark Souls combat.

This game is truly a gem. A lot of brilliant ideas coming together and pouring into one game : Dragons Dogma.

It took me nearly 80 Hours to beat it, and i am sure i really enjoyed nearly evey minute of it. This game knows how to be fun while giving you a lot of things to do. And i never did those same boring side quests. 80 Hours is really a good time for a game like this. And i am sure that i will play more because there is 9 classes in the game and every one of them is unique. All different skills, passive skills,builds, armors,weapons,animations... And i only fully discovered 3 of them. Story is nice but the storytelling is not great. It doesn't matter that much in my opinion in the endgame. Because final is really bittersweet. I will not forget the ending for a long, long time. Truly remarkable. Enemy variations are the first place of its kind. I've never remember a game like this to have all those different kinds of enemies. Each of them needs different tactics. I am really sucked in Dragon's Dogma's world. It feels so natural that all of things i've ever witnessed. And the pawn system. So original and magnificent. What would be more fun to build one character ? Build two characters at the same time of course :) Pawn's AI System is nice too. Not the best but nice. I remember some times that they just decide to jump off a cliff. But they did great in fights. As a programmer i know that Knowledge system need some really big effort and efficent programming. Knowledge system is when your pawn,or a pawn in your party fights and beats a monster, they learen what that monster is vulnarable and not for the next fights. Training your pawn is really important. And i want to say that animations and the all visual effects are really great too. Lighing looks great. When your sword got a fire buff and it shines on a dark dungeon it feels like i am about to kill a god. This game should be a book : How to make a GREAT RPG.

Positive : 
+ Enemy variations and all of the different attacks. It is a real challenge. It feels like i am really living in this world.
+ All Classes,builds and weapons. So much to try and all of them promises fun.
+Pawns and Pawn system
+Different places
+ Mount and climb mechanics. There is just so much ways to kill a boss.
+Bitterblack Island is a perfect DLC for this game. It is really challenging, adds tons of weapons and armor,a short cute story, and badass new places. Bosses too.
+When i hit an enemy, i know that i hit him real hard. Strike feeling is great,even if you play an archer or a sorcerer. Opposite of Skyrim.
+Different weaknesses of all bosses makes all one of them unique fights.
+A couple of soundtracks are great. I will listen to them after i stop playing.

Negative :
- Story would've been a little bit better. Especially the storytelling.
- Sometimes you just run,run,run and run. No shortcuts. It takes time and boring.

Aaaand Dragons Dogma 2 is on the way bois :) I can't wait. Dragons Dogma is already one of the best RPG's ever made. It has the chance to be better then even Elden Ring. Thank you Capcom for giving us this masterpiece and thank you again for making a sequel.

Final Point: 92/100. If you love RPG's or not, it doesn't matter. You got to play this game before you grow old and die.

Best RPG game I've played since Skyrim. Heck it might be better than it if it was a bit more polished and modable. I played the game with mods to make it more playable and focused more on the fun parts of the game rather than the awkward parts of it. It's safe to say it has made my experience really good. 

I didn't have to worry about stamina, inventory space, and all the other annoying stuff. 
It didn't take away anything from the game, instead I feel like it added more to it since I was able to focus on the fun parts. 

Here's hoping DD2 will be better than ever, a more modern style of gameplay (maybe similar but not the same as MHW?) who knows, I'm excited!

DD = Base game Dragon's Dogma
BBI = Dark Arisen DLC, BitterBlack Isle

Forewarning: lots of criticism and debatable complaining

This game is a very good JRPG but it's also a very flawed game. This is a pretty good representation of a game that takes a classic fantasy setting and does a lot with it. More often than not the negatives outweigh the good but ultimately I do recommend this game, with great caution. 

The story is... debatable in its quality. The gist is that a dragon attacks your village, you foolishly try to fight back, and then it steals your heart. Now you have to get your heart back and also there's a bunch of soulless minions at your adventurous whims. This game takes a big influence from classic fantasy and uses many recognisable monsters to great effect. Supposedly, this game was not even *near* to what the vision of it was. The number I've seen of how much of the final product we got bounces around 40% but this game is visibly lacking in many areas. The story is very short and you can easily beat the game in 8~ hours, not including Dark Arisen, but that's a whole other beast. Near the halfway point, you can see how the story just cuts straight to "okay cool let's kill the dragon" and it's a little disappointing.

Fortunately, the gameplay is really good. The best way I can explain it is that it's a mix between Dark Souls and Monster Hunter, and I've only played one of those games. That's the short of it. It does have its issues, however. 

-It's a JRPG so naturally it's very grindy and there's some min-maxing that occurs with the stat growth system(not enough word count to explain it here). It also takes *forever* max out every vocation and its skills. 

-This game has some cool knockdown / critical hit point mechanics and it's a lot of fun to see an enemy get knocked on its ass.

-There's a lot of debilitations(status effects) that provide a fair amount of strategic variety to the skills you can use and tactics you can use against your enemies.

-There's a TON of equipment in this game. This game, similarly to Dark Souls, has adopted a variety of names but I love the name "Fashion's Dogma". A lot of the equipment, especially when max upgraded, provides a variety of resistances so you can mix up your armour and it won't be a huge problem. A lot of this game is about avoiding being hit to begin with, so fashion it up GAMERS.

-A huge negative of this game's gameplay is that it is so tedious and, sometimes, difficult that results in a huge part of the "guide" community for this game suggesting that explicitly exploiting the game's systems and mechanics is part of the game itself, which I obviously disagree with. You do need to use several exploits to avoid stress and frustrations with how clunky and annoying 

-This game relies on crowd control and stun/lockdown *a lot*, to an un-fun extent. The base game itself isn't a huge issue as it's incredibly easy to just grind past the difficulty curves but BBI is  a pretty big outlier of this entire game and there's a lot of discussion of when and how you're supposed to tackle BBI. 

-Without going to in-depth because this is a huge issue with the game that I can't fit into this review, the pawns in this game are badly implemented. Their AI is beyond bad and in my experience they contribute very little if they're any class other than fighter or mage/sorcerer, but even then fighters seem to do nothing half the time. I've had many situations where pawns will stand around doing nothing or will stand within spell zones and just die because they lack the proper AI to avoid attacks and have any kind of self preservation.

-Final point, connecting with the last point, this game does not have a lot of counters to many abilities / enemies and lacks damage mitigation for most classes. There are i-frames but they are limited to assassin, fighter, and dagger skills. It basically boils down to: Don't get hit and if you do you die and that's your fault. This is, of course, stupid. To keep to my relatively short point-by-point system here, I'll explain it later in regards to BBI, but this game has severe balancing issues.

So... BBI. It's honestly the only real reason to play this game in my opinion and it's pretty much the only part of the game where I get genuine satisfaction and enjoyment out of coming from an experienced player's point of view. It's the DLC of DD and it is seemingly up in the air as to whether not it's the bad part of DD or the good part. I personally think it's good but it's very clear it's not balanced in regards to DD nor a single playthrough. There's guides that will tell you how to get to max level and beat BBI within 8~ hours but that's... insane. It completely removes the actual gameplay loops and twists you have to jump through in the process of playing the game. It's like playing a Final Fantasy game and just cheating in max level, all items, skills, etc. It removes the whole point of the game itself.

I can narrow my many many many issues with BBI down to 3: The dragons, Death,  and Daimon(the final boss). A bonus is I'll complain about the overall balancing and abilities you'd otherwise not see in DD.

The dragons: The dragons are fantastic in this game and they're fun to fight but BBI's suck. Translation: DD's dragon spawns are very few. There's 1 single dragon before the post-game segments in which there is... 3. Not many. BBI has *many* dragon spawns and they are absurdly strong to boot. There's stronger variations of the three dragons(Drake, Wyrm, Wyvern) and the Cursed Dragon. Ironically enough, the Cursed Dragon, who is the big spooky one, is the weakest of the bunch but it can only be damaged via hitting its heart. All the other dragons either deal absurd amounts physical damage, magic damage, or just throw you all over the place. I played the game on PS4 as well and usually Wyverns would just spam maelstrom but in this version, it seems they don't do it anymore. Fire drakes just spam tail spin(which can 1-2HKO easily) and arm grab(same deal), and the Wyrm either spams comets or lightning bolts which, again, easily 1-2HKO you. The Cursed Dragon just kind of sucks. So, yeah, they kind of suck and you'll encounter several of them, They really mess up the flow of BBI.

Death: Death is the "secret" boss of BBI. To cut straight to it, the biggest issue with him is that he's resistant to essentially every attack because of his ridiculously high defence and magic defence. I wouldn't have an issue with this if he didn't lack an actual weak spot and wasn't the one single enemy in the game that can only be defeated explicitly with exploits. He's is THE speed-levelling exploitable enemy. He also has a scythe that insta-kills which goes back to the whole "pawns don't know how to avoid attacks" issue. The pawns are basically just fodder for Death, and often times Death disappears after getting at least 1 kill, so the whole encounter just doesn't work unless you're willing to follow a guide step-by-step to get... very little for your efforts.

Daimon: He's the final boss for BBI. He has two phases. The first phase is accessed via a single run through of the dungeon, and the second phase occurs when you run through the dungeon to fight him again, and all continuous fights have 2 phases. Altogether, you probably go through like, what, 20 health bars with 2 phases? He's not a bad boss but again, consistent issue with BBI. It's not balanced for what DD is. 

The bonus: A lot of enemy abilities in BBI are abilities that 1HKO e.g. Great Gamble, Seism, Maelstrom. The overall balancing is off the rails for BBI, ranging from 1HKOs to huge defence values on enemies(meaning you need to grind to do any damage).

I really enjoy this game. It's very unique, it's fun, and it's also incredibly grindy and tedious. Do I recommend it? Yeah, sure, maybe. Just be cautious that there's a lot of bullshit and outrageously bad balancing, resulting in some crazy difficulty curves.

I came back to this game on Switch recently and basically did everything (80 hours or so) including the fantastic DLC endgame which I wish more games would do these days. Across both platforms I have concluded this game belongs in the list of best fantasy rpgs of all time and had sooooo many unique ideas that were ahead of it's time or still unique to this game. The combat itself is basically still untouched (besides maybe monster hunter) as you can climb all over massive beasts while they fly up into the air and create some really weird but cool class combinations. 

The online component to this game had massive potential and was one of the features ahead of it's time as it let you heavily customise your companions build/looks and share them online for others to hire and use in their game (and vice versa). You get rewards if someone likes your companion and keeps them long term and even has a rating system when finished and option to give the host a gift. The game itself is likely considered open world but it isn't generic far cry locations they are mostly unique and have rewards for exploring. A sequel was finally announced for this game and I am beyond excited with the possibilities as DD is truly a unique game that sticks in my mind despite what some consider minor flaws but was near perfect for me.

PS a TON of great stuff and sections of the map are optional so if you wan't to experience most of the game do the side quests (not including sign post quests they are mostly filler) as it will take you to some great locations and get some unique loot. Lastly when you finish the game there is an expansion location called bitterback isle as end game and it's massive and worth playing if you want more to do. Highly recommend DD as it's often dirt cheap on sale on all platforms also!

Brand new to this game and I never heard of it because this game came out when I was still in elementary school but guys let me tell you. Words cannot describe the journey this game has taken me on and I still haven't even completed it yet. It's a bit aged and you can tell in the graphics but I promise you the gameplay will make you forget all about that.

This game is boring for the first little bit. It feels directionless most times and you will wind up running, running out of stamina, stopped to catch breath, then running some more only to find out you have caught the eye of a superior beast who will absolutely kill you and reset you to the last checkpoint. The first few times I tried to get into this game this was my experience and it caused me to bounce off. The first 3 hours of the game are unbearably slow, and this is around the time you will begin to notice if you chose the right starting class. Pro tip: you can kick the ox to make it move faster, just remember it can die. There is hope for those of you who are at that point and realising you  wanna do more than what you currently can with the class you have. The first class you choose will not prevent you from beating the game at all. The problems with not building a streamline character come once you beat the game and want to do all the juicy New Game + grinding and levelling. No need to restart if things are not working for you, new vocations come soon after the first couple tutorial missions. 

I just beat the game at around level 65 or so. It can be done sooner though. Took me around 70 hours or so to get to NG+.

The story is goofy fantasy and serves it purpose, but honestly go look up a few  guide videos and at the wiki from time to time if you are confused as to what to do next. Its open ended and wont hold your hand for what quests you need to do next. 

BIG WARNING! there are quests that can be failed and you can permanently lose rewards. Its worth using a guide to help with getting the most out of the game. Really the story is spoil-able and still fun, its not as bad as spoiling other games and its probably gonna let you see more of the game than you would just playing blind. There is a quest involving an NPC being put on trial. Once you accept the quest a timer will start, collect the evidence needed to acquit him or find him guilty, just dont have both types of evidence in your inventory if you want to save him. you have in game days to do it. 

Oh also you cant really reset your class levels so if you are wanting to make a min maxed perfect build then make sure to have a guide and understand what levels you need to take and when. 

This game is fun, but it isnt perfect. A solid 8/10.

I really tried to get through this game and enjoy it, since there are quite a few great things about it, but some design decisions completely ruin it for me. I find it really annoying that existing quests fail when you progress the main quest, there is no indication this will happen. The world isn't changing in a way where that area in inaccessible, so there's no reason to fail that quest.

It's super annoying to send everyone to Bitterblack Isle at the very start of the game. I had no idea it was endgame content, there is a marker on my map I can't get rid of and it starts from the home town. So I go there just to waste time and find out there is no way I can do that yet.

Having 1 save slot is brutal. I can't experiment with other things at the same time without completely deleting my main save. I'm fine with having 1 slot per character like Dark Souls, but literally 1 save slot sucks.

The pawn chatter is INCREDIBLY annoying but since they often state what the weakness is of what you are fighting it's detrimental to turn it off in the settings. They will overlap with each other like "They hunt in -" "They hate fire!" They hunt in packs they hate fire!"

Lastly the hidden character stats are also really annoying. There is no way to know that smaller body sizes have different stamina and stamina regeneration stats. I found out when reading the wiki that my combination of body and class makes no sense and is really suboptimal, but the game presents it as an aesthetic only choice.
Wish I could have played DDON, can't wait for for DD2.

I purchased this game for £3.83 and played 46 hours so I have to give it the thumbs up. I saw the 2016 date but didn't realise until I installed it that it was because of the dlc, and the original game is from 2012. Indeed it does look dated. Fortunately I found support for a 21:9 mode on my 32:9 monitor, although the map doesn't seem to work quite right.

Now I ought to like these games because I started to play D&D when the only video games were like space invaders and we had to go to an arcade to play them. But DD:DA is similar to the "dungeon hack and slash" style gaming that we started with before that got boring and we started to properly enjoy the "role playing" style. I soon got bored of the quests which just involved killing and collecting and stuck to the main story which was not the best. It is also badly balanced. At least in the witcher games it gives you a clue about when you'll be powerful enough for a quest. In DD:DA go to the wrong place and death is certain. I admit that I used WeMod to make sure that I survived so that I could follow the story and complete the game - without it I would certainly have given up.

Dragons Dogma is so freaking fun. 
Wanna stab a cyclops in the eye? You got it.
Wanna grab a giant bird by the tail and fly in the air? You can do it.
Do you want to be the literal God of the game? You sure can.
The open world is very diverse and definitely not B-lined. The graphics are there, the combat is fluid, controls on keyboard and controller feel natural. Best thing about this game is how big it is. It's quite literally on the scale of Skyrim, or Oblivion size.
Give Dragons Dogma a chance and be a badass.

Honestly this is one of the best Fantasy games I have ever played. With little hand holding the game throws you into a world where quests are hard to follow, hard to find, sometimes limited in time to complete. It gets confusing at points, but multiple play throughs will see you through most of the quests. The combat is second to none, a variety of enemies to learn to take down, and some that look similiar but force you to learn whole new tactics. The Pawn system is interesting, once you learn to set their inclinations correctly for their class and once they learn tactics on particular enemies you will be golden. Only thing that would make them better is if the owners of your support pawns could jump in your game and take control of them.

All in all you cant go wrong buying this one. Capcom needs to reboot Breath of Fire and throw it in this engine but a bigger world and your main character as the dragon =) But other than that amazing game!

The game is pretty good! If you're a Dragon Age fan, this game is for you. Nice classes (called "vocations" in this game), which you can change during your gameplay. Some interesting NPCs and fun quests. Amazing soundtrack and voice acting (specially Mercede's, such a cute accent). The best part probably is the combat: it's just incredible. 

But it got its issues: I just HAD to install a mod in order to stop wasting stamina outside combat (running). The map is pretty big and the stamina gauge takes a long time to fill up. The game does not give you any kind of mount, so you must run A LOT in a HUGE map, so I almost given up the game and only keep playing due to this mod. 

Another annoying thing is about the quests that fail just because. There's no reason explained in the game as to why some quests do have a tiny window in order to complete them. 

But overall, a great game that deserves a remaster or a sequel. Kind of a lost gem, and it's worth a shot!

This gets a qualified thumbs up from me. My main problem is that the story is practically non-existent. You're given no motivation for playing the story missions.  Without spoilers, something was taken from you and you want to get it back. Why? You're doing just fine without it. People say there's a dragon threatening the land but you never see any signs that there's anything wrong. You may as well get on with your life the way you'd already planned it.

Only one class has any sort of lock-on ability for ranged attacks, and spells take a long time to build up power to cast. The starting armor is some of the best in the game. I finished with a few pieces of the starter gear because I never found anything better.  Your torso and legs have separate slots for "clothing" and "armor", but which is which seems completely arbitrary. Playing a female character I ran around half the game in my panties because the "clothing" slot was a set of thigh-high leather leggings and my "armor" slot was boots. I eventually found a pair of trousers that had stats only a little bit worse than my underpants, so I got to cover myself.

The "pawn" system rubs me the wrong way. Your party members are called "pawns". You get to customize one of them. You can borrow two more from other players. This is the extent of the online interaction, you trade your pawns around. (There's an offline mode where you hire randomly generated pawns instead.) Pawns look and act human, except they have no free will. This reeks of a last-minute rewrite when someone pointed out, "Um, guys? You know, passing your party members around to be used by other players seems a whole lot like slavery, or at least pimping." So they added a few lines about pawns having no free will and now it's all okay.  But for creatures with no free will there seem to be an awful lot of them wandering around the countryside unsupervised.

Despite all that, I still enjoyed it.  The combat flows nicely. The landscape is pretty. It's fun to plow into a horde of low-level goblins with your weapons set on "puree", and being able to climb up the large enemies to get at their weak spots feels appropriately heroic.  Get it on sale.

[h1] Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen (2016), 85/100 [/h1]

[i] - Tis a troubling foe! [/i]


[b] 10 HIGHLIGHTS [/b]

- Action RPG, dark fantasy, open world, epic boss battles, climb dragons and oxen alike, fashion dogma, git gud, incessant unsolicited advice, loot two eyes of one cyclops, dirt cheap.


[b] TO SUM UP... [/b]

- Really worth it. A fantastic and rewarding combat system sustains the game, a bit clumsy and rough around the edges, but nevertheless of epic scope, specially against big beasts. Varied, flashy and fun skills. Countless personalization options, weapons and armors for the discerning fashionista. Interesting pawn mechanics, but lacks control and information. Generic main and side quests, with an excellent soundtrack to round out the package.


[i] Played Build ID 2364871, January 2022, Windows 10, Lenovo Legion. [/i]

[i] - Stable: some texture and model bugs when fighting big beasts in small rooms, but nothing to worry about, more to laugh about. [/i]

I have 450+ hours in this game because like an addicted crack addict who keeps promising himself he's on the path to rehabilitation, I end up relapsing and running back to my crack dealer Hideaki Itsuno and his refined product as it fills such a beautiful niche that so few games do for me.

There is an announced sequel to this game and it has the potential to be an Action Combat RPG which redefines the entire genre. I love this game and think it can develop into a massively successful IP if the sequel lands well. I carry a strong belief alongside all my fellow arisen that Itsuno will deliver fantastically with the sequel - whenever it's ready to come out.

[b]As for who this game is for?[/b]

[b][u]Long story short:[/u][/b]
If you are looking for a game with captivating combat systems and lots of variety in skill choice and class selection, this game is for you. If you like the idea of climbing on top of massive enemies, gouging out their body parts as your companions rain hellfire and steel upon them (or stare in awe with their thumbs up their a**es, depending on the inclinations your pawns have), or perfect timing a parry and blinking behind a Hobgoblin and slicing his throat open, then this game is for you.
The spells in this game also make you feel like a god. Summoning meteors? Calling forth tornadoes? Yea, you can do that. And it's not a small a** tiny tornado either. It's a big boy.

[b][u]DON'T PLAY this game if:[/u][/b]
- You want a captivating, well written story (The story is really only truly refreshing and epic towards the very tail end)

- You want to explore a huge diverse world with a variety of locations and themes (The world  is decently large - but with one setting: generic european high fantasy forest/highlands)

- You want to experience fascinating quest structure and/or NPC interactions (There are some cool interactions - but i'd argue quests are typically far from unique or interesting in structure.)

[b][u]IN CONCLUSION[/u][/b]

There are a variety of other problems with the game and great things it offers, but it really comes down to if you want to experience a well made combat system with a variety of classes and custom-made/picked party members in the form of pawns.

You'll learn to find other aspects of the game to appreciate if the combat is enough to keep you interested.

It's almost always on sale and for like $5.00 its most CERTAINLY worth it. 5 bucks is like an extra large king sized Hershey's bar these days. I can eat that in like 30 minutes. 30 minutes of chocolate induced sickness, or potentially hundreds of hours of fun? Hmm, I'll let you decide.

10/10 experience personally, can't wait to see who Grigori chooses as my beloved in the end and why is it always Aldous.

Do i enjoy the game?
221.9 hrs on record. (cross 4 consoles, more like 800+)
59/59 achievements.
Owning it on 4 different consoles.
A bit.

Jokes aside, this game is Fan-Flipping-tastic!
Do i think it is Flawless? Gods no!
But even with it's flaws, you'll see that this game is a Gem that unfortunatly was highly under-appreciated, it went under almost everyones radar when it first came out, thankfully it has gotten a lot more well deserved praise over the years. (even a Netflix anime that i found out about Today, watching it after finishing this review)
Dragon's Dogma is a game whos story is not told upfront, they're not Explaning the story, YOU have to figure it out. Oh the npcs will talk about the lore of the world, sure sure. But they will Not do some dumb story exposition, you have to figure it out and puzzle it together yourself.

You CANNOT fully beat the game on your first playthrough (unless you know EXACTLY what to do, but then it's not your first playthrough, now is it?) Quests will fail, you might get annoyed, but do not worry, The game has a bit of a "hidden" New Game+ function, ones you have beaten the main story, you will unlock Hard Mode, and doing so will reset you back to the Start, with everything you had obtained previously (if you want you can change the difficulty back to Normal immediatly afterwards) also gives you a chanse to remake your Arise and Pawn, even change Gender if you see fit.

What makes Dragon's Dogma so appealing is, not just it's hidden story, but the combat itself, now, you might think that the attacks/skills are mediocer or basic...at first, then you realize, those 3 classes you chose from the start... that's not all the Classes, oh no, there are Many more, and you can change class as you see fit (aswell as making some epic builds by combining perks from other classes into your prefered class). But what i love with it's combat is that unlike the majority of games, if you fight a Massive 2-4 floored big monster, what do you do in 99% of games? you start attacking their toes...riveting.
In Dragon's Dogma however! if you use the Grapple button, you will start to CLIMB the bigger monsters, reach their weak spots, knock off Armor, or cut off limbs (on Chimeras, Hydras and Evil Eyes) So here you are fighting a Chimera, like in the Tutorial, a Chimera is a creature that is a combinating of a Lion's main upper body+head, a Goat growing out the back aswell as a goats lower body who uses Magic, and the Tail is a Snake that both spits Poison and can even grapple your party, if you keep slicing the Snake, you will cut it off, removing it's Poison abilities, if you keep attacking the Goat, it will lose it's Magic abilities, and if you kill the Lion then the goat will pretty much go insane, it does not prefer Mele combat so it will panic and jump all over the place.
But my favotire thing is when you are fighting a Gryphon! you grapple onto it as it takes flight, you climb up on it's back, you equip/unsheat your Flame weapon and start attacking, Setting it's Feathers ablaze, sending it crashing to the ground! (watch that Stamina tho)

The lore of the game's start is as following.
You, a regular normal Fisher from Cassardis is enjoying another peaceful day, when all of a sudden! a DRAGON attacks!
Everyone flees in terror, including the guards who were there recruiting (understandable) but You? Not you! you pick up a sword that one of the  guards dropped and you Run towards the dragon to fight it headon!... it does not go well and it knocks you on your ass, the Dragon (whos name i will not say, you'll have to figure that one out yourself, part of the story) deames you Worthy of being the new Arisen, so it says some words in the Dragon's Tounge and then pierces your chest with it's claw, stealing your heart!
But you do not die, just fall unnconsious, when you wake up, the Dragon speaks to you in your mind, the words he said in his own tounge ends with "if you wish to face me, take up arms, Newly Arisen" so you go to the table, pick a class out of 3 (again, don't worry, many to choose from later) and you are off to do your Arisen duty, and reclaim your heart!

The start of the game might feel slow, almost kinda boring? But it will ramp up soon after!
And when it comes to quests, you don't always have to follow what is said, if you know where to go (or by accident) to the location it Actually takes place, you can go there immediatly, like finding a secret meeting held by some conspirators in the  city, quest is telling you to talk to like 8 different people so you Figure out where to go, but you can just Go there immediatly and get the same results, time saved!

Now a fair warning, the game is not that big. the size is well and good, but it's no Elder Scrolls.
Quests are not that many (think like, 30-50) but they can drag on quite a bit, so it's no 30 second quest or some such crap (mostly)
And a complaint i have seen/heard MANY talk about (which i honestly do not get) is that your Pawn (and 2 hired) Talks constantly, i will admit they DO talk a lot, but they're not Aggrovatingly talketive, people are just over-exagerating.

Now, with all that said. Take up arms, Newly Arisen! For their kind does Not face the Toothless.

Side note: Do yourself a favor and look up the OG Theme.

Also a warning! Since this is Dark Arisen, you will unlock access to Bitter Black Isles insanely early, STAY AWAY FROM THERE!
A woman will end up standing on the dock at Night, the map will show a Purple swirly thing, IGNORE IT!
Bitter Black Isle is very late game content, i would recommend TWO playthrouhgs before you try to tackle that place, you've been warned.
Very solid RPG. Graphics mean very little to me, so this game may look aged to some. Everything else is very solid. I can't wait to sink more time into Dragon's Dogma.

Don't get me wrong, it's a fun game, but it's not really a "good" game. Here's a few examples.

How do you fight flying enemies as a melee class? You can try jump attacking them, but you don't jump very high and swing even less than that. Some classes have attacks where the hitbox goes kinda higher up, but you can't use them while jumping. The fighter class has a skill to try and draw them down by bashing their shield, that doesn't always work. So, the answer to the question is, you don't. You stand around wait for the ranged classes in your party to snipe them out of the air.

The game has a romance system where the character with the highest relationship status to you is set as your "beloved", how do you choose this character? Do you maybe gift them plenty of their favored gifts? Maybe straight up gift them a wedding ring? No, various quests you do throughout the game raises the relationship status with characters, as well as just talking to them. the status also decays over time, so there's half a chance the blacksmith you were talking to or the merchant you just did a quest for is selected as your "beloved" in the ending instead of the pretty dark-skinned french-accented tomboy knight you gave 2 wedding rings to. There is a save editor on the Nexus, by the way, funny that.

How do you allocate your stats for specific builds? Maybe you want a higher magic stat for a specific build you want, do you allocate skill points to your magic stat? No, you play the magic class for something like 50 level-ups because stats are automatically allocated based on the class you were playing when you level up, so in order to optimize the class you actually want to play, you have to instead play a bunch of other classes you don't care about to get the necessary stat points, as well as passive skills that are locked behind class progression but can be used on any class, that part is okay, and kinda cool. The stat thing is not, and hey, did I or did I not mention the thing about the save editor?

How do you know what strengths and weaknesses different enemies have? You listen for your NPC followers to shout them out, if they know it, or check the wiki. There is no ingame bestiary.

How do you tell your archer follower to stay at a distance and use their bow instead of running in with their daggers? You play a ranged character yourself and hope the lesson sticks.

How do you tell your support mage follower to stop enchanting your weapons with fire against fire enemies? You use a frost weapon and hope the lesson sticks. And that the same support mage doesn't overwrite your frost weapon's element with a fire enchantment.

I'm still gonna give a thumbs-up, because it is fun. But man, I sure do hope the sequel irons a bunch of this stuff out. I mean, they can keep it all if they want, but let me shake off weapon enchantments given by the support mage, add a character that lets me re-allocate my skill points manually, let melee classes target flying enemies better, and for the love of all that is good, make the wedding ring actually hard-set the beloved.

Gameplay is great, it plays somewhat similar to a mix of monster hunter and shadow of the colossus in that the bread and butter of the game is fighting against monsters and their core feature is you can climb on them to attack weak spots or break off parts for gear upgrade.
I'm slightly turned off by the fact you have limited way to defend yourself as dodge is not available to most classes meaning unless you have a shield or play dagger melee quickly turn into a damage trading fight and especially in Dark Arisen its not viable because mobs can one shot you even with high end armor. 

Story is....eh? If you want a rich and in depth story this may not be it as so much of the story can be ignored with little to no consequence. 

However all that said if you enjoy a game where you can travel around doing quest and kill the occasional large monster with the ultimate goal of killing a dragon this game is pretty good.

So, there's um, this dragon. And you've a role to play. Errr.... somehow. Basically, don't worry about it. And don't play a mage. Or (ymmv) a warrior. But as a strider / assassin / ranger type? Or even better, mystic archer? Kick back, enjoy the ride and wonder where the **** the year went. Oh, and don't forget to level your pawn up, dress her up in something pretty and rent her out on pawnguild.xyz 

It's a slightly sad reflection on gaming today that the most fun I've had in a game in.... far too long is something that was released ten years ago, had it's development cycle cut short and sort of skipped the plot. It still knocks spots off just about any AAA release I've played. Overall, a classic and, for like £3 when it's on sale, an absolute steal. How this game didn't get a sequel - or a bunch of them - is beyond me.

TLDR- BUY IT, I *H I G H L Y* RECOMMEND IT. I have 300+ hours and have bought it 4 times. A must have for any action rpg fan. combat is the show and story and quests are just there to facilitate the great combat, class, and gear systems. Great exploration as well.

Okay so I know this says that I have 5 hours in the game BUT I have owned the game on GOG since the PC version was available there, AND I also own the game for the Nintendo Switch. I bought the game on STEAM for the ease of use on my new steam deck so I could play the game on the go. While I could do that on the Switch, I like the deck a lottttt more because it is larger and I have some pretty big hands so it is more comfortable for me to play that way plus I only have to take my deck and not the deck and switch both if i want to play this game.

With that said, I have at minimum 300+ hours in Dragons Dogma so I think it should go without saying that I highly recommend this game. Here are some bullet points on why I like it.

-----The Good-----

- GREAT combat
-Multiple classes you can switch to at any time when you go to an inn.
-Fun loot to collect
-Pawn system grew on me a lot over time
-I like the party customization with pawns and gear
-the different classes actually change up the game play quite a bit
-trying out new class abilities/builds is very fun
-Dungeons are a freaking blast when you find them
-large monsters really steal show. Feels monster hunter lite at times with a sprinkle of show of the colossus.

-----Now for some of the Meh-----

- The open world is fun to explore but can be a slog at times due to back tracking and repetitive enemies although I don't think it is as bad as some people say

-The Fast travel system can but some people off a bit. You drop a stone on the ground and and teleport from major towns and back. you can drop multiple stones and leave them there to make your own teleport network but stones must be acquired from exploration. teleporting is free with the eternal stone added in the dark arisen version. you get it as soon as you make to the capital maybe 2-3 hours into the game.

-dialogue is not very good and feels unnatural at times (although i feel like it makes sense for Pawns)

-the story starts slow and does not pick up for quite a while and will leave you scratching your head for quite a bit. ESPECIALLY at the start.

-there can be a severe lack of direction at times but some people like that

-lots of hidden mechanics. for example, if you make a large character in the creation system, you can do more melee damage. Skinny/ tall characters run faster and short character can be lifted by larger characters. the game does NOT tell you this at all.

-Night time is VERY dark. some people love this, personally I hate it and avoid traveling at night but that's what the devs were going for. I wouldn't have made that design choice myself but i know a lot of people really like that feature.

-The post game DLC area is very hard. You have to be leveled up and geared correctly and you must still have a large amount of player skill of your own. BUT I love the dungeon. The dungeons are a highlight in DD for me and they are few and far between so I personally love the large end game one. 

- the graphics. Personally, I have a very very high tolerance for bad graphics and jank in games, I can appreciate good graphics but its never a deal breaker for me if they aren't great. The game is a xbox 360/ps3 game and it shows. I am completely fine with the way the game looks but a lot of people are graphics snobs so this might be hard on those types of players eyes



-----The bad -----

The music. I love the main menu theme but I honestly do not like the ambient music they have in combat or when traveling the open world. It drives me insane. This is a personal opinion for  people and I have never seen other popele complain about it online but I for one do not like it at all. I turn it off in the menus or if im just grinding for exp I listen to my own music.


I want to mention grinding real quick since I but it in the music section. - This game is not grindy. you can play the game to completion without grinding once. But if you want to level up a class fast or get some high level gear quickly (before youre normally ready) you can grind if it so pleases you. Personally I like grinding some times just to unwind but if you hate it, you do NOT need to do it at all and will never feel like you have to. Id argue that if you do, you will make the game a bit to easy.


------STEAM DECK----- 
 - The game runs great in hand held mode EXCEPT for during the character and pawn creations menus. I could not get the controls to work there and had to hook my deck up to my dock. after I got through the pawn creation section, I have had no issues with handheld mode since. I also did not have the issues in creation with a controller, only the steam decks handheld controller was an issue at the very start.

dragons dogman

One of my favorite games of all time, and one of the most underrated. Dragon's Dogma feels like a combination of the best parts of games like Shadow of the Colossus, Devil May Cry, Monster Hunter, Dark Souls, and Skyrim, with worldbuilding inspired by Berserk. Basically all of my favorite things were combined into one. Dragon's Dogma is completely bursting with life and passion, despite not getting the time or money it deserved in development. I have probably double my hours here if you include the time I spent playing on Xbox 360. It may not be a perfect game, but it is my favorite.

The combat is amazing. Some of the best in any game. Every vocation feels distinct and fun and immerses you into the class fantasy more than any other game I can think of. Even the default attacks feel good. Classes are split into red, yellow, and blue, for melee, ranged, and magic, with 3 hybrid classes that combine them in different ways. The red classes, Fighter and Warrior, have real weight behind their attacks, with some of the best Big Sword Gameplay in any game ever, chopping through multiple enemies, whacking them into the sky, slapping them across the room. Blocking and parrying is great, and there's even a way to build a Mystic Knight that is basically devoted to parrying as your main attack. The yellow classes, Strider and Ranger, feel light and agile, and bow combat is insanely fun. You can fire arrows like a machine gun, or expend all of your strength with one powerful shot, among many other moves. I'm usually a sword and board kinda guy, but I've spent a lot of time playing the other classes in Dragon's Dogma just because they are all so fun to experience, and I always end up returning to using a bow. It even feels good to play with a controller, and I usually hate aiming with a controller. The blue classes, Mage and Sorcerer feel like absolute gods of destruction. Some of the endgame spells feel like complete chaos, summoning a tornado or carpet bombing an entire forest just to kill some poor goblins. My personal favorites, though, are the hybrid classes: Mystic Knight, Assassin, and Magick Archer. Mystic Knight is all about big shields and big tanking, and is able to exploit every elemental weakness, Assassin is the ultimate monster climbing class, with a move devoted to just obliterating a monster's weak spot by stabbing your sword in and wiggling it around violently. Magick Archer has things like homing shots, sticky bombs, and bouncing arrows, which makes for a very fun toolkit and a playstyle unlike really any other game I can think of.

On top of the classes feeling so great to play, the actual approach to combat is amazing. Every major monster has a unique mechanic that you have to learn to take it down, and knowing what element enemies are resistant and weak to is often vital. Don't worry, your pawns will let you know. Repeatedly. The most important thing, though, is CLIMBING. Shadow of the Colossus style climbing up a huge monster to stab it in its weak spot, holding on to flying enemies for dear life, trying not to be thrown off. It just wouldn't feel the same if I was poking at everything's feet, and it makes a huge difference in a game like this. You can fling your pawn into the air to grab onto a flying dragon and knock it down, or grab onto a flying harpy until it can't bear your weight anymore. Very few games have so much verticality in combat. There are also nice ways of being able to buff up and prepare for fights, with usable items intentionally designed to LET you abuse the system to get an advantage, there is literally an in game system for item duping, and many effects stack. You actually use your items in this game instead of hoarding them for the entire duration.

The character creation was one of the best for its time, and still holds up great. You can see that they worked around the limitations of the engine mostly by giving a lot of preset options, but there was a lot of care put into the sheer variety of options given, that many games still to this day completely overlook. 

The pawn system is a unique approach to a singleplayer game. You are able to create your own pawn basically as if you have a second character, and hire two pawns created by other players. Its like having a party in an mmo in a singleplayer game, except every one of them is lobotomized. They talk way too much unless you tell them to shut up (which you can) but I personally love it. The game is an unintentional meme generator, hearing your pawns yell WOLVES HUNT IN PACKS every single time they see a wolf. The actual intention behind it is interesting and adds a lot of flavor to the game, and it is genuinely helpful on a first playthrough, as they will make comments about locations, items, quests, enemies, and generally try to help you take the best approach to things. They also learn how to fight different types of enemies over time, and learn more about quests as you do them, and even carry over things they learned by helping other players, or in other playthroughs. After many hours spent with your pawn as your companion, you get attached to them, and your friends may too, since they are able to hire your pawn for free and regardless of level. In a way your pawn is indirectly including you in someone else's playthrough and their memories of the game, and I think there is something special to that.

The armor and weapons in the game look amazing, blending realism and fantasy is my favorite aesthetic. There are also layers to clothing, with a bottom and top layer for your torso and legs, so you can get a pretty diverse combination of looks. You are also able to upgrade every piece of equipment, so if you like something a lot you can pretty much take it to endgame. This is a top tier mechanic that I wish was in every game. There is even a way to upgrade things further beyond, but I don't want to give it away because I think its cool as hell when you find out how on your own. I also really like the way you get the endgame gear in the base game, and the way you get the even more endgame gear in the DLC, which gives you a lot of content in the postgame.

I think most of the story is great, but unfortunately it is the main part of this game that is lacking. It's very clear that development didn't get the resources it needed, and the devs have said as much. You can see the threads of genius, and places the writers wanted to explore, but simply couldn't go as far as they wanted. Some of the main story moves rather abruptly forward, and I know the early game takes a bit of time to get people hooked. The pacing is a bit messy. I love the worldbuilding, though, and the lore of the game does feel mostly complete. Grigori makes for a fantastic antagonist throughout, and I definitely think the best parts of the story are toward the ending of the game, and on Bitterblack. The ending is still phenomenal, and I also think the approach to New Game+ is very, very interesting.

The endgame and DLC deserves its own recognition, because I think the actual best part of the game begins at the end, and a lot of the endgame systems feel really innovative especially given how old the game is now.  Without spoiling too much, there is an endgame area before the true ending of the game with a lot of interesting mechanics involved, that you could grind indefinitely if you really wanted to. They then took this idea forward into the major DLC, Dark Arisen, with what is almost a pseudo-roguelite mode with fantastic and challenging fights and really good reward progression on Bitterblack Isle. I've spent more time in Bitterblack than in the actual main game, and I still have more I would like to do there. It's practically its own game. Discovering I could kill a certain something on Bitterblack is one of my peak gaming memories.

I just finish this game for the first time and here is my review for Dragon's Dogma: Dark Arisen [spoiler] also, in 69 hours, nice [/spoiler]

What I Like:
[olist]
[*] many class (vocation) to choose from
[*] simple yet engaging combat
[*] spells feels unique and powerful.
[*] High replay value
[*] you can climb big enemies
[/olist]

What I don't like:
[olist]
[*] you can't decide what stats you want to improve every time you level up. To improve your stats, you need to be using certain vocation when you level up. which is kinda suck if you want to optimize your character.

[*] unless you have a certain augment (its like a perk) your character will get tired a lot (especially if you are a hoarder), which makes travelling a slog.

[*] you have a house but YOU CAN'T SLEEP IN IT. YOU HAVE TO SLEEP IN THE INN NEXT DOOR

[*]awkward affinity system (you can call it romance system if you want) Its awkward because your character (in a cut scenes) almost didn't say anything while your potential "lover" is awed by your mere existence.
[/olist]
Nitpick's
[olist]
[*] I feel like many elements of this game is borrowed from other Capcom games, like Resident Evil 4 and monster hunter.
for example (its in spoiler so I don't ruin your experience) [spoiler] when you kill a monster/enemy, it has the same decaying animation as resident evil 4's decay animator (they even go melt almost similarly), and when you open a door using lever or button, the camera move the same way as re4. [/spoiler] but its fine though, just a bit distracting for me.

[*]pawn (your companions) hiring system is both a curse and a blessing. In this game, you have a main pawn (made by you) and hired pawn (made by other people who buy this game) most of the pawn you hire when you play for the first time is from people who didn't finish the game at all, so many of them are incomplete or not that good. There are some hidden gem pawn that can carry you through difficult parts of the game but its hard to find such pawn at low level.
[/olist]

There is also item combination mechanic that can give you decent items which also act as gold saver. Item farming is ok but boss farming especially is meh.

There is much for me to say. but let me just stop here.

TLDR A truly underrated masterpiece that's rough around the edges but has one of the best combat, class, levelling and party member systems of any rpg in recent years.

Dragons dogma is a rpg by capcom and is one of the best cult hit games i have ever played, the only way to explain this game is if you were to take devil may cry, monster hunter, dragon age/elder scrolls, shadow of the collossus, a pinch of dark souls and good ol D&D and mix it together you would get Dragons dogma a game about a hero known as the arisen who has had his heart stolen by a dragon and is on a quest to take it back. 

on the way you will be guided by the pawns who are emotionless puppets who you command as party members and you have 3 + yourself for a party of 4. Only one pawn can be customised which is your main pawn the other 2 are pawns other players have made and you can "rent" to help you on your journey.

speaking of customisation this game is deep, with a characters creater that allows you to be male/female young/old, hair + colour and physique which for the time this game released what pretty impressive stuff but thats not all, the best part is the freeform class system, what does that mean? well basically you are not railroaded into picking one class, there are classes in the game which determine your weapons and gear you can use but you are free to change constantly which one you want to be allowing for different playstyles, your stat increases when you level also scale slightly different depending on which class you play when you lvl up, allowing for some interesting character growth.

there are also a lot of classes im talking warrior, strider, ranger, assassin, magic knight, magic archer, mage, sorcerer and many more each with their own unique attributes and play styles to bring to the table. for example a mage and sorcerer both use magic but as a mage you play a more supportive role with buffs and heals but as a sorcerer you wreak havoc summoning tornado's, meteors, giant ice storms the magic in this game is just nuts. basically no matter who you are there is definitely at least one class you'll enjoy.

The feel of this game is great to, it hasn't age at all, movement is solid and controls are as good as modern rpgs.

What has ages however is the graphics with them being slightly washed out and pale looking at times, this is a game that doesnt have a whole lot of colours and the overworld can be a bit boring to look at.

the story is also extremely vague but not in the darksouls way where its deliberate, this game just doesn't explain its story too well which is a shame because i understand the story and it is good, really dark depressing and hopeless similar in vein to the NieR series where the game masquerades as a simple adventure game ala zelda but devolves into something much more dark by the end.

but the pros more than make up for the cons and its a entertaining game through and through with its amazing combat where you can climb up large enemies like a dragon whilst they are flying and stab at their weakspots making them plummet so you can hak at them, its just such good stuff.

I reccommend and hope this games gets a long deserved sequel.
Buy it! and play it! it is ducking amazing. I love it.

I would recommend, truly one of the best fighting mechanics I've seen in an RPG, and I've played too much of them. There's some jankiness here and there in the dialogues and story, but really this game shines in the movement and combat animations and pacing. Very crisp, fluid, believable, the gameplay in combat is quite fast. The RPG aspect is also surprisingly fleshed out, abilities are used with a stamina system and can be comboed one after the other, not only with your abilities, but with the abilities of your companions to create greater effects. The fact that you can climb on large monsters to then target weak spots is the icing on the cake.

The unique aspects of this rpg will bring freshness to the most hardcore fans of the genre, 8/10

Overall Dragon's Dogma Dark Arisen is a fantastic game, but a game that no-one else I know has played. That alone is a shame.

UPDATE 2023: I still love this game. It has aged like wine, in most respects, with graphics probably being its weakest aspect (still, the game is not ugly by any means, and with mods it looks spectacular). Even hours upon hours over the course of a decade, the game still draws me in. Would recommend it to any fan of Berserk, Monster Hunter, Shadow of the Colossus, and fast arcade-style combat.

Being an avid Monster Hunter fan at the time of this game's announcement, when I heard there were similarities, I decided to download the demo (on PS3). Fell in love.

PROS: The combat is arguably the best out of any 3D action RPG. It's classic Capcom, with fast, responsive controls akin to the Dungeons & Dragons series.
The character creator - Not only does the way your player character is created (as in, how tall he is, etc) factor into different in-game stats, but the amount of equipment that you can pick up, put on, and look bad ass it pretty extensive. Fashion's Dogma is superb.
The bestiary is pretty extensive. You fight everything from huge cyclops, to flying griffins, to drakes, to Chimeras, to bandits that can have the same abilities you can have. At night time, in classic Capcom style, you get zombies and undead warrios... hell, you even fight Death itself. 
The music fits the setting pretty well. The tunes don't get old, even after all the time I've logged into the game.

Cons- The story isn't the greatest. While it has some interesting parts (especially near the end), for the most part, it's a pretty generic fantasy story. 
The pawns, while useful in battle, and cool as a multiplayer component, talk too damn much. Eventually their chatter becomes a meme like Navi off Ocarina of Time.
It lacks a proper quick-travel system. You do, however, get port crystals which you can use to teleport at points where you've dropped them, which if placed stragetically can become a very good way to quick-travel. But out the gate, there isn't really a way to quick-travel between places.

And that's about all I can think of. Overall, I highly recommend this game. While the story isn't OMG AMAZING WOW NEEDS A PULITZER IN FICTION 10/10, it's entertaining enough to where doing everything that's available (and there's plenty to do) isn't a chore, or necessarily boring. Where the game shines is in the gameplay. This Shadow of the Colossus meets Monster Hunter in Berserk's world mash-up is probably some of the best time you'll have with an action RPG.
All about the Combat

An actual RPG with satisfying combat. Bit overwhelming at the start because they basically give you access to all mechanics at once but only explain them over time. But you get to create a character as you wish, both looks and skills, without having to think about skill points. The pawn/companion system is novel, too.

One thing it lacks is good story pacing. Story mostly happens at the start and end. Inbetween it all feels more like doing sidequests. Good thing the combat is fun. Being able to climb upon bigger enemies is cool.

Graphics look dull, too. I didn't expect a fairytale look, but the color grading they used looks too bleak IMO. At least you can fix that with Reshade.

The game's map is not so drastic like other open world games. However, the freedom of implanting your own teleportation points makes it user-friendly. Another aspect of the game being user-friendly is how it pauses when you consume potions or in this case "Curatives". I know, there are opinions that this feature makes the difficulty rock-bottom. However the weight feature limits what you can bring since the character's equipment also quantifies on that aspect. If you are looking for a souls series but a little tone down and not quite stressful, this is the game. There are enemies that can one shot you if your equipment is not really optimal or underleveled. While underlevelled equipments also means that the DPS that you emit cannot kill your target plausibly. By plausibly, I meant in the terms of time-efficient and worth efficient. By time efficient is when the boss can be killed by a time you are comfortable with and how do you fare in lasting for that time. By worth efficient is the confirmation of your rewards if it is worth it by spending for all that effort. So grinding for equips and levels is still a must if you want to move forward story-wise or equipment wise. The class system in the game is unique since the passives you have learned in other classes can be equipped to your current class. Which means that variety and diversity of builds here is high which is good for me since I am trying out several classes anyways. If you are bored in a class I recommend trying out other classes, since boredom isnt the only thing satisfied when trying out new classes but passives that might help you in the class that you might like the most. Moreover, the equipment upgrades in this game is quite fun since there is a certain mechanics that you should do before maxxing out these equpments. Another is interactivity. Interactivity however in modern games means multiplayer communication. It is comprised of chatting, and trading, etc. However this game, utilize so called companions which practically speak and their behaviors can be modified. It is a new form of communication that the game invented to help your co-arisen in their journey. In your case, your main companion or "pawn" 's behavior can be customized by yours truly (with equips and class). Which makes it like playing with another person since your craft can be utilized by others. Like your child. I recommend this game 7/10

I must have racked up hundreds, if not, thousands of hours on the ps3 back in the good old days of youth. If you want a quick summary, this game is more than worth it after all these years. It has almost everything, and with the sequel starting development recently, in maybe half a life time we may even see some of the weaker areas strengthened.

Ignoring Bitter Black Isle (BBI, The DLC) for now, DD is set in the vast duchy of Gransys and provides a wide range of areas for exploration. There are plenty of quests to do, lots of interesting encounters, but more importantly the combat, which is the core appeal of this game. Unfortunately this means the role-playing takes a bit of a backseat, but the story itself is more than one would first expect from such a game, and I would suggest you pay attention to.

To explain the combat would take me years, so to summarise, at the start of the game you have three basic vocations: Fighter, Strider, Mage. Next, the advanced, but by no means superior: Warrior, Ranger, Sorcerer. Finally, the hybrid, who are not available to pawns: Assassin, Magic archer, Mystic Knight. Whilst the weapons and armour may stay the same between certain vocations, each play incredibly differently to each other and have different skills to take advantage of their strengths and cover for weaknesses.

Pawns, again, would take far too long to fully describe - they are the npc followers that help you throughout your play through. At the start you will be able to create your own, and then level them up along with you. They have no autonomy over their equipment, so it is up to you to decide what they wear and use, but aside from that will start off as bumbling fools, and as you fight more monsters and learn more of the world and quests, they will gain more and more knowledge. It may take several play throughs, but pawns with a high enough knowledge of certain quests can show you the way to complete them, give useful insights, and certainly turn the tide of battle if they successfully know how to exploit the weaknesses of a boss.

Now for a quick summary of BBI - incredible. That's it, it's incredible. It condenses everything fun about DD and plops it all down into a nice, linear dungeon that will take you hours and hours to beat. It features many more enemies, incredible atmosphere and unforgettable bosses. It's only for high level players, as the damage you'll be doing early game is atrocious, but it won't take too long to get to a point where you can more comfortably track your way through and beat it. After defeating the final boss of the dungeon, it will also switch enemies around to keep things fresh.

To conclude, I would recommend to everyone, especially if you enjoy combat-focused RPGs with very deep systems at play. Pick it up as soon as you can and have a wonderful time. And remember:

Up to this day, this game has remained one of my favorites of all-time, and there still isn't another to which I can compare it's gameplay. It's truly one of a kind. Beginning with its original release, and sky-rocketing with the Dark Arisen expansion, I played hundreds (if not thousands) of hours replaying the game over and over. Even though it is considered a single-player game, much of my playtime was spent exchanging "pawns" (ai-controlled companions made by, and customized by, other players) and contributing damage to a cross-player world boss known as the Ur-Dragon. At the time of writing this review, the developers released a video retrospective (in light of a long-awaited sequel announcement) where they made special note of the passion they put into this psuedo-multiplayer experience. And it clearly shows.

That said, even without the multiplayer aspects, the single-player experience is one of a kind. There are so many small details that you come across while exploring the open-world, which add to the immersion far beyond most any game I've played. For the sake of not spoiling the experience, I'd rather keep them a mystery and instead recommend that you try it out, going in blind. You won't be disappointed.

Story: 
what starts off as a grand epic of the underdog-arisen against an almighty dragon soon turns into incoherent storytelling. There is no overall story thread, no main quest that you can refer to if you want to refresh where you were, nothing. And this is the MAIN story line. I'm not even gonna mention the side quests

Fighting: 
is quite fun to be honest - being able to perform combo strikes with the companions as well as having three sets of possible strike types that are easily enabled by hitting ALT or CTRL is a really nice touch. On top of that, being able to climb huge bosses is quite fun as well. Unfortunately, the fighting system + class management is very constricted. For instance. you wanna start bashing skulls in with a two-handed weapon right from the start? Well, forget about it - not before you reach a "rank" in the organization that "worships" you are you gonna be allowed to take up a different weapon. Similarly, if you want to be a warrior but wear light clothes to save some weight and gain additional speed, well, that ain't happening either. Not to mention that you can't loot the bandits you slay for weaps/armor. An the rotten cherry on the cake - I learn skills as I progress, but I can't even use them all at once? Really?

Companions: 
pawn system has been praised a lot, and I agree - it's innovative insomuch as to allow players to share their pawns. But from that gameplay standpoint - those are mindless slaves that 1) you cannot communicate with 2) won't offer you any side quests 3) though having no will of their own (as one ingame NPC puts it), they seem to have enough will to advise you on how to do the quests (the tips are welcome but the inconsistency is not). I can continue the list, but I think I made myself clear

The world:
beautiful, there's no denying that. Some locations seem quite lively as well - with NPCs going back and forth on their business. This is no more than an illusion, however, as the Gran Soren - the capital of the kingdom - is almost dead. There are hardly any centry guards, NPCs are scarce. Right outside the capital there are bandits lurking about - no patrols by the great Duke? Where the MMO part comes into play is the mob respawning - I go through a location clearing it thoroughly. 2 min later I'm going back the same way, and lo and behold, all the mobs are back and ready to kick my tired out-of-curatives ass.
