This is one of the greatest games you've probably never played, in the same category as Witcher 3 and Skyrim but not quite reaching their level. The narrative is bread-and-butter fantasy but with a uniquely JRPG twist. Class system is good overall, with each class having something unique and fun to offer. Character building is a thing, should you wish for that intimate level of involvement. Gameplay is smooth and reactive with intuitive controls. Combat is fast but fair, and individual mechanics are mostly good. Nearly all of the frustrating elements are minor (lantern goes out if you touch water, items degrade in quality over time), the only significant drawback being the expansion. Some players may take issue with side quests disappearing at random as main story quests are completed; however there is a reliable guide on Steam forums which players can use to achieve 100%. 

Bitterblack Isle (the expansion) has a wonderful Castlevania aesthetic, but unfortunately features MUCH copy-pasting and significant balance issues with monster NPCs. While some players may enjoy the possibility of being one-shotted even at level 200, the randomness with which monsters appear and the unfairness of certain fight mechanics make exploring more stressful and tedious than fun. The expansion also took a note from MMORPGs, making drop rates for advanced armor and weapons extremely low (less than or equal to 5%). While some players may enjoy this, IMHO such design has no place in a single-player game, where gear should be a guaranteed reward for overcoming challenges. Many players try to circumvent the low drop rate issue by "godsbaning": they save before a chest, open it, have their character commit suicide if the desired item is not inside, then reload and try again. Although this is a successful strategy, the consequence is that the game becomes a veritable slot machine for several hours while players endlessly load and reload until getting the item they want. (If randomized loot was a dev goal, then boss drop mechanics of about 20-30% would have been much better. That way players could still have fun fighting the bosses while trying for loot.)

That being said, as a lifelong gamer in my 40's, this game still features boss battles which have been the most fun I have ever played, and hands down the best final boss battle of any game out there. There is also a sick and twisted pleasure I derive from some of the assassin class ability animations - especially when playing a short character. Generally speaking: this is a good game worthy of your time, and definitely worth picking up on sale.

6. More community events like the Ur Dragon. 
7. Cooperative play.
Thanks for all the hard work y’all do.
Ps. if Magic Archer isn’t an option in DD2 I’m coming for y’all.

Top tier action combat, the best I've played fantasy-wise. It's a good mix of weightiness and mobility, there's a solid range of classes and abilities to suit different styles, and enemy/boss variety is a plus. Pawns are a fun take on AI party members, they are pretty useful if set up right and amusing if not.

The rest of the game is janky (UI, dialogue, graphics), but it's entertaining despite the lack of polish. The story is an intriguing concept but it doesn't reveal itself as such until late. There is too much traversing around, it would've been nice to have a mount, a smaller map, and/or more fast travel points.

Worth it at full price.

I played this game through multiple times, minmaxing a lot of classes (and regret starting a new save, because the game only has ONE SAVE SLOT, PERIOD). That's right, you only have ONE save slot. Never start a new game game unless you're in NG+ Bitter Black Isle and have absolutely no other game to play in your library. Since you can change classes, and they rely completely on your equipment stats + attributes, there is no need to EVER EVER start a New Game. NEVER DO IT.

This is a great RPG if you enjoy exploring, long boss fights with tons of good reaction/smart thinking needed, and managing a few resources/units. Not so much managing units, though. Classes are varied, and have a lot of equipment that can be shared inbetween them, making it very easy to grind for XP/Points and master new ones for the very-OP passive skills each one gets to purchase. Mages are ICBMs made of cardboard; rogues are quick, can handle ranged combat seamlessly and can dodge/reset stance to reduce vulnerability windows; warriors are frontline aggro-sponge, but can also dish some freight-train-sized pain, along with very important stuns and "lifting" moves for buddies.

The true fun of classes comes with the mixed-jobs, like Mystic Knight or Magick Archer. Assassin is also very busted, but MA takes the cake; since your pawns cannot take these jobs to play as, they become very unique, and can make use of other basic jobs' accumulated weapons/skills too. Not to say advanced jobs aren't good, IE: Ranger is also one of the best damage-dealing ones.

Overall gameplay is balanced around jobs having active skills to perform certain "events" during fights. These come to stunning a monster, cutting off a limb, exploiting a weakness, or even disjointing armor. Things become quite complex when you realize climbing large monsters is quite important, and can make the difference between easy and hard encounters. These "events" are very much necessary, and not always play in your favor. Working to be changing the tides of each bossfight in your favor is one of the strongest points for fun in DD, as they demand some knowledge of what your moves/buddies' moves do to monsters' behavior.

The pawns are this game's low-point, because they are lolsorandumxd. You can, with a bit of fiddling (buying and equipping only the right skills, shouting the right commands, and giving only right items), setup your own follower very well and have them do useful things forever, and online. The issues start with the other 2 followers (which you must summon from a server, and are created by other players like yourself).

Since "casual players" pay much less attention to minmaxing their follower (which really isn't necessary for the vanilla game), you may end up starting Dark Arisen's (expansion) campaign having to summon better pawns than your current level (10lv~20lv>), and the currency overlaps with the one used to get new items from a certain vendor. If you get through this "early game" on the DLC where you start looking for pawns with "THE RIGHT SKILLS" and "THE RIGHT AI", and ALSO "THE RIGHT GEAR", BBI

Play it, it's dirt cheap and you can get mods to overcome flaws/ameliorate annoyances. One thing I find very annoying after playing for so long after some playthroughs is equipment and item weight — which is limited per character. The capacity is something I find to be there just to stretch the gameplay, so I use a mod that gives me infinite carry capacity.

This game goes on sale for 5 bucks sometimes. Buy it and play it even for just the Dark Arisen content. If you wanted you could go look up how the game got cut short and we missed out on some wacky stuff like apparently we were supposed to go to the moon and etc. Despite all that this game gets a lot SO right. The Devil May Cry mixed with Shadow of the Colossus and Monster Hunter put in a generic medieval fantasy rpg hits just the right itch for me. The potential in this game is so high, I can't wait for the sequel. If they keep a lot of what was great about this game and improve in the other areas while expanding the game and not getting cut short, then there is game of the year potential there. At first I thought it was a bit too intense because I kept getting wrecked trying to do anything but just pick your battles and save before you try certain side quests because some might be a bit too much. (note your first encounter in the Cassardis sewer you'll find out fast) 

Not much for great items you can find randomly out in the open world but if you want to find minor items you need or want, they are out there. I've never found armor though but I haven't made it far yet but don't think armor and weapons are found in the open world. Maybe I'm wrong? 
Still I think it's a pretty cool game if you really want to feel like you're in a large world because it is pretty vast.

This is a good game that tries its hardest to get you to hate it. Besides the opening cutscene the story sucks, the voice acting isn't particularly good, quests are either pretty bad or just passable, and menus are a pain to navigate through, having you hear the same voice lines over and over as you go back and forth.

So why do people love this game? The combat and character creation is just that good, arguably the best of any action RPG. If you can put up with all the dated and bad design decisions you'll have a great time. 

It's worth trying, especially seeing as it goes on sale for very cheap all the time. But be warned, you will have no idea what you're doing or what items are good to carry for the first ten hours or so. The game doesn't do a great job of explaining all of its mechanics.

Good: Combat is fluid and fun, with the right amount of dificulty. The special abilities are varied and fun to use. There are many different classes to choose from and you can combine them as you like. So far the quests are fun and the gameworld is vast. I like that you can combine materials to produce different items and to enhance your equipment. The graphics, while dated, still look good.

Not so good: Only one save slot, and because of that sometimes I have refrained from saving, died, and had to repeat some fights. A minor nuisance. I hear there's a mod for the save feature, haven't tried it yet though. Some people may actually like the save feature as it is, since it forces you to live with your mistakes and move on, creating a unique gaming experience on different playthroughs.

If you're a big nerd that loves creating characters you will love this game. It's just so much fun to to make the best looking character for your own tastes while also making him/her viable gameplay wise, while also playing with your friends characters too.

The combat in this game is the main draw. The combat system is similar to that of a hack-and-slash game, but it is more complex. You can grab onto both large and small enemies. When you stun or knock down small enemies, you can either grab them yourself and attack their weak points or hope your pawn grabs them, leaving them vulnerable to extra damage from the rest of the party. The PC port's overall performance is very good; I've only encountered a small handful of bugs or crashes in my hours of play. Dragon's Dogma is a game worth playing if you're tired of the seemingly copy-paste RPGs of today.

I understand there being constraints as to how big a 10 year old game can be, but with a game so intriguing and fun, it's always so disappointed to finally get to the end of it all. First off, this is **NOT** a souls-like games, its more a classic RPG game. That out of the way...

This game is THE best RPG I have ever played. After playing Dark Souls I told myself "How can any other RPG game ever fascinate me again after this?", then I somehow found Dragon's Dogma. At first glance, as soon as I started the game I thought it was another mediocre RPG, but then I got flashbacks to Dragon Age Origins and Dark Souls "At first it's ugly, boring, clunky, but then it makes you eat your own words". Well, this game made me eat my own words, it's absolutely fantastic and I bought it twice (on Steam, and then on GOG which is the DRM-free version and I have like 100 hours there). It's that good. No, really. 

Why haven't you heard of it if it's that good? Don't get fooled by Steam's algorithm, don't get fooled by the generic name, don't get fooled by the appearances, if you like Dark Souls then you know how looks can deceiving.
Best game I've ever played.

Average Elden Ring fans vs Dragon's Dogma enthusiasts.

Absolutely tickles my RPG-bone (prostate) just right. 
Most ingenious equipment system where  you have under clothing and armor separately. Also character customisation is so good, being able to choose body proportions and height as you wish. This has some jank as bigger characters have bigger starting stamina pool and carry weight but smaller have faster stamina recovery and can go to places where bigger ones cant. Realistically this means like 1 place in the whole game.You can buy during the game a metamorphosis item from firs encampment which enables you to chance your appearance from main menu once. You can acquire a permanent option to chance your appearance in post game from the same place. Extra jank is when medium characters have smaller *light* carry weight capacity than slightly small characters. In average-mans playthrough this is slightly annoying since carry capacity makes you move slower. This can be circumvented by dumping all loot to your pawn.
Pawns are quite interesting addition to game making it this pseudo-multiplayer where you customise other character, which can rented to friends or random pawns through games rift system. Do not worry my friend since all the multiplayer function can be disabled in the options menu if you don't want to show your pawn to strangers online by setting it to so friends or nobody can summon your pawn. There should not be anything to be ashamed since few people seem to enjoy making childlike characters in the skimpy clothing so your pawn can't be much worse what people have made/seen already. I myself saw my friends pawn to be skimpily clothed woman full-sized this time so at least my friends taste is not so repulsive. Your pawns AI can be quite bad at times since game does not tell you about importance of pawns inclinations this is affected by answers you choose in the end of the pawns customisation so here is a few starting ones: 
For melee classes (red) SCATHER/MITIGATOR, mage (starting blue) MITIGATOR/MEDICANT and for every other MITIGATOR/CHALLENGER. Inclinations can be chanced by your actions or buying potions at the first encampment. These potions can be quite expensive at the start of the game, but you will get the currency plentifully at the end game.
Combat is enjoyable and you can encounter strong enemies quite early making replaying it is a blast. If you are starting out I would recommend buying better weapon at the general goods store in the starting town since games defence mechanic works so enemies defence works as a quite direct attack - defence = damage so even small numbers can make a difference. And from damage we get to the quite controversial topic: minmaxing. In my opinion minmaxing is not needed in any other than minmaxing playthroughs since your stats that come mostly from equipment outweighing your character level and/or minmaxed stats. Minmaxing does helps you break through some enemies defences more early, but this is just for an advanced players or for your second playthrough. 
Replaying it might seem huge hurdle since game has only one save slot, but you can circumvent  this by going to folder C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\userdata\Steam ID(some numbers or something)\367500\remote and creating a backup copy of the DDDA.sav file.
Story of this game is background for this adventure which you embark and is not really necessary to follow anything else than: kill the dragon. Story is there and has some interesting points, but you have to really dig for the full picture since some random NPC:s do tell pieces of it and you have to piece it together yourself.
Game also has some missable items and quest, but in newgame+ you can breeze through the game fast so missing something in your first playthrough is not big deal. Of course you can play any way you like so don't let this half-old-man tell you how to enjoy your game. So I hope you enjoy or have already enjoyed the game as much I have, since this game is one of my favourites even with its jank and all. In my opinion jank makes it more lovable or it might be just me inhaling fumes of pure copium coming from my PC for not being able to handle current year games.

tldr: Good combat, adventuring is fun, story can be skipped, need to go to files if you want multiple save slots and janky as hell, but one of my favourite games. I could go many hours just discussing this game and its flaws, but I love it dearly and this is absolute truth.

Simply put, it's a must play for all RPG fans out there. 

It's open world may not be on the scale of Skyrim or have the intricate npc conversations of Dragon Age but the game excels in an area the other two slightly lack and that's the combat. 

The action combat is what makes this game shine, whether you're coming up against gigantic Ogres or Griffins circling you from the sky, the combat is built in a way to give you most the enjoyment out of every encounter. 

There are drawbacks, some systems the designers have decided to go with may not satisfy some of the more hardcore audience but that's one for yourself to decide.

With the addition of post-game content you can easily see yourself getting at least 100+ hours plus out of this title and with the game currently on sale for under £10 it's a steal!

i have a love-hate relationship with the game, the pawn system is surprisingly pretty complex and the gameplay is really fun, other than that the filler content is pretty annoying, meaning there lost's of quests that are pretty much pointless to do and the story is something that i never cared about, the coolest part about the game is about creating and working on your character, that is what the game excels at, still pretty fun tho.

[h1]Positives[/h1]
+ Deep combat system with loads of customization in the form of different "vocations" (classes). Can rank up in each vocation, mix and match skills/passives, and target specific stats from each vocation's leveling. Combined with weapon choices (primary/secondary) and companions, there is an abundance of ways to slay baddies.

+ "Pawns" (AI companions) are actually intelligent and competent in combat, for the most part. You can customize your personal Pawn's AI to behave a certain way to better suit your needs.  Better yet, the Pawn learns as you do and will adapt new strategies depending on how you play.  They also level up separately and are fully customizable (appearance, gear, vocation, skills, etc.). They have their own inventory where they can auto-use consumables and tools, so no worries about micromanaging. Even their dialogue is helpful; often giving a clue about your current quest, calling out found items, or alerting you to enemy weaknesses. Definitely one of the best companion systems I've ever experienced.

+ Climbing on large monsters and slicing them up while you hang on for dear life is awesome. Other games with oversized enemies will have you chopping away at an ankle, which seems like a bit of a waste when designing behemoths to fight.  Capcom loves to add verticality to their fights to make them feel more dynamic, as well as let the player appreciate a larger portion of the enemy design both visually and mechanically.  Dragon's Dogma keeps to that philosophy and does it well.

+ Fast travel system doesn't feel as immersion breaking or "cheaty" as some other RPGs. Fast travel is done using a consumable, which you can get a reusable variant of if you explore enough.  Also, you're able to place your own custom fast travel nodes using crystals found throughout the world, and you can move these crystals at any time by picking them up and placing them elsewhere. Certain points of interest will come with a built-in fast travel node that cannot be moved, but otherwise used like your custom nodes. It feels much more rewarding to find one of these crystals/consumables through exploration and being able to use fast travel like a tool, rather than just a QoL feature baked into the game from the get-go.

+ Plenty of post-game quests and harder monsters to kill once main quest line is completed.


[h1]Negatives[/h1]
- Main story is lack luster.

- Hard to tell if you are hitting enemy weak points; there is no visual hit indicator, only a slight audio cue that can be obscured by other combat sounds.

- As with many RPGs, this one also suffers from having a TON of random loot strewn about. It's hard to tell what is useful and what is junk.

- The UI and menus are a bit dated and can be hard to navigate quickly at times.

- Item stats are confusing at times; when buying/equipping an item, the increased/decreased stats are based on your totals in those stats, but when viewing the item in inventory it shows just the item's stats. The UI also doesn't show if you will lose a stat bonus completely when equipping an item; for example, if your current armor gives +100 HP, and the new armor does not give any bonus HP, then the UI will not show the -100 HP when comparing stats on the equipment management screen. The difference would only be shown if the new armor piece also had some number of bonus HP.

- Combat, though fun and action packed, can feel clunky and unbalanced at times due to slow, locked animations. This is especially seen with slower weapons/skills such as the Warrior class and its weapon types. Many of the slower skills are obsolete either because they are too slow, allowing enemies to easily step out of the way even unintentionally, or they just don't do enough for when you do get that one, big hit.  Normal light attacks are much easier to land and often reward the same or greater damage than many skills and heavy attacks.

- Light from some spells is blinding, especially at night, and makes it very hard to see enemies.

- Voices are frequently desynced with mouth movement


[h1]Summary[/h1]
Base game completed:  YES
DLC completed:  N/A
Rating:  7.5 / 10 - Good

a prime example of how good games USED to be, releasing with a full set of features, minimal bugs, none of them game breaking, and where beta testing was properly performed PRIOR to launch of retail release, not  beta testing performed by YOU the consumer. ( looking at you ACTIVISION, EA, ROCKSTAR, And UBI SOFT, and yes even you CAPCOM although not as bad as the first two listed)  the character progression system is well thought out, and fulfilling the story arc is engaging, the monster variety is good, and the game doesn't nerf later game cross classes for the sake of balance, instead it rewards you with powerful classes that make the late game easier which is also part of the progression system that allows your character to become more powerful as they progress.  for instance, with the right gear, the Arcane Knight is powerful  same with the strider/warrior class, they provide additional benefit by being more flexible and adaptive to the combat. 

and even after this many years, the game still looks great!

unfortunately, games like this are from a bygone era, if you want to experience what it was like to pickup a FULL game, for 60 USD, with all gear, and cosmetics, already unlocked and achievable in game, and with minimal/no game breaking bugs, where you DON'T feel like you shelled out money to be one of the group of en mass retail beta testers, then give this one a try

I know many people enjoyed this game and rated it high. If you dear reader did, genuinely I'm glad. I wanted to give it a "Yes, I recommend it", I was going to, but few things really ruined this experience for me.
The game has great potential but the flaws... there are quite a few, many of very easily fixable.


1. There is a singular game save slot. ONE save slot, period. And you can't even "quite" save on it manually. What do I mean by "quite"? Allow me to explain. The game autosaves in some moments, at some checkpoints, and you "technically" can save the game manually... and the game sometimes saves when you enter new locations or finish quests, but as it turns out, it's very 'picky' when to treat something as a 'checkpoint' and when it's "just a random save".

I was exploring the game world for quite a while, and slained A LOT of monsters, spent multiple HOURS doing so, and then expected the game's 'checkpoint' to be when I entered a certain cave for the first time which was filled with monsters and randomly generated treasures. Just to be sure, I made a manual save. 
I then  came across some monsters... which were absolutely unkillable. I assumed I was either too low level or had wrong loadout (loadouts... another thing I'll mention). Either way, I died, and then went "Ok, this doesn't seem to work out well... guess I'll come back here later".
I pressed 'go back to checkpoint', since I either expected to get back to one of my last saves, or the cave entrance, or at least at the quest that I completed somewhere nearby the cave and I was notified 'game saved'. Logical to assume I'll go back to one of those saves, isn't? There's only one save slot after all, and the game told me it saved on multiple occasions, checkpoint had to be somewhere nearby right? WRONG! Turns out the game rewinded me MULTIPLE HOURS OF GAMEPLAY BACK, at a checkpoint somewhere in some city. Oh, so I guess all the manual saves didn't mattered, as well as entering some new locations, same for quest completions and multiple "game saved" notifications.
Great... so why even add an option 'continue from a checkpoint', if the said checkpoint happens once in a full moon?
And want to hear something extra "funny"? The moment you load a "go back to checkpoint save", the game autosaves imminently, overwriting your manual saves with that at a "checkpoint"!

...This... is just on multiple levels... one of the most idiotic, poor game design choices I've ever seen.

2. Some monsters are STUPIDLY tanky

3. Grabs and stuns. Seriously, sometimes you just find yourself getting grabbed/stunned so many times that you might as well grab yourself a cup of tea and lean back since it just takes so much time you might as well. Ugh, so annoying.

4. Pathfinding. (seriosly, your 'teammates' just won't stop walking off cliffs...)

5. Loadouts.
If you're somewhere in the wilderness, enter some location, and turns out you don't have one f'ing element needed to defeat an enemy(all attacks deal next to no damage to them unless you hit them with the 'right' element), you can't just go into options and set it. Maybe you previously didn't had enough points for those abilities and only now farmed enough to unlock them on the way there... so, can spend points there? Or rearrange loadout? No! You have to get out of that place, backtrack all the way to a nearest city, go to a trainer, and THERE you can swap/learn skills. Oh yea, so fun, not annoying at all.
Oh by the way, did I mentioned you have 6 skill slots? It sounds reasonable, right? Not quite, since 1. If you have one mage in the party, you can't make them a cool battle-wizard, casting fireballs or what you want, since then everyone else in the party will be next to useless against foes vulnerable to only one element! So the mage HAS to be a buffing-servant for the remaining members of the squad. One slot for healing spell, another for spell that removes many negative status effects THAT DON'T GO AWAY WITH TIME, and then another 4 for elemental buffs to weapons for the party, since many enemies are vulnerable to just one element, so to 'be prepared', you need to have fire, ice, lighting and holy damage types of buff-spells to weapons of your comrades. Either buffer, OR a battlemage(and if pick the latter, other members of the team are then almost useless), and with two mages, not only you would've had your party very vulnerable in close-combat, it wouldn't be good comp-wise.

The situation is even worse when YOU want to play as the mage of the group, and don't want to have 2 mages since it doesn't work very well for the team composition. You then are forced to either play a role of buff-doofus, buffing/healing your party(so fun, exciting...), or play as the 'battle mage' and then have all 3 remaining members of your squad useless against an enemy that's basically immune to just-physical attacks.


6. Out of 9 available classes, only two are capable of blocking. Why not all of them?! Why can't a two-handed weapon user, that struggles with mobility, block with their weapon? Mage block with their magical staff? Assasin or Strider with daggers? No because reasons! If enemy is about to hit, grab or tackle you, you can only try sprinting away - often resulting in getting hit and/or shot in the back. Not to mention there is no "tactical roll" like in soul-like games to save yourself with. ( No roll may be a good choice, since in medieval setting most people wouldn't be able to roll, wearing all the armor and/or tools, but I'm mentioning this as yet another reason to give player option to block, not just as two classes but others as well!)


7. Character respecialization. It's allowed to switch from a mage to a warrior during the game. That's good, would be quite unfortunate to not have that as an option. BUT, as you started the game as one class, every level up you got, added certain amount of points into your Strength and Magic, and it won't 'swap' with your class change. Mage level-ups add next to nothing to strength while leveling up magic, and if you swap to a non-magic user, your stats won't change with you... so your strength and HP will stay low, severely handicapping your character, permanently. Only "cure" for it is to start a completely new game.

8. There is no "transfer all" option, when you want to transfer materials from your inventory to storage, you have to move each and every item separately, one by one, over and over again troughout the whole game.

9. "Ser" instead of "Sir". It's a small thing, but often small things are the ones that matter and can really annoy or/and hurt the immersion.

10. Another small thing but it's that moment where you just scratch yourself on the head. Whenever you change something in the settings, anything, even adjust game audio, when you press to 'save the changes', the game needs multiple seconds of loading to save them. Umm... what? Why it makes this game buffer?


I don't mean to $hit on the game or the developers, I say this because I care. Just... how those issues could've make it to the final product? How could those things not been fixed over the years?
I'm really disappointed... it could've been so much better. It's just hurtful to see something not live up to it's potential. Potential which is definitely here, but there are some very poor design choices and lack of patches.
Very nice game with new ideas. Hope we get a sequel.

Just recently I had finally played through the game - on PS3.  I would not recommend that approach in general even though it still plays fairly well on the platform.

On PC, it is much, much prettier of a game, and more stable.  On the original platform I typically ran into issues with the hardware trying to render particle effects for spells at the same time - which based on my build happened all the time.

As for the game itself...

It's still pretty unique, even today as far as action RPG's go.  There are some souls-like aspects (mainly restricted to the flow of combat) which would make some sense given the time it came out, but also borrows a lot from say Shadow of the Colossus in that they approach large scale enemies much differently from FromSoft.  Any enemy can be either grappled or climbed on, and in many cases it is required on a larger boss.  The weak spots are not exactly hidden most of the time, but it can add a level of interaction in the fights that is lacking from the usual 'sit behind the big boss and poke'-ness of say many Dark Souls encounters, something that the designers had pointed out themselves in interviews if I remember correctly.

The classes are also pretty interesting to dive into and encourage branching out into different builds to some degree.  There is some min-maxing of course to be had in being very specific in how you chose each class and when, but once you have access you can change your own class at any time and swap out skills.

One other nice unique feature is the pawns - a system for NPC management.  In the PS3 version, this was pretty limited as the servers have been down for ages.  However on PC it is still active, which makes it a lot easier to find better pawns.  The pawns are basically NPC's that other player's have sort of 'raised'.  You get your own initially, and this is the NPC then that other players can summon to help in their party (if I remember right to a total of 4 including your own character and main pawn).  The pawn comes geared with the same equipment and skill that the player had set on them.  They also learn battle tactics for different enemies and can shot out clues when encountering a given monster for a weakness to exploit.  You can both rate and give tribute to the original player for a pawn when leaving your party, or give items directly to the pawn - which you cannot take back if equipped.

Story wise the game is somewhat lean on the surface - as the main quests don't have a ton of depth to them except on the ends of the main archs.  This is fleshed out a bit more though in the side-quests, and also probably still has much more overt story than Dark Souls.  There are cut-scenes and such but don't go in expecting say Mass Effect or something along those lines.

Overall I really enjoyed it once I dug in, and would recommend to any who enjoys action RPG's.

There's undeniably some jank, but the fun so far outweighs it, I forgot about immediately.

I would pay no more than five dollars USD for this could have been fantastic game!  Oh, if only the programmers had the confidence in their product to let it stand on its own!

Dragon's Dogma is an action third person sword and sorcery game.  If you have played Monster Hunter, this game features Monster Hunter combat mechanics in a truly interesting dungeons and dragons realm.  Sound awesome?  It is!  Most encounters in the game benefit from the player learning how to use all of the new skills that they acquire on their way to level 200.  Then come the Quick Time Events (QTEs) and one hit kills. 

The one hit kills, I can forgive.  They are lazy, common enough conventions that are easily avoided for the most part.  But a QTE for the end vanilla boss?  HAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA.  

Anyway, the combat for most of the game is fun, the art style is top notch.  Pick it up for a fiver, run around in game and have a blast.  Just remember, when some NPC tells you it's time to kill the dragon, just turn off the game, uninstall, and say you did.

Haha, QTE for final boss.  Barf.  I hope that is a trend that stays in the grave.

P.S.  Remember when they released the base game for consoles?  CAPCOM charged $1.99 for haircuts as on disc DLC.

I dont often provide feedback to games, but when I do its because they are exceptional in one way or another. And dragons dogma does that and more. 

Beyond simply being a cult classic, dragons dogma is an experience in and of itself. Playing it can be rewarding, depending on what you want out of a game. 

Hilariously, The length of this game entirely depends on how much of a completionist you are. Ive sunk HOURS into this gaqme just destroying barrels for their contents (not all at once, mind you, but overall). If I see a destructable or a chest, I HAVE to open it. 

Lets talk some pros and cons!

Pros:

Engaging and unique gameplay
Unique follower system, allowing you to construct a pawn, and share that pawn with other players with a benefit to both

large, relatively open map that you can freely explore from minute one (Just beware of enemies throwing you around a bit)

MONSTER CLIMBING! It reminds me of shadow of the colossus in that you arent just hitting feet, The whole monsters can be hit, clung to, magicked upon, pinned with arrows. You name it.

The combat itself is very interesting and enjoyable, while also being mostly shrouded in secrecy. The game relies on learning how each monster functions, with hints sometimes being given by the pawns in your team. As those pawns get kills, their advice becomes more and more useful. Some mobs require planning and familiarity to beat, and a calm mind at that. 

Equally dark and humorous, the quests vary from being silly, to being downright MESSY and dark. And I love that juxtaposition. Its like if demon souls and shadow of the colossus had a baby. And that baby was then raised by elderscrolls. 

Cons: 

The story is MOSTLY walking. The first playthrough is much much slower than subsequent plays.

Combat can be trial and error, making sure you have the right team, the right weapons, the right skills, etc. It can be a lot to take in. 

You can sometimes die in one hit, however USUALLY you know why.

This is definitely an interesting and unique game. The game is quite difficult at first so saving often is basically required, but once  you gain some power killing all the bosses is quite fun.

The pawn system is interesting and cool. But it's not all rainbow and sunshine.

* There's A LOT of missable content. A lot of unique quest items are needed in multiple quests. You WILL miss content if you don't play with a wiki open.
* Some quests are quite obtuse - in many cases the is no quest marker or even a pointer in quest's description and you just can't know where exactly you gotta go and at what time of day.
* The main story is extremely forgettable besides the dragon threat looming over you. All I know is that there is a dragon and a duke.
* The pawns, while cool and all, are extremely frustrating sometimes. You can give them commands but they are so vague they might as well not exist. In some cases the pawns will do their best to not do what you might want them to do, like casting a powerful spell on an enemy. They will do anything - jump around, try to heal your 1 missing hp, follow you around so close they can smell your sweat, cast a long multi-step spell and then stop as enemies come closer (even though as a player you can forgo casting the last step, the pawns do not know this), but they will not do what you expect them to do - shoot at the enemy.
* There's definitive QoL issues and "CapCom-isms" that I despise - Game has 2 main menus for some reason when starting the game, and a "PRESS ANY KEY" screen on launch that has a long animation.
* A lot of unskippable cutscenes, especially for mundane things like pressing levels and boss intros.
* The game does have online server bullshit, although its optional and you can play offline. This is most frustrating when sleeping to change time of day - as sleeping is when you upload your pawn to the server in a lengthy 10-20 second long process.
* Keyboard controls are a mess. You cannot open quests or the map with a keybind - you gotta do it through main menu. Map controls are garbage. Using skills requires you holding and pressing multiple buttons.
* Without the DLC "Dark Arisen" the fast travel is extremely prohibitive - basically it's a consumable item and there's 2 fast travel points by default. You can create your own fast travel points, but their number is very limited. And it's a big problem considering how much you will be running around across the map. The DLC adds an infinite fast travel item, but the number of locations do not change.
* Stupidly the "Easy Mode" difficulty removes or hides many quests. Why the fuck is that even a thing.
* There's only one save slot, so save scumming is quite limited. This also means if you missed a quest, you cannot go back without restarting the whole game. Be expecting to lose significant progress due to some bullshit insta-kill enemies.

Some more cool stuff:
* You can re-customize your character at any moment, both class and looks
* There's an item duplication merchant with quest implications

The Dark Arisen DLC:

In my opinion is quite bad. I wouldn't hate it nearly as much if it wan't for the EXTREMELY frustrating "gatekeeper" bosses that are so spongy and require very specific tactics. I also think you are expected to complete it twice, and fuck that kind of game design. Other than that it's just a bunch of corridors and much harder enemies.

This DLC also gives you some overpowered armor that will be better than the stuff you get near the "post-game".

This game deserves way better. It was pushed out the door to compete with Skyrim, but that didn't stop the combat, character designer, or the unique climbing system from being the best I've ever seen.
Everyone should play this game just to experience what more modern RPGs are missing out on.

This is one my top 10 favorite games of all times. If you love swords, sorcery and intense combat, please try this. There are very few games that have a sense of danger. Exploring thick forests at night with only a lamp to find your way, while you can see shadows moving around you. The enemies are menacing, and it feels like a real victory once you defeat a dragon or other giant creatures. The pawn system is very unique and offers a lot of new things to learn and to try. Image having your own team where you are the hero, but pick a tank, a healer, an archer and so on to accompany you. Each pawn has their own combat style and personality, which makes them more like companions rather than disposable cannon fodder. The only thing I could hope for is a multiplayer option, but perhaps this will be an option in the future.

You can find much better reviews elsewhere, but here are some tips:

- you can hire friends' pawns for free
- the "From a Different Sky" quests in the Pawn's Guild basement can be a decent way to earn rift crystals if nobody's hiring your pawn; don't sell them, you can put them in storage, and retrieve them in NG+ to instantly solve the quests again
- check the steam guide for missable quests, cuz the games sure as hell doesn't warn you
- buy wakestone shards as often as possible
- there are more merchants in the game besides in the two towns
- carry some skeleton keys and airtight flasks on you just in case
- look up the pawn inclinations and what they do, and make sure you give your pawn the ones you want (there are clear favorites among the fanbase but YMMV)
- when you get to Gran Soren you can retrieve an Eternal Ferrystone, allowing fast travel to Cassardis and Gran Soren, and later any portcrystals you find and place yourself
- place your portcrystals near high-traffic/frequently visited areas to cut down on travel time (although, getting to know the world by traveling through it a lot is also a great experience if you don't mind it)

[h1] The very definition of a hidden gem [/h1]

Dragon's Dogma is an amazing game set in an immersive medieval fantasy world with visceral melee combat and powerful magic spells set alongside thrilling moments in intense battles.

After finishing Elden Ring, this game almost feels like spiritual predecessor. With it's large open world, there is much to explore and it does not hold your hand gently. Instead it teaches you many things the hard way. And without any guidance, the game can sometimes feel a bit gruelling.

Yet it still has it's own unique elements which make it stand out from other games, such as the pawn system and climbing onto monsters to target specific weak spots. The graphics are obviously far from next-gen, however for an older game it is still quite serviceable and holds up.

[h1] Aged like fine wine but perhaps not everyone's cup of tea [/h1]

This game is everything I wanted in a dark medieval-fantasy action RPG and I can't believe I've only just discovered it 10 years later from it's original release.

I previously did not recommend this game because the checkpoints are not great. After giving it a second chance, I think you should push through if you have any grievance about the game until at least you get into the habit of saving often to select retry instead of last checkpoint.

The game is very enjoyable but you can have a hard time to complete some quests about killing X numbers of specific monsters if you don't do it in the right order or if you don't sleep many times to reset some spawns.

I played as a Strider as almost everyone suggested and it was fun but I find the Skull Render to be just busted in comparison to every other attacks I tried.

Story is shallow and is made of what feels like mandatory filler sidequests, altho it gets good in the final act. I uderstand theres a theory of the king trying to kill you but I wished the story was more interesting before everything goes to shit.
Requires a lot of grinding
The world is a pain to navigate in with the worst fast travel mechanic Ive ever seen
The Grigori fight (dragon) boss sucks because of how hard to hit his weakspots are unless you use range attacks or the ballistas that go down in one hit and dont respawn.
The combat is cool but the lack of dodge, parry and block without a shield makes you a damage sponge
The color pallete is eye soring
The world feels dead, even the capital
Pawns are braindead, they cant dodge scripted boss attacks and they cant revive eachother which basically hinders the experience
Timed sidequests - THIS - this right here is so stupid and useless, baffles me how devs still include them
The OST is godlike

Overall 6/10 - Believe me, I will play DD2 and I hope it fixes a lot of stuff. I really tried to enjoy this game, I really did. Its not an "uNdErRaTeD gEm"
A great RPG that more people should play. Ignore the UI mess. Looking forward to DD2.

I really wish I could recommend this game, because it is very unique in many aspects and there are so many things in there that are so much fun, like climbing up on big monsters to stab them, which I've never seen like this in any game before.

Unfortunately this great game is buried beneath a very thick layer of both bad game design as well as bad UI/Ux design. The game's severely lacking in QoL features and at the same time offers many questionable design choices. Just to give a few examples:
The game does have a very limited autosave feature and relies on manual saves for most of your journey, a bit like Skyrim, but it not only lacks a quicksave/quickload feature, it's not even possible to just load an older save, directly from the escape menu. Instead you have to first quit to the title menu and then press "load game" from there, which then automatically loads your latest save. Also there's only one save file, which means you have to manually navigate to your save folder and make a backup of your current save game if you want to create a new character.
This kind of idiotic design is found throughout every aspect of the game. Be it game menus (map, equipment, journal) that cannot be accessed via hotkey but only via the escape key menu (with the exception of the inventory) or the map that shows basically nothing and is a nightmare to use.
Every menu is designed in such a convoluted way that takes you many more button presses/clicks than actually necessary which gets incredibly annyoing to use really quickly.


I'd say this game is a prime example of 2010s Capcom game design as those issues are found in almost all of their games of the last decade. Anyone who's played the older Monster Hunter games will know what I'm talking about. I'd say the roots of those design choices go back to the early resident evil games as the menu navigation of those games is very similar to what this game has. Thing is in RE you had a max of like 12 items to manage and very few other menus...here however you have a full party with each member being able to hold a ton of items in addition to the player character and that just doesn't work with such an oldschool inventory management approach.
Ultimately this whole thing is a constant struggle against the many quirks of the game that becomes really exhausting after a while, which is a shame cos I really wanted to explore more of this world, but I just can't.

That being said, I'd still recommend this game to anyone who isn't deterred by this kind of janky design because what lies underneath all that stuff is really friggin good.
yup

I played this game back when it came out on xbox 360. Maybe xbox one but I think it was the 360. Absolute banger. Combat was fun. Mounting monsters, combo-ing elements, dropping fucking METEORS on kids and getting slaves to follow you around and heal you or fight for you is just cool.

This is an exceptional game, many compare it to Skyrim and erroneously (I believe) say that it's better than Skyrim.
Here's my point by point comparison between the two:

Classes - winner Skyrim
Every class in Dark Arisen is OP eventually with the right end-game gear, but some are just painful to level up with, and you pretty much have to mix and match your leveling to build a decent character.

Quests - winner Dark Arisen
There's a bunch of kill X creatures types of quests, sure, but there are a lot of very interesting quests with backstory that give the game depth.

Equipment - winner Skyrim
Seriously in Dark Arisen gear (except end game) is all but meaningless. I always just vendor everything I get. I don't even try to check the armor stats any more because I know it will always be worse than the gear that you're given for free when you choose your vocation. You will buy a weapon from Gran Soren, and that will be about it. You will just level it up a bit.

Crafting - hands down Skyrim
Dark Arisen is absolutely terrible at this. Most people don't even bother with it except to make certain arrows, or stamina potions. It's a complete waste for the most part. 

Game Mechanics - Skyrim
Dark Arisen's UI is clunky. For example, to switching from special arrows to normal arrows requires you to go into your inventory screen and select the arrows that you're currently using, and unequip them. There's no hotkey or anything for that.

Storyline - Dark Arisen
I won't ruin anything, but Dark Arisen did a much better job of putting together an interesting storyline.

Magic - Skyrim
Spells take FOREVER to cast in Dark Arisen, and targeted spells like healing are nearly impossible to aim properly. Fortunately your pawns can do it as if they were born to it, but good luck trying to heal your party yourself. Now the spells in Dark Arisen are sick, powerful and fun, don't get me wrong. You're just going to find yourself getting your face bashed in a lot instead of getting spells launched due to the insane casting times. You can multi-class to mitigate the interruption problem though.

Played Dragon's Dogma for about 5 hours today. 
This is a very rambling note I just wrote to a friend, but I think it details some things well.
Very interesting game. A lot like Skyrim. Quests, companions, mines to explore, leveling. Learning curve is different. One weird thing I had to learn is that Warriors get special skills for sword and hammer but they are all under the sword tab. Like, I have a ring of swords, only, I don't use a sword, I use a huge hammer. In this game, sword = hammer and vice versa. You just go with it.
Skills are the same, like slashing strike, with a hammer. Upward thrust, but with a hammer.
You start out and make your guy and then it has a pawn system. You make essentially a traveling companion that has their own AI. I made a healer/mage named Wendy. When you level up you can go to an inn and buy new skills. There's no new stats that I can find. You just get better spells or better skills. And you do this for your lone personal companion too. They loot for you, heal you, cast lightning, randomly talk about the area or shout "Goblins!"
A bit later you can rent pawns. I rented 2 magic users that do the same as your personal companion, but you can't adjust skills or armor or anything on them. They have their own dialogue, loot, help you in combat but require no input from you.
The graphics are both simple, yet extraodinary. My three mages are all blasting spells all the time in battle.
You have one save. You can save any time, but if you say, start new game, that save is gone. You can''t ever go back. If you want to go back to save before you were thrown in jail, nope.
Travel is a bit terrible, night is the same, all surmountable.
Dark Arisen is essentially when they ported the game to PC, so you get an Eternal Ferry Stone that will port you back to one of two major cities from anywhere, any time.
I had a quest to clear out a mine of three Ogres. TERRIFIC battle. Took me like 90 minutes to finally win.
Good times.
I did almost quit for like 3 hours but now I'm hooked.
I just bought the wrong things after I discovered I needed to level up Wendy and then found a tab I didn't see earlier with the things I should have bought. So, something to drive me forward to go out and get her some more levels.. But I didn't know I had to do that for 10 levels so she will be much more powerful now.
I came into a town and there is very sexy woman standing next to a monastery. She has on a bikini and a sword on her back. She is level infinite and you can hire her for 3 million gold.
This game is both clunky and unique and has wonderful little touches, like how the ogre grabbed one my mages, leaped off a ledge and then ran off with her.
Clunky, like in the swords/hammer thing, and don't expect a lot of random weapons, I've found very few. And maybe you get a higher level class later, but right now, being a warrior means I have access to swords and hammers. Bows too I think. But there aren't like claws or tridents or atgeir or exotic weapons.
I don't think I was clear earlier. I can't select or direct Wendy in combat. The only time I can interact with her character at all is at the inn to buy new skills. You're not controlling 2 characters. Just you.
Thought I should clarify as I don't really like making up a party of 6 and managing their attacks, weapons, gear, attacks, etc. So, I like that I can have a party - but it's just me I'm directing.
Very fun game once you wrap your head around it.

Finally picked this up this year after hearing a lot of hype about it and it sitting in my library for a matter of years. I want to keep this review short and just share a few things. 

The game is really good, but it may take a bit of time before you realize that or appreciate it. I didn't become what I would consider to be truly familiar with a lot of the games systems and intricacies until about 8 hours of gameplay. On the grand scale of a big RPG that obviously isn't a ton, but for some people that could be what they expect out of an entire game. 
There's really a LOT on offer here. Just so much meat in nearly every aspect of its gameplay. The writing and dialogue is pretty weak, but every other facet of the game shines, especially the plethora of post-game content. Speaking of post-game... My advice: don't do Bitterblack Isle until after you complete the main quest at minimum.

It took me a while to get into this one. It is pretty boring until you get to a decent level and get better equipment. I would say around the 20 hour mark things start to get more interesting. The pros far outweigh the cons. I played this in October of 2022 and I strongly recommend it even at its regular price.

Overall Thoughts
* semi open world
* JRPG disguised as western RPG
* leveling and upgrading is addicting
* spend a fair amount of time in menus
* some level scaled areas

Pros
* good story
* fun and fairly intuitive combat
* snappy and responsive controls
* overall decent visuals
* you can climb the large enemies
* pawn system means you get to rotate your party members a lot 🙂
* pretty epic boss fights
* plays nicely with keyboard and mouse
* companion AI isn’t half bad

Cons
* sometimes textures look bad
* somewhat empty world
* crafting is not intuitive
* fast travel is very limited
* pawn system means you have to rotate your party members a lot ☹️
* because of the pawn system, sometimes you don’t feel that invested in 2/4 of your party members

Dragon's Dogma combines a number of different games into one very bad overall package. It may be a product of its time, and if so it has not aged well at all.

Dragon's Dogma is an open world RPG. You create your character and class and march off into the world talking to NPCs, doing quests, leveling up, and eventually beating the big-bad-guy. This is absolutely nothing new, so how does Dragon's Dogma distinguish itself?

If you take a little of Dark Souls, DMC/God of War, Monster Hunter, MMORPGs, and Skyrim you'll have an idea of what you're in for; but just a bad version of all of that. It has the combat pacing and speed of DMC without the depth. It has the stamina/health system of Dark Souls without the atmosphere and tight combat. You have the big Monster fights of Monster Hunter but without any of the preparation or complexity. And then you have MMORPG quests without any Player Characters to make those quests any fun.

Much is lauded about the Pawn system. And I can actually agree on paper it's very unique. While you create one player character, you also create one follower. Those 2 toons are permanent and never change. You can then hire 2 mercenaries ("Pawns"), which are actually characters created by other people that are uploaded to the Dragon's Dogma server. Hiring the different classes to help suit whatever encounter you are doing is a great idea. In practice you'll just stick with whatever class you're missing and trundle off. Moreover, because these are essentially generated characters and not characters that exist in the world, they have essentially no personality and you don't care at all if they die, since you'll just pull new ones off the cloud server anyway.

If you've heard the story is lacking, you'd be right. NPCs wander around aimlessly. You'll have no interesting dialogue with anyone, and certainly no tough choices or moral dilemmas. NPCs are just quest givers, again, as if this was an MMORPG. The world itself is both small but tedious to navigate. Monsters respawn at whim, and the lack of a horse/vehicle to travel around means you'll be walking and sprinting everywhere, ever mindful of your stamina bar. This is compounded by the complete lack of knowing how difficult any quest is. You really have no idea if any given quest is something you can achieve at your level. You'll plod off in the general direction, get destroyed, and have to limp back home and pick a different quest. This is made more exacerbating by the save system. While you can save anywhere, it doesn't save automatically, and you can't save in combat. Falling 3 meters can be lethal, but even when you learn to avoid that if you find yourself stuck in a bad encounter and forgot to save, you better hope you can run away or you'll have to reload from however long ago that was. Normally, you can just quick saves in games like this, but well....

This is very obviously a console port. Menus are terrible, inventory bloat is annoying, and saving your game requires 3 submenus instead of F5. Graphically it's dated the way games that try to realistic often do. Lighting & shadow effects are very poor and character models are hideous. Animations however do look good and the big set piece boss fights are impressive. 

I was already dreading playing this game after 4 hours, and after 8 hours i had to call it quits after the [spoiler]Water Altar[/spoiler], so my experience is only up to level 20 or so. The thought of another 20 levels is simply too excruciating to bare.
Still a fun experience in 2022! Approx. 100 hours to 100%.

I really tried to give this game a chance. I tried playing it twice on Xbox 360 and one other time on PC and stopped about 2 hours in because I couldn't get into it. Now I finally sat down to really play this and after nearly 40 hours in and I can safely say this is one of the most overrated games I've ever played. The combat is bad unless you're fighting a big monster. The fact there isn't a lock-on is a CRIME. The world is big and boring, the upgrade system is a joke because there's just way too much junk you can pick up in your inventory and it gets so cluttered you barely know what is useful and what you can sell. 90% of the quests are either kill X amount of monster or escort an NPC to a place. Play Dark Souls or Skyrim or Dragon Age instead. Also towards the end the game started crashing and bugging out when the Duke let me into the treasury and now it won't load at all. It's cursed and I wasn't meant to finish it. NEVER AGAIN
Honestly the most underrated game ever made, its a must play

Awesome gameplay, disappointing ending.

I really loved this game. It felt like a classic dragon RPG with cool real-time combat. At the beginning of the game you're thrown into intense combat and it's awesome. The monsters are cool and really intimidating. I love clambering up giant cyclops to get their helmet off. It's fun finding the weaknesses of different creatures.

The plot was interesting, but the end was really disappointing to me. No spoilers here, but I felt there was a lot of build-up in the story for an unsatisfying end.

Still worth the purchase. Remains a really fun game. If the story was better I would be recommending this to my family and friends.

very nice

+ the feeling of being an adventurer questing around the world to explore and get rich and powerful - unfortuantely the quests themselves are uninspired
+ some monster combat encounters are cool. I really liked chopping hydra's heads off
+ well-built overworld and decent dungeon crawling (especially The Dark Arisen Dungeon)
+ pawns pick loot from the ground, so you don't have to... when they feel like it

+/- pawns existence makes you not feel so lonely, which is common in open world games. Unfortunately from the beginning you see them more as bots than as people. Even the lore doesn't see them as humans.
+/- janky, mostly because it attempts to do a lot of pretty original stuff - have you even seen a piece of meat that is burnt on the outside and raw inside? that's how this game feels like
+/- you can change the class almost effortlessly, but it it's not a reset - the stats you gained on one class carry over, so you can break your character if you want to min-max

- UI is obviously terrible
- encumbrance management makes sure that you don't forget how terrible the UI is
- there is too much running through the same locations over and over again
- story goes nowhere - there are characters, an overarching narrative, but it's barely an afterthought. I would actually say that there is no story, just "story bits" here and there. Like taking a 1000 pages script and picking 50 pages at random - would this be a coherent story? Sometimes, but mostly not. You don't get a chance to get attached to anything. The one question that was constantly on my mind was "but why?" and there was never any answer. No one even asked the question.
- difficulty is all over the place. The difficulty comes from two sources - spongy enemies and huge damage spikes, which come in the endgame. There can be no other type of difficulty since you can quaff litres of healing potions in an instant (TES-like). The most difficult enemies I encountered in the game? Not dragons, cyclops or hydras. These are easy. But a bunch of tanky wolves shooting fireballs... or this one enemy `spawning the same wolves in infinite quantities`. The biggest issue are the staggers...
- being unable to move my character because of staggers and stun locks started to be really annoying. There seemed to be no answer. Wolves are the worst and I just gave up in the middle of The Dark Arisen Dungeon, since I got bored and wasn't looking forward to more of the same (haven't finished the main story, but I think I was close)


It's not a great game, but it's not a bad one either. In the end I choose to give a negative, since the "Very Positive" rating at the time of review is too generous. If you don't mind the jank and pointless story then by all rights - try it out.
Fun game , played over 470 hours.

I really like the character development, story (which starts as a typical RPG type, but gets [i] interesting [/i] towards the end), quests, surprises/twists and the pawn system. On the down side combat mechanics are sometimes challenging, and inventory management is way underdeveloped.  Personally, I found the game to be very immersive and thoroughly fun over multiple play-throughs. Goes on sale occasionally so try to grab it when it does, but I consider this a must play if you're into RPGs.

An excellent action RPG.
It took me 5-10 hours to truly get into it, but I'm glad I didn't give up.
There isn't that much variety in terms of monsters and locations, but most monsters are quite well designed and are fun to fight against.
While the game would probably be good enough without it, the pawn system is clearly what sets it apart from its competition the most. In short: the game is meant to be played as a 4-men party where one is the player, one is the player's pawn, and the other two are other players' pawns. A pawn is a character that you build alongside your main char that is controlled by the AI and supports you during the game. You can customize its class, skills, looks and even its ai. Pawns can learn how to fight specific enemies and also give you hints during quests. Having 3 AIs with different behaviours and skills, that you probably will have to rely on a lot if you're a purely physical or magical fighter, makes for very dynamic and memorable battles.
I love this game a lot but the pawns are really dumb.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing
this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My
son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed
it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the
week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as
it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my
son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching
YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this
game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the
game, made my character and world and started playing but I
was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son
for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was
the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died.
This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again
and now we actually spend time together outside the house
together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be
had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many
happy memories.

I bought this on a whim, then I dropped it and forgotten about it. 3-4 years later in 2022, I picked it back up and found myself enjoying this GOLDEN gem of a game more than I thought I would.

Reminds me of Skyrim, but better.

The story follows a number of similar beats; game opens, dragon attacks, your story begins, you travel to Gran Soren (Whiterun), Griffin attacks, you join guards to slay monster, whitebeards are on vacation so you meet with hobo in Stonehenge, and blahblahblah slay dragon blahblahblah.

The dragon is basically Alduin, but scary.  If I recall the Alduin fights correctly, you just yell at him a few times, he lands, you whack away, and he dies.  The dragon in this game, however, challenges you to either sacrifice a life to make him go away, or face him in battle; he then has this huge, crazy build-up as he chases you throughout an ancient ruin, taunting you all the while; then you have an epic (and challenging) final battle against an overpowered opponent, and... the game doesn't end.  There's more to the story!

Duke Edmun is like Jarl Balgruuf, but interesting.  He is said to be the previous "Arisen" (basically, bootleg dragonborn), who previously slew the dragon.  For much of the story, you run fetch quests for him, and then spoilers happen.  Sorry, not spoiling!

Then you have the game's "vocation" (read as class) system, which you can change at any time.  Almost.

Plus, there's a good variety in enemies, as opposed to just bandits and draugr.  Much more interesting.

10/10, would play Not-Skyrim again.

outright my favorite ARPG. I love the pawn system being able to make your pawn then filling out the other 2 slots with other players pawns is cool not to mention how they are somewhat smarter than other npc party members. Another point i love is how strong all the vocations i have used feel.
Controls are a bit wonky early, but you get somewhat used to them. It's a good old RPG with decent story.

There are some good bits, but the negatives and QOL issues made me abandon it. The world is interesting, there's some great storylines, but... 

- Travel takes forever, fast travel is gated behind rare materials
- Quest's didn't always trigger properly, eg quest givers still asked for the quest to be undertaken while I held the items required to fulfil the quest
- Inventory... or rather what inventory?
- Loot is sparse, which means equipment was hard to get, plus step change PvE difficulties meant lots of dying and VERY long walks
It's a gem, play it. Goes on sale for dirt cheap all the time.

The action combat of this game is fantastic. The ability to climb large foes is a great idea, but the implementation is slow and clunky. This game requires some patience to get into, so don't come into it expecting an easy start.

Between PS3, PS4, Nintendo Switch, and PC, i have played this game game for upwards of 3k hours.
I got 100% trophies on ps3, ps4, and pc.

Graphics-For being 10 years old, the graphics still hold up.
They aren't the best on the market but they play into the game so well. even to today's standards they are good.
8/10

Audio-The Music, Sound effects, and voice acting.
The music fits the theme of the game very well, the music during combat is exciting and ends leaving you feeling triumph with every boss fight. The music during cut scenes set the mood so well every time, supporting in the best way.
The voice acting is the most amazing, and you can often times hear loops of the same dialog over once in a while.
give the guy who plays jester a raise.7/10

Gameplay- Dark Souls meets Monster Hunter. on the easier difficulties and early areas, this game is very welcoming, you only really fight goblins, wolf, and the occasional bandit. None of them prove to difficult, or to easy the pacing is well.
But as you draw further into the game you find more difficult enemies.. or more difficult areas to fight enemies.
Something as simple as a cyclops can slap you off the face of a cliff ending your life, Making every fight with a large enemy or boss very rewarding. Knowing you can best enemies no matter the circumstances.
At higher difficulties and at end game, The enemies are ruthless, and unforgiving. you can find yourself in a situation of dying over and over if you dont play the fight just right.
The Climbing mechanic is okay, its not amazing, but its also not terrible. it leaves a lot open for creativity, but you dont miss to much by not using it.9/10

The Loot/Gear- Finding equipment to use early on is.. well it isn't, the equipment you can buy is slightly expensive to justify early on but can be done.. That being said, finding equipment comes at a good pace. You aren't SO reliant on gear early on. 
When you do find a new weapon or armor piece, it feels so gratifying. this does reward people who like to explore every single nook and cranny, and people who like to do every single quest.
95% of the gear looks amazing and feels great. and for the other 5% you don't even notice it long enough to matter.7/10

Trophies- A large portion of the trophies you get by just having fun playing the game.
But if you're looking for all 100%, be prepared to stab out your eyeballs.
There is a never ending list of quests that require you to run errands, stand around waiting, or preform tasks that have no relevance anywhere else. 
None of them are really that hard, and only a few are really time consuming so don't be scared going into that.8/10

Customization-Character creation is pretty unique, as your choices effect actual stats and mechanics in the game, though not enough to make anything unplayable or not viable.
Not to much to say here, maybe 7/10.

NewGame+. This game is heavily influenced by newgame+, Your fast travel is better and better with each play through making it worth to speed run the game 1-2 times before setting out on uncovering the map and hitting everything. Newgame+/10

Class System- There is a slew of classes, from your generic fighter/archer/Mage. But also with creative hybrids.
They all have their own unique play style, and they are all viable. Play whats most fun to you they all are great.
8/10 


The pawn system- I could write a novel here but instead im just gonna say, if you want to know about it read someones guide or something. I just throw my pawns off a cliff and play solo so i dont have to hear them blabbering. Rook/10


Final Thoughs.
As far as a single player rpg goes, this really is cream of the crop in my eyes. It does so many things so right, and so different in the best way possible. It rewards creative play style and thinking. all around very polished.8.5/10

10 years after its release, not one studio has managed to present magic quite like DDDA. The incantation mechanic is a stroke of genius: of course, the most powerful spells will take a long time to cast, but that only makes the end product that much satisfying. Playing this game makes you feel like a sorcerer, while magic in most other games are, by comparison, throwing fireballs around while rolling in the dirt.

Truly plays like a DND camapaign, the tropey cutscenes and your pawns carrying your unconcious allys to saftey, climbing chimeras multiple times to stab them in the face. Versatility of different classes and thier movesets.
10/10 my favourite game of all time, such joy it brings to my heart

If you like having every class in the game feel wholly unique and enjoy interesting mechanics, I'd suggest picking it up.

It's entertaining when you have nothing else to play, you can tell it's heart was in the right place and it is VERY interesting, but you can tell this was made for people who LIKE to be challenged over simple things. 
            My biggest hang up is there are no Mounts and the only ability to fast travel is those stupid portcrystals that are in limited supply. They are heavy, so you can only take a few at a time, and you have to have already been to the place to put them down where you want to come back. It's not like other games where you can just discover it and you can fast travel later. In fact, other games reserve that for HARDCORE MODE but this game has that bullshit on EASY! Also, every single time, you have to defeat the same enemies on the way to your destination over and over again EVERY SINGLE TIME!
           There's even one enemy where you are NOT supposed to defeat it and by the time you find out, your potions are used up, your party is dead and you're going to die by whatever is waiting for you next. That enemy is the Black Chimera. 
       There is another wild card enemy called the Cockatrice where the first time you encounter it, the game waits to tell you until the LAST POSSIBLE MOMENT that you need to get special potions or else it will Petrify you to death.....but the town, which includes the ONLY APOTHECARY WHO HAS THEM is closed off due to the attack from this thing. It's like they were purposely trying to be irritating! I had to lose about 2 hours of game progress to go back to a check point and stock up, which included 4 gathering quests that I had to do over and turn in. 
       WIth all that said, the game is visually stunning, the lore is fascinating, and the combat itself is pretty well thought out. It could use more detail with how you command your pawns, besides Come, Help, and Go. I wish I could give them specific orders like "Mage, Attack the Lion's head, Rogue, Climb the snake to chop off the head, Tank, keep the Goat head distracted so the mage doesn't get whacked." 
         I also like how you can change your class through the game, but I highly recommend NOT doing that until your vocation is completely maxed out, and max out your new one BEFORE you get to a key point in the game. 
         All things considered, this is a good game to pass the time, while not perfect. You can tell the developers worked erroneously hard to make something different but still stay true to the type of games they loved and enjoyed for inspiration.

It's a very enjoyable game I would 100% recommend, especially to people who love the RPG genre like myself. Found it when I was looking for a good Elder Scrolls alternative and I was impressed by it all. However, I depart my first playthrough with mixed feelings.

-I love the concept and the story was intriguing throughout. 
-The pawn system is a unique way of having a customisable follower and I adore this game for that. 
-The fact that you can change class for both yourself and your main pawn is brilliant and more games need the variety that this has.
-Every fight against a monster feels high stakes and challenging and even if the battle lasts half an hour, it has felt tense and exciting throughout. However, one or two of the bosses have felt a little underpowered for how much they were built up, such as [spoiler] against the Seneschal and Salomet [/spoiler].
-The customisation of your character and your main pawn is extensive, few games do it as well as I think DD has done. 
-The armours all look brilliant and you could reasonably play with armour that is very much sub-optimal and still have a good time. The customisation is again impeccable.

I would definitely recommend finishing the game, including all the post-Dragon content, and seeing the story fully end. The lore and the story behind the whole ending is brilliant and I aspire to that level of interesting world-building but despite this, the ending felt a little unsatisfactory to me, no matter which path you choose. This has made me a little reluctant to replay and clean up all the quests I didn't complete the first time, though I will come back again for another play, as it is, honestly, a really good RPG all things considered.

Completely recommend playing, I loved it.
