I have conflicting feelings about this game. I do recommend it: basically because it is a masterpiece, although I have to say that I hoped it would have aged better. It is heavily conceived for console and it becomes very odd to play in 2022. The controls are horrible and the game has excessive loading screens.

Leaving aside the poor adaptation for PC, the game itself is a masterpiece for being such an old game, although today, having played countless other games, it becomes very strange to follow and get into the plot. In addition, the IA is not as clever as you may guess. The menus are pretty awful and hard to understand, player customization is very limited, and the story is pretty simple. However, it adds some interesting stuff and mechanics (reputation, crafting, etc) that makes the game interesting.

I do think it has to be in any bookstore for having marked a milestone in history, although it is not easy to play nowadays. If you have the change, get the music DLC, it's a masterpiece.

The sound mixing is simply atrocious. It's the second time I tried getting into the game I just can't get past it. The voice acting is bad but the mixing makes it ten times worse. You essentially have a party of 3 npcs and they keep sprouting useless information and speaking over one another. 
As other reviews have pointed out the combat is the main focus and I can see it even with my limited play time. It's fun climbing on enemies I'll admit but sometimes you can clip right through the texture. Also through the game assets. I would see a ladder and try to climb it only to pass through it like a ghost. This game has a rare talent to break my immersion but maybe it's a personal thing.

Tengo +300 horas en Nintendo Switch de este gran Juego y básicamente lo tengo en PS3,PS4,NS,STEAM, es uno de los 5 juegos single player más adictivos que he jugado (Skyrim, Xenoblade X, Elden Ring, FFXII).

Hasta ahora no hay un juego que entregue lo que este juego hace:

- Combate ágil versatil con muchas armas distintas y habilidades (el cambio de arco a espada por ejemplo no es igualado en ningún otro rpg que haya jugado
- Variedad de enemigos para usar esas habilidades, incluidos pequeños goblins hasta grandes dragones.
- Variedad de armaduras (Fashion Dogma) desde las armaduras más gruesas hasta las bikini armors este juego ofrece una de las más robustas personalizaciones en cualquier single player RPG game.
- Companions: un "pawn" que puedes personalizar como gustes y dos adicionales que puedes obtener directamente de otros jugadores que también diseñaron su pawn. Este sistema incrementa el sentido de aventura en equipo y lo lleva más lejos que Skyrim donde solo puedes tener un compañero sin MODs. 
- Diseño de calabozos, el equipo se esforzó en hacer los calabozos experiencias immersivas y no cuevas copy paste.
- Sistema de mejora de armas que alientan al adictivo grind, lo cual en este juego es un placer gracias a su gran gameplay.


No todo es genial, lamenteblamente:

- La Historía es presentada de una forma poco pregnante así como el worldbuilding parece pulido a medias.
- Lo anterior pega también a las interacciones con los npc que tampoco terminan de cuajar.
- Las gráficas ya están algo obsoletas sobre todo en el cabello de los personajes así como los rostros
- Hubiera sido genial poder cambiar de arma o clase "on the fly" y no tener que ir al menú o a un Inn a hacer los respectivos cambios.
- Un modo Online hubiera sido genial.
- El sistema de pawns es genial pero también hace que estos personajes sean genéricos y no tienen una personalidad real que pudo haberse arreglado con más compañeros predefinidos en la historia.
- El sistema de fast travel es limitado.

Al final los pros superan por mucho a las contras, espero que en la secuela todos estos issues se arreglen

This game makes use of the videogame medium like no other. Games are replayable, social, and explorable. Dragon's Dogma utilizes these idiosyncrasies perfectly in the best game of this decade filled with thrilling combat, lore, and humor. 

[b]replayability[/b]
Most games include New Game+ as an extra, but Dragon's Dogma’s story is told in an infinite cycle. If you like to minmax, make unique characters, collect all the fashion items, unlock all the crafting recipes, pursue your one true Beloved, or just analyze a rich story and setting, you will replay the game many times. Initially, bandits will be nearly impossible to fight, but your character will be mowing through them before NG+. However, there will be a few challenges even after a NG+ or two in the main campaign. Bitterblack Isle and the Ur-Dragon, will be challenging even at max level. Nothing besides your personal ability stops you from entering any area or facing anything, though.

[b]single-player with optional pawn trading[/b]
This is a single-player game with online connectivity. (Offline with pre-made pawns is always an option.) As the Arisen, you will have complete control over the development of one fully-customizable party member known as a Pawn. It will fight by your side, learn from the behaviors you exhibit (if you loot everything, your pawn will learn to loot everything), study monsters through battle, and automatically be hireable for RC by other players to benefit from your training. If that other player shows your Pawn a new strategy, it will bring the new information home. The Pawn system also allows for reviewing with helpful/funny preset comments and trading via gifts. This way, you can actually earn recognition for the Utilitarian/Challenge pawn with a Triple-Dragonforged Delta Guard. 

[b]exploration[/b]
I’m still learning things after hundreds of hours across platforms! The map is big and extends far beyond the scope of the story. It also has a lot of hidden verticality for bizarrely competent platforming. The From a Different Sky quests really highlight this feature. If you like lore and story, Dragon’s Dogma has an inexhaustible amount of lore to investigate. The setting of Gransys has a rich history, evidenced in the variances of architecture, quest and NPC dialogue, and the costumes of the other Arisens. The characters are all interdependent and political. 

Many people accuse the game of having minimal story. It’s true that the main story line dialogue is [i]mostly[/i] to-the-point about you being an undead hero of prophecy come to rid the land of an ancient dragon (or just run some errands for the Duke who wishes to delay you at all costs). However, dig deeper into their motivations and relationships, and there is definitely plenty of story. They don't spell everything out for you.

[b]best combat ever, easily in line with Monster Hunter or Dark Souls[/b]
Today, my Arisen oiled the wings of a Griffon with arrows, and grasped onto its legs as it lifted from the ground to flee. Holding on for dear life as the Griffon was gaining altitude, my Arisen gained a firm grip and drove fiery daggers into the beast’s flesh until both its wings were set ablaze. She rode the burning griffon to the ground where her pawns finished it off. I was so scared the whole time that I’d lose my grip. That wasn’t even a quest, just a random encounter. 

[b]romance[/b]
Dragon’s Dogma subverts the Damsel in Distress cliché. The Arisen can be male or female, and the “damsel” can be nearly any NPC in the game. By any, I mean you can seriously accidentally get married to gross old men, pre-married women, and children. There are tricks to getting who you want, but something always seems to go wrong and you end up with Fournival or Caxton as your Beloved. It lends some anticipation for the climax cutscene. 

[b]ridiculous people[/b]
The characters are as ridiculous as the dialogue. The cast includes a foreign rich girl who pretends to be a knight, an overly flirtacious girl who opens a shop with access to an exclusive master weaponsmith through unreturned favors, a villager who pretends to be an adventurer only to die along the easiest paths (voiced by Vic Mignogna no less! haha!), a rarity trader who frequents the local counterfeiter, [spoiler]the dreamy Night’s Champion[/spoiler], and so many others.

In short, buy this game immediately. You are missing out every second you don't!

Fans already know, but for the rest of us this is a hidden gem! Hack'n'slash combat not unlike Dragon Age: Inquisition, with giant, multi-stage monsters like Elden Ring, in a dark and unforgiving world that requires discretion and preparation like the Witcher. Graphics are ten years old but hold up quite well thanks to fantastic art and world design. Story isn't the most compelling but wandering the countryside stumbling on dungeons is way more fun anyway. Tons of content and you can expect dozens and dozens of hours of gameplay. 

It also runs really well on the Steam Deck with just a couple of minor issues (no audio in a couple cutscenes, some cloth doesn't always render properly). Default settings and 30 FPS cap work great; smooth gameplay and reasonable battery life even under load.

(Note my play time is much higher than listed as I was playing offline on a Steam Deck)
You'll be hard pressed to find another game like this until DD2 comes out.  Refreshingly unique, this game will always hold a special place in my heart.

Some quests are still annoying, but these games all have that in whatever you play.

This is one of those games that deserve a "maybe" recommendation. It's commonly compared with "Skyrim" because it's an open world (although kinda linear in places) RPG in a fantasy medieval setting in which you create a character from scratch and follow a questline involving a dragon. 

It's a less ambitious and more limited game than "Skyrim", but has way better combat (although not as good as the one in "Dark Souls", the game that made "Skyrim" obsolete). It would be toppled by the likes of "The Witcher 3" and "Kingdom Come: Deliverance", but it's still playable today. 

Story and characters are not memorable, but there are some cool boss fights, like the hydra, the chimera, the ogre, the golem, the griffin and, of course, the dragon. The map is not that interesting and exploration is not fulfilling; combat gets older eventually and I gave up on the game after defeating the dragon _ the "post game" portion seemed like a huge grind and I felt I was done. 

I hope the sequel surpasses this a lot in terms of quality; if the developers just make a bigger game with better graphics, without improving the gameplay or the plot and characters, it'd be a shame.

TL/DR : Steam told me this game is similar to Skyrim but for every single thing this game try to overdo Skyrim, sadly it screwed several times over.

I'll start with the obvious, pawn system - the Skyrim equivalent of follower.
Game lets you borrow two, plus one permanent customable pawn. You design it to your own liking, other borrow if they need, and it's the greatest selling point of this game for me. Until I realize the AI is so messed up.

AI casters tend to spam HIGHEST spell like meteor swarm, lasting 15-20 seconds under constant threat and may accomplish NOTHING. Because small fries like goblin die in 2 seconds, and a sneeze from sub-bosses interrupts casting.

And it's frustrating that some spells literally fill your entire screen, including healing spells. It gets worse in end game hard mode when healing could take 20 seconds and 1 hit from sub-bosses puts you back.

Furthermore, AI casters may cast spells in MELEE range. The combat range is really short. In comparison, Skyrim's AI is not much better but the spells aren't interruptible and have very short cast time.

Also, fortunately in Skyrim they don't have huge ass cyclops/gorecyclops swinging literally five/fifteen metres hammer, hitting everything in the process, including your poor mage pawn who should be a dead, dead weight by now. Pun intended.

And unfortunately, you can't get rid of the mage, because some enemies (read : enemies, not bosses) are immune to physical.

The game is balanced around four characters, unless you spam periapts of cheese.
Therefore you, the only human, have to nit-pick mages, summoning 5 each time, from a laundry list of mages. Because they need correct inclination (AI behavior), otherwise no matter how godly the gear/skillset is, it's busted.

So some people feels compelled to play a mage, as the moron among us is better than the AI.

To make it worse, the upgrade system requires, you, not your pawn, to wear the gear you want to upgrade, and kill any type of dragon (drake, wyrm, wyvern).

This process they name it : dragonforged. It was novel and awesome until it is a problem because some gear can't be worn unless you're the correct class, or gender.

The gender isn't a problem unless you want to dress your follower, ahem, half naked.

But the class is a problem.
Because if you play a mage, you might want a fighter/warrior pawn to tank. And you can't wear warrior gear.

So you ended up going back and forth swapping pawns and changing class, available only in cities/towns -only to suffer your patience tested. Because you're invested as mage, your physical stats are lacking, your physical skills are lacking - so you rely on moron AI.

Fortunately, game is really forgiving when you messed up your build - otherwise it would be terrible since multi save is not possible, back up save does not exist some side quests fail if you progress main quest.

Ultimately after continuously harassed by your ultimate archenemy, death itself, and grinding yourself to max level, max gear, and you fight him on equal term, your pawn goes apeshit and HE FLEES. If this is not infuriating then I don't know what infuriating is.

IN MY OPINION :
Dragon's Dogma could have been a mainstream, comparable to Skyrim, but never did, because it's drained down by boatload of issues.

Some of them is literally trivial, such as spell description missing basic necessity like stamina cost, damage modifier, cast time and only has vague explanation like "summon a pillar of ice blah blah".

Saw a guy upgraded his pawn's meteor storm only to rant. Because the upgraded version took 50% longer to cast, on an already long cast time, in which he probably have finished his coffee when the spell came.

Going for the thumbs down despite having 124 hours in this game, cleared hard mode, level 200, plenty of enjoyable moments, because when I'm buying something I always find thumbs down most helpful in finding deal-breakers.

Boring quests, awful lighting, spells blinding, can't remember the last time I saw a less engaging story, OBNOXIOUS stamina system, painfully awkward walk cycles, exploration feels pointless, just small roads between separate zones, AWFUL enemy scaling and balance in the early game. Every enemy is beatable sure, but my GOD is it obnoxious to hit random enemy and see literally no change in their health bar, and then just sit there smacking them while they 2 shot stagger you, and constantly one shot your pawns, and you just run back and forth between your pawns resurrecting them as they basically fight the enemy for you while you hit them as much as you can, hoping the enemy doesn't accidentally notice or hit you and instantly kill you. From lizards to bandits with more health than most dark souls bosses, to 2 dozen wolves that just flee, leap and down you, flee, leap and down you, I've never encountered more obnoxious enemies in any game. Doable? sure. Fun? Fuck off with that. Gets better later? Cool, explain why the beginning has to be awful? No seriously, why is it necessary for the beginning to be genuinely trash? No? No actual reason? Cool, gonna uninstall and play literally anything else. Playing DS2 and 3 at SL 1 with only starting equipment is more balanced and fun. Not even joking, it's genuinely more fun. Also, WORST stamina travel system.

If you're here because you've heard endless praise, I'm hear to remind you that Avatar also made over a billion dollars, there's definitely been zero drops in quality for pokemon games, the Kardashians are apparently worth worshiping, and homeless people apparently just don't want to work for a living. Not everything a large group of people say and think is entirely valid. Sure, the game has really fun combat, lots of options, and some great spectacles. But fuck this, I'll just play any dark souls, shadow of the colossus, or any other half decent fantasy rpg. Hell, unmodded Skyrim is more fun and engaging than this. Don't care if it gets better, or I've "chosen the wrong way to play". What game gimps 1 of the only 3 starting class option? I refuse to believe I'm supposed to choose fighter or caster, or just grind levels in the opening area. And if that is the case, take ONE class in game design, present a game concept with half these issues, and regardless of the positives, I just don't think you'll get a very good grade on that assignment.

Also! FUCK THE NAME CENSORSHIP. apparently any combination of letters that, in any european language, isn't aggressively G rated, it just censors that part of the name. Censors a LOT more than you'd think. Your name includes a series of letters that are a dirty word in Finnish? Censored. I honestly don't understand amount of positive reviews here. The only reason I can think of - it's first aRPG for most of the players.
In past 5-7 years I've played Risen, Gothic 2 and I liked them. Maybe except Gothic ending. I've played a lot of Souls-likes and platinum'd them. I've been trying to play Skyrim 3 times but couldn't, not my cup of tea. I mention this on purpose to be clear.

But I've dropped this game. Extremely boring and poorly designed.

Combat system is awful. I've started on Hard difficulty, right away noticed it's most likely not designed for 1st playthrough, because almost all enemies, except the smallest were killing me in one or two hits. I've played mage, mage + rogue hybrid class. You don't have any defensive mechanics, except Roll from latter class later in game. I don't even think it has i-frames. Point is, archers shoot your seeker projectiles, big opponents are very fast and have charge attacks. Small opponents are also quick. All casts and bow skills took stamina, which you need to run away from danger, the only possible way. If you overused offensive skills and drained all stamina, character falls into fatigue, being extremely slow and unable to act. Companion can run to you and recover a bit, but not always. I've even installed mod for unlimited Sprint. At first glance everything became a little more bearable. But still extremely boring.
I swapped diff-ty to normal after ~10 hours. Enemies were doing much less damage, more forgiving stamina managing, but..nothing changed dramatically. Didn't have fun. Played for several more hours and didn't return to it since.

Another bad part of the game is Health management. The more hits you take, the less Max HP you have until you rest in town. So, at some point, while still playing at Hard Mode I've had half hp all the time. I'm looking at you human archers. On top of that the most effective way of healing is to have companion with long ass single healing  aoe cast. Potions aren't common and don't regen much. Maybe I failed to see or understand smth, idk.

Also never liked mute protagonists. I know it's for immersion or due to lack of funds. But considering amount of voice lines and chatter from companions, latter isn't the case.

I swapped difficulty to check the story and...there isn't much story. Dragon stole you heart, you want it back. You've made some research, received Jester hat at court and that's basically it. That's all the story for 15 hours.

The only feature I liked - classes. There are basic, advanced and hybrid classes. So, you start as Mage, then you can pick Sorcerer. Then you can pick either Magic Archer or Mystic Knight. And no one forbid you to play as the Fighter (Warrior) or Strider (Rogue). Basically you can play every class in the game in one save. The only requirement - small fee to unlock it. Progression isn't bad too, but let's keep it short.

TL;DR: I didn't like because of multiple questionable game design decisions, boring story.

PS: I've played indie game from small developer (Katana Zero) and had 10 times more fun than here.

This game gets a lot of praise, but I personally can't really see why. It does have some interesting ideas, but very few are well executed.

Exploration - this is a key part of my enjoyment of openworld rpgs, and here it's thoroughly dull. Not only is going around very cumbersome - you don't have a mount, stamina is consumed upon sprinting outside of towns (can get a mod to change this), limited fast travel (can only go to crystals you place down, these can't be purchased until NG+ apparently, and there's only a handful to find). But also it commits the cardinal sin of just being boring, there's little of interest to find if you do go out and explore every little nook and cranny making it feel very unrewarding.

Combat - fell floaty and lacking punch. I think as only certain classes can block or dodge that leads quite a bit to it feeling like you can't be responsive.

Quests - the usual boring chosen one kinda deal. I will say one of the few well implemented ideas is that you can make forgeries of things. Want to keep that item you've been told to go get for someone, make a forgery and give them that instead... buuuut, maybe down the line this'll have some unforeseen consequence.

Bitterblack Isle was a significant improvement. It felt dangerous and interesting to sulk around in. But by that point I was so done with the game I had to force myself to keep heading through.

Also bonus points to some weird bug that makes the game take a screenshot every time you get an achievement so I've not got tons at as a cutscene is fading in to start, haha.

I was caught off guard by how much I enjoyed this game. I played as a Sorcerer for the heavy majority of it, which was quite enjoyable. Playing in a party of 4 (With 2 being Pawns) made the combat flow stand out to me since I wasn't the only one contributing.
Solid 8/10
A few things you may be curious about

Teleportation:
Yes, you can only teleport to select locations. You can teleport to the 2 main towns and through the story you can get Port Crystals to place down at a spot you want to teleport to (you get 3 iirc). At most you maybe have a 3 minute walk. Traveling really isn't that bad. Check your Storage at an Inn and there should be an Eternal Ferrystone there for unlimited teleports.

Combat:
I played as Sorcerer so I was much more passive. You can select the classes of your Pawns to customize how you want your team to fight. You are usually a party of 4. Climbing up monsters is pretty satisfying, although you almost never do it as a mage class. Sorcerers get crazy spells which are awesome to use. The only thing I'd want to add is some sort of roll button. My only method of dodging was either sprinting away or jumping. 

Graphics: I mean, this game is 10 years old. It looks decent by my standards. There is an ENB and textures mod if you really want it to look better.

Story: A dragon shows up to your home town and you are brave enough to challenge it. The dragon easily defeats you and steals your heart, making you an Arisen. The dragon beckons you to defeat it once you are ready. You go on an adventure and fight a bunch of monsters to try and take down the dragon. That's a basic summary without much spoilers. I quite enjoyed it tbh. At the end there are some quests I feel like could've been flushed out more with dialogue but it isn't bad by any means. The entire cycle the game revolves around is extremely interesting to me.

How long to beat?
The bare bones "beat the dragon" took me 30 hours. The post game content took 10-15. There is DLC called Bitterback Isle that I did not get to, which is even more content

such a gem of a game. its like dark souls, skyrim, and shadow of the colossus had a baby. early game can be a bit grueling due to how weak you start out (from my understanding, enemy levels do not scale based on player level), not to mention fast travel is basically non existent until you've hacked your way through a large chunk of the game to collect portcrystals, but its not necessarily a bad thing. the game makes you work for it but that just makes it all the more satisfying when you can finally go anywhere you want at the drop of a hat. 
the spells are cool, combat is enjoyable and rewarding, and having the freedom to change your class (vocation) at any point in the play through grants so much versatility and helps to combat stagnancy. Even after the main story is completed, there's still SO MUCH CONTENT so I'm 60 hours into my first play through with no end in sight. Dragons Dogma deserved way more hype and popularity than it ever got and i hope capcom releases a sequel or a remaster at some point.
why is valmiro my beloved?

Only 7/10 you ask..? let me tell you why!

Dragons Dogma is a good game, decent graphics for its time and runs smoothly. Lots to do which gives it massive longevity to keep you coming back for more. Huge selection of weapons and armours as you progress, all upgradable with specific materials you gain from exploring, mining and killing stuff. Good selection of classes, skills and spells to keep each play-through fresh and with Game+ mode you just keep getting stronger.

BUT! After 450+ hours I have some negative, if not a little infuriating points you may wish to consider. [b]Pawns[/b]
Your companions called (Paws) are there to help support your quest, either with combat or healing. The problem being they are morons who often do very little when it counts, except do nothing, get killed and need constant reviving. Even after hundreds of hours training, they are still more of a hindrance then a help in later game, seriously dumb as mud!

The devs love putting treasure chests on the edge of cliffs, and Pawns love to hop over things... you guessed it, they jump off the cliffs! You can summon them back later [i](before you say YAY!)[/i] all the inventory they were holding for you, including rare crafting materials has now vanished.  Seriously don't trust them with your valuables, actually just don't rely on them much at all.

[b]Affinity[/b]
Got to love some romance in a game to add some personal depth, Dragon's Dogma has that.. well sort of. By giving gifts and doing quests you gain affinity with NPC's, practically anyone is fair game with only a couple of exceptions.  But.. it's about as accurate as a fart in a hurricane, and as reliable as the Pawn's IA. You could literally end up with anyone you do quests for, or the same person over and over with every play-through. A big glass bowl they could all put their car keys in would have been better.

[b]Combat[/b]
While I can't fault the actual combat system, it's pretty good and fluid throughout, many ways to play changing the whole dynamic of the game.  Then you get to Bitterblack Isle, the Dark Arisen part of the game which is mostly fun, challenging with greater rewards.  Crazy boss fights and lots of new dangerous foes, dark dungeon crawling... Until you reach higher levels where challenging just becomes a tedious.  Long bouts of button bashing, being knocked on your backside, grappled. Getting hit with spells over and over is fun, the residence of Biterblack Isle can cast more spells in half the time and a never ending pool of stamina to do it with. 

Apart from the much later game it's a good fun, but that's why it only gets a 7/10 from me. Infuriating at times, but not enough to ruin the rest of the game.

Strength in numbers, Arisen!

Dragon's Dogma is Capcom's response to Skyrim and Dark Souls during their janky years. It is a charming, corny, and janky game that in 2022 feels like an Early Access title. The story is barely there and really not worth mentioning at all other than the absolutely hammy English dub. The quest system was not very good in 2012 and is pretty horrible 10 years later. Where Dragon's Dogma shines is its combat system, it is very fun and rewards experimentation. While the combat system favors ranged attacks more than close quarters, pretty much every class is playable and fun to do. Magic Archer and Sorcerer can be outright broken once you nail the mechanics down and equip the right abilities. 

The game can be done in about 20 hours with the "Dark Arisen" release adding the Everfall and Bitter Back Island that gives a more satisfying conclusion to the story. Bitterback is an extremely hard dungeon that can be very rewarding if you stick to it and experiment with the great combat mechanics. In Dragon's Dogma your team consists of "Pawns" which are basically blank slate humanoid servants that follow you around. You get one fully customizable Pawn for yourself, and can choose various user created Pawns that other players made as recruitable members to your team but do not level up. While their dialogue can be annoying, the Pawn system is pretty neat with the Pawns learning your playstyle and adapting to it. Another interesting thing about the Pawn system is that if you recruit a Pawn that has already done whatever quest you are currently on they can give you hints on what to do next if you are stuck.  

Dragon's Dogma was an underrated title when it came out in 2012, it plays like a mix of Monster Hunter and Dark Souls that rewards creativity and dedication. A major gripe with the title is their really is not a good fast travel system so you will have to run from place to place rather frequently which can actually take quite a while. To alleviate that I recommend getting the infinite running stamina, increased jump, and increased carry load from Nexus mods to decrease potential frustration. 

TLDR: Dragons Dogma is great and I am excited for the sequel.

Well I sank over 140 hours into it and still haven't finished my first playthrough.  The game is fun depending on which class you choose, but you can respec very easily part way through with no penalty other than you may have bad stats since each class gets a different distribution at level up. Classes to avoid are mage, sorcerer, and warrior. Spellcasting is tedious and better left to pawns, the warrior's attacks are so slow I can't stand it. I favored the ranger or assassin, fighter is meh because there is no need for a tank and the mystic night can do everything it can but better and augment weapons for the whole group. You will run around a lot at first (hiking sim plus baddies), it gets a lot better when you can start using the portacrystal system which allows you to place fast travel spots around the map, only 5 at first but then 10 on your second playthrough. Overall pretty good but put enough time in and you will get to a high level and balance goes out the window with most things being helpless and then a few enemies on bitterblack isle will still be very dangerous (instagib capable) and hard to kill even at high levels (hours to kill 1 time). Probably worth your time to try, maybe not 100%, after all I'm at 141 hours and have not finished my first playthrough.

This game really COULDVE been a huge landmark in the RPG genre but missed the bar on some majors issues. Altough i gotta say that i enjoyed my time on the game, it didnt feel like a chore and it is pretty immersive. 

Pros:
-Character customization
-Pawn(helper) customization (you can also chose their class, spells, equipements)
-Pawn system
-Climbing system. If you play something with a sharp edge (i.e. fighter, assassin etc.) you can actually climb on big monsters and stab them in their weak spots.

Mixed:
-Music is mid. Sometimes i almost wanted to put it on mute and put a personal playlist.
-Spells. Some class have really cool spells and can have 9+ spells simultaneously, while other class get some really useless stuff and only 2 spell slots. Not much personalization of skills too

Cons:
- Armor/weapons. I didnt feel like any weapon was GODLY or had a HUGE advantage over another. The best armor you'll play with is found in the main city and purchasable, so there is really no incentive on trying to find better gear. (I cleared the game easily with the armor sold in the main city)
-Atmosphere. There is absolutly no change beside a night/day cycle. No snow biome, no swamp biome, no scorched earth biome etc. Always in the same grassy land/forest.
-HUD. The HUD might just be the absolute nail in the coffin for this game, it is absolutly NOT user friendly. You cant press I to acces inventory, nor M to acces the map, or Q to acces quest. You have to press ESC everytime, and then chose what menu you want to open. On top of that, if youre in your inventory and want to equip a cool new sword, you have to open up another menu just to equip it. It is really not genuine.

Conclusion:
If you get this game for 5$ (like i did) and you like RPG/skyrim style, it is a game that will keep you entertained for a good amount of hours.

Highly recommend jumping into this blind. Very excited for the sequel. I'd say about 60 hours to finish the primary story and the DLC. Has a legit post game where you can keep killing things for better gear, and new game plus so you can use all of your fun new toys.

The game can be completed sub 1h, but there's 100-150hrs of optional content (100% achievement).

[b]Pros:[/b]
- You feel a sense of satisfaction progressing the game and completing challenges (mostly the DLC island)
- Monster climbing
- Pick up a monster and throw it to another monster. Pick up your allies and throw them to their deaths, or to a monster to deal dmg with them. Pick up objects from the ground and throw them to deal damage.
- You can change classes (vocations) as many times as you want, get all permanent perks and progress all of them (downside, you'll get stuck with whatever stats scaling they had when you were leveling eg. you played sorcerer the most -> 0 strength, max magic permanently).
- Early levels are unforgiving for melee classes (eg. low lvl tank experience: instant death from a wolf bite if not blocked), pretty neat
- Lighting: lantern is a must at night if you dont already know where you are. Night time is almost pitch black, but a clear sky with a moonlight is enough to navigate the main road. Lanterns have to be refilled every now and then.

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Combat can be incredibly clunky for some classes, but quite smooth for others.
- No animation cancel (you started a 2 second action? well, i guess you're stuck watching it: lantern, climbing, skill, dialog, etc.)
- Action queue (you accidentally pressed a button 2x? you wanted to switch on that lantern? well, you're stuck watching your character turning it on, then off for 6 seconds)
- Some spell effects are a constant flashbang, blocking all view
- Pawns are incredibly dumb (they like to randomly jump off cliffs to their deaths if you're sprinting)
- AI is ridiculously dumb (avoid escort quests, some npcs start spinning and running in circles, get exhaused, run 1 meter, get exhausted again, and can also just jump off to their deaths for no reason even without sprinting)
- Most random dialogs gave me brain damage (avoid talking to anything that's not a quest related dialog, you'll regret it)
- Pawn dialogs = unfinished placeholder tooltips (eg. "If you're tired, rest.", "You got lost? Just look at the map", "The outside world has treasures, but dangers too")
- Most quests are relatively boring and simple
- Nothing can influence the outcome of the main quest. Even if you choose a different ending, kill the quest npcs, etc, you must continue the predetermined storyline. Your character just dies after an unacceptiable outcome.

Overall a mixed experience, but you can find a playstyle and content you can enjoy. For 5€ on sale, max ~150hrs is quite a deal!

This game has somehow frustrated me into rage quitting in a mere 8 hours. Let's break down my biggest problems with it so far: (Please note that I'm playing as a mage on easy mode as this is my first time playing this game, though I have decent experience in this genre)

1. The save system pisses me off to no end and actively makes the gameplay experience worse. Turns out this game has two save systems, checkpoints, which the game determines and lets you load from the save menu, and the most recent manual save, which you can only return to upon death. For example, you can't be losing a battle and go into the Loading menu and choose to load you last save, which may be right before the fight you lost. Alternatively, it lets you load the last checkpoint which will drag you back any amount of time or progress then will immediately save over that manual save. So if you load your last checkpoint by mistake you lose all your progress beyond that point permanently. I hate this so so much.

2. Being a mage is extremely unintuitive for first-time (keyboard) players. The game does not tell you how to use your abilities. I had to look through vague control settings to see if there was some better way to do magic than shooting 4 light-balls since I purchased many special spell abilities (the cool shit mages should be using). Turns out to access the menu for THOSE spells I needed to hold down L or R control before it would show me the keys I needed to press to enable the use of the actual spells. There is no way to make your primary or secondary moves on the basic move screen that only lets you physically hit things and shoot some shit damage light-balls. At that point I was many hours into the game and never once was any of that mentioned. It felt wrong for a game to have such a shitty magical system so I had to google my solutions to find out why my mage couldnt do any damage to anyone. This along with the mages devastatingly low beginning health (unknown comparatively with other classes, maybe they have the same amount of health, just better physical defense probably) means on easy mode you might survive 3 hits from non-archer bandits. And the bandits never stop coming.

3. Quests and openworld areas don't tell you how difficult they will be. There might have been some kind of number value somewhere on the signboard, but evidently I've missed it every single time. Otherwise you can walk from a basic zone to a zone with a 15 bandits right next to that basic zone with no indication you're doing so.

4. The weapon menu and inventory are clunky as hell. The controls for keyboard are an awkward mix of keyboard and mouse where sometimes the mouse will be able to select things and sometimes it wont be. As well every character has their own exclusive inventory that you're constantly trying to shuffle items in between. I can't help but think there could have been a better way to do this.

5. Early game has way too many combat encounters. Every minute I spend travelling between cities during the day will have at least 2 minutes worth of combat encounters with random garbage enemies like bandits, goblins and wolves. Not to mention it's incredibly difficult to judge how hard the combat encounter will be as sometimes all enemies are aggroed at once and they'll wipe the whole team and sometimes it's just one or two enemies at a time, which will be easy peasy to clear out. Frequently I'll encounter a troop of bandits is either a TPK or a breeze and there's no way to tell which it will be, even on easy mode. This is my biggest pet peeve with the game. You spend so much time in overly frequent combat for several minutes at a time that you can't get anything done.

So many small things in this game just make it so damn frustrating as all getout to play.

Here are some good things:
- Lots of unique looking character customization options for yourself and your pawn companion.
- I like the concept of a constant pawn companion who will grow beside you. I made mind a warrior so he would always protect me (mage). I generally enjoy the concept of pawns even if they talk a bit too much about nothing.
- Games visuals have held up well enough for a game this old.
- Becoming a suicidal/arrogant dragons chosen champion is a cool concept, even if everyone hypes up my abilities way too much early on XD I'm literally a fisherman with a staff, stop pretending like we actually killed that hydra instead of it running away lol

游戏太厉害了，非常佩服。
原本我以为是一个“英雄杀死恶龙拯救世界”的俗套故事，但是我错了，结尾非常amazing。
[spoiler]
杀死巨龙之后，城市会出现一个大坑，这个大坑跳进去是无限循环的。（星新一《喂，出来》的既视感）这个坑应该是连接着无数个平行世界。完了还有任务，要我收集二十个复活石，然后遇到了界王，就是所谓的“神”，告诉了我世界的真相。说这个世界是虚构的，大家都是npc，你虽然不是npc但是你也没有自由意志，你是被操控的。只有先杀了界王然后再自杀才能解脱，获得真正的自由。然后我自杀了，我的随从和我掉进洞里，穿越了无数个世界，无数个世界里的无数个我的随从聚合成了一个随从（大概类似于世界线收束？说实话这一段不太懂），然后我的随从变成了我的样貌但是声音仍然是随从的声音，只有商人玛德琳认了出来，然后就开启了二周目（这一段也不是太懂，说实话）。但是，大概是因为二周目的我已经不是原本的我，所以大概一周目的我已经获得了解脱了吧 （？）  @_@ [/spoiler]

很佩服这脑洞。真厉害。

6/10. I have mixed feelings about this game. It had been on-and-off my wishlist for several years, and eventually I (obviously) decided to buy it. It's not _terrible_, but there are a few things that contribute to that mediocre score. 1) It constantly hijacks your camera to show you your pawns doing singularly uninspiring and unhelpful things (very annoying), 2) A number of the boss fights rely on a 'climbing' mechanic, which does not at all work well with a keyboard and mouse, 3) There are a number of quests of the "find rare item" type, where, to be blunt, you have zero chance of just stumbling across the item (worse, some of them require you to combine two or more _different_ rare items), 4) Some of the dialog seems to imply that you know / should know some element of the story that has not been made clear,  5) Some quests just randomly fail for no apparent reason.

All in all, it's not a complete loss (hence the 'uptick'), but I will definitely not be playing it again, and I have no particular desire to play the expansion content.

Dungeons and Dragons and Ogres and Death oh my. A game with mediocre graphics and story, but amazing combat. The combat really is the star of the show and it is super fun. Climbing monsters, stabbing them in face, holding on for life to dragon trying to fly away, showering down meteors, doing trick shots with magic bows, throwing your pawn of a cliff, it's all good fun. Bitter Black Isle is one of the best dungeons around, truly awesome level design.

I paid 7 bucks for this game. No idea why it was so low but I bought it and its literally the best 7 bucks I have ever paid for a game. The UI(load, save, map, inventory) really is annoying because I play on PC and the game was obviously a console game. But when your not doing anything with those particular features its a fun game. It really is. A bit rough around the edges but very very decent. I definitely recommend the game even at the current price.  Its a decent RPG, free roam world, dungeons, quest game. Great graphics. Great fighting motions.

Do you like Dark Souls? Do you like Breath of The Wild? Do you like Monster Hunter? Do you like Genshin Impact? This game offers a little bit of something from all the games I've mentioned. This game was so ahead of its time that it feels more at home today than back when it was released.

Seriously... give it a bit of time and I promise you it'll get better as you progress through the game.
